name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The first item on the agenda is the Commission statement on the sustainable exploitation of sea bass (2015/2596(RSP))

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, on behalf of my colleague Commissioner Vella, who unfortunately cannot be here with you today, I would like to thank Mr Cadec as Chair of the Committee of Fisheries for his initiative to have a resolution on sea bass, and all Members who will support it. The sea bass stock in the southern North Sea, the English Channel, the Celtic Sea and the Irish Sea has been declining rapidly since 2012 and will, according to scientific advice, approach its historically lowest level in 2016. The concrete proposals in your motion for a resolution to establish a coordinated approach to the management of sea bass are therefore very important. For the past three years the Commission has worked very hard to broker an agreement between Member States on improved management of this stock. In 2012 the Commission proposed the introduction of total allowable catch (TAC) and has had ongoing discussions with Member States. Unfortunately Member States were unable to agree, mainly because they could not agree on how to share the TAC between them. Last November the Commission proposed alternative management measures, notably limiting the number of days at sea, freezing the number of licences for commercial fishermen and limiting the daily catches for recreational fishermen, all to contain fishing pressure on the stock. Again the Council was not able to come to an agreement on the Commission’s proposal. Considering the state of the resources and the urgency of the situation, the Commission has subsequently decided to take temporary emergency measures for pelagic vessels targeting spawning aggregations of sea bass as part of a response to the state of the stock. These emergency measures are the first element in a package of envisaged measures which the Commission plans to be adopted for the management of sea bass in 2015. The second element in this package is a Commission proposal to limit the catches of recreational anglers to three fish per angler per day. Recreational fishermen produce a quarter of all landings of sea bass and it is therefore important and justified that they contribute to decreasing the pressure on this stock. This proposal is now with the Council, which is looking very favourably at the proposal. The adoption of these rules by the Council is scheduled for 16 March. The Commission is currently discussing the third element of the package with the Member States concerned. This would cover several parts of the commercial sector which also impact on sea bass. It may take the form of catch limits. Once this initial package is in place, and in order to rebuild the stock, we are envisaging including sea bass in the multiannual plan for the Western Atlantic quotas, as foreseen under the new common fisheries policy (CFP).  We fully agree with you that in the preparation of such plans we need to consult all stakeholders, build on their knowledge and ensure a fair approach. We will also need to integrate the latest scientific advice on sea bass in the preparation of that plan.

name: Alain Cadec
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, Commissioner, I thank you for your words. As you rightly pointed out, the state of the bar stock is a concern. The European Union must react and put in place coherent management measures. The European Commission has recently, as you said, taken emergency measures to close the pelagic trawl fishery from 26 January to 30 April, i.e. during the spawning period. These emergency measures are temporary and are not intended to be extended. We must therefore, now, prepare for the future and take a long-term view. I have therefore decided to propose, on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries, a resolution containing proposals for sustainable management of the bar. We call for a multi-year management plan at European level, in line with the rules of the Common Fisheries Policy. This plan will need to be based on sound and scientific advice. This requires an accurate assessment of the status of the stock and its delimitation, as well as the migrations of the species and the precise breeding sites. The resolution therefore calls on the Commission and member states to build on the European Fund for Maritime Affairs and Fisheries, which provides for significant funding for the collection of scientific data. It is also necessary to accurately assess the share of the different trades fishing the bar as well as the share of recreational fishing in these catches. We need this information to make relevant decisions. When we work on a management plan on the bar, we will have to look at the different types of measures that are possible. Several options are possible, as you have just said, for example: the establishment of an all-eligible catch total (TAC), the introduction of a minimum landing size or the establishment of biological rest periods during spawning, among others.  These are, at this stage, only options and it will be up to the legislature to make decisions in the light of scientific advice. I would like to take this opportunity to remind the Council that management plans are entirely part of the codecision procedure. A management plan on the bar must take into account commercial fishing, but also recreational fishing, as you said, which accounts for almost a quarter of the catch. The introduction of quantitative limitations for this fishery seems to me to be necessary. The measures to be taken must be prepared by closely involving all the players in the bar fishery, in a spirit of compromise. Advisory boards will have an important role to play in this regard. The management of the bar is everyone's business. It is together that we will find solutions to protect this beautiful species while preserving the activity of those who live by it.

name: Ulrike Rodust
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The sea fish population is in a catastrophic state. This is also the co-responsibility of the Member States, which have not behaved responsibly in the past. In the basic regulation, we have an instrument, with Article 12, to counteract this. That is what we are doing today with this resolution, which is on the table. I support this, in particular I support management measures in the form of a multiannual plan that brings stocks above a level that allows for the highest possible sustainable yield.

name: Peter van Dalen
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Presiding, I too am very concerned about the position of the sea bass and the European Commission has rightly intervened recently and taken a number of measures to protect the sea bass. I am a little less happy with the resolution that is now on the table and, above all, with the way in which it has been achieved. I would have preferred that we in the Committee on Fisheries had had a good debate and weighed up all the odds and cons. The shortcut we're making now is actually a little too short.  You can also see this in the content of the resolution, because when I read that there should be a quota for the sea bass, I do not think that this is a good management mechanism for the sea bass. For many cutter fishermen, sea bass is really a fluke, and if we come up with a quota, it will bring a lot of political strife and red tape, whereas we want to reduce the bureaucratic pressure for fishing. The most important thing is that we take sustainable measures to protect the sea bass in spawning time and spawning areas.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: "Mr. President, may I ask you, as there has clearly been a serious confusion, it says here that the session begins today at 9:30, not at 9:00 a.m. Mrs. Nicolai, who was supposed to speak on behalf of the ALDE group, is not here, so I'm asking that either I say something now or that she says when she comes. In any case, please take into account the fact that it says 9:30, not 9:00 a.m. here.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: According to this regulation, it is not permitted. The agenda was amended on Monday and it was announced in good time to all MEPs that our sitting today will start at 9 a.m.  I am sorry, but I cannot accept your request, so I give the floor to Mr João Ferreira for a minute on behalf of the Group of the European United Left.

name: João Ferreira
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, fisheries management measures are often implemented in a top-bottom, top-down approach, supported by poor scientific knowledge, distanced from regional specificities, indifferent to the involvement of the sector and communities, their contributions and, as well as, the impacts that these measures may have. As is well known, we are very critical of this approach. This resolution begins by considering – and well – the lack of scientific information on sea bass, and calls on the Commission and the Member States to carry out an assessment of the appeal. We can't agree more.   We also value other positive aspects of this resolution, such as the reference to the importance of proximity management, which take into account the diversity of situations at regional level.    Nevertheless, there is general considerations and, from now on, with management measures at European level which are apparently contradictory to these principles and seem to ignore the diversity of existing situations.   The meaning of the amendments we have tabled here – and which we hope can be supported – is to try to eliminate these apparent contradictions by favouring undoubtedly necessary management measures, but adjusted to each specific need.

name: Norica Nicolai
text: on behalf of the ALDE group. – Mr President, I apologise for the delay. Undoubtedly, the issue of sea bass, as put out in the resolution proposed by our colleague Alain Cadec, is in fact an early warning about the sustainability of multiannual plans. I understand the attractiveness of this species of fish for the whole fishing industry, for artisanal fishing, for sport fishing, and I believe that we need to ensure a balance between the sustainability of resources, stocks, and the need for fishing, which brings us so many jobs. However, this ban, which will run until 30 April 2015, does not, in my opinion, resolve the issue of the sustainability of multiannual plans. We must find quick solutions, together with the Member States, to unblock this deadlock in the Council, and I must remind the Council that, during this period, on the basis of disputes over Article 43 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, the Court of Justice has decided to give justice to the European Parliament and the Commission. The fact that this decision has been reached means that Parliament's vision of the common fisheries policy is a fair one, which concerns both concrete fishing opportunities and the need to pursue an appropriate legislative procedure. I believe that, in the case of multiannual plans, we are in exactly this situation revealed by the Court of Justice of the European Union. With regard to the technical measures to reduce sea bass stocks to a sustainable level, in addition to the regional multiannual plans, which I consider a good solution for the proper management of resources in the medium term, I believe that we must also take into account sport fishing.

name: Linnéa Engström
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I would like to thank Mr Cadec, who has produced this resolution, who has initiated it. The sea bass, which is one of our most magnificent predatory fish, is heavily depleted. Today, the fishing mortality rate for sea bass is four times higher than the level that could ensure maximum sustainable yield, MSY. We are talking about a fish that grows very slowly and does not become sexually mature until the age of four to seven.  The International Maritime Fisheries Council (ICES) warns that a management plan should be put in place as soon as possible and that fishing should be reduced by 80%. Today, sea bass catches are not regulated at all in the EU. There are no limits on the maximum allowable catch, nor are there any quotas. The basically only restriction that is in commercial fishing is a minimum limit of 36 cm. However, it is not only commercial fishing that is carried out. It is estimated that as much as 25% of catches are made in recreational fishing. The Council has not been able to agree on measures. Instead, the Commission has had to pull the emergency brake and stop parts of trawling until the end of April. It is high time to take responsibility for the situation before it is too late. The Commission should develop a draft management plan as soon as possible. That management plan should reasonably take into account all fishing of sea bass, both commercially and recreationally. Fair management of a limited common resource must reasonably cover all those who use the resource. Then we will have an administration for the good of all.

name: Raymond Finch
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the Commission should note that the title of this item is ‘sustainable exploitation of sea bass’. The operative word you are using is ‘exploitation’. That is all you are interested in. Eleven years ago, the British Government banned pair trawling for bass. Our then Fisheries Minister asked the French Government to do likewise. They refused. We went to the Commission to ask for a ban. The Commission refused. So our fishermen halted pair trawling – and the French, with the connivance of the European Union, simply took our fish from our waters, and now you have the nerve to punish our fishermen and sea anglers for your own crimes. The common fisheries policy, based as it is on outright naked theft of natural resources by giant businesses under the protection of the EU, is an unmitigated economic, ecological and environmental catastrophe. All of you sitting here – although there are not many this morning because perhaps you are just busy signing on – in this Chamber spouting smug platitudes about caring for the ecosystem, looking after the impoverished of our world and acting as good stewards of the planet, I have news for you: you are being used by this giant corporatist scam and you are blinding yourselves to the truth. In the words of Johnny Rotten, ever get the feeling you have been had?  The biomass of our bass population has dropped by 80% and you are going to bring in vindictive, ill-thought-out, unenforceable legislation. British sea anglers have been calling for years to save the bass and you have done nothing because you are owned, lock stock and barrel, by vested interests. I call on the UK Government today to leave the callous, corrupting, catastrophic common fisheries policy, restore a proper 12-mile limit and institute a 200-mile exclusive economic zone, as guaranteed by the European Law of the Sea. The sooner the common fisheries policy is gone, the better. (The speaker agreed to take two blue-card questions under Rule 162(8))

name: Julie Girling (ECR)
text: blue-card question. – I should like to ask Mr Finch a straight question. Do you or do you not support the resolution of this Parliament, regardless of how we got here? It was interesting to hear your views, but do you support this resolution or do you not?

name: Raymond Finch (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – Ms Girling, I do not consider myself a Vichyist. I say the UK should leave the EU, leave the common fisheries policy – anything else is merely putting off the inevitable. I hope that answers your question.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: "blue card" question. "Colleague Finch, I have two questions. First, did you read the resolution? It seems to me that it's not.  Second question: it seems to me that you want a renationalization of fisheries policy, yes or no?

name: Raymond Finch (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – The first answer Mr Cadec is ‘yes’– I have nothing better to do with my time. Second answer is ‘yes’ – of course I am looking for each nation to have a responsible attitude and to look after its own natural resources.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, it is always a pleasure to speak after Mr Finch, because one can return to reality, and I think that is good, right now. While it is true that there is not sufficient scientific information on the biology and exploitation of sea bass, several studies show that the state of populations is very worrying. We are all aware that hundreds of artisanal fishermen rely solely on bass fishing to survive and that they do not also have the possibility of switching fisheries easily. But we cannot lose sight of the view that, apart from professional fishermen, sea bass, by a very important percentage, is the subject of recreational fishing. Taking action, apart from those taken as an emergency for the pelagic fleet, becomes essential and it must be regretted that Member States have not been able to reach an agreement to ensure the recovery of populations. So far the regulation has been left to the Member States, and the time has come to develop an appropriate multi-year plan, within the basis of regionalisation, which includes the establishment of taxiots and which is agreed by all parties, not to mention specific measures aimed at recreational fishing.

name: Renata Briano (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the resolution introduces important principles consistent with the CFP, such as the scientific approach to the management of fish stocks, the principle of management, rather than the ban, and the evaluation of recreational and recreational fishing, which must be absolutely involved in the process of managing and conserving fish stocks.  I would, however, like to add a point concerning the need for parallel intensive communication and dissemination to the European population on the responsible consumption of this species and beyond. Indeed, if demand remains high because consumers prefer this species exclusively or as a matter of priority over other stocks of sea bass in non-EU waters, they risk being overexploited, thus not achieving the objective of this resolution. Among the conservation measures, therefore, it is also proposed to encourage food education and responsible consumption measures, mainly aimed at directing European consumers on the use of other little-known, little-known and under-exploited fish species.

name: Julie Girling (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I welcome this resolution and I thank Mr Cadec for bringing it forward and for his work.  In June 2014 ICES published its report on bass stocks, which clearly illustrated the need for action. In the following December Council, the UK Government submitted a reasoned request to the Commission for emergency measures. I would like to congratulate the UK Minister George Eustice for taking this stand. There is one part of the resolution that I would like to highlight this morning. That is to ask Members to give further and careful consideration to recreational fishing. In the UK I believe the recreational sector has taken a sensible approach to the issue by showing a willingness to accept conservation measures, such as the bag limit, but we need to have further discussions on exactly how that will work and we need to make sure that the measures are proportionate and workable. In my region, the south-west of England, many of the recreational fishing boats are actually crewed and owned by fishermen, either doing it on the days when they are not able to go to sea because of EU conservation rules or because they have moved out of fishing altogether. I would like to support that and make sure that we do not give the wrong messages about their work.

name: Nils Torvalds (ALDE).
text: Mr President, it is nice to see all the usual suspects from the common fisheries reform here. I think that they take good responsibility for the decision. After this introduction I will go over to my native Swedish. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul The sea bass is a very delicious fish with high nutritional value. It has been fished in the North Sea or the Atlantic Ocean or on the Iberian coast. This is what it could sound like in a restaurant or at a dinner table, and it has sounded like this too many times. The problem we are now seeing is a typical common pool problem, i.e. what Elinor Ostrom described in her book on common resources and to which she also had a solution. The solution is that common pool assets must be regulated. For this reason, I am more than happy that my friend Monsieur Cadec has taken this initiative. And I am pleased that our other members of the Committee on Fisheries are actually taking on the responsibility that we should perhaps have taken a little earlier.

name: Anja Hazekamp (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, almost 90% of all fish species are seriously overfished and so is sea bass. This species is in bad ly, which is why Brussels has taken emergency measures, but these measures could not yet have sufficient effect. In addition, they expire on April 30. It is important to extend these emergency measures, at least until there is a multi-annual management plan with additional protection measures for the sea bass.  This species can live up to 30 years. It is a species that grows slowly, reproduces less quickly than a lot of other species and therefore needs more time. I therefore call on my colleagues to vote in favour of the resolution to protect the sea bass, to also vote in favour of the amendment calling for additional measures and calling for the extension of the emergency measures.  I also believe that European agricultural subsidies and fisheries subsidies should be abolished.

name: Werner Kuhn (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to thank our committee chairman, Mr Cadec, for taking this parliamentary initiative and for accompanying the necessary emergency measures by the Commission to make them sustainable. Sustainability is a crucial point. Mrs Hazekamp, you have to read the latest figures: two thirds of all stocks that we fish in the European Union, in our waters, are fished sustainably. That is the result of the last 15 to 20 years. After all, sea perecane has only recently become native to our waters, and it has become attractive for commerce. That is why we have a situation where there were no TACs and quota for sea pereerand before and it was fished uncontrollably. That's just the way it is. What Alain Cadec said is necessary: we must insist here that a multi-annual multi-annual plan for these fishing areas of the English Channel, the Celtic Sea and the North Sea should also be undertaken in connection with the Eastern Atlantic. Only in this way can we achieve a reasonable stock afterwards, so that this sea perk can be preserved.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D).
text: – Mr President, professional fishing in Portugal has relative interannual stability in the discharge of wild sea bass and this fish maintains good commercial value. The stability of the fished volume could be indicative of its sustainability, but, as in other regions of Europe, there is no scientific knowledge to certify the state of the Portuguese spring and the amounts of annual fisheries are not even measured in terms of catches per effort unit, but as an overall value.  The opinions of scientific entities warn of the need for specific management objectives, based on better science, in which they are seconded by the regional fisheries advisory councils. The recent decoding of the sea bass genome allowed the identification of two differentiated sea bass populations in the Atlantic and Mediterranean. The complexity of the situation and the need to maintain sustainable springs accessible to two distinct and sometimes competitive fishing activities, commercial fishing and recreational fishing, therefore require integrative, comprehensive, pan-geographical and European regulation.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to express my sincere support for the motion for a Resolution by Alain Cadec, in favour of introducing measures to improve the situation of bass stocks. This is a kind of great economic value, as we all know, which has undergone a strong development in recent years, especially in the field of recreational fishing, so I believe that its sustainable exploitation must be ensured. And before the European Union is forced to apply drastic prohibitions in this fishery, it is appropriate to introduce a multiannual management plan, which ensures a lasting exploitation of it and preserves fishermen's activity.  Moreover, as indicated in the report, it would also be appropriate to establish total allowable catches, although quota-setting could be complicated due to difficulties in determining historical allocations. However, as the motion for a resolution says, it is a necessary measure if we are to move these populations forward.  I believe that this motion for a Resolution is welcome and goes very far in line with the demands made by the same affected sectors; the introduction of both measures is currently imposed in the light of scientific studies recommending a very significant reduction in sea bass mortality to achieve population recovery.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, I would like to thank Mr. Cadec for this resolution, however, I am particularly interested in recreational fishing, especially points 3 and 7 of your resolution.  I see you've recognised recreational fishing and you say the principle of regionalisation needs to be taken into account. I think it's very important to take into account regional differences. I mean the Croatian Adriatic. During the negotiations for entry into the European Union, unfortunately we did not negotiate well in such a way that recreational fishermen over sixty years have even census financially and cannot participate in recreational fishing. Therefore, please take a good look at these two points to add perhaps, in this 7th you have said the gravity of encompassing recreational fishing. You're aware that it's not easy.  I know 1/4 of fishing when it comes to sea bass waste on recreational fishing, but I would ask you to take care that you have a regional approach in mind. I believe that's what you've been taking care of.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, I would like to point out that the European Union's Common Fisheries Policy was formed on the occasion of a major conflict between France and the United Kingdom over the management of fish stocks in the 1970s, at a time when there was - and then - a severe economic crisis.  We are now back on a serious issue, that of stock management, with the conflict having elements not so ethnic but of being a conflict between those who are professionally engaged in fisheries and have interests that need to be protected and, on the other hand, the need to protect the stocks themselves.  That is why serious measures must be taken to protect professional fishermen throughout Europe and for the Mediterranean as well as for Greece, because fishermen are also facing problems there. Here, therefore, there must be a synthesis in dealing with these problems and the issue must be resolved by consensus, so that we also have protection of catches, but at the same time protect the interests of professional fishermen and amateurs.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, I will agree with those who have spoken about the need to protect the sea bass, but I will disagree with the reasoning. For me fish should not be treated as catches, i.e. as prey to humans, fish are our roommates on this planet, like all other species of living beings.  Over the past 50,000 years homo sapiens has proven to be the largest life destroyer on the planet, after the meteorite that had fallen in Yucatan 65 million years ago and changed the natural environment altogether.  We need to change this devastating course. If we continue like this, the 22nd century will be called by the historian of the future "desert animal period". Nature must be protected. We are part of nature and not its owners.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, regional specificities or specificities should definitely be taken into account.  It is not the same to fish sea bass in the Adriatic Sea or in the North Sea. So please take these specifics into account in particular. I also want to emphasize the social component of fishing, which is recreational fishing, especially on small Adriatic islands where only a dozen, maybe fifteen families live to whom life means something.  There are two things I want to make particular emphasis. We absolutely have to protect our natural sea bass hatchetions because, thank God, there are still some. We should also consider the possibility of restocking some seas that are smaller closed seas, because scientists have also talked about this, and I want to say in particular that in the long term, in order for sea bass to remain on our menus, we need to encourage aquaculture well, meaning farms, and let this be part of the topics and reflections of our rapporteur.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – I also agree with what his predecessor said. I think that the situation we are in at the moment, given that there are no specific restrictions on sea bass catches, is putting this species ahead of practical extinction. Even given that the commercialisation of catches of this fish has increased significantly. I would add, however, that, of course, the management measures resulting from this resolution should be welcomed, as well as the need to introduce international management of sea bass catch management. However, I think that all these measures will be too harsh if this commercialisation is not treated more rationally, and I am aware, of course, that this is an important industry. And here, there is a kind of unint manner between the industry and the loss of income due to restrictions, and, of course, the resources available for subsidies, and, on the third page, of course, the concern that we are not at risk of extinction over time.

name: Εμμανουήλ Γλέζος (
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, I fully agree with what Mr Chrysogonos said. Because I have almost lived with the fish, I inform you for those who do not know it, that the sea bass is a cannibal, eats all the other fish. It is the fox of the sea and in the place where it lives and feeds its young does not hunt the other fish, to see how cunning fish it is.  But, I took the floor to say - because the sea bass is combined with the predator - that today Greece is ready to eat the sea bass, which is its lenders, who are the ones who want to devour it and that is why I asked to speak.  It is not going to stop my voice - as long as I am here alive - saying: let the Greek people determine their fate, do not interfere in the life of a people.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for this debate on the issue of sea bass. I have to confess that I really enjoyed this debate personally. I have another confession to make – maritime affairs would have been my preferred dossier but for someone from a landlocked country this is probably unrealistic. So anyway I also really appreciated this debate for personal reasons but, coming back to the issue of the sea bass, I think many of you have rightly underlined that action is indeed urgently required and the Commission has initiated a set of measures as I have highlighted already in my earlier statement. While I sense nearly overall support for the sea bass measures mentioned, I also take note of the concerns some of you have expressed and I will convey them to my colleague Karmenu Vella.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Union has taken a historic turn by achieving the goal of sustainable maximum performance. It must now be accompanied by appropriate management measures. A year ago to the day, it was in these terms that I intervened in plenary to alert the Commission of the urgency of applying the RMD to the bar. A year later, the species is still in free fall - the ICES recommends reducing fishing pressure by 60%. Without having been able to make decisions on time, decisions are made in an emergency and through enforcement measures. Do we have to see the urgency every year to regulate this fishery? Bar fisheries should not be an exception. They also need long-term visibility. The MDR is not an incantation, we need to have effective tools, and I am calling for quota. All activities must contribute to the effort, both professional and recreational, since the EC estimates that 25% of the total recreational fishing catch is. Professional fishing cannot be the adjustment variable of the RMD.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the 28th session of the United Nations Human Rights Council (2015/2572(RSP))

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative. – Mr President, you held a very fruitful and comprehensive debate on the Panzeri report yesterday. I am honoured to present to you now the EU priorities for the UN Human Rights Council in Geneva, which resumed its work last week.  This debate gives us the opportunity to publicly renew our commitment to a strong multilateral human rights system. The European Union has been a staunch supporter of the Human Rights Council from the very beginning, and over the years we have contributed to strengthening its capacity to address violations and to promote greater respect for human rights all over the world. For this reason, it was particularly important for the Vice—President / High Representative to participate in this high level segment last week. Her presence in Geneva, together with the EU Special Representative Stavros Lambrinidis, was meant to remind the world, but also ourselves, of the great importance which is accorded to human rights in EU foreign policy. She also wanted to give voice to the work that the EU does and which this House does to uphold human rights worldwide.  The Council is the place where the gravest human rights violations are publicly condemned and where new partnerships can be forged with countries from all regions to take resolute action to prevent and respond to human rights violations and abuses, and to fight discrimination and violence.  Unavoidably, the debate in Geneva is very much focused on the many human rights crises resulting from ongoing conflict or fragility. Your resolution refers to a number of them, and they correspond to the situations that the Vice—President/High Representative highlighted at the Council last week. Firstly, the EU condemns the serious deterioration of the human rights situation in Ukraine, where the price paid by the civilian population is simply appalling – almost 6 000 people have been killed and twice as many have been injured – and where the Tatar community in Crimea is persecuted and journalists and the media are intimidated. Together with partners, the EU strongly calls for an end to violations and abuses, for respecting international human rights and human rights law, for granting safe passage and for allowing the release of hostages and detained persons.  The EU supports the work done by the UN Human Rights monitoring mission in Ukraine, which is documenting violations and will guarantee the accountability of those who have perpetrated them, and calls for unimpeded access to the mission to Crimea.  Secondly, in Syria, entire communities, women and children, are taken hostage both by a brutal regime and by ruthless terrorist groups who wage a war under the false pretence of protecting their religion. The EU supports the work of the Commission of Inquiry set up by the Human Rights Council since we know from experience that restoring justice to the victims of atrocities is crucial to achieving sustainable peace and reconciliation. Moreover, where impunity prevails, there we find disaffection and alienation – feelings which are exploited by extremists. The result is a spiral of violence and destruction which is difficult to control. This is why, when the time comes, we will support also the role of the ICC in addressing these violations.  Third, finally let me mention South Sudan, a country we will discuss afterwards and where the conflict spares no one, not even young children. Here the EU urges the African Union Peace and Security Council to consider the report of the African Union Commission of Inquiry. Again, justice and accountability are vital elements in the reconciliation process for the country.  Human rights are not only violated in situations of conflict. The EU also deems it important to shed light on long—standing and grave human rights violations or accompany countries in transition to democracy. Therefore, we again are a partner with Japan to bring international attention to human rights in the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea – a situation which the General Assembly last December, on our initiative, recommended to the attention of the UN Security Council with the request that it should consider a referral to the International Criminal Court. Like you, we have not forgotten the situation in Myanmar/Burma where progress has been made indeed but where, at the same time, we continue to be concerned about the inter—communal violence towards the Roghingya and by the situation in conflict-affected areas and by the possible adoption of legislation on the protection of race and religion. Moreover, the European Union continues to work to bring attention to the rights of children, who are our future but who are all too often the first victims of conflict or crisis. We are the long-standing sponsor of resolutions on the rights of the child, both in Geneva and New York, and support in particular the protection of children from war, violence and abuse. Last, but not least, let me mention the EU’s commitment to freedom of religion or belief on which we are going to table a resolution at this session. We have also just hosted, on Tuesday 10 March 2015, a successful event with UN Special Rapporteur Bielefeldt on the timely subject of speaking out against acts of intolerance, discrimination and violence allegedly committed in the name of religion or belief. This is a complex phenomenon which requires a firm response by states, regional organisations, religious or belief communities, NGOs and by media representatives. Let me say in this respect that realising all human rights for all and fighting marginalisation, discrimination and intolerance is the European answer to radicalisation, violence and abuse. Before closing let me mention three issues of particular importance to this House. Firstly, as you rightly point out in your resolution, civil society representatives and human rights defenders experience harassment and imprisonment, threats and violence as well as restrictions on their activities in many countries around the world. The EU defends their space at the United Nations and raises their plight in bilateral dialogues. We now go beyond traditional diplomatic or political tools, together with the High Commissioner for Human Rights and the Brazilian Permanent Mission to the United Nations, the Republic of Korea and Tunisia. In Geneva we have just launched an innovative social media campaign called ‘#I Defend’ making sure civil society has its voice. With this initiative we want to express support to, and solidarity with, human rights defenders and civil society representatives. Secondly, we must lead by example. Our collective commitment to the universal peer review or principal decision to cooperate with all special procedures of the United Nations are extremely important for our credibility and for the credibility of the Human Rights Council. This also means bringing human rights back home and vigorously working on our own shortcomings. In her speech in Geneva the High Representative has openly spoken about the challenge of migration and the EU’s commitment to better protect the human rights of migrants in the future through deeper cooperation among the EU Member States and support for the work of the UNHCR.  Third and finally, let me recall that the credibility of the UN human rights systems rests primarily on the independence and integrity of the Office of the High Commissioner. We must defend this independence by supporting the Office financially and by staving off attempts to place its activities under the scrutiny of Member States. I would like to thank you for this debate and for the recommendations regarding the EU priorities.

name: Andrzej Grzyb
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I would like to thank you very much for these many debates, just in this session, on human rights. This is an important sign that this session is focused on these issues. We are not in a position to discuss all the elements, but I would like to emphasise that our debate follows the last meeting of the Foreign Affairs Council of 9 February, which addressed the priorities to be addressed by the UN Council in its 28th session. I would like to thank Commissioner Hahn for presenting what has happened in this matter in the Council. I am very positive about the priorities in this area and I also stress my full support for the independence of the Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights.  On a number of issues raised in the motion for a resolution, I would like to emphasise, above all, the issue of persecution of the weak in conflict areas – this concerns women, this concerns children, including the elderly – but also the issue of the persecution of minorities, including religious minorities. Here I stress the dramatic situation with regard to the persecution of Christians, other faiths, as well as this humanitarian crisis in the neighbourhood.

name: Elena Valenciano
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, today we are going to vote on an important resolution, which this Parliament will raise to the 28th session of the Council of the United Nations. The Resolution has reached broad consensus among all the groups in this House, and I think it is therefore worth highlighting the European Parliament's effort to speak with a single voice in the context of the United Nations. In the world there is not a single day when millions of human beings are still persecuted; a single day when barbarism, bigotry, violence rest. There is not a single day when millions and millions of human beings are not deprived of all dignity. That's why we can't give in a millimeter in that fight for defending your rights. Without any relativism. Cultural relativism does not fit in the defence of human rights; religious relativism does not fit; gender relativism does not fit. And, of course, there is no need for commercial or economic relativism. Human rights must be vertebrates of our action abroad. Human rights have to stop being a utopia, to become a reality. We have a great responsibility. You cannot imagine how many people come to us with desperate emails and calls, so that we can make your voice heard in this House. And today I want to pay tribute to human rights defenders working in very difficult areas, journalists reporting from conflict zones, to activists who play their lives every day to defend the rights of all. That's the reality. And this Parliament has to be the soundboard of that reality that comes to us all on a daily basis. It is our role and it is our responsibility: to defend the victims and to seek that those responsible are ultimately responsible. Building human Europe—a political army that devotes itself only to that, to defending those who suffer the most—is our most important role.

name: Charles Tannock
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the ECR supports the continued independent presence of individual Member States at the 28th Session of the United Nation’s Human Rights Council. Although it does accept that collectively the EU plays a very active role in the work of the Council in proposing resolutions and making declarations on the protection and promotion of human rights and freedoms and establishing and developing the system of UN special rapporteurs on human rights issues. I am proud, personally, to say that my country, the UK, is living up to its commitments to the UN to safeguard fundamental human rights at a time of escalating violence, particularly in the Middle East. ISIS continues to broadcast its acts of horror in Syria, Iraq and Libya, murdering, torturing, raping and even selling children – which was highlighted a few weeks ago by the Committee for the Rights of the Child – as well as mass public beheadings and the burning of people alive in cages.  I would also like to put on the record that the ECR does not support the calls in paragraph 68 of this resolution for the EU to re-engage with item 7 of the HRC which, in our view, unfairly singles out Israel for special discrimination.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would like to begin my speech by sending a greeting and thanking my ALDE Group colleague, Renate Weber, who has actively and fruitfully contributed to this document and who is sick. I would like to thank you for your work and also for your point of view, because this motion for a resolution, which has great value — as has already been highlighted – of consensus, which has managed to unify criteria and have strong support from the groups, is a comprehensive and balanced motion for a resolution but is late. It is a proposal for a resolution which is being made with a view to the meeting that is already being held, we are voting on it today and it has been held since 2 March — in fact, one of the achievements has been to change its title so that we can talk about council meetings in 2015. And it is also a motion for a Resolution that has a certain content, an internal aspect: we seem to address ourselves a lot more than we want to address, which are the United Nations. What I did want to emphasize is that one of the main tasks of this Council, of course, as the name suggests, is the promotion and protection of human rights and to act objectively on human rights violations in the world. However, among the criteria for membership is not respect for these human rights and democracy and although we have not been able to name it in the motion for a resolution, I do want to name one of those countries that are members of this Council and which are not respecting human rights, such as: Venezuela, Morocco, China, Cuba, Ethiopia, Saudi Arabia , Gabon, Algeria, Mexico, Kazakhstan, Qatar, Vietnam and, last but not least, Russia.  With regard to Russia, I would like to highlight one of which I consider to be great contributions to this document, which is to make clear an opposition from the European Parliament in this regard, because we are not only expressly condemning Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea, but we also describe its policy as aggressive, expansionist and certainly a threat to Ukraine's unity and independence.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, how important are the sessions of the United Nations Human Rights Council (HRC) to this assembly? I wonder.  Once again, we are holding this debate at a time when the 28th session of the HRC is already well under way and many major reports have been adopted. Once again, the resolution before us ignores its agenda. However, it addresses issues that the European Union would be well advised to take into account, such as the situation in Eritrea or the effects of external debt on the full exercise of all human rights, while the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights has just reminded us that economic, social and cultural rights have suffered from austerity policies, which have disproportionately affected the right of peoples to participate in decisions that affect their lives. Everything is said in this sentence.  But to be interested in it, to work on it, to make recommendations in this area would mean that we are also pointing the finger at the effects of European policies, both within the European Union and in its relations with third countries. So we are kicking in and sticking to generalities that are more in touch with the priorities of the Union than with those of the HRC, even if it means accentuating a "lesson-giver" side and fuelling cultural relativism. That is not our vision of multilateral relations, nor that of the United Nations. To hear you, Commissioner, I would like to add that I would have liked to hear, for Israel and Palestine, the same strong condemnation of the violation of international law as you have expressed for Ukraine. Just as I would have liked you to condemn with the same firmness what is happening in the Republic of Sudan, where civilian populations are being bombarded by the government of the day. Finally, on migrants, invite the High Representative to ask Member States to finally sign the international convention on migrant workers.

name: Barbara Lochbihler
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, Commissioner Hahn, I would like to thank commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. The annual resolution on the meeting of the Human Rights Council has once again become a successful policy recommendation to the EU delegation in Geneva. It contains demands as to what is to be achieved in the individual country resolutions, for example on Iran, North Korea, Myanmar and Egypt. In addition, we are taking up issues that are new or not yet so regularly and prominently on the agenda of the Human Rights Council, such as climate change and human rights. The Human Rights Council has already recognised the negative impact of climate change on the living conditions of many people, and it is advisable that the EU or the EU External Action Service also actively participate in the discussion to find a good definition of climate refugees. On the subject of armed drones and autonomous weapons, we call for the development of a common EU position on the conditions under which such weapons can be used while international humanitarian law is respected, and we call for a ban on the development, production and use of fully automatic weapons that can be used without human intervention. In the resolution, we criticise the fact that authoritarian states are increasingly competing for major international events in the field of sport and culture in order to bask in international splendour, while at the same time muzzled critical voices in the country. We must take this development seriously, and we hope that the EU will take up this issue. We need to have discussions with national and international sports federations, with companies and civil society. In concrete terms, this must already be done at the first European Games in Baku this year and also at the FIFA World Cup in Russia 2018 and in Qatar in 2022. Finally, I would like to thank High Representative Mogherini for participating in the high-level segment. This is not self-evident in their agenda and underlines their appreciation for human rights work.

name: Mike Hookem
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, a great deal has been achieved in the protection of human rights across the globe since the formation of the UN Human Rights Council. It is right that we celebrate the successes that we have already had. We must however acknowledge that there is still a long way to go. Throughout the globe there is still areas where severe violations of human rights occur. Indeed it looks like in some ways the West is also moving backwards. In the UK, and in many other areas of Europe, we are being too afraid to stand up for the rights of women and girls, who should be protected from the barbarous act of female genital mutilation, over fears of breaching cultural sensitivities. Whilst it is right that we look around the world and act through international organisations such as the UN and the very generous act of giving money to charity, it is important we also get our own house in order and to no longer be afraid of speaking out against abuses when they happen within our own borders.

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI).
text: Mr President, the European Union lacks realism in its defence of human rights. The position she has just expressed before the United Nations proves this. I will give two examples.  The first example is Syria. The Union rightly condemns the human rights violations committed there, but it sends back to back Bashar al-Assad and Islamist terrorism. However, the Union's interest is to take a clear stand in favour of Bashar al-Assad, because it is for us a bulwark against the Islamic State. If his regime collapses, Syria will provide a backbone for the terrorists, who will use it to multiply attacks in Europe like the one against Charlie Hebdo.  The second example concerns Ukraine. The Union unequivocally condemns Russia and aligns its position with that of the United States. Mr Juncker even wants to create a European army against Russia. It would be more realistic to recognize that the people of Crimea have decided to join Russia, and to let France and Germany try to restore peace in eastern Ukraine.  Diplomacy is the business of sovereign states, not the European Union.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I think this is an excellent document and it summarises very clearly what needs to be achieved.  One point I would like to highlight in particular is paragraph 8, which says that Members of the Council should only come from States that uphold respect for human rights. I think that is something we should certainly push, because it would make a very important diplomatic statement. Secondly, one has to ask the question, are violations of human rights lessening or growing in the world? Certainly the barbarity seems to be growing, when in recent times we have had beheadings, public floggings, burning people alive, and sometimes this is done in the name of religion. I think we should recall what King Abdullah II of Jordan said, that ʽno religion espouses hate, religion is about love and respectʼ. I think that is something that needs to be brought home to many people. I also agree with what has been said about women’s rights, and also in relation to culture and sports events – we can move there.

name: Soraya Post (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr It is a very important resolution that we are facing, especially at this time of great concern around the world. I would like to go back to 1948, when the Universal Declaration of Human Rights came about as a lesson from world wars and annihilation. Since then, there has been a string of conventions to enable individuals to live free and equal in mutual respect for each other. Rights are universal and interdependent and should not depend on arbitrariness. The last declaration forbids us as individuals, as a group and as a state to act actively against its content. Today, despite the hope of previous generations that their mistakes will not be repeated, we are actively opposing human rights both inside and outside the Member States every day. The rights themselves are not guarantees. It is we humans who can give the guarantee. It is therefore up to us to live up to human rights. We must point out against increasing discriminatory laws and violations against people on the grounds of sexual orientation or gender identity in Europe and in the world. Human rights for women as well as for LGBTQ people, refugees, migrants and children are all equally fundamental to peace and democracy. Men's violence against women is one of the world's biggest security problems. Women's right to education and health, as well as sexual and reproductive rights, are fundamental human rights. The European Parliament must actively work towards the implementation of the Beijing Platform, which was adopted 20 years ago. This resolution consolidates our desire to implement human rights in all areas. We're committed. We must stand up for what we are committed to. That is our duty.

name: Mirosław Piotrowski (ECR).
text: – In the context of the forthcoming 28th session of the UN Human Rights Council, our Parliament has tabled a joint resolution detailing more than twenty topics described in total in 69 points. This text draws attention m.in the rights of women, children, indigenous peoples, but also with care the rights of so-called sexual minorities, or LGBTI. There are many risks, but there is no separate paragraph in which our Parliament stigmatises the persecution of Christians in the world, and this is an extremely serious problem, because, according to Open Doors, Christians are the most persecuted religious group in the world. 100 million people in 50 countries are persecuted. Drastic examples of their murders, such as the sheading of Egyptian Christians, have recently been shown in the context of the fight against Islamic terrorism. In the resolution on Christians, we mention Christians marginally, for example, with regard to the situation in Iraq and Syria. However, this is not enough, I believe, in the face of such great terror against Christians around the world.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President. Allow me, ladies and gentlemen, to read to you a poem by Julio Herrera: "Excuse-moi, monsieur, I am not a migratory bird / that on a whim abandoned its abode / at the arrival of adverse seasons: / I am a castaway from a whipped country / which an infamous pirate sank into the seas of misery". Today, ladies and gentlemen, we are voting here on a report on human rights in the world. And we should not forget that human rights are also violated in Europe and at the gates of Europe. I bring you the case of Hassanna Aalia, a young Saharawi who arrived in Spain after being convicted by a Moroccan court. According to Amnesty International, Hassanna Aalia was tortured and subjected to trial without guarantees. He applied for asylum in Spain and, a few weeks ago, our government refused him asylum. This Eurochamber has an obligation to remind european governments and the Spanish Government that the right to asylum is part of one of Europe's most important democratic heritage.

name: Alyn Smith (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I will be brief but I will start by welcoming the Commissioner to this debate and saying, Commissioner, that I appreciated your comments earlier on. I will focus particularly on paragraph 68 – not try to repeat points that other colleagues have made – because this paragraph is significant in the Palestine—Israel relations debate. It calls on the EU and Member States to publicly express support for the UN Commission of Inquiry into gross human rights abuses within the occupied Palestinian territories (OPT). Now, there is a sense of momentum behind this. Last February even, for the first time, the Foreign Affairs Council identified the human rights situation within the OPT as an EU priority. I think we are going to see these findings in June, after the Israeli elections, so I would ask you, Commissioner, in the spirit of both the Foreign Affairs Council and this resolution, what will the Commission, the External Action Service, do to reflect the spirit of paragraph 68 and the Foreign Affairs Council conclusions and, given that there will be recommendations from this independent commission of inquiry, could you commit to their being implemented by the External Action Service to recognise past abuses and prevent future ones?

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am pleased that, having spoken yesterday about Mr Panzeri's annual report on human rights, we are still talking about human rights today with a view to the Council meeting at the United Nations. Unfortunately, However, I am sorry to see that there are always very few of us in this House when it comes to human rights.  This document is a good resolution – which we will vote on – which deals more or less with all human rights issues globally. I am pleased that we are talking about climate change and climate refugees, which are estimated to be around 650 million in the coming years, and I am pleased that we are talking about sporting mega-events, which serve to legitimise states that are in fact systematically violating human rights. Unfortunately, what I am sorry to stress is that our words often and willingly remain purely words: we do not have the means to ensure that our declarations and requests are actually implemented.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE).
text: - Mr. President, I thank Commissioner Hahn for the european union's priorities presented for this year's Human Rights Council session, which substantially coincide with the key messages of the European Parliament resolution that we will adopt today. I think it is very good that High Representative Mogherini was in person already at the session, as I welcome the activities of our High Representative for Human Rights Lambrinidis and the activities of the Subcommittee of the European Parliament.  I believe that the mechanism of universal, periodic review of human rights, in which I myself participated a couple of years ago defending the report of the Republic of Croatia, is one of the key multilateral instruments of real and detailed monitoring of human rights of all countries in the world.  I am particularly pleased that the priority this year is the situation in Ukraine, and what you have said to Commissioner Hahn, a large number of human rights violations in the occupied territories of Ukraine, in illegal and against international law of annexed Crimea, are of utmost importance to the European Union and therefore we must highlight this as well as the numerous, systematic, worst human rights violations that we are looking at currently by the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.

name: Kati Piri (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the United Nations Human Rights Council is at the heart of the global approach to human rights violations. I am therefore very proud that my own country, the Netherlands, has been elected as a member of the Council for the next three years. However, we should not underestimate the task we have to do both in the Human Rights Council and in the EU. Unfortunately, the human rights situation worldwide has reached a low point. Every day, there are serious violations around the world. Opposition leaders are being put behind bars without due process, human rights defenders and journalists must fear for their lives simply because they dare to be critical. Discrimination and violence against LGBT people are the order of the day and tens of thousands of refugees still drown in the Mediterranean every year.  It's up to us to turn the tide. We can only do this by consistently paying attention to human rights issues in our external action, but at the same time by remaining critical of ourselves. I would like to draw additional attention from Commissioner Hahn to the situation in Azerbaijan, where many prominent human rights defenders and members of the opposition have been imprisoned over the past year. The case of Leyla Yunus, nominated by this Parliament for the Sakharov Prize, symbolises the repressive nature of the government in Baku. The first step has been taken with the priorities we have set out for the 28th UN Human Rights Council. I therefore call on the Commission, Parliament and the Member States to continue this course together.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I welcome the Union's priorities for the forthcoming 28th session of the UN Human Rights Council, which is set out in the Council conclusions. The joint resolution contains the most important human rights issues. As a member of the Committee on Education, Culture and Sport, I draw attention to the increasingly authoritarian practice of states organising major sporting or cultural events in order to increase their international legitimacy while continuing to impose restrictions on national political opponents. I therefore call on the European Union and the Member States to actively raise this issue, including at the level of the UN Human Rights Council. It is crucial to establish a dialogue with national sports federations and civil society organisations on the conditions and their participation in such events, including the first European Games in Baku in 2015 and the FIFA World Cup in Russia in 2018.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: – The United Nations brings together 193 countries committed to human rights. But human rights are only important as long as they are comfortable with us and as long as we can choose a la carte from them. The European Union must lead by example, but will it go without first cleaning up at home on our own doorstep? We are asking third countries to respect the right to a fair trial, but in the European Union in Slovakia, will we quietly look at their state trampling? In the case of Hedviga Malin, there is a political trial for intimidation and demonstration of the state over the citizen. The student was beaten up in the street eight years ago because she was on the phone in Hungarian with her mother tongue. But instead of the perpetrators, Hedviga was charged with perjury. When it looked like he was finally going to have peace, the prosecutor appealed the court's decision and the state continued to bully the innocent woman.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to express my conviction that Europe must speak with a single voice, at the next UN Human Rights Council session in Geneva. This is the only way to raise the visibility and influence of the European Union as a global actor and to encourage all moderate states in the United Nations to stand at our side on highly important matters like, for example, what is going on right now: huge violations and abuses of human rights in Europe – in Ukraine and in Crimea. I would like to state my satisfaction at the call in the resolution on the EU Member States to actively oppose any attempt to undermine the concepts of universality, indivisibility and interdependence of human rights, to focus on the need to keep special procedures and to preserve the independence and adequate funding of the Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights, as well as sufficient funding to keep regional offices of the High Commissioner for Human Rights open.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, the 28th session of the UN Human Rights Commission is particularly important. But let me point out that in the European Union there is more bilingualism on the issue of the protection of human rights in the world, at a time when the troika has, without any consequence, violated human rights in the countries that have been put to a memorandum and especially in Greece. In fact, the Commission, which is also a member of the troika, in response to a parliamentary question, accepted that human rights are not protected against memoranda, because they are supposedly not related to European Union law.  As the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe held that austerity leads to the violation of human rights, mercely austerity, which the European Union serves with religious reverence, leads to a massive and persistent violation of the human rights of the citizens of the Union.  What does the Commission say about all this? He goes on to "business as usual," insisting on austerity. Therefore, before the European Union supposedly decides to save the world, it is better to put its own house in order.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, it is true that human rights are also being violated in Europe and the truth is that our Member States also have human rights problems in many areas, on many issues, whether that right to minority language or other rights. But let's put our hand to heart, Europe is nevertheless the leader in human rights in the world. And that is why we should be that example in relation to all countries, in all 193 members who are at the rally in Switzerland.  What I want to highlight in particular is the problem of children's rights. This is a universal right - from children being poor, having nothing to eat to what we see today in the developed world and what we have talked about, which is online violence towards children. We must do everything to try our action, primarily to protect the most vulnerable groups, and in this sense children are a particularly vulnerable group.

name: Εμμανουήλ Γλέζος (
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, one of the most important human rights is the right to a people's verdict. When there are no elections in a country, we consider the country undemocratic. We believe that there is a brutal violation of human rights.  Elections were held in Greece on 25 January 2015. The Greek people, with their verdict, wanted to carve out their own path against all those who have passed a noose around their necks and want to drown them with loans.  I called Mr Weber yesterday to tell me: should the Greek people swallow their language? Does he have to undo what he voted for? He answered me with words that have absolutely no value. I ask him again, as in all of you, what should the Greek people do?

name: António Marinho e Pinto (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, there are two ways to combat violations of any rights. It is through the prevention of these violations and the repression of violators of rights.  The violation of human rights is mainly prevented by combating poverty. It is in poverty that the greatest victims of human rights are. It is in poverty that some of the greatest violators of these rights are recruited. Therefore, an international plan to combat poverty is urgent, also as a way of combating the violation of human rights.  But violations are also being fought through repression, and to do so it is necessary to strengthen the authority of the International Criminal Court. Let no rapist be calm after committing these heinous crimes, especially crimes against humanity, crimes of torture or genocide. Strengthening the authority and action of the International Criminal Court is absolutely important for this task.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of VP/HR. – Mr President, once again I would like to thank you for this debate, and for your recommendations regarding the EU priorities for the 28th session of the Human Rights Council.  They correspond a great deal with those endorsed by the Foreign Affairs Council on 9 February. This is an important signal that the EU stands united in reaffirming the universality of human rights. Let me close with a reference to gender equality, which I know is dear to you. On Monday in New York, the High Representative/Vice President attended the 59th session of the UN Commission on the Status of Women. This is a priority for the Commission at large. The advancement of gender equality and the empowerment of women and girls should concern us all.  True, much more needs to be done to protect and empower women and girls worldwide, including in our own countries. However, we should support this, and with the support of all 28 Member States, the European Union can make a real difference. Throughout this debate I have seen a joint commitment to the human rights actions of the United Nations. As your resolution shows, we have many common priorities. I would like to invite you to join our efforts in the promotion of human rights around the globe. We must not rest on our laurels. As the currently ongoing session of the Human Rights Council shows, we have our work cut out for us. I count on Parliament’s support and look forward to our continued cooperation.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. The 28th session of the UN Human Rights Council will celebrate the anniversary of its birth in March 2006. Since then, its role and, above all, its work for the protection of human rights in the world has been un questionable. Today, too, we are celebrating it and applauding its commitment to the thousands of persecuted people and refugees in different parts of the world it assists. But let me say there's a little bit of hypocrisy in all of this. The UNHRC, to which we attach reliability and credibility, has repeatedly criticised the European Union's immigration policy, criticised our asylum system and triton's inadequacy. It recommended that Europe – and I will give just a few examples – have a 'coordinated response to strengthen solidarity in the EU', 'sharing responsibilities for access to European territory' and 'creating legal alternatives to dangerous irregular movements'. It seems to me that the direction of European immigration policy is heading in the opposite direction to date. I hope that, in addition to celebrating the UNHRC, the EU will also respect its recommendations.

name: Ramona Nicole Mănescu (PPE)
text: in writing. – The recent terrorist attacks in Paris and Copenhagen have been a harsh reminder that, in the heart of Europe, human rights face serious threats, as Islamist terrorists particularly target freedom of expression and religion. We must condemn terrorist acts around our borders, whether we are talking about Syria, Iraq, Nigeria or Central Africa. We must do everything in our rights to promote the right to life and other essential human rights.  To achieve this, we need to address not only the effects, but also the causes of these forms of extremism, such as poverty, unemployment and lack of opportunities or the marginalisation of different communities. While terrorism poses a serious threat to human rights, it is precisely these rights that remain the most powerful weapons in the fight against terrorism. That is why the Human Rights Council has a special responsibility to combat extremism wherever it appears.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the recent attacks and kidnappings by Daesh in the Middle East, mainly Assyrians (2015/2599(RSP))

name: n/a
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Now that I have the chance to start this debate, I would like to say that my first thoughts go out to all those who have been affected by the indiscriminate violence of IS, and to all those who are currently worried about perhaps becoming the next victims or that their relatives will soon be. Not least, I know that many at home in Sweden, where we have a large group of Chaldeans, Assyrians and Syrians, live with constant concern about developments at home. I suffer with them and I understand their concerns. Last summer, Mosul and the Nineveh Plain were emptied of their indigenous people. Much of the cultural heritage has been destroyed and today the history of Khabur is reiterating itself. It is our responsibility to say that what is happening today is international crimes against humanity and that we should not allow it to continue. I am therefore very pleased that the resolution has a clear support for the various groupings in the European Parliament. The EU has a role to play, not least in supporting humanitarian operations in the area in the near future and in working to ensure that Chaldeans, Assyrians, Syrians and other vulnerable groups are given the opportunity, where practically possible, to live in a protected area of the Nineveh Plains, where these groups have historically lived in peace side by side.

name: Javier Nart
text: Author. – Mr President, the motion for a resolution is about moving from metaphysics to reality. Christian communities in the Middle East are under threat and are a part without which it is not possible to understand the culture or history of the Middle East. We are therefore not only condemning the crimes — that is where we would all agree – but supporting the necessary reaction, which means military support to end barbarism, in the face of which real and not simply philosophical decisions must be made. This is what paragraphs 4 and 5 are all about. The overall fight against daesh is supported. In paragraph 7, making a specific mention, there are institutions and individuals of the Arabian Gulf , or Persian, which are actively and economically supporting the Daesh. Finally, there is a specific mention of the cultural barbarity that means the destruction of culture in the Middle East by this fundamentalist barbarism. We move from philosophy and words to necessity. And the need is military reaction and effective political reaction.

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: Author. Mr President, a few minutes ago, an e-mail from the European Syriac Union was in the running. While we are debating here, the Assyrian city of Tell Tamer is under attack by Islamic State. The e-mail is a plea for help. And yes, we will again condemn the brutality of IS in the strongest terms today, but unfortunately the terror group does not interfere with international rules. Their philosophy is based on a selective and reprehensible interpretation of Islam, in which dissenting interpretations or other beliefs are eradicated, among them centuries-old religious communities and their heritage such as Yazidis, Copts, Assyrians, etc.  But never, ever can hatred and terror lead to harmonious society! Individuals can crack but age-old beliefs cannot. There will be a day when Daesh will no longer exist and it seems to me useful as an international community to reflect on the post-IS era. This absolute evil must be dealt with in an all-encompassing way, militarily, ideologically, culturally and socio-economically.

name: György Hölvényi
text: Author. – Mr President, honourable Colleagues, today's decision is a serious step towards Europe finally understanding and taking on its task of dealing with the crisis brought about by Islam. Today, I must stress once again that Christian and other indigenous ethnic minorities are on the verge of dispersal and total disappearance in the region. Being a diaspora makes them even more defenseless. The leader of the Chaldete Christians, Patriarch Sako, who has been personally welcomed by several of us, turned to us in another desperate message this week. The increasingly violent jihadist advance and the operations of the Iraka military forces have dramatically exacerbated the situation of the refugees. Thousands of other innocent families remain without a vision. There is no specific rescue plan. We need food, medicine, accommodation, education, the patriarch urges the decision-makers. As underlined by today's joint decision, it is our job to shelter the persecuted, especially in their own country. This catastrophe cannot go unrestricted if Europe does not provide adequate humanitarian aid, now primarily humanitarian aid, no one else knows, will not do it for us.

name: Javier Couso Permuy
text: Author. – Mr President, we are very much given in this House to be upset and to show dismay whenever there are human rights emergencies.
