But when it comes time for analysis, we sometimes look the other way or, even worse, ask for indiscriminate bombardment. However, analysis and memory are critical to not making the solution worse. An important historian said that the two decades after 1989 were those of the years devoured by locusts. The triumphalism of the new world order brought us genocide, ethnic sectarianism, religious integrisms and Western interventions. And beneath that criminal dynamic are the peoples, who are an obstacle within this logic. Minorities in the Middle East must be protected, because they are the last reserve of the lay States, of the states of citizens. And I'm talking about countries like Iraq and Syria, which have been sacrificed and that have generated monsters like the Islamic State organization. And I am referring to peoples like the Assyrian, who have only found a home in the lay States and who have been sacrificed in the name of an order of sectarian nationalisms manageable by the mighty of this world.

name: Josef Weidenholzer
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the In the Middle East, we are witnessing a tragedy of historic proportions. Daesh is destroying the foundations of our civilization. Everything that stands in the way of their terrorist arbitrariness is to be destroyed: monuments, writings, cultural achievements and, above all, people. People who refuse to obey their orders and people whose only offence is to belong to another religion. In contrast to what has been common in the region for 2000 years, people of different religions lived side by side and together. Since there have been Christians, they have lived in the Middle East. Two weeks ago, more than 200 Assyrian Christians were kidnapped. Their fate is uncertain, the worst is to be feared. We must not accept this attempt at extermination under any circumstances!

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to say first of all that it was our group that initiated this resolution on the situation of Christians, especially Syrians, but also other religious minorities in the Near East. Of course, we regret that other proposals that we have made, first of all the proposal to discuss Nadia Savchenko and the Crimean Tatars, have not been accepted. Our fellow socialists have blocked the debate on these topics for the second time. However, we are glad that we can discuss the situation of Christians, all the more so since, at the time we are discussing, there are attacks against Christians in Tell Tamer, in the khabur River valley. It is a more than current subject: the moment we discuss this, people die at the attack of those who claim the Caliphate and the prophet's vengeance. I hope we can find some political solutions to protect these Christians.

name: Francisco Assis
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I will begin by quoting a statement coming out today in a French press agency, a statement by a Christian, the Syrian refugee in Lebanon named Rafa El-Nawfali, which says this: Islamic State fighters have no religion. They seek to eradicate the other, one who is different from them, whether Christian or Muslim.  This is the mark today of the Islamic State. It means a profound civilizational setback. And this civilizational setback, this threat, is a threat that has to be fought. Christians mean and represent the other, radical to them, and by attacking Christians they also naturally aim to outrage western public opinion especially.  But we can never lose sight of the concern that Christians and Muslims are concerned, that the first victims are the populations of all those regions. And that requires a clear political response. And that political response has to have two components, a diplomatic component, but it also has to have a military component. We cannot ignore this reality and we must use all the political instruments at our disposal to combat this evil.

name: Bas Belder
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, Christians are an integral part of the Middle East, as King Abdullah of Jordan told parliament on Tuesday. An outright test case for the European Union, because how do we support the Jordanian monarch's vision in concrete terms? I make two proposals, two urgent appeals to the European Union and, above all, its Member States.  Firstly, fully support the Christian units in Syria and Iraq who are trying to protect their own families, villages and property from the IS barbarism. They are our boots-on-the-ground. Let us therefore work closely with Assyrian and Chaldean networks in Europe. Secondly, support the creation of an autonomous province for religious minorities in the Plain of Ninive. That would give hope and hope to the displaced and persecuted Christians scattered around tent camps in the region. Let us give all our support to the message of King Abdullah.

name: Kristina Winberg
text: On the other: The EFDD Group. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The Christian minority in Syria and Iraq knows that ISIS' sole purpose is to kill and destroy. Since February this year, ISIS has been invading Christian villages in the Khabur Valley in Syria. The first attack on these villages came on 22 February. Since then, ISIS has continued to attack Christians and other minorities in the area. More than 350 people were captured on 22 February. Several of these have been killed, others have been taken as sex slaves. 1.5 million people in the area are at risk of the same fate. Unfortunately, those fleeing have been met by a closed Turkish border and have not been able to obtain shelter, food or water. International aid is therefore absolutely crucial to whether these refugees are to survive or not, but that is not enough. The governments of Iraq, Turkey, Syria and Kurdistan must act together with the UN and the Member States to ensure that Christians and other minorities are protected from the religious and cultural cleansing of ISIS and guaranteed safe places in the region where they can live in peace. I want to fight for that.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am certainly in favour of this resolution. It is very pleased that action is finally being taken to try to defend those who are the most persecuted in recent years, namely Christians, and above all it is a pleasure because we often and willingly talk in this House about the defence of minorities in Europe, we talk about the fact that we must never again repeat the mistakes of the past, the fact that Nazism is to be erased. : but at a time when in Syria and Iraq the homes of Christians are marked with the "N" as "Nazarenes", well what is it but a new form of Nazism? And why is Europe so hard to intervene? I saw that in Libya, when there were economic interests, action was taken immediately, and it seems to me that we are making a great effort to defend Christians in the world. And be ware: the problem of persecution of Christians does not exist only in Syria and Iraq; there are at least fifty countries in the world in which 150 million Christians are persecuted. So if we are so good at declaring war on economic interests and imposing sanctions on economic interests, why do we not do the same against these countries that persecute peaceful Christians?

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr As the initiator, I would strongly urge my colleagues in this House to vote in favour of this resolution.  We are now seeing a people's millennia-old history uprooted. We see how Islamic State purposefully conducts ethno-religious cleansing in both Iraq and Syria. If it is difficult for us to see images of islamic state atrocities and the erasure of the historical heritage of a ethnic group, we can only imagine what Chaldeans, Assyrians and Syrians throughout the world feel right now.  There's a genocide going on. Back in September, I and the EPP proposed a closed zone for Chaldeans, Assyrians, Syrians and others in the Nineveh Plain. That is why it is a very important signal that the European Parliament is today in favour of this particular proposal, while at the same time stressing the need for cooperation with the regional and local protection forces currently fighting against Islamic State.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – (2) Mr President, if there were coordination between the Member States and the European Union, we could do more and better to help the people of Iraq and Syria, at the mercy of the atrocities of the band of criminals who call themselves Islamic State and causing a humanitarian catastrophe of biblical proportions in the region.  We could be more effective in supporting the indispensable military campaign that the Kurds courageously conduct to eradicate DAESH from control of cities and to halt persecution against Christian and Yazidis, Kurds, Shiites and others in the region, such as the hundreds of Christians recently kidnapped.  We could be more effective in supporting the organization of networks to free enslaved hostages, which include thousands of women and children. And I have spoken to other Members, recently with young people who have managed to escape Mosul and who desperately need medical and psychological support and who should take priority in European aid.  Palavas and resolutions are not enough. We can be more effective in humanitarian aid and another, the aid we pay and which is desperately needed in Iraq and Syria, if it is properly coordinated, directed to ensure that, for example, schools in refugee and displaced persons camps work, and especially if we help the former pre-Islamic communities of the region, which are now persecuted, to understand that there will be a future for them in Iraq and Syria.

name: David Campbell Bannerman (ECR).
text: – Mr President, Daesh or ISIS has embarked upon a campaign to eradicate all traces of religious and faith communities other than those representing its own twisted interpretation of Islam. Christians, Yazidis, Turkmens, Shiites and other minorities have been subject to this terror campaign. Their methods are barbaric; they are killing or expelling inhabitants and destroying their holy places, including unique internationally—recognised heritage. This is a process of cultural cleansing, comparable to that of Cambodia’s Khmer Rouge back in the 1970s – a vile attempt to take the region back to ground zero. Just last month, ISIS butchered 21 Egyptian Coptic Christians in Libya, and abducted around 22 Assyrian Christians in Syria. As Chairman of the Iraq Delegation, I salute the courage of local Iraqi forces, the Kurdish Peshmerga and the Iraqi armed forces in fighting the evil of ISIS, such as at Tikrit. I encourage international partners vigorously to support military moves against ISIS, right across the region, to protect these endangered minorities.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Despite positive news of an alleged weakening of ISIS, the organization has lost none of its danger. It is and remains a gang of murderers that terrorises the Middle East, and kidnappings play a central role in this. And once again, the most persecuted religious group in the world, namely the Christians, this time up to 400 people who have been snatched from their old Assyrian homeland, are being held captive and living in daily fear of death, while their Christian brothers in Tall Tamer continue to resist desperately. We must therefore open our eyes to the fact that Christianity is the most persecuted religion in the world and that Islamism is to blame. It is up to Europe to draw political conclusions from this: countries that do not offer protection to their Christian minorities, countries that allow persecution or even tolerate persecution, must expect all the consequences! Anyone who advocates sanctions against Russia should also have the same courage among Islamic states!

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), – Mr President, once again we are debating and being called upon to vote to condemn the atrocities of the Islamic Caliphate. Last time he was against the Kurds. Now against the Assyrians. The next one against who's going to be?  Resolutions and wishful speech do not address religious fanaticism and intolerance. Unfortunately, I am afraid that next time the resolution will concern crimes that the Caliphate will have committed within European territory. With the policies we are pursuing today, we are essentially opening Europe's doors to the jihadists.  But not all the countries of the Union have the same responsibility for this. Not all countries supported the foolish expansionist policy of the Americans that created the right environment to develop the Caliphate. Not all countries have sought to overthrow governments in their own interests. It is better, then, for everyone to assume their responsibilities, and also to stop pretending to be a global gendarme before it is too late. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: – I am a co-bearer of this resolution because I believe that the outrages caused by the Islamic State, both on the fates of millions and on world cultural heritage, are inadmissible and we must offer certainty to those suffering and find adequate ways to preserve locally the heritage that is at great risk of destruction. The atrocities that the terrorists of this self-proclaimed caliphate apply, especially to people of other faiths, such as Assyrian Christians in the region, are shocking and should not be material for a media and PR campaign by European and world politicians, but to provide adequate channels.... (speech interrupted)

name: President. –
text: This is not a question to your colleague.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: Mr President, I have just returned from the Middle East, where I have met leading political and religious figures, including the Maronite Patriarch, the Syriac Patriarch and the Chaldean Bishop of Beirut. The situation of all Christians, not just Assyrians, is absolutely dramatic in these countries. But what to do?  I think we need to help them defend themselves. The right of self-defence is absolute in the face of such barbarism that is attacking people, cultural heritage and humanity.  In this context, the silence of the Arab countries is absolutely deafening. What is the Arab League doing? Do the Arab League countries - for example, on the grounds that they are mostly Sunnis - actually become accomplices of the Islamic State?  We urgently need an international military intervention that is not necessarily the work of the West, but we must help on all fronts, including their security, and of course also on the material level, the unfortunate refugees, whose disappearance would mark the recoil over several thousand kilometres of our civilization.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the condemnation of the persecution of Christians, whether Assyrian, Chaldean or Coptic, and of all religious minorities is extremely harsh and clear on our part. We cannot allow any community to be eradicated from its ancestral lands in the silence of the international community. But we must also remember, ladies and gentlemen, that falling into the rhetoric of the Jihad Crusade, of the clash of civilisations is exactly what these terrorist groups, such as Daesh, want.  If we created tension and suspicion in our societies towards Muslim communities, we would then push moderate Islam towards social exclusion and radicalisation, creating new breeding ground for recruits and foreign fighters. Let us also not forget that the Muslims themselves, in number of victims, are the most affected, Sunni but also Shiite. Daesh uses religion as a pretext, and that is why we must work together with representatives of political Islam, such as the Arab League, and religious Islam, to completely dissociate themselves and leave no ambiguity as to their contiguity with these groups.  We all work together before it's too late.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: – I am glad to have signed this resolution, but it is not enough just to re-condemn the terrorists of the so-called Islamic State. Again, outraged to talk about the murder, kidnapping and enslaving of Christians. Action and real help are needed. Whole families have been driven out of their homes, they have lost their roofs, they need food and medicine. They need at least makeshift schools, otherwise the poverty in which parents suddenly find themselves will be passed on to the next generation. For 2,000 years, Assyrian and Chaldean Christians have professed the same values on which Schuman, Adenauer and De Gasperi based their dream of a united Europe. It's our brothers and sisters who have been affected by great misfortune. They believe we can help them. Let us be aware that we are witnessing a genocide on which we have detailed information. Responsibility for the next fate of Christians in Syria and Iraq lies primarily on our shoulders.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The security and life and survival of Christian communities should be the subject not only of our resolutions, but of an essential premise of Western policy in the Middle East. If we are talking today about the need for an inclusive government in Iraq, one of the criteria of this inclusive nature should be the participation of Christian communities, the political representation of these communities in the Iraqi authorities. And the Iraqi authorities, to whom we provide support, should be expected both to protect Christians militarily where they are directly threatened and to provide means of defence to the Christian formations that are currently self-defending syrians or other Christian communities that live there. Of course, all this does not relieve us of our direct responsibility to defend them internationally or directly.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, I had previously asked to take part in the catch the eye procedure for this debate, to my colleague in the Bureau, and she told me that there was no problem. I was here when the conversation started and I had asked to participate in the catch the eye process. You weren't the president, it was some other lady and she said OK. So I would like the floor in the context of catch the eye before the Commissioner starts. I asked for it, and I was here.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I have already given my voice to the Commissioner. I'm very sorry, but I didn't have that information. I ask you to speak to the Commissioner at the moment. I'm sorry it happened, but it's not really my fault.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am honoured to address you on behalf of the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, although it is on a very sad subject. During previous plenary debates on this matter we highlighted the fact that Daesh poses a complex terrorist threat also for Europe. However, we must remember that Syrian and Iraqi citizens are truly on the front line. Daesh’s actions are horrific. The human rights abuses committed by them are increasing both in the number of victims and in atrocity. They include the vicious and barbaric murder of prisoners, abuses of the worst kind against children and women and the persecution of persons belonging to different religions, ethnic communities and vulnerable groups. The kidnapping of more than 200 Christian Assyrians in the Hassakeh region of Syria, at the end of February, is just the most recent in Daesh’s long list of brutal actions that may amount to more crimes and crimes against humanity according to the UN Commission of Inquiry on Syria. All of this is in complete violation of international human rights law and goes directly against freedom of religion or belief, which includes the right for persons of all faiths to live and practise their religion freely, without fear of intolerance or attacks. In terms of numbers, the first victims of Daesh are Sunni Muslims. At the same time it is clear that Daesh poses a specific and more deliberate threat to minorities in the region, to Christians, but also to Yazidis, Shabakis and other groups. Let us be clear, Daesh’s actions jeopardise the survival of the multi—ethnic and multi—religious character of the Middle East, and the prospect for inclusive stability in the long—term. The European Union and its partners cannot tolerate this. We also denounce the attacks on, and destruction of, world heritage sites, and the illicit trafficking in cultural properties. This is why on numerous occasions we have expressed views and the determination to contain and defeat Daesh and to contribute as fully as possible, both at the individual level of Member States and the collective level of the EU, to the efforts of the global coalition. We believe that military action is essential, but not sufficient on its own. It is necessary to address the underlying violence in Syria and Iraq, which has given terrorist groups a foothold. It is the instability in Syria, caused by the Assad regime’s brutal war against its own people and the non—inclusive policies in Iraq, that has allowed Daesh to flourish. The Foreign Affairs Council should adopt shortly a new regional strategy on Syria and Iraq, as well as on the Daesh threat, based on the recent joint communication of the European Commission and the High Representative on the subject. A EUR 1 billion assistance package has been mobilised in support of the regional strategy, but it is important to secure additional financial support at bilateral and multilateral level to ensure that the response to the crisis meets the ever—increasing level of needs. I call on the European Parliament to continue to support all the strands of EU action to tackle, in a comprehensive manner, the multiple causes and consequences of the crisis.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate.  The vote will take place after the debate. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. I welcome the fact that the so-called "Islamic State" (IS) is unanimously against it, but I regret that we are slow to acknowledge our past mistakes and to review our strategy in the region, particularly with regard to our dangerous links with Qatar and Saudi Arabia. However, there is an urgent need to put an end to the odious persecution of Christians by Daesh, as well as the abominable destruction of the cultural heritage of this region which is experiencing and flourishing so many prodigious civilizations. The images of the Mosul museum rampage and even more those of the bulldozer destruction of the ancient Assyrian city of Nimroud will remain forever etched in my memory... and I hold the Americans co-responsible for these priceless losses, for it is they who, through their simple ideas, have sowed chaos in this eminently complex region.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. – Da’esh caliphate is by far the most barbaric terrorist organization; they are savages, not humans. They are killing people of different religions and positions. They represent a deadly threat to the existence of Christians and other religions in the Middle East. Historical mosques, monuments, shrines, churches, other places of worships, tombs and cemeteries, as well as priceless archaeological and cultural heritage sites, have been destroyed. Assyrians are one of the oldest civilisations on earth, but their cultural and historical heritage is disappearing, step by step, in the Middle East. I make a call to all States and entities providing military support in the fight against Da’esh to organize as soon as possible special military units in order to protect the minorities in the area and, as well, to protect and save the historical and cultural heritage of mankind in the areas occupied by the barbaric, inhuman terrorist organisation Da’esh. Unfortunately, priceless artefacts are being destroyed forever.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. For many months, Daesh has spread terror among ethnic and religious minorities by increasing attacks, murderous acts and kidnappings. This situation is unbearable and it is now fundamental that the international community engages more immediately to combat these acts and to recall the inalienable right of all religious and ethnic minorities, including Christians in Iraq and Syria, to continue to live in dignity and security, and to be able to continue to practice their religion. I am deeply shocked by this chaotic situation and its evolution. Daesh attacks not only minorities and peoples, but also humanity by destroying cultural symbols and heritages in its path. I call on the European Union, the Member States and the international community to strengthen their cooperation in order to provide assistance to these religious and ethnic minorities as soon as possible, to combat this threat, and to promote and defend our fundamental freedoms.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE)
text: in writing. – From 25 February, the so called Islamic State began a deliberate campaign to destroy cultural heritage in the Nineveh province, beginning with the destruction of the Mosul Museum, continuing on to levelling of Nimrud, Hatra and Khorsabad with bulldozers. Three thousand years of history and UNESCO World Heritage sites were destroyed within ten days. Not only are Assyrian Christian and Yazidi people targeted as populations, but also by means of their built environment and heritage. The destruction of religious and historical sites and patrimony works in tandem with the direct physical violence against these communities, whose historical presence is being systematically wiped out. According to the protocols of the 1954 Hague Convention and the principles of the Geneva Convention, the deliberate destruction of cultural patrimony is a war crime. The Director General of UNESCO and Ban Ki-Moon have condemned these acts as war crimes. The European Parliament should also do the same.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: in writing. – I am very glad that the European Parliament has discussed this resolution, which summarises the current situation of minorities in the Middle East and North Africa. We have recently expressed our condemnation of the barbaric acts of terrorist organisations that commit inhuman crimes against innocent people in the name of religion. It was clear from the outset that the activities of these terrorist organisations had nothing to do with the religion in whose name they were committing these acts. But this is all the more obvious at a time when these terrorists are destroying the cultural heritage of past generations, depriving future generations of their identity. I'm sure that's their intention. These terrorists have thus only confirmed that they are truly opposed to the universal values of human civilization as a whole. Further attention must be paid to the protection of minorities, and if we have information that suggests that minorities, especially religious ones, are being threatened, including in refugee camps, for example, this problem needs to be addressed and appropriate measures taken on the ground. It is certainly very difficult to ensure security in large-scale refugee camps, but if we have information that suggests certain problems, we must try to respond to them.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on South Sudan, including the recent kidnappings of children (2015/2603(RSP)).

name: Judith Sargentini
text: Author. Mr President, the conflict in South Sudan does not need an introduction. We've talked about this before. The president and the former vice president are at each other's lives and the population suffers. The preliminary low point is the kidnapping of, at least, 89 children but perhaps a lot more from a village in South Sudan. Children, boys as young as 12 who are already considered fit to fight as soldiers in the army of one of the two warring factions.  It reminded me of the book "What is the What?" by Dave Eggers, the 2006 book that describes the journey of a young man who also fled from a village in South Sudan because of the government army, a journey through Sudan to Ethiopia, to refugee camps. We actually see "What is the What" in reality. Our question is: bring the kids back.

name: Petr Ježek
text: author. – Mr President, I am glad that we agreed on a common resolution which demonstrates that we are fully aware of the scale of the catastrophe in South Sudan. Approximately 1.4 million people have been displaced, 500 000 have fled to neighbouring countries, 2 000 children have been recruited as soldiers, and thousands more killed, raped, displaced and orphaned. Four million people are at risk of malnutrition and famine. In this respect, I am glad Parliament, in this resolution, calls on the international community to convene a new donor conference on South Sudan when the necessary conditions are in place. I am in contact with different people working on the ground and I hear how desperate and frustrating the situation is there. Everything that could go wrong did go wrong. All the factors are in place to lead to a disaster on a huge scale. I strongly support, therefore, the idea gaining ground of establishing an international contact group in South Sudan, bringing together a number of actors involved in the peace process. This would ensure coherence and generate the desirable pressure and momentum.

name: Jana Žitňanská
text: Author – Children suffer the most in any conflict of war. Since the beginning of this conflict, 400 000 children have had to leave school, and up to 12 000 of them have been forcibly taken from the school benches directly to the front line of the conflict. The latest incident in mid-February involved more than 89 children, with hundreds of boys and girls becoming involuntary soldiers, according to UNICEF. Many of the children, who are often under the age of 12, persecu live during training, others already in a fierce battle. The rest will carry this trauma all their lives. It is appalling that these practices are being resorted to by both sides of the conflict and, despite numerous attempts and signed ceasefires, peace seems to be in sight. I therefore welcome the strong action taken by the UN Security Council, which has decided to adopt sanctions against those South Sudanese officials who would put obstacles to the end of this conflict.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that any further comment on the inhumanity and atrocity of what is happening in South Sudan is superfluous. There is no point in constantly listing how inhumane what happens to child soldiers is, but also what happens to abducted girls, first treated as slaves and then destined for the prostitution market. South Sudan is the youngest state in the world, if not one of the youngest states in the world, and it must certainly make us reflect the fact that since its inception it has been practically in a situation of perennial civil war. Perhaps we should pay attention to those who are interested in keeping South Sudan in this situation, to those who have an economic interest in maintaining the two factions, the opposition and the government, which are constantly fighting each other and thus fomenting this kind of inhumanity.

name: Teresa Jiménez-Becerril Barrio
text: Author. – Mr President, the human rights situation in South Sudan is one of the worst in the world. Peace has had few opportunities since this country gained independence in 2011. Since 2013 it has been immersed in a civil war with devastating consequences for so many victims: here we have cited it, girls who are raped, recruited to be sex slaves and also, most importantly, of which this motion for resolution deals, child soldiers. The numbers are alarming, more than 12,000 children recruited for war. Thousands more killed, raped, kidnapped. It's impossible to accept so much cruelty.  The action plan to which the two parties committed has not been respected; it is therefore necessary to put an end to the recruitment of child soldiers, which we cannot admit, and I congratulate myself on the fact that this Parliament has been able to be united; it is impossible not to be united in the face of such barbarism. And from here we say 'enough' and that we have to put a solution to this very serious violation of human rights.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez
text: Author. – Mr President, we express our strong condemnation of the use of children in wars, as well as to all kinds of violence against women and girls. We also condemn a conflict behind which there are, as always, strong interests of the Western powers in their natural resources: land, oil, iron, copper, diamonds and gold.  We ask that we use all diplomatic avenues to end this conflict in South Sudan, to respect human rights and to end the kidnapping of children, as well as to support for these children—soldiers to recover their childhood. We ask for clear and strong support to improve the living conditions of the population and to eradicate poverty, hunger and malnutrition. We also ask for support for farmers to have precise resources for food production, which is land, water and economic support.  But we're not the ones who have to tell you what the government has to do in South Sudan.

name: Josef Weidenholzer
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the It was not long ago that we dealt with the situation in South Sudan in this context. We have deplored the increasingly out-of-control situation, which is leading to the destruction of state structures and the loss of social relations. We have expressed our hope that the situation will improve. That was in November last year. None of this has happened. The situation has deteriorated, the number of internally displaced persons has grown to 1.5 million, and more than 2.5 million people – almost a quarter of the population – are suffering from hunger. The country is deeply divided and the conflicts are fought with cruel violence. Increasingly, children are also being used as soldiers. This literally puts the future of the country on the run. We must end this cycle of destruction. That is why we must not remain silent and must keep reminding ourselves of these things.

name: Davor Ivo Stier
text: on behalf of the PPE Club. – Mr. President, just under 4 years ago South Sudan and its citizens gained independence and then many, popularly named lost boys of Sudan from generations who were kidnapped and separated from their parents and recruited for military purposes and tens of thousands who fled the country, decided to return to South Sudan because they wanted to build a better future for their state. Unfortunately, those lost boys who fled the war returned to their home to find only another war. Already in December 2013, violent ethnic conflicts began, which passed the nightmares of war and lost childhood on to another generation of children. According to UNICEF, about 12,000 child soldiers recruited on both sides were used across the country last year alone.  The recent abductions of 89 boys in South Sudan have reminded us again of this reality, and that is why I support the UN sanctions of 5 March to punish those obstructing the attempt to end the conflict.

name: Ana Gomes
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, the abduction and recruitment of children to fight in the government and opposition armed forces in South Sudan, which has been in war for more than a year with successive failed peace agreements, is a war crime and against humanity, in addition to others committed since the beginning of the conflict , in a climate of impunity that the international community cannot continue to tolerate.  The conduct of the peace negotiations by IGAD has failed, which is not surprising, because the countries of the region themselves have competing interests in the conflict, and the mediators cannot be impartial.  The UN Security Council resolution, which provides for sanctions, to be imposed on leaders obstructing the peace process, must now be implemented. The European Union should help implement the arms embargo enacted by the Security Council and call for international scrutiny on the use of the proceeds of oil exploration in the country, which have been used to sustain the war effort.  The European Union and the Member States should put pressure on the African Union to take a stand and publish the report of its committee of inquiry into South Sudan. The massacred people of South Sudan deserve justice, an end to war and impunity.

name: Nathalie Griesbeck
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are stunned by the proliferation of so many theatres of war in the world.  We are seeing the spread of fear, which is leading democracies and more and more citizens to withdraw into themselves. Needless to say, South Sudan, the youngest country in the world, is the object and bloodied theatre of fighting between brothers: thousands of children killed, children raped, abused, little girls slaves, twelve thousand children abducted to become soldiers... Faced with this observation, it is horror. It is not enough to say this and to sign resolutions and declarations, we must act and not leave the international community inert in the face of this disaster.  This resolution calls for the resumption of negotiations, an immediate end to these violations, which are a disgrace to the international community, and access to humanitarian assistance.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, is cuimhin liom a bheith ag caint sa Pharlaimint anseo cúpla bliain ó shin nuair a fuair an tSúdáin Theas neamhspleáchas agus ag an am sin bhíomar dóchasach go rachadh an tír ar aghaidh, ach ní mar sin a tharla faraor. I ndáiríre tá sí imithe ar chúl. Ní féidir aon dul chun cinn a dhéanamh nuair a bhíonn cogadh cathartha i dtír mar atá sa tSúdáin Theas. Is tragóideach go bhfuil siad ag úsáid buachaillí óga mar shaighdiúirí; ag dul isteach i dtithe agus i scoileanna ag tógaint buachaillí óga amach, ag cur gunnaí ina lámha chun daoine eile a lámhach nó, níos dóichí b’fhéidir, chun go marófar iad féin. Caithfimid gach iarracht a dhéanamh chun deireadh a chur leis seo agus ansin an acmhainn shaibhir atá acu, go háirithe ola, a úsáid ar mhaithe lena ndaoine agus na scoileanna a oscailt chun oideachas a thabhairt do na daoine óga.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, South Sudan is a rich region, has enormous oil production potential and, of course, after gaining its independence, it is a fact that foreign interests, taking advantage of the contradictions and contradictions that existed in society, have led that region into a civil war.  We now have 1.5 million displaced people, we have 500,000 refugees in neighbouring states, we have dealt with this issue at European Parliament meetings and it seems that we are being led to a humanitarian crisis in the region, as over 4 million souls are at risk.  The new evidence is that children are now being recruited into this civil war and even children are being kidnapped in order to recruit them violently. There must be immediate, catalytic action by the European Union on this issue, so that we can prevent the humanitarian crisis. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Mr. Marias, I must say that I am shaken by the situation in South Sudan, especially since child abductions occur on a daily basis. Children recruit, separate from their parents, their parents kill, women rape and those who manage to survive this situation unfortunately, due to lack of food and the appearance of diseases are threatened. That is why I am interested in what a fellow MEP thinks in view of this situation, is it enough to adopt resolutions or should the European Union do something concrete?

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), "blue card" answer. Mr President, the issue of South Sudan is very serious and we have discussed it. What we are doing at this stage is highlighting the issue and pushing for concrete measures. We cannot without concrete measures deal with this situation.  The first and most important thing is to go to the causes and causes of the exploitation of the resources of wealth in South Sudan. Who are those who gain from the state of civil war? When we look at this we can look at and take action against these causes in order to deal with all the other issues.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: – The act of kidnapping hundreds of children is inadmissible, no matter which end of the world we are talking about. Events in South Sudan are a grave fate for the local population. However, Europe must play an active role in the search for a way to address this and other similar challenges together with international organisations, because conflicts around the world are increasing every year and more minors are either suffering or being involved in them.  The situation in the country is particularly critical. Schools there are used for military purposes, and adolescents are taken and trained as soldiers. More than 400,000 children have stopped attending school in recent months because of the conflicts there, according to international organizations. That's nearly half a million kids becoming a risk group.  I firmly believe that the European Commission should help mobilise resources for the long-term reintegration of children who have been involved in conflicts, and this must be done in coordination with the UN Special Envoy for Children in Armed Conflict, UNICEF and other agencies.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, when we used to have an agenda item on the work of the UNHCR, then I talked about the problem of human rights violations, especially children. In South Sudan, we see best an example of the tragedy of child human rights violations and all that is happening, which is truly heinous.  I want to draw attention that today there are 12,000 children in the military, on the parties to the conflict and of course everything can only be detected by the fact that there are great interests in South Sudan, great interests because of the wealth of that country. I call on the Commission, knowing the great efforts made by the Commission, to continue, as the tragedy with children needs to be put to an end.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this is not the first time that we have found ourselves here, ladies and gentlemen, discussing a hapless country called South Sudan. As in other states, raw materials are more of a curse than a resource. Twelve thousand children have been transformed into an instrument of death by factions which, unfortunately, are also suffering from external interests in order to take control of South Sudanese oil.  We say forcefully that they must return to their homes and we must therefore help to rebuild the state's infrastructure, especially schools, and to carry out real reintegration projects into society. Those responsible for this crime must be brought to justice, as must those who speculate on this crisis, who profit from the proceeds of this country's blood-mixed oil, as Mr Marias said. It is time to adopt immediate sanctions on the basis of the UN resolution on the leaders of these factions and to strictly enforce the arms embargo. We want negotiations and this time they must be serious. The youngest state in the world must safeguard the future of its youngest citizens.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D).
text: "Mr. President, I know you are doing everything you can.  This is my intervention on the Islamic State. Trash!  This is the one about Sudan. Trash!  This is the one on land grabbing in Tanzania, for which I hope you will give me some time to speak. And I would like us to introduce a new card in this Parliament: it is the 'yellow card', with the aim of banning fake blue cards, such as the one we have seen here, which prevent people from being able to express themselves on the subject.  Colleagues who misuse the blue card should be punished first with a warning and then excluded - perhaps by a "red card" - from the right to request blue cards.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I think this is an important appeal. Thank you, Mr President. Indeed, sometimes we deal with such things. I am very sorry, Mr President.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, South Sudan has been at war with itself for 15 months. Every day that passes increases the risk of more intense conflict and worsens the already dreadful humanitarian and human rights situation of the long-suffering people of South Sudan. The recent abduction of a group of children in Wau Shilluk is yet another illustration of the complete disregard by all parties for international human rights law. The High Representative Vice-President has condemned them in the strongest possible words. Preventing and responding to violations against children affected by armed conflicts is a top priority for the European Union. We are working closely with Mrs Zerrougui, the UN Special Representative for children and armed conflict, and Unicef to end the use of children in combat. Our delegation in Juba is pressing both the government and opposition forces to release all children from the armed forces and to help them return to places of safety. The European Commission, through its humanitarian aid and civil protection department ECHO, provides funding to Unicef to support the reintegration of released child soldiers from the Cobra faction. Accountability for crimes committed in the course of the conflict is essential to ensure sustainable peace. The EU has called repeatedly for the publication of the African Union Commission of Inquiry report. This is an inquiry launched by the African Union itself and as such is an historic step to assume responsibility for the investigation of crimes perpetrated on the African continent. We look forward to hearing formally what recommendations the inquiry has to make. We believe that the human disaster wrought in South Sudan is the responsibility of its political and military leaders. They resorted to violence rather than debate. There are no alibis. Last week, the two principle protagonists in the civil war once again refused to make the mutual compromises required to reach an agreement that could pave the way for a comprehensive settlement of the conflict. In response, IGAD’s Chair, the Ethiopian Prime Minister, asked regional and international partners to work together to reinvigorate the peace process and agree a common approach. The EU stands ready to support IGAD in this endeavour. The EU Special Representative Alexander Rondos has already been active in supporting the IGAD-led negotiation process. The UN Security Council has also agreed a unanimous resolution creating a framework for sanctions against those who impede the peace process and persons who have committed war crimes. The EU agrees it is important to increase pressure on the parties without further delay. Let me conclude by stressing the following: it is essential that the warring parties in South Sudan put their own interests aside and instead reach a compromise in the interests of all citizens of South Sudan, the world’s youngest nation. The Union will continue to make every effort to support a swift political solution to the crisis, with a view to achieving a lasting peace.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate.  The vote will take place after the debate.  Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. – During the last 15 months of the civil war in South Sudan, approximately 1.4 million people have been displaced, 500 000 have fled to neighbouring countries, thousands more have been killed, raped and orphaned. More than four million people are currently at risk of malnutrition and famine. During a recent incident in South Sudan, 89 children were forcibly recruited as child soldiers while doing their exams. According to a UNICEF report, in the past year South Sudan recruited more than 12 000 child soldiers, most of them boys and aged between 11 and 17. The recruitment and use of child soldiers under the age of 15 constitutes a war crime. Children need to go to school and not to war! Regretfully, in times of armed conflict children are the ones that suffer the most. They suffer both physically and emotionally and they need psychological support, so that they can go back to school and have a normal life with their families. Therefore, I welcome this resolution, which concludes that recruitment and use of children in armed forces and groups is a crucial violation of national and international law and this has to end.

name: Tadeusz Zwiefka (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Three months after the resolution on Dr Medani was adopted, Sudan is once again the subject of lively debate in the European Parliament. Recent events require immediate intervention, as they primarily concern those to whom international law provides special protection. We are talking about children abducted from their home towns and forcibly cared into the army. According to UNICEF, up to 12-year-old boys can take an active part in fighting on both sides of the conflict. It is alarming that schools, which should be a place for learning and educating young generations, are being converted into recruitment points in Sudan. Children are the hope of every nation. Sudan, currently mired in chaos, could become a place with a stable political situation in the future. However, in order for this to happen, it cannot be allowed that those young people who will build a new order are now killed in a war in the name of the ideals of the older generation. I would like this resolution to be widely echoed and to turn the world's eyes to the sudan problem. The European Union, as a haven of human rights, should stand up for those who are unable to do so themselves. Let's be clear that a child's place should be at school with a pencil in hand, not in an army with a rifle thrown over his shoulder.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the debate on six motions for resolutions on Tanzania, in particular the issue of land expropriation (2015/2604(RSP)).

name: Heidi Hautala
text: author. – Mr President, this joint resolution is about our concern for an indigenous people in Tanzania – the Masai people. It appears that thousands of indigenous people have been evicted from land to which they have customary rights.  The European Parliament is, of course, an important actor here, because Tanzania is one of the development partner countries of the European Union.  It is necessary to ensure that the European Union and its Member States, with the help of its development aid, encourage and demand full transparency and good governance on land tenure issues. The issue is that a very powerful presidential administration is doing big land deals with foreign companies in secret. We should insist on open accessible land registers so that the public and developing partners also have the right to know what kind of deals are being made at the cost of human rights.

name: Catherine Bearder
text: author. – Mr President, attacking pastoralists’ right to roam on their own land is an issue that has come up time and time again. The Masai Mara Serengeti ecosystem supports the highest concentration of wildlife on earth. It is estimated that Masai territories provide habitats for 80% of East Africa’s wildlife. The Masai and other pastoralists see themselves as custodians of the land they inhabit and they play an essential role in conservation and environmental protection. They are ideally placed to be the eyes and ears to protect vulnerable species from poaching and other wildlife crimes.  Rather than being considered a threat to conservation, the Masai and other pastoralists must be included in plans to protect this fragile land on which they have co-existed peacefully and sustainably for millennia.  Tanzania must respect the numerous promises they have made to these people over the years. Pastoralists all over the world need protection from land encroachment and so the Commission and Member States must put pressure on the Tanzanian Government to make sure it brings forward legally binding laws to protect the rights of the Masai, not sell off their land to the highest bidder to create a playground for the rich and powerful.

name: Branislav Škripek
text: Author – I want to publicly condemn land seling in Tanzania. This unhealthy phenomenon allows the stronger to deprive the weaker of the possibility of subsual in the name of luxury. I believe that the future of every nation, but especially of the African continent, is small farmers. Those Tanzanian are already in a difficult situation because of the corruption and the environment that reigns in their country and the abuse of their illiteracy by many of them. If Europe wants to contribute to the development of Africa, it should be interested in ordinary people, whose one luxury safari will certainly not be plucked from misery and will be helped more by the opportunity to cultivate the land of its ancestors without fear of losing it overnight, and we should contribute to this, on the contrary, in order to somehow achieve that the owners themselves will understand that they are owners on this basis. that they can have proof of this and can claim their rights, their grandfather, the land of their ancestors. I don't think there's a better way.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Author. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, well, we have moved from the black gold rush to the land race: the land of the indigenous people, the land of the Maasai, as in the case of Tanzania, which we are dealing with. Only that the Maasai, unlike us, of our speculative ideas towards the land of others, have the idea that the earth is nobody's, that it is of the dead, of the living, and of those who have yet to be born. We, with regard to Tanzania and these people, act with the classic hypocritical attitude of those who condemn, as in this resolution – which we will clearly vote for and which I hope the whole Parliament will vote for – and then endorse increasing investment in biofuels in countries such as Tanzania, which will cause other indigenous peoples to be wiped out from their places of origin. So we have to be careful what we say, what we vote for and then what we actually do, because many of the companies that go to invest there – and the Gallagher report that was commissioned by the British Government shows that these are increasing investments, in 2020 we are talking about 31.5 million hectares of biofuel production – make our attitude very ambiguous. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. Mr. Corrao, I have listened carefully. I share your opinion and my question is very simple: do you agree with me that this is a premeditated crime against the People of the Masai and that the European Union should end all serious business relations with Tanzania in such a situation?

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: Answer to a blue card question. I fully agree with Mr Jakovčić that the way in which we endorse this speculation on Tanzanian territory is absolutely criminal. I would like us to think about what we would do if others came to European territory and kicked us out because they have to cultivate something that is useful to them for energy reasons... I fully agree that we should break off any relationship with the Tanzanian Government if we do not put an end to speculative attitudes such as this.

name: Maurice Ponga
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are discussing an important issue today: the issue of land grabbing, which particularly affects Tanzania.  Following a large-scale project in the United Arab Emirates in Serengeti province, more than 40,000 Maasai will be evicted from their lands in the coming weeks. Unfortunately, this situation is not isolated in Tanzania. Indeed, many projects threaten the traditional ways of life of pastoralist communities, especially the Maasai of Tanzania.  In our resolution, we strongly condemn the illegal displacement of rural communities and the destruction of their traditional way of life. We call on the Tanzanian authorities to respect the rights of indigenous peoples and to protect the rights of the Maasai, including their ancestral lands. We also call on the European Union to promote good land governance and to support the transparency of large-scale investments that have a land impact in Tanzania.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez
text: Author. – Mr President, land ownership by companies or investors is called acaparamento. Land-based land is a reality in the South, but also in Europe: Galicia, Romania, Ukraine and more countries.  There have been many of my interventions in this Parliament for the end of land use. I have also promoted activities to raise awareness about the impact on farmers and farmers, both in my country, in Galicia, and in the South, in Colombia. But today, unfortunately, I cannot support this resolution, because it does not refuse the acaparamento itself. Because making land transactions transparently remains acaparamento. Because there is transparency in the accountability of European Union companies, financial institutions and large-scale agro-industrial investments, these land acquisitions in Tanzania continue to be leveraged.

name: Josef Weidenholzer
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the The right to have his ancestral land and to be able to follow the traditional ways of life there is a natural right of the people. Rousseau has already pointed this out. It was often violated, at the time in the course of colonisation, now as a result of market opening and commodification originally public goods. In 1962, in the resolution on perpetual sovereignty over natural resources, the United Nations established the link between the degeneration of human rights. This is the context of Serengeti National Park. Private investors have acquired legal titles that will result in up to 80,000 people of the ancestral Massai population losing their natural livelihoods. When we demand respect for human rights worldwide, we should not allow us to criticise landgrabbing for what it is: a violation of human rights.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Population displacement, environmental migration are taking on a massive character in Tanzania. The majority of observed displacements affect members of the poorest and marginalised populations. Communities particularly burdened by the consequences of illegal displacement are those without formal land rights. The absence of these rights is often the reason for refusing resettlement compensation, which breaks human rights standards. Tanzania's weakness is that many pieces of legislation are missing. I condemn the unlawful displacement of the population, discrimination in the area of property rights and the violation of fundamental human rights linked to the illegal misappropriation of the land of the local community. There is concern about the lack of transparent information on the number of investments in Tanzania. I call on the Tanzanian authorities to support an agricultural policy that benefits the local population and to implement land ownership legislation to protect this community. I stress the importance of providing adequate compensation in accordance with the actual value of the land previously inhabited or used.

name: Kashetu Kyenge
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, restrictions on land ownership imposed on ethnic or national or gender grounds must be lifted on behalf of the Group of the Party of European People's Party (S&D). Everyone, men and women, has a right to the land. The land must be shared among those who live and work there. Thousands of Maasai have been violently driven from their homes and ancestral lands in Tanzania, without them being given fair compensation. All this to make room for a few rich tourists. It is not a local phenomenon, it is not an African affair: it is a fact that concerns us closely. We must demand more transparency from European companies operating in the agricultural sector in Africa or from the private sector, greater awareness in their codes of conduct. Because of this phenomenon, entire communities are expelled from the land, left without compensation or a source of income. Let us not forget that poverty is one of the main causes of conflicts.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – The recent eviction at gunpoint of thousands of Masai in Tanzania is a manifest violation of the universal human right to own property and an act that should be immediately stopped.   In the case of these pastoralist cultures, land, animals and people are a cohesive whole. This is a case where there could be a strong synergy between the interests of the Masai and those of conservation and tourism. Unfortunately we see, sometimes in the EU too, that indigenous people, time and again, are denied the principle of free, prior and informed consent when it comes to their future. Not only should we strongly condemn such acts, we should also make maximal use of all the tools the EU has at its disposal to prevent such measures before they take place, and especially the EU development financing, which should be fully linked to respect for human rights and cultural and environmental preservation principles.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Land expropriation is a serious problem in many African countries, including Tanzania. It is primarily about losing the right of the local community to land, water and other natural resources. In recent years, there has been a new wave of large-scale land takeovers, due to increasing global demand for raw materials, agricultural products, biofuels and tourism. However, the takeover does not guarantee development, for example most of the investments in biofuels between 2003 and 2008, for which 640 hectares have been allocated, have collapsed.  In Tanzania, 75% of the population are farmers, but only 10% of them have formal certificates of ownership of the land they cultivate. Widespread corruption and abuse of power by politicians and government officials leads to the appropriation of land cultivated by local people and their transfer into the hands of foreign investors, and deprived of access to natural resources, residents are forced to migrate in search of food and water. The Tanzanian Government should support investments that benefit the local community, and we, as the European Union, should pursue a policy of dialogue, trade and monitoring of European companies' operations in this part of the world.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – I would also like to support this resolution. Of course, I consider the development of agriculture in Tanzania to be key.  In any case, the expelment of the Masai must be condemned, and I would also like to point out that only 10% of the population in Tanzania has a specific document proving their ownership of the land. This is, of course, a problem, because then investors who want to get to the land have a relatively facilitated situation.  I would also like to draw attention to another key point, and that is the issue of education. I think that we should support the Tanzanian Government and call on it to strengthen the education of its people in the field of agriculture, because according to the latest figures published in the journal Foreign Affairs in February 2015, only 2% of African undergraduates are educated in agriculture. I think that's one of those reasons. (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the Blue Card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Blue card question. I wanted to ask Mr Polčák whether he agrees that we should sanction and prevent European companies from going to Tanzania to exploit the territory and thus drive out populations, such as the Maasai, in order to make speculative investments in that territory. What does he think.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. - Thank you for the question. I'm hardly going to order or order the Tanzanian government to impose sanctions from my position. Whether similar sanctions should be introduced at EU level for businesses behaving in this way in Tanzania, I cannot imagine this without knowing the specific problem. I have not considered this problem in this way.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D).
text: Mr President, it is estimated that it was in the 15th century that the Maasai emigrating from South Sudan settled in the wild plains of Kenya and Tanzania. Many of these plains have since become safari parks for tourists, threatening the natural riches of the land and the tranquillity of this people of hunter-breeders. Today, more than ever, it is the greed and greed of the government and hunting companies that threaten the maasai ancestral lands. Since 2009, burned houses, land grabbing and violence have been part of the daily life of this tribe. In February 2014, the authorities ordered the Serengeti National Guardsmen to forcibly evict the population. As a result, in three days, 114 Maasai homes were reduced to ashes and 2,000 to 3,000 homeless.  But violence against these ancestral peoples is not Tanzania's only problem. Between poverty, unemployment, corruption, inequality and discrimination, the choice is great. It is therefore time to bang our fists on the table to denounce this violence and defend the inalienable right of peoples to self-determination. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: "blue card" question. Mr Tarabella, I would like to ask you about the situation of the Maasai population: would it not be more important for the European Union to help the Government of Tanzania to create a more efficient land registry service and to establish the necessary papers for this population?

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: "blue card" answer. It is clear that we can always export our best practices.  As far as the land registry is concerned, we owe it to Napoleon, whose two-hundredth anniversary of the defeat we will celebrate. I know it makes a lot of noise, because in Belgium we have published a commemorative coin - that is history. Our French friends do not like this, but one of the merits of Napoleon is to have, in particular, introduced the land registry as well as the Civil Code.  It is true that we could export these practices in order to strike a judicious balance between, on the one hand, the rights of peoples to have territories and not be driven out of them, as well as to be able to make a living from their economy and activities on these lands, and, on the other hand, other activities which are surely very interesting, such as the export of natural resources.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, land grabbing in Africa is on the agenda. Various large companies and so-called investors are by force acquiring vast tracts of land because they want to use it either for agricultural cultivation or for biofuels. What is happening, in this particular case, is that companies from the United Arab Emirates have succeeded in acquiring specific areas and the illegal expulsion of the Masai from their territory has now begun.  They're supposed to be told they don't have documents proving ownership. But their ownership of the land results from the use, it arises from cultivation for at least five centuries. Therefore, they acquired rights. Property rights are also protected by the Human Rights Treaties. They must also be protected as a minority. Measures are needed to protect them!

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: "Mr. President, this tragedy of the Masai people reminds me of those tragedies otherwise experienced by my Istrians. Namely, the seizure of land in the last century was many everywhere because of the totalitarian regimes that they were, and it was my region that suffered enormously because of it. And people lost their land. Here, today, in this century, it's truly amazing that these things happen without us taking any sanctions and no action. I sympathize with what is happening because this way of kidnapping the country is really scandalous and I am trying to make it clear that Europe, the European Union, needs to react, especially if it has knowledge that European companies are involved.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, commissioner, who are they and what are European companies doing in Tanzania? That is the question we should ask ourselves. Do you think it can still be tolerable that in the third millennium local communities, in this case the Maasai, should see their lands expropriated with acts of incredible violence and without any respect for their ancestral rights? Lands that have always been destined for funeral rites, for the community, to give space to business companies that speculate to build tourist resorts and allow big hunting, this ignoble and cowardly trastullo for western European and Arab rich people? With this resolution we want to give a voice to more than two million citizens of the world who have signed this appeal. With this speech I ask you to help develop a model of sustainable agriculture, to restore hope to those who have seen the rights of the living and the pity of the dead of the people offended. It is time to penalise those who contribute to this perverse mechanism.  Tanzania cannot and must not be either the land side or the playground of the West, we are with the Maasai.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I wanted to say that I do not know whether I am in Parliament or in a bar, because it seems to be in the bar here, instead of talking about important things. Look, watch the show! I mean, what are we going to talk about, the cappuccino, the coffee? Are we talking about the brioches?  I wanted to talk about the issue of the Maasai: since the issue of the Maasai is important, I see so much hypocrisy. But before we think about the Maasai, do we want to think first of the Europeans, of our people, of our security against terrorism, of what is happening, for example, in Libya, about which too little has been said? Do we want to talk about the concrete things of our people, our people, or do we always think only of others and forget instead of our young people, our elderly, the people who cannot move forward? These are the things that this Parliament should be discussing: look at the show here, look how beautiful! Why do we not also have a good party, throw a few firecrackers, pull confetti: this is the European Parliament?

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the debate today on the challenges associated with land rights in Tanzania is yet another testimony of the attention that Parliament has devoted to this matter for years and for which I thank you. This complex topic rightfully deserves our attention as it touches on issues that the European Union takes a keen interest in: human rights, rule of law and governance, and healthy and transparent business environment.  The phenomenon termed ‘land grabbing’ has different manifestations. Reports involving foreign investors or those threatening the livelihood of pastoralist communities have caused concerns. I refer to the most recent shocking case in Loliondo, Serengeti area, where park rangers and security forces burned the homes of Masai villagers, which affected 3 000 people. This was the latest episode in a longstanding conflict where the government’s authority to manage land use collides with the exercise of the pastoralist communities acquired customary rights.  The EU delegation and Member Statesʼ missions in Tanzania have consulted with the representatives of the pastoralist communities and they await the outcome of the investigation launched by district authorities. Land disputes are usually the result of complex and contrasting interests, weak legislation and administration, and poor dispute settlement mechanisms lead to conflicts that occasionally erupt with serious violations of human rights.  Tanzania has made commitments to improve land governance by signing up to the land transparency initiative launched by the G8 or by participating in the multilateral Open Government Partnership. We support these efforts and advocate for efficient and corruption—free land administration and law enforcement.  As we celebrated Women’s Day last Sunday, let me conclude by mentioning a special form of land grabbing that is often overlooked. Women in Africa are often denied ownership of land and lose it if their husband dies. In Tanzania, the EU supports a project promoting women’s ownership of land in densely populated areas. This contributes to a more equitable use of land and a more balanced growth, and ultimately to women’s empowerment.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate.  The vote will take place after the debate. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We welcome the call on the rights of indigenous women in Tanzania and denounce cases of land grabbing. It also appeals to the coherence of development cooperation policies, as well as the responsibility and role of the EU and European companies in land grabbing actions. It also stresses the importance of transparency and accountability and emphasizes the problem of food insecurity due to increased biofuels. However, we find the Resolution somewhat vague in not looking at fundamental points such as food sovereignty, the problem of corruption, the right to decide, the problem of the privatization of common goods such as water and other resources resources.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI).
text: Mr President, a motion of order, please, on Appendix XI, Article 5. We would like to know whether MEPs will be informed of Mr Schulz's referral of the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) concerning his only accredited assistant, Herbert Hansen, who is based in the Aachen region and is the head of the SPD's travel agency. Of course, this is a situation that may create - or, in any case, may be suspicious - of a conflict of interest.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you for pointing it out. Ladies and gentlemen! Before we proceed to the vote, I have one more announcement: the President has decided to remove Mr Buonanno's entitlement to daily allowance for seven days as a sanction for disrupting the normal course of the sitting by making insulting and provocative statements.  (Applause) This decision was announced to him today. Pursuant to Rule 167 of the Rules of Procedure, Mr Buonanno may lodge an internal complaint against this decision with the Bureau within two weeks.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item is voting time.

name: Charles Tannock (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the ECR Group is formally requesting a roll call vote on paragraph 20 – both parts of the split – and on recital N.

name: President. –
text: Unfortunately this request has been presented after the deadline and not all political groups are in agreement with that request so I cannot allow it.

name: Charles Tannock (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the ECR Group would like to have an oral amendment to paragraph 36, to become a new paragraph 36a. It is the paragraph concerning the discrimination and persecution of Christians and other religious minorities. We would like to add the words ‘and ethnic’ to it. I understand it will have broader support across the House if we add those two words so it reads ‘and ethnic minority groups’.

name: Arnaud Danjean (PPE).
text: Mr President, with the rapporteur's agreement, I would like to add an oral amendment to paragraph 47, with a view to giving the right name to the terrorist groups mentioned in Africa and, in particular, to replace the mention of the Mujao terrorist group with the Al-Mourabitoune group. This would give the following amendment in the English version, after "Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb": 'Al-Mourabitoun born from the fusion of' the... MUJAO 'and Mokhtar Belmokhtar's Masked Men Brigade'.  For the record, this terrorist group claimed responsibility for last week's Bamako attack, in which a Belgian citizen and a French citizen were murdered.

name: Elmar Brok (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very I would suggest that you accept this amendment as an addition to the previous text. Applicants agree.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the In the second part in the German translation, the word "legal" does not take place at all. In other words, we are voting in the German translation on something that does not exist. I would ask the translation services to add to this.

name: Silvia Costa (S&D).
text: – Mr President, on behalf of the S&D Group and in agreement with the rapporteur and with other colleagues, in particular, of the Committee on Culture and Education, I present this oral amendment to follow paragraph 210: ʽReiterates that in the framework of the universality of human rights and on the basis of UNESCO Conventions, cultural diversity and cultural heritage are the world’s heritage and that the international community has the duty to cooperate in their protection and valorisation; considers that intentional forms of destructions of cultural and artistic heritage, as it is currently occurring in Iraq and in Syria, should be persecuted as war crimes and as crimes against humanityʼ. I hope this amendment will be supported. (Applause)

name: Charles Tannock (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I think there is a linguistic issue here. It is not ‘persecuted’. I think Ms Costa means ‘prosecuted’. You do not persecute a war crime.

name: Victor Boștinaru (S&D).
text: – Mr President, for Amendment 4, I wish to put forward the following amendment: ‘Calls on the authorities of EU and LAS member states to respect the prohibition of torture as it is most notably enshrined in the UN Convention against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment, which most of them have signed and ratified; reiterates that forced confessions under torture are not valid’.

name: Victor Boștinaru (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I also wish to move the following oral amendment: ‘Calls on the Council to verify whether there have been breaches of the EU Code of Conduct on Arms Exports in relation to repression’.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE).
text: – Mr President, thank you for the opportunity of explaining my support for the Semester. I think it is crucially important if we are to really deal with the problems of poverty and inequality in Europe that we create a pro-jobs, enterprising Europe where countries are encouraged to create jobs and where the right environment is there. That is the best way to tackle poverty.
