The case in Ireland recently where in excess of 90 000 net new jobs have been created over a three-year period is an example of how the restructuring of our economy has helped to create more jobs, reducing unemployment from 15% to 10%. This year alone in Ireland in excess of 40 000 net new jobs will be created. So here is an example of a country that can restructure itself based on the recommendations that were there within the Semester and create real job opportunities for people. Finally, can I say this. Another reason why I voted in favour of the Semester is that we need the same set of rules for every country within the eurozone and for every country within the European Union. We cannot have one rule for big countries and another rule for small countries. That is why it is important that we stick to these rules... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I too supported this report because it makes a strong call for the European Union to shift its policies towards growth-led policies which focus on creation of quality jobs. It also highlights a number of key points such as the need to have refocusing of policies to achieve the 2020 targets, the fight against inequality, the need to move away from jobless growth, combating youth unemployment, giving SMEs adequate tools to operate voluntary mobility, and shifting taxation from labour to capital. This report mentions introduction of a minimum income scheme throughout the EU and stresses that the employment and social considerations in the European Semester should be put on a par with macroeconomic ones. I believe that the employment and social aspects of the European Semester and Annual Growth Survey are fundamental in order to put Europe back on its track.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE).
text: – I support the report because, above all, it emphasises the benefits of the green economy and the need for ecological transformation, because it is the development of the green economy that can help us to use resources more efficiently and ensure sustainable development and create 5 million jobs by 2020. Jobs. Secondly, the report calls for the reduction of the minimum wage gap in different countries and for a conference on the European minimum wage system. The harmonisation of the minimum wage would help to address competition and emigration problems. Thirdly, the text calls on the Member States to ensure that self-employed persons enjoy fundamental rights and adequate social protection. The implementation of this provision would help people to reconcile work and family life, allow people on paternity or maternity leave to enter the labour market and not lose their qualifications.

name: Morten Messerschmidt (ECR).
text: Mr President! It sounds very good that you want to create jobs and include social aspects in your policy. But fundamentally, this report contains a number of areas in which member states must transfer new sovereignty, including – and I would say, most seriously – in terms of wage policy. It is directly worded. You have to have what is called the European Framework for minimum wages. I don't think a lot of people want that. For example, in Denmark, we have a model where it is the social partners and the worker and employer who negotiate wages. This is not something we need legislation on, let alone eu legislation. May I not ask the institutions here to keep their fingers far, far away in this area! That is why I voted against this report.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI).
text: Mr President, this House yesterday voted on a new report masterpiece. The establishment of centralised governance of the single market is once again presented as the miraculous remedy to the ills of our Europe which would allow for sustained growth and job creation with certainty.  But how can you give any credit to your solutions when all your smoky theories are based on the study of a totally unbalanced and especially not objective report that is that of the cost of non-Europe? How do you want the peoples of Europe to continue to follow you, an elite disconnected from reality and, above all, often at odds with the views expressed by our fellow citizens? The real finding of your policies is this: 11.4% unemployment in the euro area, zero economic growth and the social, moral and political decay of our civilization. This report aims to put Member States under guardianship, and to require them to report regularly and to implement the Commission's binding recommendations. That is why we voted against this report.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of this report as I believe the single market is one of the most powerful engines at EU level, and its potential needs to be fully exploited to boost growth, competitiveness and creation of new jobs. The report fully reflects this. This report sends a strong message to the Commission and the Member States, and calls for improvement of single market governance to promote and facilitate growth and jobs, but also serves as the benchmark for commitment to structural reform in the Member States. In my region, the West Midlands, the report identifies a number of key sectors: SMEs, public procurement, digital single market, free movement of goods, better consumer protection and tools for single market integration. I really applaud the recommendations as to how to improve these in order to unlock the potential of the single market. That could generate billions of euro in additional revenue.

name: Morten Messerschmidt (ECR).
text: Mr President! What I am particularly concerned about in this report is that it is stressed that the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality must, of course, be respected. Or is it so natural? Because I believe that for years there has been a violation of both the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. That is why it is good that the Commission is now placing more emphasis on also consulting the national parliaments, which have actually been given the power in the Lisbon Treaty to check whether the rules have been complied with. This is not happening at all today, and that is why we have seen EU legislation interfere in all sorts of details – I would say ridiculous details at times – which should be left to the Member States themselves to regulate. It is time for us to go the other way so that the Member States can take back sovereignty, and this can be done, among other things, by spending much more powder on focusing on the principle of subsidiarity. So I welcome, if not all parts of this report, then at least the passages that go in that direction.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I am pleased that Parliament voted on this resolution on the fight against child sexual abuse on the Internet, because it is critical that we act efficiently and decisively to eradicate this horrible practice that ruins the lives of millions of children worldwide every year. In the UK, it is estimated that a staggering 1 in 58 children will suffer contact sexual abuse before turning 18, with approximately 10 000 new child victims being reported each year. As Internet availability grows worldwide, online child abuse is increasing at an alarming rate. Online child sex offenders commit their atrocities and offences across borders; therefore we cannot let borders stop us from stopping them. The EU directive on combating this is crucial. Harmonising criminal offences in this field is also critical, and we must ensure that we have common minimum sanctions.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: – Violence against children in cyberspace is not only increasing, but is also gaining intensity and cruelty and is beginning to outsmil us. In Europe, globally, we do not know, I think, to cope well with it. Our youngest and most vulnerable cannot resist sophisticated attacks of cyberbullying and cybergrouping. It's a responsibility to us adults. I therefore welcome the efforts to work more closely with all stakeholders, the European institutions, the police, state bodies, non-profit organisations, schools, educators, etc. However, the key role of parents, who have a major responsibility in raising and protecting children, should be emphasised; for this reason, I stress the need to inform them and to educate them in this area as well. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by For many years, both the European Commission and the European Parliament have been taking a number of initiatives to combat the online sexual exploitation of children. These activities are mainly aimed at educating and raising public awareness of how to use the internet safely and how to protect our children from the dangers but also irresponsible behaviour on their part.  Statistics from recent years show that this problem is on the rise. This shows very clearly that we must first take preventive action. Only by making children aware of the consequences of their actions and identifying the dangers waiting in the global network can we reduce this phenomenon. For this to happen, parents, carers and teachers need to be involved. Fortunately, over the years, there has been some progress in this area, which has certainly been helped by the Safe Internet Day, which has been celebrated for several years. Therefore, I would like to thank all the people and entities involved in the organization of this year's edition.  Finally, I wanted to express my outrage that almost half of the Member States have not implemented a directive on combating the sexual exploitation of children online. This just shows how neglected this problem is in Europe.

name: Luigi Morgano (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted with conviction in favour of the resolution on online child sexual abuse. The horrific images of child abuse circulating on the Internet, run by unscrupulous criminals, constitute serious violations of fundamental rights, enshrined in the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. The data provided by NGOs on internet pages containing child abuse material is appalling: 80 % of the victims are under the age of 10. Unfortunately, the measures taken so far by the Member States for prevention have not always been effective. In order to combat the lure of children into the digital world, it is necessary to ensure that any illegal content is promptly removed and reported to law enforcement authorities, but appropriate legal instruments must be provided to investigate and prosecute offenders. The international scale of the phenomenon therefore requires a coordinated and comprehensive European approach that starts from greater education and awareness of the potential risks of the network and from measures that commit the social media sector to take its share of responsibility.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: – I supported the joint resolution on online child sexual abuse because I believe that the increasingly digitised world in which we live does not provide sufficient protection for adolescents from the dangers that exist online. It is undeniable that children are starting to use the internet earlier and this obliges us to give the guarantees that they will not feel uncomfortable there, and that they will be in a safe and secure environment. We can only achieve this with partnership and collaboration between institutions, NGOs, the media and business representatives. We need to support educational and explanatory initiatives, both in front of minors and in front of their parents, custodians and teachers.  I call on the Commission and the governments of the Member States to engage with representatives of alternative payment systems for more effective cooperation with law enforcement authorities in order to better identify payment processes related to the commercial distribution of child abuse material.

name: Csaba Sógor
text: (PPE). – Mr President, the world of the Internet has undergone a major transformation as social media has advanced, and we have a duty to keep up with changes on the regulatory side with a view to preventing serious crime. I find it scandalous that directive 2011/90/EU on measures to combat the sexual exploitation of children has only been fully transposed into its legal order by less than half of the Member States more than a year after the transposition deadline. We are irresponsible if we do not do everything we can to deal with this issue according to the weight of the Member States. We may not be able to fully understand the complexity of the dangers. The aim is clear: to act effectively with the existing rules, by improving technical possibilities, but also by further modernising the rules, to counter the unfortunately increasingly widespread phenomenon.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki (ECR).
text: – I thank the President for his human and liberal approach to the matter, thank you for the opportunity to speak. I would say in this way that with the internet it is just like with a knife: a knife can cut bread, which is used for food, and it can also kill. I voted the way I voted because I believe that it is necessary, however, to show the wrong side of the internet that it is being used to do evil, often evil, which can no longer be reversed. Especially children should be under special protection. I think there are issues in this Parliament that bring together – maybe there are not so many of them – but this issue should certainly unite. Changes are necessary: we must move towards greater, wise restrictions, of course, not to pour a child with a bath and to suppress freedom on the internet, but on this matter we should act very decisively.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, honourable colleagues, i would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. Today I voted against the resolution and would like to explain why. What was the original purpose of this resolution in principle? I think to express my negative attitude to the brutal murder of Boris Taketov, to express sympathy for his loved ones, to ask the Russian authorities to find and punish the murderers.  But as a result, does this text look like this? It was accompanied by a number of other issues, the title and content added to a wide range of topics about the state of democracy in Russia. The resolution dedicated to The Death of Taketkov included additional questions about the Estonian police officer, about Russian politician Navaly and his brother Oleg, on Ukrainian pilot Nadezhda Shavchenko, on the annexation of Crimea, on Russia's information war against its neighbours and on the polish plane disaster, and on many other issues. Dear colleagues, In my opinion, it is not a good practice to start talking about one subject, then to replace it practically with another. I therefore call for the original idea of the resolution to be held up in the future, rather than radically changing it during the consultation. Thank you!

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: – I have a slightly different opinion than my colleague. I strongly condemn the murder of the opposition politician Boris Nemtsov, I believe that the case will be investigated, the real culprits, the perpetrators will be punished. I would like to express my deepest condolences to the family of the murdered and I extend my prayers. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution because I am concerned about president Putin's statements in which he has pledged to personally oversee the investigation. The most senior constitutional official, in my opinion, should, instead of intervening, create the space for an independent investigation. Unfortunately, this case, together with other unsolved murders of journalists and opposition politicians of the past, do not portray Russia positively from the point of view of democracy. The resolution also touches on the inability of Russian investigators to end the case of a Polish plane crash on Russian territory five years ago. It outrages me that the plane has not yet been put in Polish hands. I really find the constant obstruction of the Russian authorities to restore the black boxes to be outrageous.

name: Tatjana Ždanoka (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I voted against this resolution. The murder of Boris Nemtsov is a very tragic event. The first thing to analyse in such a crime is to pose the question of who benefits from it. Certainly not the President of Russia. Anti—Putin hysteria has inflated around this event, and clearly one of the elements of the resolution proves this statement. Therefore, there are clear elements of provocation in this murder. Who has profited from this situation apart from those who ordered Nemtsov’s killing? Certainly those who, while being superficially familiar with Boris, are making cheap self-advertising around his murder when not being allowed to cross the Russian border for the funeral. As regards the state of democracy in Russia, people say that Boris Nemtsov was killed in the aftermath of an opposition rally, but nobody mentions that on the very same day he was inviting people to this rally through the very influential source of mass information financed by the state—owned company Gazprom – Radio Ekho Moskvy, so ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Peter Jahr (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I was pleased that the European Parliament has spoken on this issue and I voted in favour of it. I believe that bad things are also happening in democratic societies, and the question is really only how to carry out the enlightenment. In Russia, there seems to be a script: politically motivated murders happen, and then an offender is quickly identified, but the actual background is not clarified. That is really the difference that I would like to make clear here, the difference with democratic societies. I do believe that Russia should not only enlighten here, but also ensure transparency. Transparency, by the way, is a sign of developed, democratic societies, and that is where Russia has a huge amount of catching up to do. That is why it was right and important for the European Parliament to give its opinion on this.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the murder of Boris Nemtsov is a tragedy which must not be exploited under any circumstances. However, this belligerent and excessive text serves as a pretext for an attack in good standing against Russia. The text insidiously accuses the Russian government on the grounds that the murder took place in a protected area. This same suspicion extends to the plane crash in Smolensk in April 2010, which cost the Polish president his life. Russian politics as a whole is therefore in the spotlight. Despite Mr. Putin's undeniable popular support in his country, we are being led to believe that Russian society is stifling under an infamous domination. Look for the error! Finally, the proposal to initiate an international investigation is absolutely inadmissible and would constitute a denial of Russian sovereignty. After Russia, why not China? There are fewer volunteers. In contrast to this arrogant stance, the European Union would benefit from building a respectful and lasting relationship with a great continental power.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, cosúil le Feisirí eile chuir marú cheannaire an fhreasúra, Boris Nemtsov, déistin ormsa agus chuir a lán daoine an cheist: conas go bhféadfadh a leithéid tarlú chomh gairid leis an gCreimil. Bhí amhras agus imní ar dhaoine faoi sin.  Freisin, caithfidh mé a rá gur chuir sé déistin agus díomá orm nár ligeadh dár gcomhghleacaí agus mo chara, Sandra Kalniete, freastal ar an tsochraid. Coimeádadh í ag an aerfort, tógadh a doiciméid uaithi agus bhí uirthi fanacht ansin ar feadh mórán uaire gan a fhios aici cad a bhí ag tarlú. Ní maith an scéal é sin agus taispeánann sé nach bhfuil mórán measa ag Putin ar an daonlathas nó ar an Aontas Eorpach ach go háirithe.  Rud amháin nach bhfuil mé ró-shásta faoi inniu ná nach raibh vótáil le glao rolla againn ag an deireadh; bhí vóta ginearálta againn. Bheadh sé níos fearr dá mbeadh a fhios againn cé mhéad Feisire a bhí i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo. Bheadh sé níos fearr mar theachtaireacht do Putin dá mbeadh an figiúr ceart againn. Ach taobh amuigh de sin, vótáil mé le mo ghrúpa ins na vótaí go léir.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. "U2012 Following statements by the Union's VP/AR for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the assassination of Russian opposition leader Boris Nemtsov and the state of democracy in Russia, the European Parliament calls for a resolution to clarify the circumstances of the death of opposition politician Boris Nemtsov, investigate his brutal murder and bring the culprits to justice quickly. The European institutions, the European Parliament of course, and the European governments have condemned this crime and insisted that there be a diligent investigation.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because it continues in line with Parliament's views of the candidate countries, in which a colonial relationship between a rich and powerful centre is reproduced in the face of an impoverished and obedient periphery. In this case, a positive vote is equivalent to the endorsement of the Atlantic Alliance's policy in the Balkans, imposed through illegal wars in order to divide the peoples of the former Yugoslavia and reposition the United States in Europe. The Resolution was an appeal to the authorities of the self-proclaimed Republic of Kosovo to consolidate the state attributes that have been being equipped in recent years, which is why I voted against it.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. I welcome the call for an international investigation into the assassination of Russian opposition leader Boris Nemtsov. It is right to call for the investigation of a murder that took place in a climate of intimidation and harassment. The EU's continued commitment to democratic and fundamental values is commendable.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interests of democracy, I would like to make it clear that I abstained on the final vote – which was not a roll-call vote. I believe that the public have the right to know how I voted on this resolution. I did, however, support many of the amendments.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, which aims to call for an independent international investigation into the murder of Mr Nemtsov. I agree that the instruments at the disposal of the OSCE, the Council of Europe and the United Nations will help to ensure an impartial and fair investigation. The EU needs a unified and coherent policy towards Russia, requiring the 28 EU Member States and the EU institutions to take a strong common position on the role of human rights in eu-Russia relations and on the need to put an end to the suppression of freedoms of expression, assembly and association in Russia. I agree that the Council of the EU should develop a common policy towards Russia and allocate more funds to the civil society of Russia and occupied Crimea. The Russian authorities must put an end to any political and judicial pressure on opposition leaders, representatives of civil society and independent media.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this ignominious resolution that ignores the Russian judicial process. Once again, Russia is responsible for all evils, especially the "climate of hatred and tension in Europe". When will the Eurocrats stop systematically throwing oil on the fire?

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. After the assassination of opposition leader Boris Nemsov and the deteriorating state of democracy in Russia, the European Parliament had to condemn the assassination and show solidarity with Russian political opponents. It was also essential to remind the Russian Federation of its obligations regarding democracy, the rule of law and human rights in accordance with the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, of which it is a signatory. Finally, it is essential that the European Union and its Member States adopt a firm common position in the face of current events, both in Russia and In Ukraine.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. This Resolution pays tribute to the Russian opposition politician, founder and leader of the Solidarnost Boris Nemtsov political movement. All this at a time when the climate of hatred against the opposition, human rights defenders and minorities is increasing alarmingly and is encouraged by the Russian authorities themselves. Through this text, the European Parliament calls for an independent international investigation into the murder, while calling on the Council and other EU institutions to make a firm commitment to the defence of freedoms in Russia and urges the High Representative to prepare a programme to support civil society in Russia and Crimea. For all of the above, I can only support this Resolution.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. The assassination of Russian opposition leader Boris Nemtsov is a tragedy and we all agree. Nevertheless, we must be careful not to exploit this assassination. Unfortunately, this text is used to attack the Russian government and President Putin (though praised by his people) and indirectly accuses him of murder.  On the other hand, the proposal to launch an international investigation constitutes a denial of Russian sovereignty. Rather, the European Union should forge lasting ties with Russia so as not to systematically align itself with US policy. So I voted against this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report is unbalanced and I support it and for these reasons I did not intend to vote in favour of it.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. "U2012 Following statements by the Union's VP/AR for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the assassination of Russian opposition leader Boris Nemtsov and the state of democracy in Russia, the European Parliament calls for a resolution to clarify the circumstances of the death of opposition politician Boris Nemtsov, investigate his brutal murder and bring the culprits to justice quickly. The European institutions, the European Parliament of course, and the European governments have condemned this crime and insisted that there be a diligent investigation.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because there is an increasing need for a unified, strong, coherent and comprehensive European Union policy towards Russia, supported by all Member States in providing assistance, expressing support and strong and reasonable criticism based on the universal values that both the EU and Russia have committed themselves to. The European Parliament has repeatedly expressed its concern about the democratic situation in Russia and the fact that it consistently respects the rule of law and does not respect fundamental rights. Russia also does not respect the rule of law, standards of fair trial, due process and independence of judicial authorities. The European Parliament pays tribute to Boris Nemtsov, the prominent leader of the opposition, the founder and leader of the Solidarity Political Movement, who has dedicated his life to a more democratic, prosperous, open Russia and russia's strong partnership with neighbouring countries and partners. Parliament expresses its deepest condolences to Boris Nemtsov's family and friends, opposition figures and the Russian people. Parliament condemns the decision of Russian leaders not to allow some EU diplomats and state delegations to attend his funeral, thus hindering the EU's attempt to pay tribute to brave Russian citizens fighting for universal values.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The murder of opposition leader Boris Nemtsov in Russia raises serious questions about respect for civil liberties. For years, members of the Russian opposition have risked their lives to stand up for democratic rights and the principle of freedom of expression. I am convinced that the 28 EU Member States need to develop a unified policy on Russia that sends the message that respect for human and minority rights plays an important role in the EU-Russia relationship. In Russia, the suppression of freedom of expression, assembly and association must end. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Boris Njemcov, a prominent reformist of Russia's post-Soviet society and economy, former deputy prime minister of the Russian Federation and one of the leaders of Russia's liberal opposition, was killed two days before a planned public outcry against the political, social and economic situation in the state and the conflict in Ukraine, of which he co-organised. In addition to my condolences to Mr. Germanov's family, I also express my deep concern at the series of attacks on opposition politicians, independent human rights organizations and civil society groups in Russia. I expect the Russian authorities to conduct a full, swift and transparent investigation into the murder and bring the perpetrators to justice swiftly.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. This resolution is a testament to the anti-Russian hysteria in the European Parliament. Without directly incurring Vladimir Putin's responsibility for the assassination of Boris Nemtsov, the motions for a resolution tend to make him indirectly guilty of all the alleged ills of Russian society and accuse him of creating a "climate of hatred and tension", which would be at the root of this criminal act. Even before the investigation into the circumstances of this murder began, such allegations were particularly misplaced and highlighted the Atlanticist Manichaeism of the European institutions.   I obviously voted against these motions for a resolution.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Boris Nemtsov was Deputy Prime Minister of the Russian Federation and a genuine politician of the opposition RPR-Parnas movement. His assassination in Late February in Moscow adds to the growing number of unsolved, politically motivated murders and suspicious deaths committed in Russia after 1998. The European Parliament has repeatedly expressed its concern about the state of democracy in Russia and the systematic failure of the authorities to respect the rule of law, democracy and human rights. Moreover, the conflict with Ukraine and the presence of Russian military forces on the territory of that state flagrantly violate international law and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.  I voted in favour of this resolution and I believe that the European Parliament is in the right to call on the Russian Federation to open an independent investigation in order to bring to justice those who are guilty of the murder of Boris Nemtsov. At the same time, I believe that the European Union must be much stronger in relation to Ukraine, so that this state can benefit at this difficult time from real political, economic and financial support from the EU, in the spirit of solidarity and the attempt to restore peace.

name: Cristian-Silviu Bușoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Boris Nemtsov was one of the leaders of the liberal and democratic opposition in Russia (founder of the Political Movement Solidarnost), a leading critic of the war in Ukraine, former Deputy Prime Minister of the Russian Federation, former governor of the Nizhni Novgorod region, a reformer of post-Soviet Russian society and economy. On February 27, 2015, he was killed near the Kremlin, in an area equipped with video cameras and patrolled by police and security forces, two days before his demonstration against the effects of the economic crisis and the conflict in Ukraine. I offer my sincere condolences to the family and close friends of Boris Nemtsov, members of the opposition and the Russian people. I support the council's development of a unified policy towards Russia, whereby the 28 Member States and the EU institutions agree to a strong common message on the role of human rights in the EU-Russia relationship, as well as on the need to end the repression of freedom of expression, assembly and association in Russia. At the same time, I believe that the objectives of the strategy developed by the EU must lead Russia to fully respect the OSCE principles and to motivate the leaders of that country in the sense of removing Russia from its political and economic self-isolation.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. "U2012 Following statements by the Union's VP/AR for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the assassination of Russian opposition leader Boris Nemtsov and the state of democracy in Russia, the European Parliament calls for a resolution to clarify the circumstances of the death of opposition politician Boris Nemtsov, investigate his brutal murder and bring the culprits to justice quickly. The European institutions, the European Parliament of course, and the European governments have condemned this crime and insisted that there be a diligent investigation.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution on the assassination of the Russian opposition leader, Boris Nemtsov, and on the state of democracy in Russia. The assassination of the Russian leader Boris Nemtsov is a crime with political implications that goes beyond the motives of the same sponsors. Although it seems that the murder is being investigated, many questions remain open and – with them – there remains concern about the difficult political and economic phase that the country is going through. This is a difficult situation to which the European Union cannot remain alien. In the immediate aftertay of Nemtsov's funeral, all the demands that were in the manifesto of the murdered political leader were reiterated: a more democratic system of access for all parties to the elections, efficient and clean justice, an end to propaganda and censorship, reform of the judicial system, cost reduction in the military, health and education sectors, and an end to the war against Ukraine.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the murder of Boris Nemtsov, which I condemn, must be the subject of credible investigations by Russia, which really guarantee a clear and impartial judgment. We must not restart a Cold War, so let us refrain from prejudices that could create an even darker atmosphere.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this ignominious resolution to Russia. Not content with having a real ideological prism regarding the Ukrainian conflict, the European parliamentarians in this resolution accuse Russia of all the evils that are currently afflicting Europe. Russia is thus identified as solely responsible for the "climate of hatred and tension in Europe", an authoritarian state with arbitrary political justice. A Manichaeism that should no longer surprise us on the part of an openly Atlanticist Parliament and which is gradually turning into a true party of war, accumulating outrageous attacks against the Russian Federation. "When a government prepares for war, it describes its adversaries as monsters."

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I express my full condemnation for the murder of the Russian opposition leader, Boris Nemcov. I believe that it is legitimate and in line with constitutional and legal principles to provide absolute clarity on this matter, and I have therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution because I share with it the strong condemnation of the assassination of Boris Nemcov, the leading leader of Russian politics, who was shot dead near the Kremlin two days before a demonstration against the effects of the economic crisis and the conflict in Ukraine, scheduled for 1 March 2015 and organised by him. I want to pay tribute to Boris Nemcov because he has dedicated his life to building a more democratic, prosperous and open Russia and to building strong partnerships between Russia and its neighbours. However, I do not feel like venturing into intellectual speculation before I have ascertained the facts.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. Over the past few years the human rights situation in Russia has been degrading and the Russian authorities have adopted a set of laws with ambiguous provisions used to impose more restrictions on opposition and civil society agents and limit freedom of expression and assembly. Since 1998 we have seen an increasing number of murders for political reasons and suspicious deaths in Russia, recently culminating in the assassination of Boris Nemtsov in the vicinity of the Kremlin two days before a demonstration he was organising and due to take place on 1 March 2015. In view of the worrying situation in Russia, I support the need for a firm, coherent and comprehensive EU policy towards Russia, endorsed by the 28 Member States, linking a strong common message on the role of human rights in EU/Russia relations and the need to end the repression of freedom of expression, assembly and association in Russia, as well as the immediate release of all political prisoners. I support the need for an independent international investigation into the murder of Boris Nemtsov.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the resolution on the murder of Boris Nemtsov. The murder of the Russian activist and political opponent, Boris Nemtsov, is something we can only condemn harshly. One of the democratic principles on which Europe is based is that it promotes political pluralism and the freedom to express one's thoughts. Voltaire's phrase "I disapprove of what you say, but I will defend to the death your right to say it" perfectly expresses the concept. That is why Nemtsov's death is intolerable and a serious attack on this principle.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against the text presented since, contrary to what might seem, it does not represent a condemnation of the violation of human rights, but a further step in the strategy of certain actors in the European Union, well coordinated with the Americans, to isolate Russia. The European Parliament does not usually worry about harassment of political leaders. In reality, this is only a problem when such events take place in countries where the EU is of particular interest. Because I am not going to play the game of majority matches and because in this particular case the authorship of crime is resolved, I have decided to vote against the Resolution.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The murder of Boris Nemcov, a leading opponent and reformist, killed in the vicinity of the Kremlin, in addition to the growing number of suspicious deaths and unsolved murders in Russia since 1998, including that of Anna Politkovskaya, is just another piece of a drift that deeply undermines relations between Russia and the European Union, digging a gap that is in danger of becoming unbridgeable. Banning some Members of the European Parliament from entering the Russian Federation, preventing them from taking part in funerals, increases the perception of the sense of precariousness and democratic uncertainty that reigns there. At the same time, the gradual decline in respect for human rights, the result of deliberate choices by the Russian authorities, which have taken measures to impose further restrictions on opposition and civil society, hindering freedom of expression and assembly, does not bode well for the future. The firm condemnation of the murder of Boris Nemcov is an opportunity to call on the Russian authorities to put an end to all repressive actions and intimidation of a political and judicial nature. Russia can become an important and strategic global player, provided, however, that this is done in accordance with international law and the commitments made within the framework of the OSCE.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ On 27 February 2015, Boris Nemtsov, former Deputy Prime Minister, the most prominent political figure of the liberal opposition and tireless advocate for a democratic, open and prosperous Russian Federation, was brutally murdered in Moscow. The killing came two days ahead of a public protest against the effects of the economic crisis and the conflict in Ukraine he was co-organising. The Russian authorities must conduct a full, rapid and transparent investigation into this assassination, bringing those responsible to justice. While acknowledging the recent arrests, several trials and judicial proceedings in the latest period, including the cases of Navalny, Magnitsky, Khodorkovsky and Politikovskaya, have cast doubt on the independence and impartiality of judicial bodies. The targeted and systematic attacks against political opposition figures, independent human rights organisations and civil society are a cause of grave concern for the international community at large. Russia, a full member of the Council of Europe and the Organization for Security and Co—operation in Europe (OSCE) and a signatory to the UN Declaration, must demonstrate with bold actions its willingness and resolution to adhere to the universal values and principles it has subscribed to, namely democracy, the rule of law and respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution strongly condemns the killing of Boris Nemtsov in what is being described as the most significant political assassination in recent Russian history. It also pays tribute to him as a prominent opposition leader, a founder and leader of the political movement Solidarnost and a leading critic of President Vladimir Putin and of the war in Ukraine, who committed his life to a more democratic, prosperous, open Russia and to strong partnerships between Russia and its neighbours and partners. The report also condemns the Russian leadership’s decision to prevent some EU diplomats and national delegations from attending his funeral. The resolution also points out that his killing is one of a growing number of unresolved politically motivated murders and suspicious deaths perpetrated in Russia since 1998, which include those of Anna Politkovskaya and Alexander Litvinenko. Thats why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This resolution strongly condemns the murder of Boris Nemtsov, a former Prime Minister, a leading figure in the Russian opposition and a staunch critic of the war in Ukraine. In addition to the growing number of unsolved political assassinations and suspicious deaths in Russia since 1998, an independent international investigation, conducted within the framework of the OSCE, the Council of Europe and the United Nations, must shed light on this murder. Concerned by the violent climate against opposition activists, human rights activists, minorities and neighbouring countries, which has worsened in Russia in recent years, I believe that the Council, the Commission and the Member States must put in place a unified policy with a strong common message on the importance of human rights in eu-Russia relations and on the need to put an end to repression of freedom of expression, assembly and association in Russia. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. The murder of Boris Nemtsov is a tragedy, and should not be exploited. However, this belligerent and excessive text serves as a pretext for an attack in good standing against Russia.  The text insidiously accuses the Russian government on the grounds that the murder site was in a protected area. This same suspicion extends to the plane crash in Smolensk in April 2010, which cost the Polish president his life. Russian politics as a whole is in the spotlight. Despite Vladimir Putin's undeniable popular support in his country, we are being led to believe that Russian society is stifling under an infamous domination. Finally, the proposal to initiate an international investigation is absolutely inadmissible and would constitute a denial of Russian sovereignty. In contrast to this arrogant stance, the European Union would benefit from building a respectful and lasting relationship with a great continental power.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the report because once again the European Parliament is promoting a completely subjective text, which has very serious inaccuracies and arbitrary conclusions. The only purpose it serves is to increase tension with Russia.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because I agree, in essence, with the content of the statement in its condemnation of the assassination of Boris Nemtsov, the opposition figurehead to Putin's government and former Deputy Prime Minister of Russia.  This is not a single case but an escalation of political assassinations since 1998, the EU can only be alarmed by the atmosphere of discrimination against political opponents, the squandered of fundamental values and the rule of law in Russia and the increasing deprivation of fundamental freedoms felt by the Russian people. It is therefore essential to take account of the economic, political and judicial crisis in russia's general situation and, as this declaration denounces this whole context, I have had my positive vote.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The murder of Russian opposition leader Boris Nemtsov is not yet fully understood, so an independent international investigation is urgently needed to determine what happened in this case. Boris Nemtsov was investigating Russia's involvement in the conflict in eastern Ukraine and was assassinated in the vicinity of the Kremlin two days before a demonstration he was organizing against the conflict. Five men have been arrested, but it remains unclear whether any of them were responsible for the deadly shootings. I pay tribute to Boris Nemtsov and regret the impediment of entry into Russia for some MEPs and diplomats, which prevented them from attending boris nemtsov's exquias. In defence of freedom and democracy, human rights and peace, it is essential that the Russian authorities put an end to all acts of pressure, repression and intimidation against opposition leaders, representatives of civil society and the media.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution seeks, on the pretext of an abominable act, a murder, which we condemn and whose causes are yet to be determined, to resume the position of the majority of the European Parliament on the conflict in Ukraine, unconditional support for the Kiev coup regime, in a process of illegitimate assault on power by the most reactionary forces of that country, and to establish the main axes of the EU's foreign policy with Russia , escalating in confrontation. Once again, the systematic and unacceptable position of interference in the relationship with third countries, in this case Russia, permeates the whole resolution. Attempts or interventions at national level to destabilise politically and align the targeted countries with the EU's strategic interests, including by using the creation and financing of NGOs, are also present. The resolution explicitly seeks to strengthen the policy of siege and provocation of the Russian Federation. We voted against it.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ The situation in Russia is tense due to the ongoing crisis not only in Russian-Ukrainian relations, but also in the EU-Russia relationship. The European Union has not been able to capture the growing tensions in the Ukrainian-Russian crisis in its beginnings, and we should therefore be careful today, but also consistent in assessing the situation in Russia. I would like to express my deep complicity with all mr Nemtsov's survivors, while at the same time expressing the belief that the Russian authorities will make every effort to clarify this murder as soon as possible, thus swept off the table any doubts about the organisation of murder by politicians.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the resolution as it is only used as a pretext for politically attacking Russia.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Once again the European Parliament is promoting a completely subjective text, which has very serious inaccuracies and arbitrary conclusions. The only purpose it serves is to increase tension with Russia. That is why I am voting against the motion for a resolution on the assassination of Russian opposition leader Boris Nemtsov and the state of democracy in Russia.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly condemn the killing of Boris Nemtsov, who was a prominent opposition leader, who committed his life to a more democratic, prosperous and open Russia and to stronger partnership between Russia and the rest of the world. This killing is one of the many unresolved politically—motivated murders and suspicious deaths perpetrated in Russia since 1988. I agree on the need for an independent international investigation into the murder and I support the call on the authorities of the Russian Federation to stop the shameful propaganda against its neighbours, and the repressive acts and intimidations against political opponents. I therefore voted in favour of this motion for resolution.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. The assassination of Boris Nemtsov, former Prime Minister of the Russian Federation, one of Russia's liberal and democratic opposition leaders, is highly worrying. Similarly, it is unclear whether any of the five men who have been arrested for his death were the perpetrator of the fatal shootings. The human rights situation in Russia has deteriorated in recent years and the Russian authorities have adopted a series of laws containing provisions that are used to impose greater restrictions on basic freedoms. From the European Parliament we must call for an independent international investigation into the murder, as well as the immediate release of all political prisoners.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. "U2012 Following statements by the Union's VP/AR for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the assassination of Russian opposition leader Boris Nemtsov and the state of democracy in Russia, the European Parliament calls for a resolution to clarify the circumstances of the death of opposition politician Boris Nemtsov, investigate his brutal murder and bring the culprits to justice quickly. The European institutions, the European Parliament of course, and the European governments have condemned this crime and insisted that there be a diligent investigation.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. "U2012 Following statements by the Union's VP/AR for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the assassination of Russian opposition leader Boris Nemtsov and the state of democracy in Russia, the European Parliament calls for a resolution to clarify the circumstances of the death of opposition politician Boris Nemtsov, investigate his brutal murder and bring the culprits to justice quickly. The European institutions, the European Parliament of course, and the European governments have condemned this crime and insisted that there be a diligent investigation.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. The killing of Russian opponent and political leader Boris Nemtsov leaves a further deep shadow over the state of democracy in Russia. Moscow is a decisive economic and political partner for the European Union, which is precisely why it is not possible to tolerate the progressive breakdown of political freedoms in the country.  I voted with conviction for the resolution on this case, which strongly expresses Parliament's support for the democratic forces in Russia in favour of an open society and a reformist agenda. Parliament rightly insists once again on calling on the Council to define a unified policy towards Russia, stressing the priority of human rights and the need for concrete gestures to put an end to the repression of freedom of expression, assembly and association.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution because we have the obligation to speak out on any incident in which people have to pay for their political beliefs or activities in defence of human rights with a price that is far too high: their life. We have reason to believe that there is a possibility this might have been the case for Boris Nemtsov. Therefore we demand an independent investigation into his murder that meets international standards. Through this resolution, we are reaching out to thousands of activists in Russia who face repression because they are standing up for what they believe in. At the same time, I find it regrettable that some Groups have been trying to use this resolution to address issues concerning Russia that go beyond the murder of Mr Nemtsov and the issue of repression against democratic activists. At all times it is to remain clear that we are reaching out to the Russian Government to restore relations based on respect for democratic values and the rule of law. But, once again, this will never stop us from speaking out. Boris Nemtsov may have been silenced by an assassin’s bullet, but we will not be silenced.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. The EU cannot ignore what is happening in Russia. And what happens there has increasingly worrying dyes. The killings of opponents and critics highlight the prevailing climate of ideological repression. It is therefore important to adopt a conviction resolution demanding a serious and impartial investigation into the murder of Boris Nemtsov. In it, we also call for an end to the smear campaign against democratic values, which are presented as alien to Russian culture, which is exalted through brazen nationalism.    It is clear that Russia is a major global player and that it is in our interest to maintain a strategic relationship with them. But we will hardly be able to reach a strong and trust-based relationship with a Lax country in respect for freedoms such as expression, manifestation and association, which we find fundamental, and in which a negative message is conveyed about the West.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The text presented underlines the position of rejection of any kind of amnesty for perpetrators of the takedown of flight MH17. The Minsk Agreements established that "forgiveness and amnesty will be granted, under a law prohibiting the persecution and punishment of those related to the events that took place, in particular in the Donetsk and Lugansk regions of Ukraine". This raised concerns about the Dutch government, as 196 Dutch civilians were killed on a commercial flight over Donetsk.  However, the Kiev government has already ensured that an amnesty will not be granted, so the amendment rains on wet conditions in this area. In any case, we understand that there is a lack of direct connection between the two cases, and that the text should have been devoted monographically to the case of the murder of opposition leader Nemtsov, so we voted against his approval.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The European Parliament resolution on the assassination of Russian opposition leader Boris Nemtsov and the state of democracy in Russia is the first such clear signal from the European Union that it does not condone the policies of Russian President Vladimir Putin. Until now, the Union has not been able to take effective action against a man who, in the eyes of the whole world, is breaking the fundamental principles of the international legal order with impunity. Soon it will be 5 years since the death of the Polish elite led by President Lech Kaczynski, who died on April 10, 2010 in Russia on the Smolensk, flying to celebrate the 70th anniversary of the genocide committed on Polish officers in Katyn. I voted in favour of this resolution because it contains a provision on the need to return the black boxes and wreckage of the Polish TU-154 aircraft. It is good that the EP has finally made such an appeal to the Russian authorities. However, I regret that, with the votes of Polish members from the ruling party, the section of the paragraph on the need for an independent international investigation was not included in the final text of the resolution.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of this resolution as it strongly condemns the killing of Boris Nemtsov and pays tribute to the role he played as an opposition leader, founder and leader of the political movement Solidarnost, and leading critic of President Vladimir Putin. His killing is one of a growing number of unresolved politically—motivated murders and suspicious deaths perpetrated in Russia since 1998, including Anna Politkovskaya and Alexander Litvinenko. Members of the European Parliament are calling for an independent international investigation into the murder. Boris Nemtsov committed his life to a more democratic, prosperous, open Russia and to strong partnerships between Russia and its neighbours and partners.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 After the statements of the Union's VP/AR for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the assassination of Russian opposition leader Boris Nemtsov and the situation of democracy in Russia, the European Parliament calls for a resolution to clarify the circumstances of the death of opposition politician Boris Nemtsov, investigate his brutal murder and bring the culprits to justice quickly. The European institutions, the European Parliament of course, and the European governments have condemned this crime and insisted that there be a diligent investigation.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The text presented underlines the position of rejection of any kind of amnesty for perpetrators of the takedown of flight MH17. The Minsk Agreements established that "forgiveness and amnesty will be granted, under a law prohibiting the persecution and punishment of those related to the events that took place, in particular in the Donetsk and Lugansk regions of Ukraine". This raised concerns about the Dutch government, as 196 Dutch civilians were killed on a commercial flight over Donetsk.  However, the Kiev government has already ensured that an amnesty will not be granted, so the amendment rains on wet conditions in this area. In any case, we understand that there is a lack of direct connection between the two cases, and that the text should have been devoted monographically to the case of the murder of opposition leader Nemtsov, so we voted against his approval.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a joint motion for a resolution on the assassination of Russian opposition leader Boris Germany and the state of democracy in Russia because I believe that in this case an independent investigation is needed that will contribute to the strengthening of fundamental human rights and the rule of law in Russia. In my view, respect for international law through mediation and diplomacy can reach a strategic agreement between the European Union and Russia to ensure a swift de-escalation of tensions. In this context, it is necessary to put an end to all human rights violations, repressive measures and other forms of pressure, so that a genuine dialogue can be established in accordance with the Russian Constitution in the form of implementing a reform plan and promoting an open society.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. The murder of Boris Nemtsov is a tragedy, and should not be exploited. However, this belligerent and excessive text serves as a pretext for an attack in good standing against Russia.  The text insidiously accuses the Russian government on the grounds that the murder site was in a protected area. This same suspicion extends to the plane crash in Smolensk in April 2010, which cost the Polish president his life! Russian politics as a whole is in the spotlight. Despite Mr Putin's undeniable popular support in his country, we are being led to believe that Russian society is stifling under an infamous domination: look for error. Finally, the proposal to initiate an international investigation is absolutely inadmissible and would constitute a denial of Russian sovereignty. In contrast to this arrogant stance, the European Union would benefit from building a respectful and lasting relationship with a great continental power.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution. The Russian authorities should respect their international obligations to uphold human rights and the rule of law. It is crucial to have an independent investigation into the murder of the opposition leader Nemtsov to ensure that those responsible for this barbaric act, whether politically motivated or not, should be held to account.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution concerning the assassination of Russian opposition leader Boris Nemtsov and the state of democracy in Russia. The draft resolution pays tribute to Boris Nemtsov, strongly condemns his murder and calls for an independent and international investigation. He recalls that the human rights situation in Russia has continued to deteriorate in recent years and also calls for the release of all political prisoners. This proposal was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – EH Bildu has voted against the JMRs on the murder of Russian opposition leader Boris Nemtsov and the state of democracy in Russia as we consider that we are in front of a propaganda resolution based on neo—liberal positions opposed to Russia. Current EU policies against – and isolation of – Russia have shown that these are contributing to and promoting an ideological and politically—based reinterpretation of human rights as a field of power struggle and are therefore counterproductive. These should be reversed. However, this JMR goes deeper on that line, stating that ‘there is a need for a united, firm, coherent and comprehensive EU policy towards Russia’ in the form of further sanctions.  Moreover, the JMR uses the murder of Boris Nemtsov and other crisis such as the accidents involving flights MH17 and Tu-154 for political purposes in an attempt to strengthen the evil image of Russia.  EH Bildu is against the assassination of Boris Nemtsov, censures the Russian authorities’ failure to respond to criticism and expresses deep concern at the dramatically—worsened conditions for civil society in Russia. However, for the above—stated reasons, we felt unable to support the JMR voted on today in the European Parliament.

name: Jan Keller (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the proposed resolution because, in my opinion, it is of a significantly manipulative nature. The finding of the assassination of Boris Nemtsov is in the context of the often discussed, whether real or hypothetical shortcomings and wrongdoings of contemporary Russia. This creates the impression that the assassination of an opposition politician is also the work of the regime. However, the murder has not yet been investigated and authorities working with many versions of the perpetrators' motives are being worked out. I refuse to participate in the judgment of anyone before they are found guilty. I consider such an approach morally dubious and politically irresponsible.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am shocked about the murder of Russian opposition politician Boris Nemtsov and am very concerned about the direction Russia is moving in, turning into a state of repression, hate speech and fear. I therefore supported the resolution condemning the assassination and calling for a full, rapid and transparent investigation to be conducted into it. I am also deeply concerned about the attacks against political opposition figures, independent human rights organisations and civil society groups in Russia. Stronger support for them is necessary.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today, 12. 3. 2015, I voted against the European Parliament's joint resolution on the murder of Russian opposition leader Boris Nemtsov and the state of democracy in Russia. In my opinion, the motion for a resolution involved inappropriately mixing unrelated events and attempting to elineate the murder of Boris Nemtsov to the case of blogger Alexei Navalny or the murder of the writer, journalist and activist Anna Politkovska. These are three totally independent cases and investigations. This simplification, mystification and effort to create artificial conspiracy theories has always been alien to me. Moreover, for absolutely incomprehensible reasons, the shooting down of Malaysia's MH 17 over eastern Ukraine was also included in the proposal, as if the shooting was somehow related to the political situation in the Russian Federation, or perhaps to prove that russian President Vladimir Putin was responsible for the murder of Boris Nemtsov. Furthermore, in my opinion, it is absolutely not for us to assess the state of democracy in Russia in any way. That is why I have decided not to contribute to widespread hysteria and growing Russophobia within the EU, and I voted against this resolution, as I continue to consider the Russian Federation to be an EU partner.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I welcome the resolution on the assassination of Russian opposition leader Boris Nemcov and the state of democracy in Russia, as I believe that the Eu ropean Union must adopt a unified and coherent political approach to Russia. Last February, the former Deputy Prime Minister of the Russian Federation was assassinated near the Kremlin. In the course of his political experience, Boris Nemcov has shown his commitment to promoting modernity and democracy throughout Russia.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The joint resolution strongly condemns the assassination of Boris Nemtsov and is logically concerned about the deleterious climate in Russia for any citizen opposition because of the intense and crude propaganda currently being implemented by the Russian authorities.  However, by calling for an "independent international investigation", this text conveys a message of distrust from the European institutions towards Russia. It reinforces a logic of confrontation used by the Russian authorities to divert the population from economic problems and serious breaches of the rule of law.  I therefore voted against this text, preferring the resolution that we tabled with my group, which condemns the numerous abuses against the rule of law in Russia without entering into a confrontation that leads nowhere.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. Like the other National Front MPs, I voted against the resolution "on the assassination of Boris Nemtsov, a figure of the Russian opposition, and the state of democracy in Russia". Of course, any violence, let alone murder, is reprehensible. Even more worrying is the murder of an opposition politician. The European Parliament could perfectly vote on a resolution in which it would express concern and declare that it was waiting for the results of the judicial investigation to be carried out. However, the political groups have decided to table a joint resolution that is totally partisan and ideological, in which the Russian government is accused of all evils. Paragraph 7 provides a sad example, when it calls on the Russian authorities to "end the shameful war of propaganda and information they wage against their neighbours, the Western world and their own people, a war that makes Russia a state marked by repression, hate speech and fear." The European Union is in no position to accuse others of waging a war of propaganda and information. We have all seen this in the referendums on the European constitution and the Lisbon Treaty, for example.

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because I consider it unrealistic and dangerous. It accuses Vladimir Putin without evidence of having ordered the assassination of Boris Nemtsov. And it more generally accuses Russia of having become "a state marked by repression, hate speech and fear". The Union would like to start a war with Russia that it would not do otherwise, especially when we know that at the same time Jean-Claude Juncker has floated the idea of creating a European army against Russia.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against the text presented since, contrary to what might seem, it does not represent a condemnation of the violation of human rights, but a further step in the strategy of certain actors in the European Union, well coordinated with the Americans, to isolate Russia. The European Parliament does not usually worry about harassment of political leaders. In reality, this is only a problem when such events take place in countries where the EU is of particular interest. Because I am not going to play the game of majority matches and because in this particular case the authorship of crime is resolved, I have decided to vote against the Resolution.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. Boris Nemtsov, former Prime Minister of the Russian Federation and former governor of Nizhny Novgorod, was one of the leaders of Russia's liberal and Democratic opposition, and was assassinated near the Kremlin two days before a demonstration scheduled for March 1, 2015 against the effects of the economic crisis and conflict in Ukraine, of which he was an organizer. I strongly condemn the murder of Boris Nemtsov, being a very significant political crime and which is not surprising that he was shot dead near the Kremlin, in an area with surveillance cameras and the presence of the police and security services. I take this opportunity to pay tribute to Boris Nemtsov as the prominent leader of the opposition and a strong fighter for a more democratic, more prosperous and open Russia. I would also like to express my heartfelt condolences to your family and close friends. I vote in favour of this resolution in which the European Parliament calls on the Russian authorities, for the sake of democratic respect, to put an end to all kinds of pressure, repressive acts and intimidation, both politically and judicially, against opposition leaders, representatives of civil society and independent media.

name: Peter Lundgren (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ While I do condemn the murder of Boris Nemtsov in the strongest possible terms and hope that the perpetrators of this awful crime will feel the full weight of justice, I wish to make it very clear that I object to what I see as the emergence of a separate EU foreign policy which, inter alia, calls for the Russian Federation to take certain actions. In my view, the EU has no right to call for any other countries to make any changes to their domestic policies whatsoever. Nevertheless, I chose to support this motion in order to express my condolences to the family, friends and supporters of Mr Nemtsov.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support an emergency resolution condemning the assassination of Boris Germanov, opposition leader and great critic of Vladimir Putin and the war in Ukraine. The slain former deputy prime minister of the Russian Federation was executed before he arrived to publish a report on Russia's involvement in the conflicts in Ukraine.  I welcome the request to conduct an impartial international investigation into the murder and for the European Union to take into account the current political atmosphere, propaganda and information war against neighbouring states and a serious violation of the rule of law and human rights in shaping its policy towards Russia. Russia is a member of the United Nations, the Council of Europe and the OSCE, however, the human rights situation in Russia has deteriorated dramatically over the past few years. The latest examples are the jailing of opposition leader Alexei Navalni for supporting demonstrations and illegally detaining Nadia Savchenko. For every condemnation is the fact that some senior foreign officials, including MEP Sandra Kalniete, were prevented by Russian authorities from paying their last respects at the funeral.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I abstained because the resolution was not objective.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. Voted against this purely ideological resolution which, in a simplified view of reality, makes Russia and its president guilty of all evils, including the "climate of hatred and tension in Europe".

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the motion for a resolution on the assassination of Russian opposition leader Boris Nemtsov and the state of democracy in Russia. Considering what happened, an independent international investigation into the murder would be appropriate. The fact that people are being held illegally also runs counter to the principles to be respected and to human rights. Russia remains an important global player, but it remains the essential factor in respect for international law and the commitments made within the framework of the OSCE.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 27 February Boris Nemcov, former Deputy Prime Minister of the Russian Federation, and former governor of Nizhny Novgorod, was assassinated near the Kremlin in Moscow. Throughout his political career, Nemcov has distinguished his commitment to promoting democracy and modernity within the country. I welcomed the resolution on the murder of Boris Nemcov, as I believe that it is an act of due homage to the victim.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. In 2012 I believe that it is necessary for us in this Parliament to encourage an independent international investigation to clarify the murder of Russian politician Boris Nemtsov. That is why all my support for the resolution calling for this matter to be dealt with with all the rigour, since we are facing the most important political assassination in recent Russian history. All Europeans must be concerned about what is happening in Russia, where there is growing discourse of hatred and fear, and there are situations such as the assassination of this Russian opposition leader, who was gathering evidence of Russian involvement in the war in eastern Ukraine and who was killed just two days before the demonstration against that war he was going to lead. Nemtsov, as this resolution points out, committed his life to a more prosperous and democratic Russia, and to a stronger friendly relationship between Russia and its neighbors. In addition, I deeply regret that some Members of the European Parliament and diplomats who wanted to attend the funeral have been denied entry into Russia.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. I condemn any kind of restrictions on freedom of expression. However, the circumstances in this case are far from clear and any interference and recrimination on the part of the European Union is inappropriate.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This false text proves the blindness of this Parliament to the situation in Russia. Thus, from the first line, the facts are recomposed to the Atlanticist ideological mane. Boris Nemtsov is described as the "leading figure of the liberal opposition in Russia" while his party made less than 1% in the last elections. We do better as a figurehead.... A few lines later, the anti-Semitic and racist Alexei Navalny is presented as the "brother" of Nemtsov...  To this point of blindness in the face of such enemies of freedom, one might as well write that the earth is flat. I regret that the European Parliament can vote in such a crude way. More than ignorance, it is a sign of the manipulative will of the initiators of this text to enter into a logic of war against Russia. The authors of this text and those who vote on it are irresponsible war-makers! It is not clear whether they are unaware of it. We must do everything we can to prevent this war. I'm voting against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because I consider an independent international investigation into the assassination of Boris Nemtsov, who was investigating Russia's participation in the conflict in eastern Ukraine and who was assassinated in the vicinity of the Kremlin two days before a demonstration that was organizing against this conflict, was important. Five men have been arrested, but it remains unclear whether any of them were responsible for the deadly shootings.  I also deplore the refusal of some MEPs and diplomats to enter Russia, which prevented them from attending Boris Nemtsov's exquias.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution that condemns the killing of Boris Nemtsov and pays tribute to a man who committed his life to fighting for a more democratic, prosperous and open Russia.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The resolution on the murder of the Russian opposition leader Boris Nemtsov and the state of democracy in Russia calls for an independent international investigation into the murder of Russian opposition politician Boris Nemtsov, who was gathering evidence about Russian involvement in the war in eastern Ukraine and was killed just two days before he was to lead a demonstration against it.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 A moment of drama and potential crossroads for Russia's destiny and an important, unequivocal resolution of the European Parliament, adopted despite unexpected reservations, and slightly surreal, from colleagues from other Member States.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. As we know, Boris Nemtsov, one of the leaders of russia's liberal and democratic opposition, one of the sharpest critics of President Putin and his regime, who fought for a modern, democratic and open Russia, and who wanted to publish the results of his investigations into Russia's role in the Donetsk conflict, was assassinated two days before the protest he organized on March 1, 2015. There is no evidence that the murder was carried out on behalf of, with or even on behalf of the power, but the fact is that, as the EP has pointed out on numerous occasions, the human rights situation in Russia is constantly deteriorating, there are regular violations of the norms of the rule of law and there are more than reasonable doubts about the independence of the judiciary.  It is also a fact that politically motivated killings and suspicious deaths are regularly carried out in Russia, which remain unexplained, but which should not take place without the political environment created by the Russian authorities, without the hateful atmosphere against opposition activists, human rights defenders, minorities and neighbouring nations created and amplified in recent years by state propaganda and official media.
