For these reasons, I consider the contents of the draft resolution, as one of the authors of the resolution, to be largely justified.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. This resolution is a caricature of the primary anti-Russian hatred that prevails within the European institutions. By pure ideology, it blames Mr Putin for all the ills of Russian society and accuses him of creating a climate of hatred and tension in Europe, even before the investigation into the death of Boris Nemtsov has begun. The adversarial inversion is at its peak...  I obviously voted against this resolution.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament wants all the light to be shed on the assassination in Russia of the opposition leader Boris Nemtsov. In the name of respect for human rights and my commitment to democratic values, I share this legitimate concern. On the other hand, I cannot accept a text in the form of a prosecution and without evidence against Russia.  This type of resolution contributes to the escalation of the deterioration of the EU-Russia relationship, which I deeply regret. I am committed to a direct and frank but respectful dialogue between the European Union and Russia, as well as with all its partners. Let us remember that our relations of friendship are strong, that our trade relations are close and that we fight together terrorism in the world. I did not vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We wish to express our condolences today for the murder of Boris Nemtsov, a politician and opposition activist who is promoting the modernisation of Russian civil society. We expect the competent judicial authorities to carry out rapid and transparent investigations to find the perpetrators and culprits. Once again, we wish to express our deep concern at the attacks on opposition politicians, independent figures, promoters of human rights and civil society.  We call on the Commission and the European Union's External Action Service to increase the financial assistance provided for civil society, through the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights, in order to establish a credible and long-term support relationship.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, which sends a strong message in defence of human rights and calls for an end to the repression against freedom of expression, assembly and association in Russia. The document calls for an independent international investigation into the murder of Russian political opponent Boris Nemcov, who was killed two days before a demonstration he organised against the conflict in Ukraine. I agree that Russia must put an end to all pressure, repressive actions and intimidation against the leaders of the opposition, civil society and the media, and I accept the demands for the release of all political prisoners.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. – I did not support the motion for a resolution because I believe that the EU policy on Russia of the last year does not lead to any constructive results, but on the contrary – it brings difficulties for millions of European citizens and cannot continue in its current form. The murder of Boris Nemtsov is undoubtedly an act that I condemn and I believe that the relevant authorities of the Russian Federation should make the necessary efforts to clarify the circumstances surrounding this murder. At the same time, however, I do not believe that it is within the competence of the European Parliament to give assessments of the Russian course, which is done through this text. You should, instead, look for a way to melt the ice. With similar texts, we build new walls in Europe. I believe that such acts only deteriorate the strained relations between the EU and the Russian Federation. The Union must offer solutions to the difficulties experienced by European citizens. A number of our citizens and industries, such as agriculture and tourism, have suffered, especially for countries traditionally known on the Russian market, such as my country - Bulgaria. I believe that the text of the resolution in this regard is unnecessarily provocative and unilateral and does not reflect the lack of adequate EU policies regarding compensation for its citizens and Member States for policies to be decided in Brussels.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution to show that this Parliament in general and the Liberals in particular support the right of the Russian people to freedom, respect for their rights and of a life free of brutal killings of important popular figures. It is very important that the truth about the murder of Boris Nemtsov comes to the surface and that the killers, and those behind them, are brought to justice!

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. I strongly supported the killing of Russian opposition leader Boris Nemtsov. This is the most significant political assassination in Russia's recent history. Russia's active propaganda activities targeting Russian society as well as other countries are encouraged by hostility. In addition, the resolution also condemns the abduction of Eston Kohveri, an official of the Estonian Defence Police from Estonian territory, and calls on the Russian authorities to release Kohver immediately and return them back to Estonia. The investigation into the shooting down of a Malaysian passenger jet and the prosecution of those responsible must also be completed.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering that Boris Nemtsov, former Deputy Prime Minister of the Russian Federation, leading reformist of society and economy in post-Soviet Russia and one of the leaders of the Russian liberal and democratic opposition, was assassinated near the Kremlin two days before a demonstration against the effects of the economic crisis and the conflict in Ukraine, scheduled for March 1, 2015 and organized by him;  whereas the Russian Federation, as a full member of the Council of Europe and the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) and as a signatory to the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, has undertaken to observe the universal principles of democracy, the rule of law and respect for fundamental freedoms and human rights;  condemning the murder of Boris Nemtsov (one of the most serious in Russian history), who was shot dead near the Kremlin, in an area guarded by video cameras and manned by police and security services; calling for an independent international investigation into the murder. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. I supported this resolution because I am horrified by the murder of prominent politician and Leader of the Russian opposition Boris Germany. This murder constitutes a direct attack on our fundamental principles - the right to life and freedom of speech. I am deeply concerned about the state of democracy in Russia and the level of human rights protection in the country, as Russia ignores its international commitments to membership in the Council of Europe and the OSCE. That is why it is important to conduct a comprehensive and impartial investigation and punish perpetrators. Justice must be served on behalf of all citizens of Russia who know what it means to fight for a democratic and modern Russia. They deserve our solidarity, as do all those who fight for the right values. I also support the call sent to the Russian authorities to release all political prisoners, especially Nadju Savchenko.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Boris Nemcov, an opponent of Putin and the war in Ukraine, who dedicated his life to building a more democratic Russia, has died a few steps from the Kremlin under suspicious circumstances, in an area where surveillance, video and police, should be at the highest level. Parliament is therefore right to call for an international investigation into the murder. Russia must put an end to the propaganda war, which only stirs up hatred and provokes clashes. I would like to remind you that the Russian Federation, together with the European Union, has made a commitment to protect democratic values and universal fundamental rights. I call on the Russian judicial authorities to apply humanitarian law, calling for the release of all political prisoners, in particular and as a matter of urgency, that of Nadija Savchenko, who was abducted on Ukrainian territory and illegally detained in a Russian prison, whose health is of concern, and that of the police officer Eston Kohver, who was taken from Estonian territory and taken to Russia.  It is in our interests that tensions be eased and diplomatic relations restored, and in order to do this, the whole of the European Union must define a unified policy involving respect for fundamental rights on the part of Russia.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ In recent years, the human rights situation in Russia has deteriorated and the Russian authorities have adopted a number of laws containing unclear provisions, which are used to further restrict opposition actors as well as civil society actors and to hinder the exercise of freedom of expression and assembly; whereas the Ministry of Justice has used the new powers granted to designate 42 groups as 'foreign agents', including the most skilled and reliable human rights organisations in the country. Multiple trials and trials over the past few years, including those of Magnitsky, Hodorkovsky and Politkovska, have cast doubt on the independence and impartiality of judicial institutions in the Russian Federation. The latest tragic example of Boris Germanov's murder is only further evidence in support of previous facts. The Russian authorities must end the current propaganda and information war against their neighbours, the Western world and their own peoples, who turn Russia into a state characterised by repression, hate speech and fear, in which the reason for the national euphoria is the annexation of Crimea and the escalating state of war in Ukraine, in which the rights of crimean Tatars are violated and in which the Kremlin nurtures and incites hatred and violence , in violation of international law.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The issue of the state of democracy in Russia following Boris Germany's execution in Moscow deserves a broad debate by the European Parliament with the European Union's High Representative for Foreign Policy and Security Federica Mogherini. Although the respected representative of the Russian political opposition, Gari Kasparov, said that the murder of the Kremlin's vocal critic Boris Germanov has extinguished any hope of a peaceful political transition in Russia, it is important to insist on a transparent, independent and thorough investigation that will uncover the perpetrators and perpetrators of this murder. The European Union, which promotes democracy and human rights, freedom and the rule of law in accordance with its founding principles, has a duty to continuously include respect for these values in all segments of its relations with Russia. At the same time, the EU needs to provide clear support to the thousands of Russian citizens who symbolically gathered in front of the Sakharov Centre before boris germanov's send-off began, and to send unequivocal support to the Russian opposition. Furthermore, I believe that the European Parliament should strongly condemn the denial of entry into Russia to fellow MEPs Sandra Kalniete, who wished to attend Boris German's funeral and was instead detained for hours at Moscow Airport on the pretext that she posed a danger to state security and to the public order of the Russian Federation.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I was very saddened by the assassination of Boris Nemcov, which took place in a highly guarded area near the Kremlin and manned by police and security services. Boris Nemcov, leader of the opposition to Vladimir Putin and the war in Ukraine, dedicated his life to the realization of a democratic Russia, an open society and a reformist agenda. I believe that Russia is an important partner of the EU and I very much hope that clarity will be shed on the murder of Boris Nemcov with an international investigation, so that tensions are reduced and good diplomatic relations are restoreed.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. Boris Nemtsov, former deputy prime minister of the Russian Federation, a prominent reformist of Russian society and economy of the post-Soviet era and one of Russia's liberal and democratic opposition leaders, was assassinated in the vicinity of the Kremlin, two days before a demonstration he was organizing against the effects of the economic crisis and the conflict in Ukraine. In the weeks leading up to his assassination, Boris Nemtsov was investigating Russia's participation in the Donbass conflict and it was his intention to publish a report on the matter. Russia, as a full member of the Council of Europe and a signatory to the UN Declaration, has committed itself to respecting the principles of democracy, the rule of law and human rights. However, several trials and legal proceedings have called into question the independence and impartiality of Russia's judicial bodies. On the other hand, the political climate that the Russian authorities have created has prepared fertile ground for such murders. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution, which calls for an independent international investigation of the murder and reiterates the need for an EU policy towards Russia that is firm, coherent and comprehensive.

name: Miloslav Ransdorf (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. – I voted against the resolution on the murder of B. Nemtsov. I believe that such a document cannot mix different topics, be used to attack a partner country, as the investigation has not yet been brought to an end. It is completely nonsensical to advocate in this text, for example, the tragic event of the polish plane crash near Smolensk. The text is about as strong as if the European Parliament were calling on the US Congress and the US government to investigate the violent killings of dark-skinned American citizens or to investigate the political murders of J.F. Kennedy, Martin Luther King, or R. Kennedy.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the EPP resolution condemning the murder of Boris Nemtsov, who was shot down near the Kremlin in an area equipped with video cameras, with police and security services, and which is the most significant political assassination in Russia's recent history, the assassination of which is of special outline stother for being a prominent opposition leader and a prominent critic of President Vladimir Putin and the war in Ukraine. It advocated a more democratic, prosperous and open Russia and strong partnership relations with its global neighbours and partners. For all this, it is important to request an independent international investigation of this murder. Finally, I leave my support to the democratic forces in Russia, which are committed to a more open society and a reformist agenda.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. Anna Politkovskaya, Aleksander Litvinenko, Stanislav Markelov, Anastasia Baburova, Natalia Estemirova, Sergei Magnitsky, Boris Nemtsov... the list of political assassinations in Russia since 1998 is long, far too long. This afternoon, the European Parliament strongly condemned the assassination of Boris Nemtsov, an emblematic figure of the liberal and democratic opposition in Russia. He was the voice of the opposition to Vladimir Putin's policies. He had dedicated his life to a more democratic, prosperous and open Russia. On February 27, his opponents finally muzzled him. Loosely, they shot him four times in the back, right next to the Kremlin, quite a symbol. With this suspicious death, it is again the entire Putin regime that is being singled out by the international community. An international community increasingly concerned about this policy of oppression and intimidation of opposition activists and minorities in neighbouring countries that despises human rights without complexity.     It is in this context that the European Union has decided to maintain its sanctions against Vladimir Putin's regime, but to continue to support the Russian people.

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution concerning the assassination of Russian opposition leader Boris Nemtsov and the state of democracy in Russia. In condemning the assassination of Boris Nemtsov, Russia's main opponent, the European Parliament reiterated the need for the European Union to adopt a common and firm strategy towards Russia, particularly on sanctions.  The murder of Boris Nemtsov is unfortunately not an isolated case and environmentalists have every reason to believe that the ongoing investigation is not being conducted impartially. Russian nationalism is now at a worrying level, reflected in extremely aggressive propaganda but also in the Ukrainian conflict. European states cannot simply look away when it comes to serious and persistent violations of human rights and democracy. It is therefore imperative that the European Union makes progress through diplomacy, but also that it unambiguously commits itself to supporting Russian civil society, including financially. The European Union has everything to gain from a clear strategy supporting those who are fighting for pluralism in the country.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. A free and democratic society should not fear freedom of expression and association. A free and democratic society must learn to live with critical opposition and independent media. The murder or imprisonment of opposition politicians, always in unclear conditions, threatens to become one in Russia. The Position of the European Union must be clear in condemning such procedures and in demanding greater transparency and independence in the investigation of these cases.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. "U2012 Following statements by the Union's VP/AR for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the assassination of Russian opposition leader Boris Nemtsov and the state of democracy in Russia, the European Parliament calls for a resolution to clarify the circumstances of the death of opposition politician Boris Nemtsov, investigate his brutal murder and bring the culprits to justice quickly. The European institutions, the European Parliament of course, and the European governments have condemned this crime and insisted that there be a diligent investigation.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Yesterday, we called for an independent international investigation into the assassination in early March of Boris Nemtsov, an opposition figurehead in Russia. The text of the resolution we voted on deplores the fact that "the latest developments demonstrate that Russia is taking a path that is not that of a healthy democracy, which is characterized by respect for the opposition, the rule of law and the independence of the judiciary". The resolution also calls on the Russian authorities to "cease all forms of pressure, repression or intimidation, both political and judicial" against opposition figures, representatives of civil society and independent media, so that they can freely carry out their activities... and the immediate release of all political prisoners, including Ukrainian pilot Nadia Savchenko and Estonian policeman Eston Kohver. Finally, we recommended to the Council that a unified policy towards Russia be developed with a strong common message on the importance of human rights in relations between the European Union and Russia, and on the need to put an end to the repression of freedom of expression, assembly and association in Russia.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this resolution, which strongly condemns the murder of Boris Nemtsov and calls for an independent international investigation. This opponent of the Russian regime was gathering information and evidence on Russia's involvement in the war in eastern Ukraine and was murdered two days before a demonstration on the subject.  Boris Nemtsov fought to defend democracy in Russia and has always worked for the development of close ties with Russia's neighbours and partners.  The situation in Russia remains worrying in terms of respect for human rights and freedoms; the regime continues to exert pressure and use intimidation on opposition figures.  The Union must consider putting in place more support for Russian civil society, in order to put an end to the repression of freedom of expression, assembly and association.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote against it because this report is totally unbalanced against Russia.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The text presented underlines the position of rejection of any kind of amnesty for perpetrators of the takedown of flight MH17. The Minsk Agreements established that "forgiveness and amnesty will be granted, under a law prohibiting the persecution and punishment of those related to the events that took place, in particular in the Donetsk and Lugansk regions of Ukraine". This raised concerns about the Dutch government, as 196 Dutch civilians were killed on a commercial flight over Donetsk.  However, the Kiev government has already ensured that an amnesty will not be granted, so the amendment rains on wet conditions in this area. In any case, we understand that there is a lack of direct connection between the two cases, and that the text should have been devoted monographically to the case of the murder of opposition leader Nemtsov, so we voted against his approval.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which strongly condemns the murder of Boris Nemtsov, a Russian opponent shot dead near the Kremlin, and calls for an independent international investigation into the killing. Boris Nemtsov, former Deputy Prime Minister of the Russian Federation and former governor of Nizhny Novgorod, was a figure of the Russian liberal and democratic opposition and had organized numerous demonstrations against the fallout from the economic crisis and the conflict in Ukraine. In this resolution, Parliament is concerned about the violence of the political climate in Russia and calls for the immediate release of all political prisoners, including Nadia Savchenko, a member of the Ukrainian Parliament and the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against the text presented since, contrary to what might seem, it does not represent a condemnation of the violation of human rights, but a further step in the strategy of certain actors in the European Union, well coordinated with the Americans, to isolate Russia. The European Parliament does not usually worry about harassment of political leaders. In reality, this is only a problem when such events take place in countries where the EU is of particular interest. In this particular case, the authorship of the crime is resolved.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in support of the joint motion for a resolution on the murder of the Russian opposition leader Boris Nemtsov and the state of democracy in Russia. Boris Nemtsov was a strong advocate for a modern, prosperous and democratic Russian Federation, open to the world. His killing is one of a growing number of unresolved politically motivated murders and suspicious deaths perpetrated in Russia since 1998. Members of the European Parliament are calling for an independent international investigation into the murder.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. I join everyone who condemns the murder of prominent opposition leader Boris Nemov. This action has struck a severe blow to the hope that dialogue with Russia can begin at a higher level. It raises a series of questions, even more than we have answers to what is really going on with democracy in Russia. I have a feeling that such actions only confirm the belief that intimidation and violence is commonplace in Russian politics. There is, of course, the question of whether democracy can be imposed in relation to the question of the reasonableness of sanctions and the resulting damage that we have done to ourselves. All forces must be directed to achieve a higher level of respect for human rights in Russia through dialogue. It is necessary to facilitate a rapid, transparent and impartial investigation of the circumstances of the murder and to find the culprits. That is why I also supported the resolution calling on Russia to regulate these problems and to improve the political situation in the country.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ As co-author of the draft resolution, I think that regardless of who murdered Boris Nemtsov, this is a great loss not only for Russia. The Germans were preparing to publish evidence of russian military involvement in the conflict in Ukraine. I have no doubt that the Putin regime will also use this event for propaganda purposes and further discredit the opposition. At the same time, this assassination reflects the critical state of Russian society, when an opposition figure can be assassinated in front of the Kremlin.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. First of all, this way I would like to express my sincerest condolences to the family and friends of Boris Nemcov. Recent developments in Russia, the latest being the murder of opposition leader Boris Nemcov, point to serious violations of democracy, human rights and undermining the rule of law there. I express my concern about this situation and support the resolution to jointly create a robust, coherent and comprehensive EU policy towards Russia. I call on the Russian authorities to stop shameful war propaganda and violations of basic human rights, to stop the continued intimidation and abuse of opposition members, and to release all political prisoners as well as the abducted Nadia Savchenko and Estonia Kohver.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution as it condemns the assassination of an opposition leader in Russia.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. I support this resolution and strongly condemn the murder of Boris German because it is an attack on freedom of speech, but also an attack on all those principles that we in the European Union hold for the fundamental. We must act on our conscience and do whatever is necessary to conduct a thorough international investigation. This is not only the interest of us in the European Union, but also of all citizens of Russia, especially as we see that in recent years their rights have been severely violated. I also think it is important to show solidarity and solidarity to the Russian Democrats and their efforts to create a dignified and true values of a based Russia.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The act of the murder of Boris Nemtsov is reprehensible, as is its use to escalate the European Union's relations with Russia.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this decision because I believe it is important for the EP to condemn this outrageous political crime and its cynical Russian government response with all its political weight and unity. A significant element of the decision is that, in the context of this tragedy, the EP once again recalled the importance of the EU's single, decisive policy, supported by all Member States, with regard to Russia. I think it is necessary to draw attention to the fact that some of the leaders of the EU Member States also see Putin's distorted, repressive democracy as a kind of political role model, including a violent showdown with political opponents. I regard our decision as a strong warning to all like-minded politicians.

name: Charles Tannock (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The Russian Federation has destabilized its surrounding region, provoking a conflict in eastern Ukraine and supplying the ‘separatists’ with arms. I have been highly critical of Russian involvement in Ukraine and have repeatedly called on Moscow to fulfil its international commitments, including the upholding of political rights and freedom of speech. The recent political assassination of Boris Nemtsov, a vocal critic of Putin and an influential opposition leader, shows how dangerous the political situation within Russia has become. Russia, as a member of the UN, has an international duty to protect political rights – an excuse ironically used by Putin last February to justify the Russian invasion and annexation of Crimea. The rights of Crimean Tatars have been heavily violated in Crimea since Russia’s illegal annexation. Russia sadly is a nation where political figures, journalists, and civilians fear censure, imprisonment, or death for criticizing the government, so has no right to use its ‘international commitment to protect political rights and the freedom of speech’ as a justification for the military invasion of the territory of a sovereign nation.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. We were all outraged by the murder of Mr Nemtsov in Moscow. No one should die for their freedom to think and express themselves. Freedom of expression was again stabbed. It was for values that we all respect and share, opposing war. This is a great loss for democracy in Russia. Russian citizens have the right to real freedom, real justice, real democracy! I therefore voted in favour of this resolution and co-signed it.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Recent events show that the path Russia is taking is not that of a functioning democracy, which is characterised by respect for the opposition, the rule of law and the independence of the judiciary. This is the reason why I voted in favour of this resolution calling on the Russian authorities to stop all pressure, repressive acts and intimidation, both political and judicial, against opposition figures, representatives of civil society and the independent media, to allow them to carry out their activities freely. I also voted in favour of this resolution to condemn the terrible assassination of Boris Nemtsov.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The text presented underlines the position of rejection of any kind of amnesty for perpetrators of the takedown of flight MH17. The Minsk Agreements established that "forgiveness and amnesty will be granted, under a law prohibiting the persecution and punishment of those related to the events that took place, in particular in the Donetsk and Lugansk regions of Ukraine". This raised concerns about the Dutch government, as 196 Dutch civilians were killed on a commercial flight over Donetsk.  However, the Kiev government has already ensured that an amnesty will not be granted, so the amendment rains on wet conditions in this area. In any case, we understand that there is a lack of direct connection between the two cases, and that the text should have been devoted monographically to the case of the murder of opposition leader Nemtsov, so we voted against his approval.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution as I believe that Parliament should clearly show its rejection of any murder on political grounds, as was the case with Boris Nemtsov.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. "U2012 Following statements by the Union's VP/AR for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the assassination of Russian opposition leader Boris Nemtsov and the state of democracy in Russia, the European Parliament calls for a resolution to clarify the circumstances of the death of opposition politician Boris Nemtsov, investigate his brutal murder and bring the culprits to justice quickly. The European institutions, the European Parliament of course, and the European governments have condemned this crime and insisted that there be a diligent investigation.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against the text presented since, contrary to what might seem, it does not represent a condemnation of the violation of human rights, but a further step in the strategy of certain actors in the European Union, well coordinated with the Americans, to isolate Russia.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ With my colleagues, I voted in favour of the statement because in an atmosphere where nationalistic fervour is being generated, we have to be careful in the language we use in order not to add to that fervour, but to challenge it. This European Parliament regularly and rightly draws attention where people anywhere in the world lose their life because of their political beliefs or the defence of human rights.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Boris Nemtsov, former deputy prime minister of the Russian Federation, former governor of Nizhny Novgorod, was assassinated near the Kremlin two days before a demonstration he was organizing, which was due to take place on March 1, 2015, against the effects of the economic crisis and the conflict in Ukraine. We regret this murder in cold blood, we reject these methods and condemn their perpetrators. We call for a complete investigation that can bring the motivations and authors to a complete clarification. We do not follow those who are already seeking to draw conclusions to the extent of their interests, without even waiting for the conclusions of the investigations which they say are distorted at the outset. Russia must represent an unavoidable partner for the EU. It is therefore in the interest of the EU to engage in dialogue with this important country and contribute to peace in the region.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. I condemn any kind of restrictions on freedom of expression. However, the circumstances in this case are far from clear and any interference and recrimination on the part of the European Union is unreasonable

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ With my colleagues, I voted in favour of the statement because in an atmosphere where nationalistic fervour is being generated, we have to be careful in the language we use in order not to add to that fervour but to challenge it. This European Parliament regularly and rightly draws attention where people anywhere in the world lose their life because of their political beliefs or the defence of human rights.

name: Kristina Winberg (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ While I do condemn the murder of Boris Nemtsov in the strongest possible terms and hope that the perpetrators of this awful crime will feel the full weight of justice, I wish to make it very clear that I object to what I see as the emergence of a separate EU foreign policy which, inter alia, calls for the Russian Federation to take certain actions. In my view, the EU has no right to call for any other countries to make any changes to their domestic policies whatsoever. Nevertheless, I chose to support this motion in order to express my condolences to the family, friends and supporters of Mr. Nemtsov.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I condemn not only the cold-blooded killing of Nemtsov, but also Russia's approach to those who wanted to honor his memory. I spoke to a Ukrainian Member who was imprisoned and beaten only because he planned to attend the funeral. In turn, Latvian MEP Sandra Kalniete was denied entry to the country by the Russian authorities, making it completely impossible for her to participate in the final farewell. Polish Senate President Bogdan Borusewicz was refused a visa. All travel restrictions were unjustified and Moscow has given them a clear signal of the direction in which its relations with the EU will move in the near future.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the joint text of the resolution because I believe that it is the duty of every European politician to condemn the brutal political murder suffered by Boris Nemtsov. Russia has now become a criminal dictatorship that solves external and internal problems with force. Supporting democratic change in the country should be one of the EU's primary responsibilities, and politicians such as Boris Nemtsov – courageous opposition leaders and critics of Vladimir Putin's oppressive regime – should be at the centre of this. Only through democratisation can Russia become a reliable partner of the EU.  In the face of ongoing aggression against Ukraine, violating all the principles of international law, any cooperation with the Russian Federation is impossible. There needs to be a joint and firm pressure from the entire international community, including all EU Member States, on the Russian authorities in order to bring about their cessation of aggressive destabilising activities in Europe. The wreckage and black boxes of the TU-154 aircraft that crashed near Smolensk on 10 April 2010 deserve special condemnation. The corrupt, executive-dependent Russian judiciary is unable to objectively and honestly explain the circumstances of this tragic event. Only the internationalization of the investigation in this case can identify the guilty of the death of The President of Poland Lech Kaczyński and the other victims.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 On the pretext of an abominable act, a murder, which we condemn, resume and attempt to strengthen the European Parliament's position on the conflict in Ukraine, unconditional support for the Kiev coup regime, in a process of illegitimate assault on power by the neo-Nazi and far-right forces of that country, and reaffirms the eu's hypocritical foreign policy position with Russia. We consider unacceptable the systemic position of interference that the EP and the EU allow in the relationship with third countries, in this case Russia, with attempts or implementation of interventions at national level, to destabilise politically, and to align the countries targeted with the strategic interests of the EU, in particular by using the creation and financing of NGOs. In the present case, it is explicitly a question of strengthening the policy of siege and provocation of the Russian Federation. It is up to the judicial authorities of this country to investigate the crime of Nemtsov's murder, without external interference.  We voted against it.

name: Tatjana Ždanoka (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I voted against this report. It advocates the enforcement of the policy giving the EU a negative role in the current conflicts in its neighbourhood. As a native Russian speaker living in an EU Member State, I am desperate seeing the policies the EU has had towards Russia after the dissolution of the USSR. The new Europe was built for the first 15 years without Russia, but for the last eight years against Russia. The Eastern Partnership Programme has turned to the so—called Baltic—Black—Caspian Sea Arch, from a bridge into an abyss. In October 2013, there was another resolution here in Strasbourg on the principles of EU foreign policy, tabled by Mr Brok, where our relations towards Russia were defined as ‘critical engagement’. In fact it was a unilateral declaration of a Cold War towards Russia. The resolution which was adopted today does not turn the EU back from the way of war. Those politicians who have supported this trend will be responsible before the court of history.

name: Peter Jahr (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I voted in favour of the report. My explanation of vote is, of course, also very different from that of my colleague, who spoke before me, because, firstly, I believe that we have never done European foreign policy as well as we do now. This also seems to be because of the conditions: we have a representative, the High Representative for External Relations, who is doing justice to the matter. Secondly, it is up to the European Union to respond to challenges in this world. You can see it as you like. In my view, Russia is on a bad path. Then it is quite simply that the discussion should be continued, but consistent and united. I believe that the representatives of the European Union at all levels have so far responded to this demand.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by It is good that the European Union's foreign policy report calls on the European Commission to oversee the joint observance of sanctions against Russia, but it is a pity that so little has been said about the Russian embargo on the export of our food. Russia, after all, openly declares that it will apply the embargo selectively. In this situation, Parliament should have clearly ruled out using the Russian food embargo to take over the eastern markets of places by those countries that will be treated favourably by Russia, to take over the markets of those countries that Russia will exclude from these markets. Adopting such a principle, which we must clearly apply, is not just a requirement of solidarity, it is a requirement of ordinary decency. It is a pity that we did not speak openly about this.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. The Annual Report takes stock of the most important developments in the CFSP and deals with human rights, non-proliferation of arms and the spread of EU values. It also discusses geographical issues on the main areas of the CFSP: enlargement, transatlantic relations, relations with Russia, the EU neighbourhood, the Middle East and Asia. This report has been agreed with broad agreement between the four political groups in Parliament: PPE, S&D, ALDE and Greens. It is clearly positioned on Russia's actions in relation to Ukraine, and in relation to the Middle East emphasizes the two-state solution. It stresses the need to focus on the fight against ISIS and address the growing challenges arising from the state's failure in Syria, Iraq, Libya and the Sahel. The Socialists and Democrats have had a broad influence on the drafting of the report through the compromise amendments that have been agreed.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it insists on the militaristic drift of the European Union, advocates closer cooperation between the EU and the Atlantic Alliance and supports the fusion of internal and external security. In the proposal for a vote, elements which I consider essential to support any initiative related to the Common Security and Defence Policy, such as progress towards nuclear disarmament at the global level, strict support and development of international law in all EU military activities and the separation of civil and military actions, were absent.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. I welcome the protection of European values and interests and the strengthening of the political and legal system in Europe to restore and ensure peace and stability.  The promotion of the security of Member States, as well as their citizens, democratisation, the rule of law and social development in the EU's neighbourhood must continue to be strengthened.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. This report is ideologically oriented with the emphasis of a "world order". It clearly outlines the will of a world government under the aegis of NATO and the United States, even though not all MEMBER States of the Union are members of NATO, and a genuine democratic centralism that goes against the sovereignty of the Member States. They are obliged to "actively and unreservedly support the Union's foreign and security policy in a spirit of loyalty". In particular, it aims to establish a single security market for a single world government in which the European Union is the only lackey of the United States. So I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ As I do not believe that the role of High Representative should exist, it seemed consistent to vote against this report. In addition, there is much of the text with which I disagree.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The European Security and Defence policy strategy needs to be revised and concrete efforts made to meet current and future security challenges. This is extremely topical as the current Russian Federation aggression against Ukraine brings continuous violations of international norms and breaches of human rights. I truly support the rapporteur’s view that a new comprehensive political vision and strategy are needed in order to contain Russia’s revisionist ambition, sustain international norms and withstand the on-going information and propaganda war against the EU and our values. The EU should step up its diplomatic efforts, urging Russia to respect its commitments and international obligations regarding Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. Bearing in mind the worrying geo-political developments in the EU neighbourhood, one must reiterate the Member States’ responsibility to act in solidarity when it comes to addressing security threats, move from reactive to proactive approach, strengthen collective defence and collaboration with NATO and respond in a univocal manner to common threats. For example, sanctions against Russia can be lifted only when it withdraws from Crimea and fully implements the Minsk Agreement, and this should apply to every Member State.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which I totally disapprove of. Elmar Brok and his supporters are the promoters of an irresponsible and dangerous policy that I am fighting in the European Parliament.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for an annual report to the European Parliament of the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. I agree that the priority of the EU's foreign and security policy should be to protect European values and interests, to improve the EU's contribution to the territorial defence of its Member States and to strengthening its ability to defend itself against the risks it faces, including terrorism, arms trafficking, drugs and trafficking in human beings. Security, democratisation, the rule of law and economic and social development in the EU's neighbourhood must be supported. The EU must also take the lead in resolving conflicts and peacekeeping activities.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. This is the annual report of the EU High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. The report highlights the growing instability in the Union's neighbourhood and stresses that the Union must become a credible player on the international stage. To achieve this, the Union's foreign policy must be based on a common vision of Europe's interests, values and objectives. For the Union to weigh in on the international scene in general and on its neighbourhood in particular, it is crucial that all the policies of the Union and its Member States move in the same direction. Consistency is the key if Europe is to weigh in on the world.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This annual report by the Union High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy once again demonstrates the Union's submission to a globalist dogma and supreme command of the United States via NATO. To this end, the report is very clearly "anti-Russian" with the desire of the Union and all Member States to speak with one voice in order to condemn the Putin regime. The report also aims to destroy the very essence of nation states by denying their sovereignty even in foreign policy. Finally, there is mention of a 'single market for 'cybersecurity' products, a single market that leads us towards ever more European federalism and the erasure of borders for the benefit of large multinationals and the world of finance.  So I voted against this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not share the positions supported in this report. The text is full of good proposals, which we already know will remain so and forgets, as is all too often the case, the real needs of our citizens and businesses. The EU persists in its anti-Russian positions, reiterating its support for the sanctions imposed, when it is now clear to everyone the devastating impact they have had on SMEs and agriculture in Veneto and Italy. For all these reasons, I did not intend to support this text with my vote.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have voted against the report. In short, the report is a strategy for building the United States of Europe with a common foreign policy, militarisation, NATO link age and confrontation on the agenda.  The EU claims to be a 'peace project'. This report shows a completely different direction. That is why I have voted against the report.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The Annual Report takes stock of the most important developments in the CFSP area over the past year, in terms of its institutional structure and horizontal issues such as human rights, non-proliferation, the spread of EU values and its main geographical areas: enlargement, transatlantic relations, relations with Russia, EU neighbourhood, the Middle East and Asia. The report, with broad agreement between the PPE, S&D, ALDE and Verts/ALE Groups, takes a tough line on Russia's actions in relation to Ukraine and a balanced approach to the Middle East peace process, with an emphasis on the two-state solution. They also highlight the need to focus on the fight against IS and address the growing challenges arising from the state's failure in Syria, Iraq, Libya and the Sahel. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because an effective foreign policy of the European Union must be based on a common understanding of europe's fundamental interests, values and objectives, in the development of foreign relations and a common understanding of the threats facing the EU as a whole. Thus, the main tasks of the EU's foreign and security policy are to protect European values and interests, as well as to consolidate the political and legal framework in Europe, thereby restoring and ensuring peace and stability. It is also essential to improve the EU's contribution to the territorial defence of its Member States and to the security of its citizens by strengthening its ability to defend itself against the risks it faces, including terrorism, arms trafficking, drugs and trafficking in human beings. It is also necessary to support security, democratisation, the rule of law and economic and social development in the EU's neighbourhood. The European Parliament considers it necessary to strengthen and consolidate the political, economic, financial and defence resources of the European Union and its Member States in order to maximise the EU's influence in the world, to create synergies and ensure peace and stability in Europe and its neighbouring countries.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In recent years, Europe has been faced with an ever-changing political environment and an increasingly difficult management of security problems, both inside and outside the Territory of the Union. Europe therefore needs more than ever to consolidate its role in defending its citizens and supporting democratic processes in neighbouring areas. In the report that I voted for, the need for renewed and coherent management of migratory flows best summarises these two challenges, calling, on the one hand, for greater support for the countries hosting asylum seekers and, on the other, for a strengthening of regional protection programmes in crisis areas. We are well aware that, in foreign policy, European countries often prefer bilateral solutions and pursue different priorities and interests, making it very difficult to plan civil and military missions jointly in crisis areas. In reiterating the need for a joint effort to deepen and consolidate the common European security and defence policy, we must ensure that cooperation with our partners, and in particular with NATO, is designed to achieve an increasingly integrated decision-making process that will make it possible to avoid dispersion of resources.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted yes since I agree with the content of my colleague's report and retain that the figure of the High Representative should be strengthened in order to reinforce the credibility of the European Union.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. The annual report of the European Union's High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy makes a simple observation: the Union is fully aligned with the interests of the United States and NATO. Indeed, the report proposes to unify the "voices" of member states against Vladimir Putin's Russia and to continue the enlargement of the European Union to the east. Moreover, it wants to strengthen the vassalisation of the foreign policy of the Member States to that of the Union "in a spirit of loyalty". The totalitarianism of the technocrats in Brussels has no limit when it comes to obeying the interests of the United States with servility. In this case, it threatens the sovereignty of Member States in the conduct of their foreign policy.  I obviously voted against these motions for a resolution.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. The annual report takes stock of the most important developments in the CFSP and deals with human rights, non-proliferation of arms and the spread of EU values. It also analyses and geographical issues on the main areas of the CFSP: enlargement, transatlantic relations, relations with Russia, the EU neighbourhood, the Middle East and Asia. This report has been agreed, with broad agreement between the four political groups in Parliament: PPE, S&D, ALDE and Verts/ALE. It is clearly positioned on Russia's actions in relation to Ukraine, and in relation to the Middle East emphasizes the two-state solution. It stresses the need to focus on the fight against ISIS and address the growing challenges arising from the state's failure in Syria, Iraq, Libya and the Sahel. The Socialists and Democrats have had a broad influence on the drafting of the report through the compromise amendments that have been agreed.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The Lisbon Treaty has given the European Union a new dimension in foreign policy. The High Representative is responsible for defining a common foreign and security policy for all Member States. I welcome his work and also note the various efforts to be made to optimize this function. However, the ongoing conflicts at the Union's borders, both eastern and southern, once again demonstrate the need for European countries to speak with one voice. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the annual report of the High Representative of the European Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy in the European Parliament. The crisis in Ukraine and the events in Paris have called for the stability and security of the European Union to unprecedented levels. Furthermore, also because of the current economic climate, the European Union has not shown itself capable of using its full potential to define the international political and security context. The lack of coordination and policy coherence between EU policies has further limited Europe's influence in the world.  In order to be seen as a credible player, the European Union must therefore have an ambitious and effective common foreign policy, based on a shared vision of the objectives. There is also a need for a new European security strategy, taking into account recent geopolitical changes. Only through the full sharing of information between member states' intelligence and increased cooperation with the countries of the Middle East and North Africa will the European Union be able to respond effectively to the new challenges and ensure both the security of its citizens.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Union's foreign policy really needs to be strengthened, as was evident during the Ukraine crisis, which was, in fact, managed by Merkel and Hollande, rather than by the High Representative.  Furthermore, the idea of a European army relaunched by President Juncker is part of the logic of a single European voice, but everything will depend on the real political will of the States to give the EU the opportunity to distinguish itself with its own voice.  This could be an opportunity to finally have autonomy in the field of foreign policy and to speak with one voice in bodies such as NATO, which is not the case today.

name: Jean-Marie Cavada (ALDE)
text: In writing. Although I largely agree with Mr Brok's report, I preferred to abstain on the final vote.  Of course, this report outlines an ambitious foreign policy for the Union, adapted to current and future challenges, including terrorism, irregular immigration and energy security. I also welcome the condemnation of the Russian military intervention in Ukraine and the reaffirmation of a common strategy towards Russia contained in this report.   However, I do not find in Mr Brok's text the commitment to the freeze on EU membership made by Mr Juncker last July. A pause in the process of eu enlargement is necessary.  The wave of accessions in 2004 and Croatia's accession in 2013 have considerably complicated the functioning of the Union.  Moreover, the Commission's pre-accession aid instrument (IAP) represents a considerable windfall of money that would be preferable to use in order to consolidate Europe's achievements at 28.  At present, therefore, it seems preferable to focus on finalising institutional adaptation to previous accessions and on the internal issues facing the Union.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. A report that shows the european Union's willingness to champion a "world order" under the leadership of NATO and the United States. It is therefore no coincidence that the text is fiercely and blindly anti-Russian, but above all perfectly totalitarian in its vision of democracy, since the Member States are called upon to adulate the Union's foreign policy with one voice and without possible discussion. For European oligarchs, the UNION's foreign policy should be aimed only at enlargement; enlargement of European leviathan at all costs, without taking into account the realities and interests of Member States or even those of third countries. I therefore refused to participate in this great mass of the world government that the European Union celebrates as the vassal of the United States.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I stress the vital importance of nato's collective defence. I think it is important to remember that the EU has an obligation to ensure that its external action is designed and implemented in order to consolidate and support democracy, the rule of law, human rights and the principles of international law. I also maintain that the Member States are called upon fully to improve their ability to contribute to territorial defence as a matter of urgency. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution because it promotes a shared view of foreign affairs and security policy and provides a common perception of threats against the EU as a whole. Recent terrorist attacks in EU countries have shown that it is increasingly difficult to separate internal and external security, and I believe that the Eu ropean Union's Member States and institutions must step up the sharing of security-related intelligence. I also hope that cooperation in the fight against terrorism will be strengthened in the EU's relations with the countries of the Middle East and North Africa.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. This report clearly demonstrates the importance of developing a coherent foreign policy and security policy based on a common vision of interests, values and objectives. Moreover, it advocates an integrated approach that understands the various policies with external impact. I share this view and i believe it is essential, also in line with what this report has advocated, that the Union does not need to aspire to an influence role in the definition of international policy. It should also be noted that the report clearly highlights the importance of a strong foreign policy for an effective immigration policy. It underlines the urgency of resonating the tragedy that is going on at the gates of Europe, specifically on the central and eastern borders of the Mediterranean.  For all this, I supported the adoption of this report.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ An ambitious and effective EU foreign policy needs to be based on a shared vision of key European interest where the EU is a credible actor. Priority tasks for EU foreign policy are particularly protecting European values and interests and enforcing the political and legal order in Europe, thereby restoring and safeguarding peace and stability, supporting security, democratisation, the rule of law and economic and social development in the EU’s neighbourhood. I welcome the report from the High Representative and I am concerned that the EU has so far not been able to use its full potential to shape the international political and security environment. To the objectives of the motion for a resolution we need a higher level in policy coordination and coherence between EU policies.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote against because I consider the role played by the High Representative of the European Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy to be totally inadequate. We cannot help noticing the anomalies in your report. There is talk of a strengthening of the EU's foreign policy, but then, in concrete terms, it is inconsistent. Emblematic was the case of the Minsk agreement last February to sign the truce between Russia and Ukraine in which the EU ambassadors were Merkel and Hollande. There is no trace of the High Representative. There is talk of ever closer cooperation with the USA and NATO, as if their influence were not already abandoned, as well as harmful. An inconsistent foreign policy that has helped fuel hotbeds of war around the world.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it insists on the militaristic drift of the European Union, advocates closer cooperation between the EU and the Atlantic Alliance and supports the fusion of internal and external security. In the proposal for a vote, elements which I consider essential to support any initiative related to the Common Security and Defence Policy, such as progress towards nuclear disarmament at the global level, strict support and development of international law in all EU military activities and the separation of civil and military actions, were absent.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report is an annual account of the work done by the office of the High Representative of the European Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. Federica Mogherini took over this role from Catherine Ashton in 2014. The report states that Europe is facing a changed political and security environment, especially in its immediate neighbourhood. However it also portrays the EU as a credible actor with an ambitious and effective EU foreign policy. But most importantly the report speaks about the need to support security and stabilisation in the southern neighbourhood of the EU, the region which is most relevant to Malta. It claims that the EU’s instruments and resources should support the building of functioning and inclusive states capable of delivering security for their citizens, promoting democracy and confronting religious extremism. It also points to the unused potential of cross-border trade within the region. Finally, it insists on close cooperation with the authorities of the countries concerned on managing migration flows while respecting human rights. As this report acknowledges the changed reality, especially in the Mediterranean area, and pushes for more attention to the needs of the region, therefore, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report presents an assessment of The Common European Foreign and Security Policy. I am convinced that, in the context of the deterioration of the Union's security environment on its eastern and southern borders, the european Union's influence in the world must be the first priority of an effective common foreign and security policy. As such, it is necessary for the Union to commit itself to supporting its eastern neighbours and containing Russia, to strengthening security and stabilisation in the south and to increasing its resources in the service of these objectives. While the last few months have sometimes shown a lack of coordination of the Union's external policies, I consider that this report presents a precise and sharp analysis of the situation and avenues for improvement as well as the reforms to be undertaken. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. This annual report looks at the European Union's foreign policy and the actions of the High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. The European Union is expected to play an increasingly important role on the international stage in the coming years and, as a representative of the peoples of Europe, it is important that the European Parliament decides on the broad outlines of its foreign policy. For example, I supported an amendment calling for greater transparency in the negotiations with the United States on the Transatlantic Free Trade Treaty. On the other hand, I did not wish to support certain paragraphs concerning sanctions applied to Russia. Concerned, however, that international law should be applied in our relations with third countries, I consider that the choice of some very strong terms in this report concerning that country is not likely to ease existing tensions.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament today discussed in plenary the policy of the EU High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. Mr Brok's report contains statements to which we can only agree, particularly on the issue of Russia and Ukraine.  However, we deplore the fact that on the issue of enlargement, the new political direction of the President of the European Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, who pledged last July to freeze new accessions, is not taken into account. The European Union needs to pause its enlargement process in order to consolidate what has been achieved at 28. That is why, in line with our commitments made during the European election campaign, the French delegation of the ALDE group chose to abstain on the final vote.

name: Diane Dodds (NI)
text: in writing. ‒ As an MEP for Northern Ireland, I have seen at first hand the vital role played by our armed forces in keeping our people and our communities safe from terrorism and other threats to security. I am immensely proud of our servicemen and women, who make so many sacrifices and put themselves on the line to serve their country both at home and abroad. And that this why it saddens me when I see reports such as this one calling for a pooling of resources, a coordination of defence budgets and most unhelpful of all – a permanent military operational headquarters in Europe.  National governments must retain complete sovereignty over matters of national security. This means spending of at least 2 % of GDP on defence. It means the capacity to develop new and advanced defence technologies without intrusion or limit.  Of course, there does remain room and indeed a need for cooperation between EU Member States and further afield. The international coalition formed to fight ISIS is indicative of this. However, this does not in any way strengthen the argument that we would be best served by an integrated, federalist and diluted defence agenda.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. This report is ideologically oriented, with the emphasis on enhanced global integration and governance. It clearly outlines the will of a world government under the aegis of NATO and the United States, even though not all MEMBER States of the Union are members of NATO, and a genuine centralism that goes against the sovereignty of the Member States. They are obliged to "actively and unreservedly support the Union's foreign and security policy in a spirit of loyalty". In particular, it aims to establish a single cyber security market, dominated by a single global authority, in which the European Union is the only lackey of the United States. So I voted against this report.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Dear Colleagues, I abstained on my colleague Brock's report on the annual report of the High Representative of the European Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy to the European Parliament. I believe that the report has its strengths, such as those of the threat coming from Islamic State, the situation in Ukraine, and the serious terrorist threats faced by many EU Member States.  On the other hand, however, I cannot help but note that the report drawn generalised conclusions which in no way contribute to the development of the common security and protection policy of the European Union and its Member States.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against this report as it seeks to strengthen EU-NATO ties.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. The annual report for 2014 reports a worsening of the security environment around the EU, especially in the Countries of the European Neighbourhood Policy. At the same time, it is known that "the international order based on the law, stability and security of Europe is challenged to an unprecedented level since the beginning of the process of European integration". In addition, the lack of coordination in EU security and defence policies, diminishing Europe's influence in the world "and its ability to assert itself as a guarantor of global security." The report calls for a policy based on a common vision of European interests, values and objectives, improving self-defence capacity to deal with growing unconventional external threats. The role of the ENP in the primacy of law and economic development on the periphery of the EU is welcomed, as well as democratisation and peacekeeping actions under the Common Security and Defence Policy. I support an EU as a more credible and conflict-solving actor, both in its immediate and global neighbourhood, as well as to mirror european values of human dignity and the rule of law in the world.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The security environment around the EU has been deteriorating, with Europe's stability and security constantly being challenged to an unprecedented level. I cannot fail to express my concern, also very much by the internal crisis, that the EU has not yet been able to use its full potential to find a more favourable political environment and international security that is more in line with European values. It is important for me to protect European values and interests and to implement the political and legal order in Europe, improving its contribution to the territorial defence of its Member States and the security of its citizens. The EU must also play an important role in conflict resolution and strengthen, together with partners, the pluralistic and rules-based global political, economic and financial order, including respect for the rule of law and human rights.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. This report is in the image of its author: irresponsible. Indeed, in addition to the frontal attack on the sovereignty of States in foreign policy, this report underlines "the obligation taken by Member States in the ratification of the Treaty on the European Union to actively and unreservedly support the Union's foreign and security policy in a spirit of loyalty". Mr Brok wants a Manichaean Europe where "the good" would be the United States and its vassal the European Union, and "evil", Russia. Such a vision only leads to chaos. I note that my colleagues from the UMPS voted for this report. Which says a lot about their adventurism in diplomatic matters.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This report assumes that the security of the EU and its Member States and neighbouring countries is being called into question by Russia and that a transformation of the global political order is taking place. According to the report, the EU has not been able to act appropriately due to the lack of political coordination and lack of coherence between EU policies, but also due to financial constraints. It stresses that it is necessary to provide the EU and the Member States with defence capability and to deepen the Common Security and Defence Policy with NATO. Read: deepening the militarisation of the EU. Obviously we voted against it. We reject the EU as an imperialist political-military bloc, whose so-called 'foreign' policy responds to the economic objectives of the great European capital and the main imperialist powers of the continent, creating better conditions for the appropriation of markets, resources and trade routes.  Democratic ruptures are needed in the EU, a process of demilitarisation and disarmament is needed, the dissolution of NATO and the creation of a collective security system that respects and ensures the sovereignty of states and the free choice of peoples.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ If the European Union wants to play a key role in world political action, it must have an ambitious and effective foreign policy. However, this should be based on a common vision of common European interests, values and objectives in external relations and on a common perception of threats affecting the whole of the European Union. The dramatically deteriorating security environment near the Borders of the European Union, for example in the Slovak Republic's neighbourhood in Ukraine, points to an ongoing transformation of the global political order. This is also accompanied by an internal crisis, especially the terrorist attacks of recent times. Last but not least, the network of European councils and delegations around the world must also be strengthened and modernised to reflect the European Union's foreign policy needs in the 21st century.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report which continues the absurd policy of sanctions against Russia, which hopes that Turkey will resume its path to EU membership more actively and convincingly, which promotes TTIP and many other points that I completely disagree with.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against this report as a whole, because it seeks to strengthen EU-NATO ties.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the Annual Report from the High Representative of the European Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy to the European Parliament. I did so because it contains a deeply worrying reference to an EU military HQ. NATO is the cornerstone of our defence policy and I do not believe that the EU should have any role in defence matters.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The annual report takes stock of the most important developments in the realm of the CFSP over the last year, in terms of the institutional set-up of the CFSP, horizontal issues, such as human rights, non-proliferation and the spread of EU values and geographical issues concerning the main areas of the CFSP: enlargement, transatlantic relations, relations with Russia, the EU neighbourhood, the Middle East and Asia. The report is a consensual one, with broad agreement between the four political groups: EPP, S&D, ALDE and Greens. The report takes a hard line on Russia’s actions vis-a-vis Ukraine and a balanced approach to the Middle East peace process, with an emphasis on the two-state solution. The need to focus on the fight against ISIS and address the mounting challenges stemming from state failure in Syria, Iraq, Libya and the Sahel are also stressed. I consequently supported the adoption of the report in the plenary.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Recent geopolitical events in the EU's immediate neighbourhood and in more remote areas raise the well-founded need to review our common foreign policy.  We must state that financial constraints and a lack of cooperation threaten Europe's role in international peacekeeping, both at regional and global level.  We therefore need a more coordinated, stronger common foreign policy, a common European Security Strategy capable of responding effectively to new challenges. We must act unitedly in areas such as the fight against terrorism, migration or energy policy.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. There is no doubt that in the last year EU security has worsened considerably, especially in our nearest area of influence. The EU has not adequately developed its role on the international stage, so further coordination and integration must be made to enable us to respond to the dimension of the challenges ahead and to take leadership in conflict resolution. We must fully exploit the lisbon Treaty's possibilities in foreign policy, as well as strengthen cooperation in the fight against terrorism in the context of the EU's relations with countries in the Middle East and North Africa.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. The annual report takes stock of the most important developments in the CFSP and deals with human rights, non-proliferation of arms and the spread of EU values. It also analyses and geographical issues on the main areas of the CFSP: enlargement, transatlantic relations, relations with Russia, the EU neighbourhood, the Middle East and Asia. This report has been agreed, with broad agreement between the four political groups in Parliament: PPE, S&D, ALDE and Verts/ALE. It is clearly positioned on Russia's actions in relation to Ukraine, and in relation to the Middle East emphasizes the two-state solution. It stresses the need to focus on the fight against ISIS and address the growing challenges arising from the state's failure in Syria, Iraq, Libya and the Sahel. The Socialists and Democrats have had a broad influence on the drafting of the report through the compromise amendments that have been agreed.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. The annual report takes stock of the most important developments in the CFSP and deals with human rights, non-proliferation of arms and the spread of EU values. It also analyses and geographical issues on the main areas of the CFSP: enlargement, transatlantic relations, relations with Russia, the EU neighbourhood, the Middle East and Asia. This report has been agreed, with broad agreement between the four political groups in Parliament: PPE, S&D, ALDE and Verts/ALE.
