It is clearly positioned on Russia's actions in relation to Ukraine, and in relation to the Middle East emphasizes the two-state solution. It stresses the need to focus on the fight against ISIS and address the growing challenges arising from the state's failure in Syria, Iraq, Libya and the Sahel. The Socialists and Democrats have had a broad influence on the drafting of the report through the compromise amendments that have been agreed.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against the annual report on foreign affairs and security policy, which shows that the European Union is moving further away from the ideal of peace that had animated it at its origins. This report promotes a new world order under the aegis of NATO and the United States. This Atlanticist policy is expressed in particular by an increasingly caricatured anti-Russian policy, the sad results of which can currently be seen in Ukraine. To promote this Atlanticist policy, the report also calls on European states to speak with one voice, that is, to give up their foreign policy sovereignty to the benefit of the European institutions. This transfer of sovereignty itself justifies the rejection of this report.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. In itself, the rapporteur's Atlanticist tropism alone, which makes NATO the only possible and desirable framework for defending the Member States of the European Union, would have been enough to motivate my negative vote. Or the conviction, which runs through the text, that the diplomatic and security interests of the European Union transcend those of each of its members. However, I will dwell on section 29. It states that the 'European legal order', which the rapporteur intends to preserve and strengthen, 'is based on respect for human rights, the rights of minorities and fundamental freedoms, sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity of States, as well as the peaceful resolution of conflicts'. In this case, the first action to be taken is to dissolve the European Union! For what about the sovereignty of Member States subject to a litany of regulations that dictate their budgets and policies? What about the fundamental rights of the Greeks under the tutelage of the troika? What about the territorial integrity of Serbia amputee of Kosovo with the complicity of Europe from Brussels? What about the participation of European states in the Yugoslav, Iraqi, Afghan, Libyan and possibly Syrian conflicts, not to mention the role of the European Union in the Ukraine crisis?

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against the Brok report as the Brok report insists that the political, economic, financial and defence resources of the European Union and its Member States must be combined in order to maximise the Union's geostrategic influence to make it a key political player on the world board. To this end, it establishes the subordination of all strategic policies under the CFSP/CSDP and explicitly requests the increase of resources for defense-related issues. We therefore vote against it as the report does not reflect the EU's negative position on conflicts in neighbouring countries (both those in the South and Eastern countries); the report does not focus on peaceful conflict resolution; defends the geopolitical nature of TTE, does not refer to the separation between EU policy and NATO policy, nor does it refer to the separation of civilian actions by the military in the field of security policy and Union cooperation.

name: Nathalie Griesbeck (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament today discussed in plenary session the policy of the EU High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. Mr Brok's report contains statements to which I can only agree, particularly on the issue of Russia and Ukraine. However, I regret that on the issue of enlargement the new policy direction of the President of the European Commission, Jean-Claude JUNCKER, which committed last July to a freeze on new accessions is not taken into account. The Union needs to take a break from its enlargement process in order to consolidate what has been achieved at 28. That is why, in line with our commitments made during the European campaign, the French delegation of the ALDE group chose to abstain on the final vote.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The annual report takes stock of the most important developments in the realm of the Common Foreign Security Policy (CFSP) over the last year, in terms of the institutional set-up of the CFSP, horizontal issues, such as human rights, non-proliferation and the spread of EU values and geographical issues concerning the main areas of the CFSP: enlargement, transatlantic relations, relations with Russia, the EU neighbourhood, the Middle East and Asia. I abstained from the vote on this report as it recommends setting up an EU standing army, which I oppose

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is important that the EU continues to demonstrate its position on the key security issues facing the world. We are currently at an important moment in global security policy and it is important that the EU and its Member States coordinates closely to protect European values and establish its potential as a global player.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against it as the Brok report insists that the political, economic, financial and defence resources of the European Union and its Member States must be combined in order to maximise the Union's geostrategic influence to make it a key political player on the world board. To this end, it establishes the subordination of all strategic policies under the CFSP/CSDP and explicitly requests the increase of resources for defense-related issues. We therefore vote against it as the report does not reflect the EU's negative position on conflicts in neighbouring countries (both those in the South and Eastern countries); the report does not focus on peaceful conflict resolution; defends the geopolitical nature of TTE, does not refer to the separation between EU policy and NATO policy, nor does it refer to the separation of civilian actions by the military in the field of security policy and Union cooperation.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the High Representative's annual report on foreign affairs and security policy, bearing in mind the great trials and challenges facing the European Union. The security environment has deteriorated, there is an ISIS problem, with attempts to export terrorism and endanger EU citizens. War is being waged on the territory of Ukraine, and relations with Russia have deteriorated. The EU has a problem aligning common positions and consistency in implementing adopted positions. The problem is also the lack of flexibility of the Union financial system given the dynamics of developments on the ground. Foreign policy is increasingly linked to EU domestic policies. In the same way, external and internal security should be taken into account. The EU needs to be made a credible participant in international processes, the network of EU delegations needs to be modernised. It is imperative to maintain the achieved degree of security and stability and the European political and legal order.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. This report is the result of the ideology that unfortunately drives the European institutions, all too often behind the foreign policy of the United States and NATO, even though several Member States are not part of the Atlantic Alliance. Member States are obliged to "actively and unreservedly support the Union's foreign and security policy in a spirit of loyalty". They would therefore lose their foreign policy sovereignty to what was decided in Brussels, in the sole interest of the European Union, to the rescue or support - too often - of the United States. I voted against this report.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Given the fact that the security environment has rapidly deteriorated, especially in Europe’s immediate neighbourhood, I am supportive of the key messages delivered in the Parliament’s resolution on the High Representative’s Annual Report. On-going violence needs to stop. The EU should play an active role in preserving European values and freedoms, the rule of law and democracy. At the same time, we should keep providing support for our partners in order to encourage development and to avoid open conflicts.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Elmar Brok's report on the european Union High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy's annual report in the European Parliament. This report takes stock of European action on foreign affairs, particularly with regard to the management of the Ukraine crisis and European sanctions against Russia. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ EH Bildu has voted against report as it insists that political, economic, financial and defence resources of the EU and Member States must be combined in order to maximise the EU’s geostrategic influence and unleash its full potential as a global player, at the same time that it promotes the subordination of all strategic policy areas under CFSP/CSDP and demands increased resources for defence and military. Furthermore the report advocates further militarisation of the EU, stronger EU-NATO cooperation and supports the merge of internal and external security. EH Bildu is an anti-militaristic coalition that strongly opposes the figure of NATO, hence since that starting point we are unable to support it. Moreover, we object it because it does not reflect EU’s negative and escalating role regarding the current conflict in the southern and eastern EU-neighbourhood. It speaks of peaceful conflict solution but focuses at the same time on boosting permanent structured cooperation and it promotes TTIP and its geopolitical character. Instead of these, we demand no military funding from EU-budget; all activities to be strictly within UN Charter and International Law; a civilian EU with strict civil peaceful approaches to conflict solutions; and a strict separation of EU from NATO.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I believe that the EU is facing an environment characterised by changes in policy and security and I believe that an ambitious and effective EU foreign policy needs to be based on a common vision of key European interests, values and objectives in external relations, as well as a common understanding of the threats affecting the EU as a whole.  We are in the midst of a dramatic deterioration of the security environment around the EU and I believe that the political, economic, financial and defence resources of the EU and its Member States must be strengthened and combined in order to maximise the EU's global influence, create synergies and ensure peace and stability in Europe and its neighbouring countries.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I agree with large parts of the report, as it argues that the EU has yet to unleash its full potential to shape the international and security environment and needs a more proactive and credible foreign policy, based on a joint perception of interests and threats. However, the report calls for the establishment of an EU permanent military operational headquarters, which could lead to creation of an EU army. I do not agree with this, I therefore abstained from voting on the report.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. It is true that the A8-0039/2015 report contains many correct points, in particular the commitment to NATO and the importance of own territorial defence of the nation states. The report also rightly emphasises the need to combat international terrorism, which takes various forms. However, I consider Articles 33 to 36 to be problematic. These sections point to the need for good relations between Russia and the EU. However, they see Russia as solely responsible. Although I see Russia as having a special responsibility, nothing should be done at the moment that could set in motion a verbal spiral of armament and, ultimately, an escalation spiral. Russia should be brought back to the negotiating table, avoiding major loss of face. It would be important to keep open the possibility of regaining Russia as a partner of the EU in the medium term.  That is why I shall abstain from the vote.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – The report is highly debatable in both its content and its editing, so I could not support it. The European Union External Action Service is one of the EU's veterinary horses, which faces a number of challenges, both in terms of professionalism, direction and other aspects. The greatest threats to the future of our continent and to our citizens in the context of the activities of the External Action Service are that it has not acted against the escalation of war conflicts in the EU's eastern and southern neighbourhoods. Negotiations on TTIP could also cause serious problems.

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: in writing. In adopting this resolution, we reaffirm the need to have a strong and effective common foreign policy, in support of human rights, based on the founding values of peace of the European Union. By calling for a genuine common defence policy, this House is not supporting a arms race but, on the contrary, rationalising and reducing military expenditure, reducing the budgets of individual Member States in this regard.  Our values, on which the rules of our coexistence are based, are the real antidote to an aggressive foreign policy. In this vote, this House further underlines the importance of relations with the African continent, given the insecurity that has repercussions in the North, up to the southern borders of the Union and the South, to the geopolitical balance of sub-Saharan Africa. We can no longer tolerate the loss of human life close to our borders.  That is why the management of migration issues must be integrated into the Union's external action, which alone can adopt an effective response.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I welcome the annual report of the EU High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy to the European Parliament, as it encourages the EU and the Member States to take a proactive stance in implementing an EU foreign and security policy that can continue to effectively protect the integrity of its citizens.  Indeed, the transformation of the world political order and the recent crises risk making the EU more vulnerable to certain serious phenomena, which could undermine the stability and security of the entire European continent.  That is why we must work with great effort and in a coordinated way to protect the security of all European citizens.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. The foreign policy outlined in the Brok report is first and foremost a matter of inconsistency and refusal to accept the Union's missteps in this area. This text underlines that international relations on the European continent have deteriorated, particularly between the partners of the Union's neighbourhood policy and Russia. Added to this is the clearly expressed desire to strengthen the transatlantic alliance within the framework of NATO, while promoting security and defence cooperation between Member States.   However, relations between Russia and the Union have largely deteriorated as a result of the Union's lack of independence from the United States. As a watermark, the report expresses a certain distrust of Russia under the guise of a strategy of security and energy independence. Finally, the report presented to Parliament defends the weakening of state sovereignty by seeking to accelerate supranational and global political integration. The defence of the single market, particularly in the area of cyber security, clearly appears to be the linchpin of the confiscation of the freedoms of nations and peoples. Considering all of these dangers, I voted against this report.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 The Annual Report of the High Representative contains a number of important and reasonably formulated objectives and measures to support a more effective internal policy of the Union. I personally regard Mr Brok's report as a competently prepared document, addressing the current challenges in matters of peace, security, respect for human rights, Community values and fundamental economic interests of the EU. The resolution is geographically balanced, the Union is not passive in view of important developments and political developments on different continents, in particular events in Ukraine, Russia's politics and NATO. The presence and participation in the debate of High Representative Mogherini reinforces the value of this report.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. In the face of the growing instability in recent years at the borders of the European Union, I have stressed that from the EU we do not want to fight but prefer to cooperate and convince. Europe faces the period of greatest threats and challenges in its recent history: security, failed states and conflicts in both the Eastern and Southern Neighbourhoods. It is therefore necessary to strengthen our internal cooperation between States, Intelligence and Diplomacy and to expand our resolute influence abroad, renewing our neighbourhood policy.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it insists on the militaristic drift of the European Union, advocates closer cooperation between the EU and the Atlantic Alliance and supports the fusion of internal and external security. In the proposal for a vote, elements which I consider essential to support any initiative related to the Common Security and Defence Policy, such as progress towards nuclear disarmament at the global level, strict support and development of international law in all EU military activities and the separation of civil and military actions, were absent.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ MEP Brok's annual report on the European Union's foreign and security policy points out that the Union has failed to use its power to shape an international environment that has deteriorated drastically due to the internal crisis.  The Union's priority is to create a foreign policy based on its key interests, values and objectives. Financial instability and constraints prevent rapid responses to crises. Poor cooperation with third countries and a lack of consistency and harmonisation of Member States create an obstacle to achieving the union's foreign and security policy objectives.  The Commission is asked to be more active in strategic planning and operational action and to create a comprehensive policy strategy to address new threats and challenges, taking into account global change.  Recent terrorist attacks, conflicts in Ukraine, but also in the Middle East, have a major impact on the security of our citizens and threaten the interests of the Union. We need to take a clear position on important topics such as terrorism, migration, energy security and relations towards Russia, the eastern and southern neighbourhoods.  I support the rapporteur's views on the Annual Report of the High Representative of the European Union, Frederic Mogherini, which aims to warn against the lack of an effective union response in crisis situations. It is important to develop coordinated cooperation strategies and partnerships within the Union and with non-member states as soon as possible in order to strengthen security and promote democracy and human rights.

name: Ramona Nicole Mănescu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report for the following reasons: the security situation around the European Union is increasingly serious, both in the east, with regard to Ukraine and Russia, and in the south, where terrorism is developing alarmingly. This is a serious challenge for the Union's foreign policy. We must respond effectively and strategically, without losing sight of the defence of Central European values. Everything we do must strengthen democracy and the rule of law, as well as human rights for all. I believe that the European Union has a vital role to play in supporting peace and stability in the Middle East. Religious extremism and terror not only cost thousands of lives in Syria, Iraq and other areas, but also increase the threat to their own national security.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: writing – An unstable social, economic, political situation, coupled with ideological and religious intolerance, especially in the developing countries of the world, threatens security not only in the Member States of the European Union, but also throughout Europe. The fight against terrorism, tackling the influx of refugees into the European Union, arms control, energy security and the need to increase the defence capacity of the Member States are only part of a number of problems that the European Union urgently needs to address in the interests of its security. The protection of European values, democracy, legality, peaceful stability, as well as an interest in the political and legal order throughout the Union require the European Union to be more actively involved in international problem-solving and to become an important partner with clear visions and messages. To do this, it is necessary to create all economic, political and legal preconditions.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report because, among other things, I totally disagree with the EU's foreign policy on Turkey and Skopje.  Although Turkey systematically violates international law towards Greece and Cyprus and refuses to abide by the terms and conditions of its pre-accession course, the EU has not taken drastic measures against Turkey until it complies with its international obligations towards Greece and Cyprus. On the contrary, the EU constantly rewards Turkey's illegal attitude and encourages the import into the Union of Turkish agricultural products, which are economically affecting Greek and Cypriot farmers.  For Skopje, which Greece does not recognise as an entity, the EU, instead of condemning Skopje's provocative and unsymotic attitude towards Greece expressed by the counterfeiting of history and the burning of the name of our Macedonia, is looking for ways to integrate the EU in the future, which finds me vertically opposed. Let the EU leadership know that the Greek people will not accept the name of our Macedonia from Skopje. Nor is it the name of Skopje to accept a complex name by any geographical designation.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. Vote against this resolution. This report is, after all, very ideological and is only an anti-Russian litany. Moreover, it is an attack on the sovereignty of Member States in terms of foreign and defence policy, which we oppose.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The current transformation of the political order, worldwide, has made the European Union particularly vulnerable to phenomena such as terrorism, arms and drug trafficking, and trafficking in human beings. Recognising the seriousness of such a framework, I have decided to support mr Brok's report, a document which encourages the Community institutions and the Member States to take a proactive stance in defining a Community foreign and security policy, designed to preserve the security of European citizens.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Union is facing a complicated security scenario, in the face of recent developments which have put the threats we are living on the table again, as Mr Elmar Brok points out in his report on the activity of the European Union's High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. I agree, and that is why my support for the proposal, that the EU has yet to exploit its full foreign policy potential, and here we must be more proactive, credible and strategic.  We need to work harder to meet challenges such as the situation in Ukraine or the growing terrorist threat highlighted by recent attacks in Paris and Copenhagen. This requires improving internal procedures and structures in the EU that will enable us to defend our democratic values and make an important real contribution to the consolidation of the international order.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. I voted against the annual report of the High Representative of the European Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, as I believe it is a clear breach of the neutrality of my Member State, Austria. I cannot support the report's demands, such as the subordination of all CFSP/CSDP strategic policies, the provision of more resources for defence and the military, the militarisation of the EU and closer cooperation between the EU and NATO. The common foreign and security policy may certainly be a cornerstone of the European Union, but not at the expense of the foreign and security sovereignty of the Member States.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Already in the vote in a parliamentary committee, this report on the common foreign and security policy was not brilliant, it is now reaching new heights. I am opposed to the principle that the Union should 'speak with one voice' on these issues, to the detriment of the sovereign positions of the Member States. A fortiori if the given frame is this. The report once again attacks Russia, even if it means "supporting political parties" financially. Neighbourhood policy is therefore just another tool against Russia. In this context, the report calls for all its political, financial and defensive resources to be combined with the bellicose organization that is NATO. To top it all off, it unconditionally supports the Great Trans-Atlantic Market and aligns itself with all U.S. policy internationally, the "essential strategic partner of the Union".  It is a fine example of all that we must denounce in one text. I welcome the overzealousness of the Chairman of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, of which I am a member, and rapporteur on this issue. I'm voting against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I generally agree with the neighbourhood policies advocated in it.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it highlights the necessity for a coherent EU migration policy and the need to address the root causes of irregular migration. The report also focuses on the fact that migration management should become a key part and priority of EU external action and its cooperation with neighbours to prevent more loss of life at the EU’s borders.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. In view of the security threats facing the European Union on a daily basis and the importance of good foreign policy management, a new European strategy is needed in some respects. Indeed, it is essential to deploy the Union's political, economic and financial resources in order to strengthen the defences of the Member States and to make the common security and defence policy more effective. In addition, the lack of coordination and coherence that characterizes the various EU policies must be overcome. Europe must continue to assert itself on the world stage, not least through greater support for its southern neighbours, but also, more generally, in the resolution of the various world conflicts.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Annual Report from the High Representative of the European Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy to the European Parliament, that takes stock of the most important developments in the realm of the CFSP over the last year, in terms of the institutional set-up of the CFSP, horizontal issues such as human rights, non-proliferation and the spread of EU values and geographical issues concerning the main areas of the CFSP: enlargement, transatlantic relations, and relations with Russia, the EU neighbourhood, the Middle East and Asia.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The strong ideas of the report are: (1) the need for unity, especially in the face of crises such as the Ukrainian one; (2) support for Ukraine, Moldova, Georgia. Mogherini made a Report, by the nature of things, on a year of political transition from the former Commission and the former High Representative. She seems to have got very good on the portfolio, we might have a nice surprise with her.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In connection with the annual report of the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy/Vice-President of the Commission, the report advocates deepening European integration, closer cooperation within the framework of the common foreign and security policy and the common security and defence policy, better exploiting the opportunities offered by these policies and strengthening Europe's internal security and external influence. I am very much in support of all this.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. The annual report of the European Union High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy demonstrates the unconditional submission of the Union's foreign policy to the United States and NATO. It proposes to unify the "voices" of member states with regard to Russia to unanimously condemn Putin.  It imposes a reflex of submission since it underlines "the obligation taken by The Member States when the treaty on the European Union was ratified to actively and unreservedly support the Union's foreign and security policy in a spirit of loyalty". It sacrifices the nation-state, yet indispensable support for an army, in favor of the market logic and the "single market of cybersecurity products", leading to ever more federalism, to the delight of multinationals.  So I voted against it.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Once again we express our regret that the European Union is unable to make full use of its potential to outline the international political and security context. The lack of coordination and coherence between the EU's internal and external policies, exacerbated by recent financial restrictions, places further limits on Europe's influence in the world and its ability to position itself as a regional and global security guarantor, contributing to conflict prevention and crisis management.  The EU can only act as a credible actor if we are able to have a shared view of the key interests, values and objectives in the field of external relations. We need common, strengthened and combined political, economic, financial and defence resources to maximise the EU's influence in the world, to produce synergies and to ensure peace and stability in Europe and its neighbourhood. The EU institutions and the Member States can now make full use of the instruments provided for in the Treaty of Lisbon to move from a proactive, coherent and strategic EU foreign and security policy, based on common values and implemented in the common European interest.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it presents a first fair and nuanced assessment of the European Union's foreign policy this year, the efforts made and those to continue to assert the weight of our continent in the international arena, while preserving the independence of France.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr Brok's report, which provides a framework for assessing the common European foreign and security policy. More specifically, it makes a number of recommendations in order to improve it taking into account the new challenges and threats facing the Union. The EU has not yet been able to make full use of its potential to chart the international political and security context.  Furthermore, the lack of coordination and coherence between Community policies, as well as financial restrictions, place further constraints on Europe's influence in the world and its ability to act as a guarantee of security at regional and global level, contributing to conflict prevention and management. The report therefore reiterates the need to reform the internal structures of the European External Action Service in order to better assist the High Representative and stresses the need to better rationalise the structure in order to provide a greater capacity for monitoring and responding to crises.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe the European Union is indeed moving forward, as this report mentions, in the creation of a true, united and cohesive foreign policy, but it important to understand that in the critical times we are living in, it is not enough. The security concerns threatening our East, the rise of radical fundamentalism almost to a self-proclaimed ‘state’ level and the advent of a new and dangerous world dynamic make it more important than ever that the EU is able to talk with one unified voice and to defend itself and its interests abroad with a stronger policy.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report because, above all, it is in Europe's interest to calm and democratise our immediate neighbourhood. To this end, the European Union must continue with a clear enlargement and neighbourhood policy. If the European Union is successful in its immediate neighbourhood, it can be expected to succeed further afield. Surely the European Union must strengthen cooperation with NATO and with countries that share the same values with the European Union.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report. This balanced report highlights the new challenges facing European foreign policy, particularly with regard to its southern neighbourhood. The special attention to the Sahel, which I have personally amended, is included in the final text and constitutes the most immediate security challenge for Europe with Libya.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that due to the dramatic deterioration of the security environment across the EU, the international order based on Europe's law, stability and security has been called for at unprecedented levels since the beginning of European integration, which highlights the ongoing transformation of the world political order; that an ambitious and effective UNION foreign policy must be based on a shared vision of key European interests, values and objectives in external relations, as well as on a common perception of threats against the EU as a whole; that priority should be given to a process of strategic reflection on the EU's foreign and security policy; That, as a result of recent developments, it is necessary to develop a new European security strategy, taking into account recent geopolitical changes and thus providing a response to new challenges and threats, I voted in favour.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU will have to seriously consider the role of a common foreign strategy in order to be able to act for its interests in a world which is getting more and more polarized. A common foreign strategy has been too long forgotten and is becoming a clear necessity, at least before the integrity of the Union comes severely under threat.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that, given the current situation, the action taken by the High Representative in the field of foreign and security policy, whose priorities, according to Parliament, should be multiple and aimed at reaffirming the EU's role as a global player, is fundamental. Above all, we must protect European values and interests, through respect for Europe's political and legal order, as well as improving territorial defence in order to protect the Member States from terrorist attacks and organised crime. It is necessary to disseminate and promote in third countries, especially those bordering the EU, security, democracy and economic development, taking the lead in conflict resolution and in strengthening the global political, economic and financial order.  We also call for financial assistance for external actions, provided by the EU and its Member States, to be reoriented and used more effectively. This assistance must be directed towards civil society and NGOs working on the ground, including by easing red tape so that funding projects can be adopted more quickly.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The security environment around the EU has deteriorated dramatically due to numerous new and crisis-long crises for some time, especially in its immediate neighbourhood, where Europe's order, stability and security, based on international law, face its biggest challenge to date since the start of the European integration process. Recent terrorist attacks in EU countries show that it is increasingly difficult to separate internal security from external security, so I support the call on Member States and the EU institutions to pool their efforts more effectively in these areas.  In particular, I would like to highlight an extremely important part of the report, which recalls that energy is increasingly being used as a foreign policy instrument and that energy cooperation forms the basis of European integration. The political reality is that, in addition to security, energy has also become an oxygen for democracy, so it is the right time to upgrade the political integration of the European Union with that of energy.  European foreign and security policy needs a thorough review that will protect European values and interests and strengthen the political and legal order in Europe, the way to restore and preserve peace and stability. In these turbulent times when, thanks to globalisation, local crises can quickly escalate into regional and global crises, we have a unique opportunity to strengthen the common foreign and security policy of the Union, which has so far often been a space of dilemmas.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The terrible attacks in France against Charlie Hebdo showed once again that the attack on the security and life of European citizens could come from outside but also from within. The Union must now combine and coordinate its internal and external security. This point was well underlined in the annual report on foreign affairs and security policy adopted by the European Parliament. I voted in favour of this text and I reaffirm my support for the main ideas put forward in order to strengthen the coherence and effectiveness of the Union's foreign policy. It is particularly important that the Union coordinates its foreign policy more closely with that of the Member States in order to be more coherent, credible and effective on the international stage.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution concerns the annual report to the European Parliament, presented by the EU High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy with a view to redefining EU foreign policy. The main priorities defined are the protection of European values, the implementation of structural reforms with a view to greater policy coordination, support for security, democratisation, the rule of law and economic and social development in the EU's neighbourhood. With regard to neighbourhood policy, the rapporteur presents two different approaches, depending on the region: to the east, he proposes an ambitious approach based on European perspectives; the South, proposes a framework of cooperation more focused on the major challenges facing the region. In this regard, it seems to me that it would be necessary to strive for a single ENP for all neighbours, both east and south, not least because we have a charneira area which is both east and Mediterranean, where, therefore, these two components can be mixed. It would, of course, be a flexible policy, with varying degrees of relationship and cooperation with each country, but in which equal political priority and the same opportunities would be given to the South and East. I voted in favour.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as it draws attention to the drastic worsening of the security environment around the EU, especially in its immediate neighbourhood, where the international order based on the law, stability and security of Europe is challenged to an unprecedented level. I also think it is important to promote the development of the industrial and technological resources needed to improve cybersecurity. It is imperative that the EU and its Member States show solidarity and speak with one voice to Russia. Close coordination between the EU and the US is essential and with the participation of major powers (such as Russia and China), a strategy that encourages regional actors (including Turkey, Iraq, Israel, Jordan, Egypt, the governments of the Gulf Cooperation Council, Iran, the Arab League and Kurdish forces) to come together in order to put an end to wars. I also consider it relevant to draw attention to the fact that energy is increasingly being used as an instrument of foreign policy and that European integration is based on cooperation in this area as well.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which assesses the annual report of the European Union High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. We are in favour of an ambitious and effective foreign policy with a common vision, which allows the European Union to influence the international scene. The instruments of this policy must live up to the objectives that the Union has set itself: for example, humanitarian aid could be allocated more effectively and the network of EU delegations would benefit from being modernised and better adapted to the realities on the ground, especially in conflict zones. Trade policy should always support our principles and values and be used as leverage to defend them. We call for the creation of a genuine common defence policy, which would be coordinated with other areas such as energy policy or migration policy.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 There have been constant threats to the security of the European Union and its Member States. Some structures created are insufficient to respond to the current environment. In this sense, it is a priority to rethink the current structures in order to protect European values and interests and to implement the political and legal order in Europe in order to ensure peace and stability. It is important that the EU supports security, not only in its Member States, but also in neighbouring states.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The Annual Report takes stock of the most important developments in the CFSP area over the past year, in terms of its institutional structure and horizontal issues such as human rights, non-proliferation, the spread of EU values and its main geographical areas: enlargement, transatlantic relations, relations with Russia, EU neighbourhood, the Middle East and Asia. The report, with broad agreement between the PPE, S&D, ALDE and Verts/ALE Groups, takes a tough line on Russia's actions in relation to Ukraine and a balanced approach to the Middle East peace process, with an emphasis on the two-state solution. They also highlight the need to focus on the fight against IS and address the growing challenges arising from the state's failure in Syria, Iraq, Libya and the Sahel. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the annual report presented by the High Representative of the European Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy because I believe that this is a rigorous and competent document in defining those which are the European Union's priority foreign policy tasks. I stress the importance of unambiguous cooperation between the EU and the Member States on political, economic, financial and defence resources, so that peace and stability can be ensured in Europe and in the world, using a more proactive and coherent approach to foreign and security policy. And I believe it is essential that there be, as the rapporteur points out, a reform of European migration-oriented policies, a European strategy on energy security and two others aimed at reinvigorating the European political and legal order and the world order.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote against it because the report is totally unbalanced against Russia and in favour of sanctions. It also hopes that Turkey will resume its path to EU membership more actively and firmly, promote TTIP and be too subject to NATO.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against it as the Brok report insists that the political, economic, financial and defence resources of the European Union and its Member States must be combined in order to maximise the Union's geostrategic influence to make it a key political player on the world board. To this end, it establishes the subordination of all strategic policies under the CFSP/CSDP and explicitly requests the increase of resources for defense-related issues. We therefore vote against it as the report does not reflect the EU's negative position on conflicts in neighbouring countries (both those in the South and Eastern countries); the report does not focus on peaceful conflict resolution; defends the geopolitical nature of TTE, does not refer to the separation between EU policy and NATO policy, nor does it refer to the separation of civilian actions by the military in the field of security policy and Union cooperation.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which calls for a more proactive, credible and strategic European foreign policy, drawn up on the basis of a common vision of the Union's interests and values and a common assessment of the threats to the security of our continent.  The report also rightly calls on Member States to urgently strengthen their capacity to contribute to territorial defence, to commit more resources and to take seriously the method of mutualisation and sharing by intensifying their cooperation. Some EUR 130 million per year would be saved if these closer cooperations were implemented.  The challenges are many: to deal with instability in Eastern and Southern Europe, to combat the jihadist threat, to protect Europe's values and interests, to improve the Energy Security of the Union, to combat organised crime and various trafficking, to play a leading role in conflict resolution and to strengthen respect for the rule of law and human rights in the world.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I wish to explain that my vote in favour of this report is conditioned by the following observation: the bedrock of the EU’s profile in international affairs has been the soft power that the EU has developed over the years, making its institutions and mode of operations attractive as seen from outside. This soft power has at times become hegemonic in its effects without really having the diplomatic and material means by which to deliver on expectations and positions, except economically; indeed, the internal rules written and unwritten on which the EU operates rightly inhibit such a development. However in the intentional and unintentional exercise of its soft power, the EU is also at times contributing to geopolitical instability in its neighbourhoods where it is generating centrifugal forces, or giving rise to widespread expectations which it can neither satisfy nor betray. There seems to be little sign that in its initiatives, the Office of the High Representative has been able to clarify or resolve these dilemmas which are becoming more complex and problematic with time.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it insists on the militaristic drift of the European Union, advocates closer cooperation between the EU and the Atlantic Alliance and supports the fusion of internal and external security. In the proposed vote, aspects which I consider essential to support any initiative related to the Common Security and Defence Policy, such as progress towards nuclear disarmament on a global scale, were absent.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs abstained from the final vote on the annual report from the High Representative of the European Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy to the European Parliament. The report discusses EU foreign policy, preserving and strengthening the European political and legal order and coordination between the EU and US on foreign policy.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: writing – Following the emergence of the new EU Commission and high representative for foreign affairs, Federica Mogherini, the new EU foreign policy ambitions are based on a common vision of key European interests, values and objectives of external relations and a shared perception of threats affecting the whole EU. The recent terrorist attacks in EU countries show that it is becoming increasingly difficult to separate internal security from external security, which is why Member States and EU institutions must join forces in exchanging security information and on counter-terrorism issues. In the interests of the security of EU states, it is essential that we adopt a new, coherent migration and humanitarian aid policy for migrants, but also for countries where there are conflicts of war. In future, the EU and its High Representative for Foreign Countries must be more flexible in resolving the EU's relations with eastern partners. Countries that have signed accession agreements and want to be members of the EU in the future must receive more support from the EU and its High Representative for Foreign Countries.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ in the context of the Juncker Initiative on the European Army, I am of the opinion that it is not in place to build duplicate armed forces. I imagine that we will work together in the EU to improve our security by building special security forces. But they must be a compatible part of NATO.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Annual Report of the High Representative of the European Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy evaluates the common policies of the Member States of the European Union in the areas of foreign and security policy and gives us a number of recommendations for their improvement. The report calls for a more proactive and ambitious European Union foreign policy and the adoption of a new European Security Strategy, taking into account global change and emerging threats and challenges. That is why I support this report and agree that eu and Member State political, economic, financial resources must be merged to address, inter alia, the new political and security environment, protect European values and interests, and support security, democratisation, the rule of law and the development of the EU neighbourhood.  The European Union must be a credible player in partnership with the rest of the world and contribute to strengthening stability based on cooperation and rules. This is particularly true of better coordination with the US as a key strategic partner of the EU, the development of a strategy on sharing responsibility for peace and stability of the world political and economic order with Russia, China and other actors, and strengthening the EU's foreign policy towards Asia.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs want Britain to play a full part in Europe’s common foreign policy but abstained on this report because of our long-standing opposition to the idea of a permanent EU military headquarters. As our Shadow Europe Minister stated this week, we must be clear that the Labour Party values our sovereignty over national defence and does not support an EU Army. We also question the wording in the text on so-called EU ‘membership’ in the United Nations, which is not part of our current thinking for UN reform.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - The security environment around the EU has deteriorated dramatically, especially in its immediate neighbourhood, where we face the biggest challenge to date since the start of the European integration process. The report warns of changes currently taking place on the world political scene. The EU's foreign and security policy priorities are to protect European values and interests and strengthen the political and legal order in Europe, the way to restore and preserve peace and stability and improve the EU's contribution to the territorial defence of its Member States and the security of its citizens by strengthening its ability to defend itself against the threats it faces, including terrorism and trafficking in arms, drugs and human beings, and to improve the EU's internal structures and working methods to strengthen its resilience and to achieve its full potential. world stage.  I emphasise that external financial assistance granted by the EU and member states must be redirected and used more efficiently in line with agreed strategic priorities and call on the EU to take more measures to achieve greater visibility, coherence and effectiveness of EU assistance. I underline the need to establish strategic cooperation and partnerships with a number of countries, with a clear plan, and to carry out audits of current strategic partnerships in light of the impact of their policies and therefore support this report.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I abstained from voting on the report. In fact, the report brings things with which I agree, such as harsh criticism of Russia's annexation of Crimea, but it also makes proposals with questionable implications, such as the proposal to create a permanent military headquarters and proposals with which I disagree, such as the call for increased funding in several areas.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report is based on the philosophy that the EU must become a strong international player through further militarisation and cooperation with NATO. Next, several points highlight the need to align Member States' foreign policy in the interests of the EU's dominant circles aiming at a full match with the US and NATO. Russia's condemnation reports are also strong.  The Group of the European United Left has tabled a minority text explaining its own views. The EU must develop a policy based on peaceful principles, disengaged from military means and interventions, to promote the demilitarization of international relations that have brought to the peoples. To free itself from nuclear weapons and contribute to the denuclearization of the planet. Promote a policy based on full respect for international law, the UN Charter, the International Declaration of Human Rights. And there are no double standards in them. When we talk about democracy, we must also accept the results of democratic processes. In this way, the EU will be able to contribute to strengthening peace.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Strengthening ties between the EU and NATO and weakening their counterparts with Russia is the wrong strategy in the context of defence and security in Europe.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Elmar Brok's report on the High Representative's work, taking into account its positive assessment and supportive nature. I appreciate the efforts of High Representative Mogherini, with which she has consistently sought to establish a more coherent, consistent and effective framework for the CFSP since taking office. As a condition for this, I consider it particularly important, in line with the findings of the report, to work on the merits of improving the organisational, operational and economic conditions of the ECS. I am convinced that the real test of our efforts to strengthen the EU as an independent and active international actor is, and will continue to be, united action in our eastern neighbourhood, on the scene of the Ukrainian-Russian conflict, and that this is what the implementation of the proposals contained in the report can serve.  For the same reason, I am in support of the High Representative being given all possible political support from the EP, as well as all the necessary conditions at Council and Commission level, in order to ensure the full unity of the Member States, in particular for EU action against the expansionary aspirations of Russian foreign policy. As the most important condition for this, I believe that the means must be created for the High Representative to act more effectively against member states' external relations efforts that weaken or oppose the CFSP, in particular in the case of steps, agreements and declarations openly serving Moscow's objectives.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the Brok report because it outlines the transformation of the EU into an armed and, if necessary, bellicose political entity which, moreover, since it does not have its own strategies, adopts those of third countries. I think it is worrying from this point of view that the geopolitical nature of TTIP is underlined.  The EU was born as a peaceful community to overcome the horrors and divisions of the Second World War. That must remain so. While EU security has deteriorated, this is also (and in many cases above all) the effect of disastrous and counterproductive EU policies towards the eastern and southern neighbourhood. In particular, the EU strategy of providing 'aid' to third countries to the extent that they transpose the European economic model, is configurable as a form of economic and cultural colonialism and takes public money away from the needs of European citizens already impoverished by unnecessary and damaging austerity policies.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text. I am in favour of an ambitious and effective eu-wide foreign policy, which must be based on a common vision of Europe's fundamental interests, values and objectives in external relations, as well as a common perception of the threats to which the Union as a whole is exposed.  I therefore underline the commitment made by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, on the basis of the Mandate of the European Council of December 2013, to launch as a priority a process of strategic reflection on foreign affairs and security policy, which should involve a wide range of stakeholders. , including Member States, European institutions and the European population. This reflection should lead to a new European security strategy, developed in line with recent geopolitical developments, in order to deal with new threats and new challenges.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this annual report. Indeed, Europe’s neighbourhood is more unstable than ever and Europe is facing conflicts on its direct borders. In this context of international tension, the EU should play an active role in the prevention of conflict and provide support for our partners facing conflicts all over the world.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. This report is very ideological with the emphasis on a "new world order". It shows the will to design a world government under the aegis of NATO and the United States. In this logic, the relationship is very ideologically and unilaterally "anti-Russian", with a practice of true Soviet-like democratic centralism with the acting annihilation of national diplomatic independences and sovereignty.  I therefore object to this text.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against the Brok report as the Brok report insists that the political, economic, financial and defence resources of the European Union and its Member States must be combined in order to maximise the Union's geostrategic influence to make it a key political player on the world board. To this end, it establishes the subordination of all strategic policies under the CFSP/CSDP and explicitly requests the increase of resources for defense-related issues. We therefore vote against it as the report does not reflect the EU's negative position on conflicts in neighbouring countries (both those in the South and Eastern countries); the report does not focus on peaceful conflict resolution; defends the geopolitical nature of TTE, does not refer to the separation between EU policy and NATO policy, nor does it refer to the separation of civilian actions by the military in the field of security policy and Union cooperation.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. The annual report takes stock of the most important developments in the CFSP and deals with human rights, non-proliferation of arms and the spread of EU values. It also analyses and geographical issues on the main areas of the CFSP: enlargement, transatlantic relations, relations with Russia, the EU neighbourhood, the Middle East and Asia. This report has been agreed, with broad agreement between four of Parliament's main groups: PPE, S&D, ALDE and Verts/ALE. It is clearly positioned on Russia's actions in relation to Ukraine, and in relation to the Middle East emphasizes the two-state solution. It stresses the need to focus on the fight against ISIS and address the growing challenges arising from the state's failure in Syria, Iraq, Libya and the Sahel. The Socialists and Democrats have had a broad influence on the drafting of the report through the compromise amendments that have been agreed.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it insists on the militaristic drift of the European Union, advocates closer cooperation between the EU and the Atlantic Alliance and supports the fusion of internal and external security. In the proposal for a vote, elements which I consider essential to support any initiative related to the Common Security and Defence Policy, such as progress towards nuclear disarmament at the global level, strict support and development of international law in all EU military activities and the separation of civil and military actions, were absent.

name: Johannes Cornelis van Baalen (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 The VVD is currently opposed to the opening of an EU embassy in Tehran. First, it must be clarified that Iran is verifiably refraining from developing a nuclear weapon.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ With my Socialist colleagues, I voted in favour of this report because it is a consensual one, with broad agreement between the four political groups: EPP, Socialists & Democrats, ALDE and Greens. The report takes a hard line on Russia’s actions vis-à-vis Ukraine and a balanced approach to the Middle East peace process, with an emphasis on the two-state solution. The need to focus on the fight against ISIS and address the mounting challenges stemming from state failure in Syria, Iraq, Libya and Sahel are also stressed.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 We are concerned about the drastic worsening of the security environment around the EU, especially in its immediate neighbourhood, where the international order based on the law, stability and security of Europe is challenged at an unprecedented level since the beginning of the process of European integration. We are concerned that the EU, also due to its internal crisis, has not given its potential to promote dialogue and political solutions. Rather, we are concerned about a bet on a bellicose discourse, often in tow of Nato and the United States, which not only does not serve the interests of the EU but also contributes to aggravating conflicts and departing from any political solution based on dialogue and international law. This latest episode with an expression of interest in a European army is in itself a telling of what the EU thinks about its foreign policy.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I would like to thank Mr Brok (CDU) for supporting the oral amendment tabled by me and my colleagues Tannock (UK) and Jurek (PL) in plenary on the persecution of Christians. Our amendment adds what the report lacked: a word about the responsibility of the Member States to protect religious freedom in their national external relations. The new paragraph reads: "Urges EU leaders and Member States to ensure the safety and freedom of Christians and members of other religious and ethnic minorities, who are increasingly subjected to discrimination and persecution and are being cross-fireed; calls on the EEAS and the Member States to ensure that future bilateral agreements include effective monitoring mechanisms to protect the human rights of religious minorities and to effectively implement the EU guidelines on the promotion and protection of freedom of religion and belief". However, I abstained from the final vote. In his very complete report, Mr Brok also calls for far-reaching powers by the Member States in the field of foreign and defence policy. I do not support the idea or the tendency for the governments of the member states to increasingly close their foreign ministers and move their military general staff to Brussels.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ With my Socialist colleagues, I voted in favour of this report because it is a consensual one, with broad agreement between the four political groups: EPP, Socialists & Democrats, ALDE and Greens. The report takes a hard line on Russia’s actions vis-à-vis Ukraine and a balanced approach to the Middle East peace process, with an emphasis on the two-state solution. The need to focus on the fight against ISIS and address the mounting challenges stemming from state failure in Syria, Iraq, Libya and Sahel are also stressed.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report assumes that the security of the EU and its Neighbouring Member States and countries is being called into question by Russia and that a transformation of the global political order is taking place. According to the report, the EU has not been able to act appropriately due to the lack of political coordination and lack of coherence between EU policies, but also due to financial constraints. Stresses that it is necessary to empower the EU and member states with defence capability and to deepen the Common Security and Defence Policy with NATO.  We reject the EU's membership and the strengthened imperialist political-military bloc, whose so-called 'external' policy responds to the economic objectives of the great European capital and the main imperialist powers of the continent by creating better conditions for the appropriation of markets, resources and trade routes.  There needs to be democratic ruptures in the EU, a process of demilitarisation and disarmament, the dissolution of NATO and the creation of a collective security system that respects and ensures the sovereignty of states and the free choice of peoples. We voted against it.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: – This annual report was supposed to speak of respect for human rights and, ultimately, openly violated these rights. This report openly calls for the legality of prenatal infanticide, the so-called abortion, to be introduced in all countries of the European Union. This is a blatant incitement against the right to life of the most vulnerable, probably based on the conviction that we will come to terms with the fact that we will not protest, that we will choose the path of European correctness. The mere assumption that we could sacrifice the lives of our children in the name of any political gain is an act of contempt for our countries. At this point, I would also like to remind you that the European Parliament has committed a clear breach of the principle of granting. None of our countries has ever agreed to action against the lives of our citizens. The Sejm of the Republic of Poland made this clear 12 years ago, when poland was still ruled by the left. It is a pity that Brussels did not hear this voice.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: – Unfortunately, I had to vote 'no' in the Panzeri report. In fact, during today's vote, it turns out that some issues that are fully within the competence of the Member States have been left in the report, which I very much regret. Furthermore, I am very pleased, on the other hand, that references to the Slovak referendum have fallen out of the report, as have the other two. In my opinion, the European Union simply has to accept any outcome of this democratic instrument of internal policy of individual Member States. In general, the report provides a broad overview of human rights and democracy in 2013, but one particular problem has not received as much attention as it deserves, and that is subsidiarity. We should make sure that subsidiarity is a priority in future reports.

name: Luigi Morgano (S&D).
text: I voted against the annual report on human rights and democracy in the world in 2013 because the text that has just been adopted contains some important concepts that we cannot support. Once again, ideologically, we wanted to use this important annual meeting, which also contains positive points, such as the affirmation and protection of freedom of thought, conscience and religion, to force the Treaties and suggest, or rather to assert at European level, the right to abortion, despite the principle of subsidiarity establishing that matters such as family law are a national competence. It is a good thing that we have amended, among other things, the text of the report, which criticised democratic referendums held in Member States such as Croatia and Slovakia, and lithuania's national legislation. Decisions on these very sensitive matters, which affect the principles and values of every person, the family model and society that we want to build, must be taken by the Member States and not by european institutions.

name: Peter Jahr (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the If you look at the text, you can only vote in favour of the report, and it is correct. Nevertheless, i am concerned about the practical implementation , especially how we shape our foreign policy. Here we should go back and sometimes look at the results. I would like to remind you of the so-called African Spring: did we really achieve an improvement in human rights there at the end? For me, this means, on the one hand, being consistent in the demands, but on the other hand proportionate in its implementation. In other words, proportionality in the dialogue with existing governments. For there is an old saying: "Well meant is the opposite of well done". We have a lot of catching up to do there. Secondly, as chairman of the Committee on Petitions, I would like to say this: we still have some catching up to do within the European Union in this respect. That is also what we must take care of!

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – I will only comment in brief on my vote, which ultimately, after much hesitation, supported this report on the state of human rights and democracy in the world.  At the same time, I would like to admit that it was indeed quite difficult for me to vote, because I am aware that there were a number of shortcomings in the report, including in the original draft report. Finally, I have moved to support it, although I also think that it does not respect the principle of subsidiarity very much. It is precisely the role of Member States in their policies that the EU should also respect. I will admit that for the next vote, say for another year, when a new annual report will be presented, my view will probably be even more critical if these principles are not respected and respected.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, tá a lán moltaí an-mhaith ins an tuarascáil seo agus vótáil mé le mo ghrúpa ins na vótaí go léir.  Tá áthas orm freisin go raibh mo ghrúpa i gcoinne cuid de na moltaí, go háirithe na cinn a bhaineann le ginmhilleadh a bheith ar fáil go forleathan mar shaghas ceart daonna. Ní dóigh liom gur ceart daonna é sin, cé go bhfuilimid i bhfabhar an ghinmhillte i gcásanna eisceachtúla áirithe agus tá sé sin scríofa mar shampla i mBunreacht na hÉireann.  Taobh amuigh de sin, tá a lán moltaí an-mhaith anseo agus go háirithe bhí áthas orm gur glacadh leis an leasú ó bhéal a bhaineann lenár n-oidhreacht chultúrtha a chosaint. Tá sé sin an-tábhachtach chomh maith.  Dá bhrí sin, i gcoitinne tá a lán rudaí maithe ann, taobh amuigh den ghinmhilleadh a bheith ar fáil go forleathan.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: – It is right that the European Union has long promoted a high standard of respect for human rights in the world. If two world wars taught us anything, it is that human life and human dignity must be protected at all times. This report also deals with other important topics, such as freedom of thought, conscience and religion. I am all the more sorry that the rapporteur used it to promote abortion as a human right. In doing so, it has grossly interfered with the competences of the Member States of the European Union, while at the same time questioning the absolute value of human life and dignity. I could not support this report in this way.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by If we are talking about human rights, let us remember that those people who are just starting to live, children conceived, also have the right to life. This is also a human right, and I would like us in the European Parliament to remember this, and I voted against this report for a simple reason. I believe that it applies a very narrow definition of human rights, it does not take into account unborn children. I think this is really an unacceptable situation, because we, when we talk a lot about human rights – it is good that we are talking about them – somehow strangely do not want to include in the category of defending human rights certain categories of people – precisely the smallest ones. It seems to me that this report is very ideological in nature and it really serves a project that often has little in common with human rights. Hence my vote against. I think it is good that there are many Members in this House who have voted against this report.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. For European Socialists, the defence, promotion and respect for human rights is a central and vertebrate element of EU foreign policy. This annual report represents one of Parliament's main instruments for monitoring and guiding Union action in this area. This year's text, drafted by a socialist rapporteur, provides an innovative perspective, focusing on cross-cutting and thematic issues, and contains specific recommendations on the main challenges facing human rights around the world.  Among the most noteworthy elements that have been introduced – despite in many cases the vote against the Group of the People's Party – are the strong defense of women's sexual and reproductive rights, the impetus for recognition of same-sex marriage or the concept of climate refugees.  The report strongly defends the universality and indivisibility of human rights in the face of the rise of the discourse of cultural relativism and addresses very important areas where further progress is needed, such as the role of businesses, especially large multinationals, and strengthening the coherence of EU policies.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report as it completely ignores the deterioration of the human rights situation in Western Sahara. In recent years, the situation in ̶ territory pending ̶ has worsened significantly in terms of freedom of association, freedom of expression and freedom of assembly. In this regard, there is no call for the release of political prisoners and Morocco is also not called upon to allow access to occupied Sahara by independent observers or Members of the European Parliament. The report mentions the situation of other specific cases, but by ignoring this particular I have found me without the possibility of voting in favour.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The defence of human rights is at the heart of the European Union's action and that is why I voted in favour of the European Parliament's report on human rights and democracy around the world in 2013 and EU policy on the subject

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. I welcome the ongoing global cooperation in all possible forums for the abolition of the death penalty, as well as the EU's efforts in the fight against torture and other degrading and inhumanpunishments or treatment, especially against women.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. This report sets out an action plan for the universal establishment of human rights in the world, which clearly aims to enshrine a right of interference by the European institutions in the internal affairs of the Member States. It allows them to sanction Member States if national laws do not correspond to the ideological vision of the European Union. Moreover, the rights of minorities are highlighted and act at the expense of the common good and the true respect for the intrinsic dignity of the human person. Sexual or religious minorities are favoured under COMMUNITY law. So I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this motion; once again, I agree with much of the report but not with other parts. Fundamentally, I could not vote for it because it gives the EU too much power over certain issues which I do not believe should be determined by the EU.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D)
text: in writing. The proclamation of the principle of the universality of human rights is a civilizational advance, and is probably the main legacy of modern European and Western thought for the world, which greatly increases our obligations in this area. A foreign policy that does not include as a central concern the issue of respect for human rights would be a foreign policy too cynical in the face of the values that should constantly inspire us.  That is why I will vote in favour of this report. Because it means the achievement of one of the greatest commitments of our European project: the commitment to promoting the safeguarding of human rights in all parts of the world. It is in this pact that the whole issue is at the heart and that is why the principle of universality of human rights cannot contain any idea of cultural relativism or political relativism, which, to be taken into account, would call them into question at all.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased to acknowledge that this report, along with its annexes, was born out of a constructive and vivid dialogue between different parliamentary bodies, political groups and consultations with NGOs. Such a systematic approach was crucial to achieve its objective, namely to complement and not duplicate already existing reporting mechanisms.
