The rapporteur struck a balance between providing a view of the most critical human rights breaches around the world on the one hand and guidelines for the international community in foreign assistance on the other. It is absolutely essential that this report address such themes as impunity and international criminal justice, freedom of expression, rights of women and children, LGTB rights, business and workers’ rights and – most importantly – protection of human rights defenders. Human rights defenders are crucial to the work of European Parliament. We must also remind ourselves that those who speak up for human rights and their violations are extremely vulnerable. We have witnessed such cases in EP hearings when many of those human rights defenders who spoke in front of the sub-committee were afterwards exposed to risks to their security or even detained and tortured by their own governments.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for an annual report on human rights and democracy in the world in 2013 and the establishment of EU policy in this area. I support the calls for the inclusion of human rights clauses in eu international agreements, including trade and investment agreements with third countries, while ensuring that these agreements facilitate the economic and social development of the country. I agree with the need to establish a human rights-based crisis prevention instrument and to integrate it into the EU's approach to external conflicts and crises, as well as to include it in the future revised European Security Strategy. It is important to apply a common European asylum system and to ensure common EU standards on the reception of refugees, in order to protect unsuplined minors and the most vulnerable. One of the EU's most important challenges today is the situation in Ukraine, ongoing military action and the deteriorating human rights situation, which need to be addressed by an urgent and united voice of the EU as a whole. It is also necessary for the EU to review its strategy also against China, which is increasingly facing serious human rights violations.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. Like the Tarabella report, the Panzeri report contravenes paragraph 7 of Article 168 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which states that so-called reproductive or reproductive health policies fall within the competence of Member States. The European Union therefore does not have to impose its views on countries that have sovereignly chosen other paths, let alone in an area that falls solely within the competence of the Member States. In addition to promoting gender ideology, the Panzeri report also confirms that the European Union spends its time teaching human rights lessons to the entire planet while, at the same time, flouting the basic rules of democracy by failing to respect the sovereignty of nations or the will of the peoples.  Thus, paragraph 165 of the report condemns the free and sovereign choice of the Croatian people to constitutionalize male-female marriage by its December 2013 referendum.  I note, however, that the Tarabella and Panzeri reports - written by Socialist MEPs who seek to further promote gender ideology - have been supported by their UMP colleagues.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. This report analyses the EU's human rights and democracy activities. As Europeans, it is our responsibility to defend and promote these values all over the world. These values are the basis of our free and democratic societies as well as our European integration project. They must also play a central role in our external policies, because democracy and human rights are universal principles.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This 84-page report on human rights around the world clearly sets out the guidelines for European human rights in this area. Under the guise of defending human rights, Brussels wants to impose sanctions on countries that do not respect its ideological vision in this area, thus eliminating national specificities, local cultures specific to nations or territories. The European vision thus fully enshrines the principle of interference to justify its decisions, whether it concerns immigration policies (it requires that no state can deport a refugee to a territory) or the rights of minorities. In view of the above arguments and the amendments tabled in committee by my colleagues, I therefore voted against this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although this report contains some chapters that we can support, the text soon turns into an under-balanced exercise in demagoguery with which I do not agree. That is why I did not intend to support you with my vote.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have voted in favour of the report.  Most writes are very good. I am particularly pleased that the right's attempts to weaken LGBTI writings failed.  However, I would like to point out that I do not support the wordings on refugee and asylum policy that indirectly support the Khartoum settlement, in which the EU and the countries of the Horn of Africa have formed cooperation with the exchange of information to stop 'irregular migration', instead of working for democracy and to help refugees, particularly from Eritrea.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. For European Socialists, the defence, promotion and respect for human rights is a central and vertebrate element of EU foreign policy. This annual report represents one of Parliament's main instruments for monitoring and guiding Union action in this area. This year's text, drafted by a socialist rapporteur, provides an innovative perspective, focusing on cross-cutting and thematic issues, and contains specific recommendations on the main challenges facing human rights around the world.  Among the most noteworthy elements that have been introduced – despite in many cases the vote against the Group of the People's Party – are the strong defense of women's sexual and reproductive rights, the impetus for recognition of same-sex marriage or the concept of climate refugees.  The report strongly defends the universality and indivisibility of human rights in the face of the rise of the discourse of cultural relativism and addresses very important areas where further progress is needed, such as the role of businesses, especially large multinationals, and strengthening the coherence of EU policies.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, in which the European Parliament calls on all the Institutions of the European Union and the Member States to focus on human rights in the EU's relations with all third countries, including strategic partners, as well as in all high-level statements and meetings. It is essential that Member States take a common position in support of the indivisibility, integrity and universality of human rights, and in particular when ratifying all international human rights instruments adopted by the United Nations. The European Parliament welcomes the council's adoption of the EU Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World in 2013 and calls on the new High Representative/VP/HR to commit to future participation in the two annual debates on EU human rights and democracy policy, which are held during Parliament's plenary sessions, to present the EU report and to discuss Parliament's report. Parliament calls for the fight to continue to combat torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment, as EU action in this area remains insufficient and does not meet its obligations under the EU guidelines on torture. The EU should step up its support for the development and strengthening of national and regional mechanisms to prevent torture.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 The report is complete and includes important elements. The EU must invest in preserving fundamental human rights in the world, in particular the rights of minorities and vulnerable groups. Tolerance and mutual respect are fundamental values of the EU. The report highlights clear priorities within and beyond the EU and that is why I support it!

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since I consider that the the improvement of the human rights and democracy standards are fundamental for a better European Union.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. The above report recommends that Member States better integrate human rights concerns into the conduct of bilateral or multilateral diplomatic relations. If the intentions seem laudable, they do not make a foreign policy. Moreover, we all remember that it is in the name of so-called respect for human rights that Western countries, including France, overthrew Colonel Gaddafi and allowed chaos, war and Islamist fundamentalism to settle in Libya. The same scenario was almost declined in Syria, which would have resulted in the massacre or forced exile of Christian, Kurdish and Alawite minorities. Moreover, the right-of-homism masks a form of arrogant moral neo-colonialism that appears totally anachronistic in 2015 (conferring the "humanitarian outings" in the nineties of Bernard Kouchner). No, the European Union does not have to teach the Lesson to the Member States, which must remain free to conduct their foreign policy in accordance with their best interests. I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the 2013 Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World and the European Union's policy in this regard. Beyond many points that correctly capture positive developments, there have also been many aspects in this report that I cannot agree with and that go beyond the limits of moral values and perceptions, reinforced in Romania and by the provisions of the Civil Code, which defines marriage as "the union between a man and a woman". The report is a bushy one, which involved hard work, but unfortunately I could not reward it with my vote, firstly for the reason set out above, and secondly because there are some aspects which, in my opinion, violate the principle of subsidiarity, that is, the right of the Member States to decide in certain areas. I believe, however, that the person and human dignity must be the central elements around which all the actions of the European Union are subsumed so that the protection of human rights is the main point on any road map of an EU country and beyond.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the 2013 Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World and the European Union's human rights and democracy policy in this area. It is fundamental that human rights and democracy are respected throughout the world. The European Union must be an example in this regard. We have seen that fundamental freedoms, such as freedom of expression, are too often flouted. Promoting human rights on the international stage must be a priority for the European Union.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the annual report on human rights and democracy in the world in 2013 and on the European Union's human rights policy. It is based on the consideration that the Treaty of Lisbon has strengthened the European Union's commitment on the international stage. This document is inspired by the principles of democracy and the rule of law, supporting the universality and indivisibility of human rights and fundamental freedoms, respect for human dignity and the principles of equality and solidarity. In this context, I would like to highlight the attention paid to the European Union's action on migration and refugees. In this regard, I believe that we need to develop stronger policies in order to address the urgent issues associated with them and that this impetus should take place in a manner consistent with international human rights law and fundamental human dignity.  As I have said in my other speeches on this subject, the construction of a European area of rights that is genuinely inclusive in its complexity, and not just a geographical boundary, is an element that should be a priority on the agenda of the Community institutions and the Member States.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Human rights and democracy are founding values of the European Union, at the heart of its interventions as well as its policies. The European Parliament's report on human rights is an important instrument for assessing the Union's intervention in this respect in third countries and their situation. It checks the state of implementation of the strategic framework of the European Union's action plan on human rights and democracy. The thematic rather than the geographical approach, which is new in the report, is, in my opinion, a change that makes it possible to make the idea of the problems better.  I voted in favour and we will ensure that the Union's action in this area is actually based on the data collected.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this text, which makes human rights the real Trojan horse of the European institutions to enshrine the principle of interference. In this report, the European Union once again wants to be a schoolteacher, distributing good and bad points, even if sanctions are taken if national legislation does not follow the European ideological vision. Moreover, right-of-hommist sentimentalism serves to justify the gradual destruction of our national sovereignty, as with this recital N which prevents Member States from taking the necessary measures against illegal immigrants.  Finally, the report tends to consecration of the rights of active minorities such as the LGBT lobby at the expense of the Common Good and the true respect for the dignity of the human person.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report is a call to the EU to protect and promote human rights across Europe and to ensure that democracy and human rights are at the core of its actions and policies. It is regrettable that last year the practice of sending a European Parliament Delegation to relevant UN Human Rights Council and General Assembly sessions was interrupted. We should work ever more closely with the UNHRC.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The in-depth report prepared by Mr Panzeri is an important document, which deals in an organic way, and with attention to the interrelationships between the internal and external dimension, many profiles related to the defence and promotion of human rights and democracy in the world.  It is not only a photograph of what has been done and a list of the main problems to be addressed, but also a valuable guide to the steps to be taken in a number of areas: from the defence and promotion of rights in agreements, or through international agreements (commercial and non-commercial), to the protection of freedom of assembly, association and , thought and expression (online and offline); from the regulation of surveillance technologies, to the fight against discrimination of all kinds and to the protection of minorities and vulnerable persons, in particular minors; from the fight against the death penalty, torture and other inhumane treatment or punishment, to respect for rights by companies; from international criminal justice and the fight against crimes such as trafficking in human beings or even corruption, to EU action on migration and refugees. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 There are still many challenges ahead of us on this issue and still a lot of work. I am convinced that picking on scapegoats does not solve the problems. We need to work on mentality, on culture in the broadest sense, on intellectual growth. My vote on the various amendments, and then on the report as a whole, followed this logical thread, which I would like to see shared by wider majorities.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This annual report by Parliament was an important instrument for the Evaluation of the European Parliament with regard to Human Rights.  I voted in favour of this report because I believe that it is making a correct assessment of the world - and the Union - in 2013. On the other hand, it calls for solutions necessary for the transformation of the European Union into a standard of human rights in the world. We need not only greater coherence between internal and external approaches, but also mechanisms that give greater effectiveness to the Union's foreign human rights policy. In line with what I have been advocating so far, I have seen with particular satisfaction the section on asylum and migration. It is imperative to save the thousands of lives that - already in 2013 - tarnished the Mediterranean to death. Nor can we be complacent about human rights violations in the reception of asylum seekers and in the treatment of refugees; and to this end, we must start by implementing the crisis mechanisms that generate effective solidarity between Member States.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The report addresses different issues on human rights often focusing on those areas in which more EU action is needed but I would like to see a stronger EU framework to carrying out such action. A framework with focused effective actions assisting third countries in the process of democratisation with the actions not only being named as priorities but also having actual and measurable targets. In doing so the EU must be seen to be consistent in upholding these principles and therefore coherence between the internal and external human right policies needs to be enhanced. With relation to a specific issue, suppression of the media and of expression creates oppression and serves only those who seize power at the expense of the best interest of their people and their country thereby leading to instability and humanitarian crises leading also to migration towards and tragedies on EU territories. Focused effective action in this respect with third countries is a must. The report calls for legal abortion, an issue that falls outside EU competence and consequently voted against.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament must ensure that human rights and democracy are at the heart of its actions and policies. The European Parliament's report on human rights is the important instrument for assessing both the EU's human rights policies and the situation in third countries. It is an instrument through which we can monitor the state of implementation of the strategic framework of the European Union's action plan on human rights and democracy. The significant novelty of this report compared to the previous ones is that of a thematic rather than a geographical approach, grouping the different human rights considerations into large thematic areas rather than on a geographical/regional basis.  I voted in favour. I would like to reiterate that, in order to ensure that these reports and votes do not just remain words on paper, we must give institutional follow-up to the issues raised in Parliament's urgent resolutions.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report as it completely ignores the deterioration of the human rights situation in Western Sahara. In recent years, the situation in ̶ territory pending ̶ has worsened significantly in terms of freedom of association, freedom of expression and freedom of assembly. In this regard, there is no call for the release of political prisoners and Morocco is also not called upon to allow access to occupied Sahara by independent observers or Members of the European Parliament. The report mentions the situation of other specific cases, but by ignoring this particular I have found me without the possibility of voting in favour.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a sensitive and important report, the adoption of which marks a new trait of distinction in the Union's ability to take the forefront, not only in defence, but also in the promotion of fundamental values, such as democracy and human rights. It is important for the Union as such, since it represents the uniqueness of its member states in identifying and delimiting the very concept of democracy and human law, avoiding unilateral acts or interpretations that may give rise to political or ideological polemics. I would like to reiterate here the extraordinary weapon at Europe's disposal: its being among the most competitive, reliable and coveted trading partners in the world. We often, quite rightly, give them benefit clauses in our relations with the least developed countries. Well, it is essential that this aspect is in no way separated from the promotion of democracy and human rights.  Countries that wish to have trade relations with Europe and that receive favourable treatment from Europe must embark on a path, properly shared and monitored, in order to achieve adequate standards of respect, protection and, in turn, promotion, rights and democracy.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against all references to abortion but in favour of the whole report because the report enters into serious issues of human rights. I believe that we need to fight sexual abuse, we need to address internal human rights challenges effectively, including discrimination against LGBTI people, media freedom and the rights of minorities; we need to take an unequivocal position against capital punishment, torture and abuse around the world and a strong position against the elimination of violence against women and girls, against the sexual abuse of young girls, early and forced marriage or child marriage. The report speaks also about LGBTI rights, rights of persons with disabilities, children’s rights and EU action on migration and refugees.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 As all types of discrimination and violence against women, including sexual abuse, female genital mutilation, forced marriages, so-called honour killings and sexual exploitation of women for commercial purposes, as well as domestic violence, should never be justified by any political, social, religious or cultural basis or by popular or tribal traditions, I consider it necessary for the Member States of the Council of Europe to sign and ratify the Convention on the Prevention and Combating of Violence against Women , and in this context, the EU will take the necessary steps to join the Convention in order to ensure coherence between the EU's internal and external action on violence against women.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report presents an annual review of the state of human rights and democracy in the world in 2013 and the Union's action, including democratisation and free elections, support for human rights defenders around the world, and actions against the death penalty and inhuman and degrading treatment. In particular, this report recalls the centrality of human rights in the Union's external policies, which must be consistent with the Union's internal policies. Finally, the report supports the continued position of the Eu's Special Representative for Human Rights with a view to making it a permanent function, with adequate means to fully fulfil its mission. Finally, issues of sexual and reproductive rights and same-sex marriage are addressed on the sidelines of the report. These issues are purely national and the European Union does not have to take legislative initiative on these issues, which is why I voted against the associated paragraphs.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to assess the state of human rights and democracy in countries outside the Union. We have the for example called for the systematic inclusion of "binding, applicable and non-negotiable clauses" on human rights in the international agreements that the European Union concludes with third countries, while ensuring that these agreements promote the economic and social development of the countries concerned.  The report calls on the European Union to strengthen cooperation with civil society through programmes of the European Fund for Democracy. With regard to certain paragraphs dealing with same-sex marriage, I did not wish to support them, because I believe, as I had already pointed out in the last Parliament, that issues relating to marriage and the family must remain exclusively within the competence of the Member States. The European Union must focus only on areas where its action is relevant, in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Luis de Grandes Pascual (PPE)
text: in writing. In my own name and right and representing the Spanish delegation of the PPE Group as Secretary-General, we would like to state, in relation to the Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World (2013) and the European Union's policy on this issue, that, while we supported this report today in the final vote — because it is of great importance , among other issues, on key issues such as the defence of the indivisibility and universality of human rights, the important role of human rights in all EU external action policies, support for human rights defenders in the world or the need to establish a horizontal human rights approach in the post-2015 Agenda— , we do not agree, and we have therefore voted against, with the references that paragraphs 135, 136 and 164 make to abortion and to sexual and reproductive health rights. These are very sensitive issues related to the right to life, a priority for our political formation, and on which we have been speaking unequivocally. Moreover, the European Union has no competence in this area.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the 2013 annual report on human rights and democracy in the world and the European Union's policy in this area. This report recalls the importance of integrating human rights and democracy into all EU activities and calls for human rights to be placed at the heart of all EU relations with third countries, including its strategic partners. This is an important message that Parliament has been very much supportive of. On the other hand, this report contains issues within the competence of the Member States, such as the issue of the recognition of same-sex marriage or the same-sex civil union. I disapprove of this European interference in the national affairs of each Member State, unfortunately all too often frequent on this type of issue. I have therefore chosen to abstain on this paragraph which, in my view, is not a matter for MEPs.

name: Diane Dodds (NI)
text: in writing. ‒ This report rightly throws a spotlight on fundamental rights abuses in an array of political contexts, and the very extent of these problems should send a message that not enough is being done to uphold them. We think of those Christians and members of religious minorities in areas of Middle East, and indeed right across the globe, who face persecution both through violence and institutionalised barriers to work, education and health. We think of the many more situations where freedoms to associate, to speak freely, and to report events have been withheld to the detriment of democracy and decency. And in my own constituency, I think of the efforts being made to eliminate the freedom to confer with one’s conscience in the running of private business.  These problems are serious but they are not insurmountable. At the very heart of any solution must be the principle that the rights of some in society cannot be secured by removing the rights of others. And that embodies why I cannot support this report - because of the insatiable and unacceptable desire to toss away the right to life of the unborn child.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. This report sets out an action plan for the universal establishment of human rights in the world, which clearly aims to enshrine a right of interference by the European institutions in the internal affairs of the Member States. It allows them to sanction Member States if national laws do not correspond to the ideological vision of the European Union. Moreover, the rights of minorities are highlighted and act at the expense of the common good and the true respect for the intrinsic dignity of the human person. Sexual or religious minorities are favoured under COMMUNITY law. So I voted against this report.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against this report because it recognises excessive rights for homosexuals, while, without receiving substantial provision for reducing illegal immigration, it requires Member States to guarantee a multitude of rights to them.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution on the annual report on human rights and democracy in the world in 2013 and on the European Union's human rights policy as human rights have become an essential element of the Union's external action. It is important for the EU to support UN resolutions on gender issues, in particular on the elimination of violence against women, discrimination against women and the role of freedom of expression and opinion in women's empowerment, as well as statements on forced and early marriage and female genital mutilation. The resolution deplores the fact that homosexuality is still criminally sanctioned in 78 countries, sometimes even with the death penalty (as in Saudi Arabia and Afghanistan), and considers that practices and acts of violence against individuals on the basis of their sexual orientation and gender identity should not go unpunished. We hope that the European External Action Service will focus in particular on situations where the death penalty is in force and/or LGBTI people are subjected to torture and ill-treatment, condemning these practices in accordance with the EU guidelines on the death penalty and those on torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. I believe in the EU's role in conducting a common foreign and security policy guided by the principles of democracy, the rule of law, universality and indivisibility of human rights. In addition, the EU has obligations with regard to its commitments to its Charter of Fundamental Rights and the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms". The report is in line with these principles, in essence, and outlines strategies for respect ing and implementing it in the world, denouncing human rights violations and promoting the EU's role as a credible and strengthened actor in promoting human rights, democracy, peace and economic prosperity, especially in its immediate vicinity, and has received my positive vote.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The strengthening of the Union's commitments to conduct a common foreign and security policy guided by the principles of democracy, the rule of law, the universality and indivisibility of human rights and fundamental freedoms, respect for human dignity, the principles of equality and solidarity and the principle of promoting international law and justice are some of the premises enshrined in the European Treaty. It is essential to me that all EU institutions and all Member States give human rights a privileged place in the EU's relations with third countries, including its strategic partners, and in all high-level declarations and meetings. It is also important that Member States express themselves in unison in favour of the indivisibility, inviolability and universality of human rights and, in particular, the ratification of all international human rights instruments created under the aegis of the United Nations.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. With this report, it is the forced march to the world "LGBTI...". Indeed, this report: "takes note of the legalization of same-sex marriage or same-sex civil unions in an increasing number of countries - seventeen at present - worldwide; encourages EU institutions and Member States to contribute more to reflection on the recognition of same-sex marriage or same-sex civil union as a political, social and civil rights issue."  I note that my colleagues from the UMP have all voted in chorus for this report, so there was no need to go first against the Taubira law during the demonstrations. The European Union reveals its true face, that of imposing on all its ultraliberal vision of society, which knows no borders, no people, no difference between the sexes.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report addresses some aspects that deserve our agreement. Nevertheless, it is essentially characterised by a manipulative and reductive view of human rights - political, social, economic and cultural - using them as an element of interference and political pressure on some States, where so-called "friends" countries are safeguarded (by omission) and "others" are criticised, always tailored to the eu's interests and conveniences. We omit glaring situations, which we recall here: the aggression against the Sahrawi people and the illegal occupation of Western Sahara by Morocco; the illegal occupation of part of cyprus' territory by Turkey; the serious humanitarian situation in the Gaza Strip, along with Israel's belligerent occupation of Palestinian territory. All with EU and US coverage. In contrast to the principles and objectives that the report proclaims as inspiring EU policies, in view of the analysis expressed there in a clear exercise of hypocrisy, the policies imposed on the peoples of Europe and the world, the EU and the USA, which have contributed to the increase in inequalities, poverty, unemployment and job security, exploitation and hunger deserve reference. , in addition to the withdrawal of rights, freedoms and guarantees.  We disagree with unconditional support for the ICC. For these reasons, we voted against it.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ Human rights and their protection are an important pillar of the European Union, its Member States, but also of civil society. As one of the world's political players, the European Union must have the ambition to be a guarantor of the protection of human rights outside its territory. The situation in third countries has also deteriorated significantly in the area of human rights, mainly due to conflicts in Syria, between Israel and Palestine and Ukraine. War conflicts are fundamentally under attacking respect for the human rights of civilians. The European Union, also because of ongoing war conflicts and human rights violations, is a place where increasing numbers of refugees seek refuge. In some areas of the European Union, this situation is critical; It is therefore our duty not only to draw attention to human rights violations, but also to offer concrete solutions and various forms of assistance.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the resolution because, in addition to a list of principles, many of which we can support, it does not affect with solutions and not from a serious and objective reading of the most relevant problems.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against this report as a whole because it recognises excessive rights for homosexuals, while, without receiving substantial provision for reducing illegal immigration, it requires Member States to guarantee a multitude of rights to them.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I thank the rapporteur Mr. Panzeri for the tremendous job he did with this report on the crucial issue of human rights.  I especially appreciate the introduction of a push for the rights of women, of children, about the rights of religion, social, ethnical minorities, of minorities in general.  These persons are a part of society that is highly discriminated  against in most countries of the world and needs greater government protection and support.  The European Union must clearly lead the way with a swift approach to the subject:  societies must change from within and governments can play important roles in education about and respect for freedom.   There should be conformity of rights inside our borders so that the people are not forced to change State in order to see their rights respected.  I consider this report to be highly strategic especially when it affirms that the European Union, when dealing with other Nations, must exert greater pressure on respect for human rights.  I also firmly support the idea that the humanitarian aid that we deliver must have a stronger interconnection with the efforts of governments that receive this aid regarding their human rights policies.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, being aware of the very importance of it and the important role of the European Parliament and the EU as a whole in the defence of human rights around the world. Much remains to be done to achieve full respect for human rights, and from this institution we must raise our voices against those who do not respect the most basic rights of every man, woman and child. The European Parliament must continue to participate in the European Union's human rights dialogues and continue to watch over any human rights violations around the world.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. For European Socialists, the defence, promotion and respect for human rights is a central and vertebrate element of EU foreign policy. This annual report represents one of Parliament's main instruments for monitoring and guiding Union action in this area. This year's text, drafted by a socialist rapporteur, provides an innovative perspective, focusing on cross-cutting and thematic issues, and contains specific recommendations on the main challenges facing human rights around the world.  Among the most noteworthy elements that have been introduced – despite in many cases the vote against the Group of the People's Party – are the strong defense of women's sexual and reproductive rights, the impetus for recognition of same-sex marriage or the concept of climate refugees.  The report strongly defends the universality and indivisibility of human rights in the face of the rise of the discourse of cultural relativism and addresses very important areas where further progress is needed such as the role of businesses, especially large multinationals, and strengthening the coherence of EU policies.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I would like to vote in favour of Mr Panzeri's report on human rights and democracy in the world of the Union, an invitation to a commitment by Europe to place human rights not only at the heart of social policies within the Union and the individual Member States, but also to make them central and priority in relations with third countries and in the substance of trade agreements themselves. The European Union must confirm itself as the 'home of dignity and human rights', a banner of inclusive, democratic human policies and guarantees of peace balances, fighting with all its measures great evils such as corruption, religious intolerances, violence against women and children, homophobia and trafficking in human beings, which are unfortunately still raging in too many parts of the world. The EU is promoting international justice that does not leave the perpetrators of major war crimes and genocide unpunished and that guarantees all those human rights defenders who are all too often imprisoned in the world to defend and promote freedom and the protection of dignity.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The globalisation of markets and the devastating economic crisis have undermined one of the fundamental human rights: the guaranteed, protected right to work, accessible to men and women without discrimination. It is therefore appropriate to call for social responsibility, freedom of trade union association, condemnation of all forms of exploitation that injure the most vulnerable: women, children and the disabled. The issue of growth and development has taken on strategic importance on our political agenda, an objective that cannot be separated from the protection of people's dignity.  I like to share the call for respect for human rights in the context of trade agreements and in every international agreement. Not just any job, but quality work as a non-negotiable human right. I would also like to stress the position taken on the issues of gender representation in politics and institutions. The principle of equal democracy is fully part of the vocabulary of human rights that have been mortified or even denied. A convinced vote in favour, which restores authority to Parliament's political action.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. – I supported this report which, through its thematic approach, provides a clear and comprehensive overview of crucial human rights issues in the world and, coinciding with the conclusion of the human rights cycle initiated in 2012 by the EEAS, sends a strong signal to the External Action Service on key actions that need to be taken to promote human rights in our foreign policies.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I thank Mr Panzeri for this very comprehensive report. I would particularly like to thank him for putting it in black and white that while wars and violent civil conflicts are being fought throughout the world, the greatest tragedy is taking place right on europe's borders. The Mediterranean is the region with the highest mortality, a cemetery that in 2013 alone counted more than 3,000 deaths. We talk a lot about human rights, but we violate the right to life of those who, in complete despair, are trying to reach Europe. And we also violate their right to asylum. The Dublin Regulation does not allow us to respect the right to international protection. As long as this burden is borne by a few Member States, in the total indifference of others, Europe will not be able to teach anyone lessons in civilisation and respect for their rights.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against the annual report on human rights and democracy in the world in 2013. This report is nothing more than a neocolonial manifesto: human rights are used to enshrine the principle of interference, as the "right of the people" was once used to enshrine the gunboat policy. This report thus distributes the good and the bad points, according to the dominant ideology, even if it means taking sanctions against sovereign states whose laws would not suit the ruling class. Of course, the report also promotes immigration, under the guise of a right of asylum that has long been known to be used to justify settlement immigration. Finally, the report intends to dictate the family policies of all Member States, for example by promoting same-sex marriage or civil union. However, the principle of subsidiarity, if understood and applied by The Europeanists, would require that issues relating to family policies and civil status be left to the sole discretion of the Member States.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against it because despite agreeing on the main issues relating to the current human rights situation in the world and having tabled many amendments introducing such important issues as peoples' self-determination, political asylum, land grabbing, gender equality... we believe that the final report excludes these issues, mainly those related to sexual and reproductive rights as well as the rights of the LGBT collective. One of the most controversial points in the report is annex 1, which refers to a list of 'prisoners of conscience', setting aside the danger that this entails in the field of defence of human rights. Such a list could lead to instrumentalization of these issues to the extent that it is based on the epES' urgencies, where certain countries have more prominence over others.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I regret that the European Parliament has adopted the Report by Mr Pier Panzeri on the 2013 Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World and the European Union (EU) policy as it stands. This is yet another document that undermines Christian values by promoting abortion and gay marriage. In accordance with EU Treaty law and the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, philosophical issues are the responsibility of the Member States. I voted against this resolution because it encroaches on the competences of the Member States in violating the principle of subsidiarity. I firmly believe that the EU should not impose a definition of marriage on the Member States. Nor is it the role of the EU institutions to promote abortion or gay marriage, but to respect the established law contained in the Treaties.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted last Thursday in favour of the Panzeri report, which presents an overview of human rights and democracy in the world. It is an important tool to report on progress and critical situations that still need concrete action. However, I would like to point out that I abstained on paragraph 162, which aims to encourage other Member States of the European Union "to contribute more to the recognition of same-sex marriage or same-sex civil union as a political, social and civil rights issue". Indeed, I felt that this paragraph did not respect the principle of subsidiarity, which is that, for family policies, each State remains sovereign and therefore decides what it thinks is good for the common good of its country.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. For European Socialists, the defence, promotion and respect for human rights is a central and vertebrate element of EU foreign policy. This annual report represents one of Parliament's main instruments for monitoring and guiding Union action in this area. This year's text, drafted by a socialist rapporteur, provides an innovative perspective, focusing on cross-cutting and thematic issues, and contains specific recommendations on the main challenges facing human rights around the world.  Among the most noteworthy elements that have been introduced - despite in many cases the vote against the Group of the People's Party - are the strong defence of women's sexual and reproductive rights, the impetus for recognition of same-sex marriage or the concept of climate refugees.  The report strongly defends the universality and indivisibility of human rights in the face of the rise of the discourse of cultural relativism and addresses very important areas where further progress is needed such as the role of businesses, especially large multinationals, and strengthening the coherence of EU policies.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. I have contributed my voice to Mr Panzeri's report on human rights, democracy in the world and the European Union's policy on human rights, at a time when there have been terrible violations of these same rights. How can we effectively stop these cases that are reported to us every day? Among the proposals made, I note in particular that sanctions should be adopted in the event of a serious violation of human rights by a partner country with which the European Union has reached an agreement. Or the strengthening of the management and control of the responsibility of EU funds for the defence of human rights, in order to avoid any misappropriation and to act as a deterrent. Among the issues raised, such as the definition of climate refugee, minority rights or a moratorium on the application of the death penalty, I have been particularly committed to recognizing the inalienable rights of women and girls to dispose of their bodies and their right to access to care and abortion. We must prevent a young girl from being subjected to female genital mutilation around the world every five minutes.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. For European Socialists, the defence, promotion and respect for human rights is a central and vertebrate element of EU foreign policy. This annual report represents one of Parliament's main instruments for monitoring and guiding Union action in this area. This year's text, drafted by a socialist rapporteur, provides an innovative perspective, focusing on cross-cutting and thematic issues, and contains specific recommendations on the main challenges facing human rights around the world.  Among the most noteworthy elements that have been introduced – despite in many cases the vote against the Group of the People's Party – are the strong defense of women's sexual and reproductive rights, the impetus for recognition of same-sex marriage or the concept of climate refugees.  The report strongly defends the universality and indivisibility of human rights in the face of the rise of the discourse of cultural relativism and addresses very important areas where further progress is needed such as the role of businesses, especially large multinationals, and strengthening the coherence of EU policies.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. I am satisfied with the overall economy of the text. However, I regret that, once again, left-wing groups have tried to include disqualifying statements towards Member States of the European Union that do not share their current thoughts on same-sex marriage. Same-sex marriage and surrogacy are, I say and repeat, national subjects, which therefore do not have to be regulated by Europe.  I guarantee that the European Parliament would gain credibility if it were not systematically the subject of media attention for positions that are totally out of step with the immediate concerns of European citizens.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against it because despite agreeing on the main issues relating to the current human rights situation in the world and having tabled many amendments introducing such important issues as peoples' self-determination, political asylum, land grabbing, gender equality... we believe that the final report excludes these issues, mainly those related to sexual and reproductive rights as well as the rights of the LGBT collective. One of the most controversial points in the report is annex 1, which refers to a list of 'prisoners of conscience', setting aside the danger that this entails in the field of defence of human rights. Such a list could lead to instrumentalization of these issues to the extent that it is based on the epES' urgencies, where certain countries have more prominence over others.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted to accept the Resolution on the 2013 Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World, and I consider this to be a fundamental issue whose aspects should be included in all the political, social and economic processes that the Union deals with. The rule of law, freedom of expression, respect for human rights, an independent judiciary define a democratic society. Today, most of the world's population does not live in such conditions, therefore it is imperative to develop relationships that create prerequisites for improving such a situation. I support the fact that human rights have become an important part of the Union's actions in bilateral, multilateral and institutional relations. I also welcome the proposal to maintain the position of EU Special Representative for Human Rights and become a permanent function with all the prerequisites for effective work.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. This report once again underlines the ideological line supported by the institutions of the European Union and some parliamentary groups. Under the pretext of defending human rights, this report proposes to the Union and other international institutions to interfere in the affairs of a State concerning, for example, the right of asylum and immigration, which nevertheless falls under the regal powers of a State. Human rights are used here for purely political and indistingoful purposes: to support communitarianism through the legal recognition of sexual orientations. I voted against this text, which makes Europe the standard of these illegitimate demands.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Pier Antonio Panzeri's report on the state of human rights and democracy in the world in 2013. This report recalls the importance of integrating human rights and democracy into all EU activities and pays particular attention to issues such as freedom of religion and freedom of expression or violence against women and girls. This text therefore provides a comprehensive overview, underscoring the extent of the work to be done and the support that the Union and the Member States can provide. The report was adopted by a large majority of 390 votes in person, 151 against and 97 abstentions, which I welcome.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I believe that respect for human rights, including economic, cultural, social and environmental rights, access to food, good governance, democratic values, peace, security and access to a fair and effective judicial system, is a prerequisite for reducing poverty and inequality. I also believe that commitments on governance and human rights are measurable and can be monitored transparently and in the light of the principles of democracy, the rule of law, universality and the ini purity of human rights and fundamental freedoms, respect for human dignity, the principles of equality and solidarity and the principle of the promotion of international law and justice; , while respecting the principles of the Charter of the United Nations, the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and international law, placing 'man and human dignity at the heart of EU action', as is apparent from the preamble to the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Human rights are part of the European Union's ethical and legal basis and for the Labour Party MEPs this is a major political commitment on foreign policy. I therefore very much welcome the report. It is an important evaluation instrument that Parliament uses and it calls inter alia for binding, enforceable and non-negotiable human rights clauses to be included in the EU's international agreements, common standards for the reception of refugees to be guaranteed, and a human-rights-based crisis-prevention element to be developed and included in the forthcoming revised European Security Strategy.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. - No, because it's all wrong. You have to build from the ground up. Just like we have to sweep our own house. The European Union has plenty to do. Starting with colonialism, profit-making through slave and child labor, and even wars and many things. First authenticity, example, then you can lead others on the right path with a good example. Secondly, the reorganization of society, the smallest unit of which is the family from the beginning of time. Within it there is a place for the rights of the individual, but at all times in accordance with his duties. The rest is after this.

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the adoption of this resolution we reaffirm the importance of protecting human rights and democracy in the world. The Member States must commit themselves to ensuring that the rights of all are respected, protecting minorities and helping those in difficult situations by all possible means. We want greater surveillance and guarantees for the protection of rights, through awareness-raising initiatives that spread the idea of equality and respect. Minorities are still not sufficiently protected today, even within the territory of the Union.  Today you are still discriminated against for your sexual preferences, for your beliefs and for the color of your skin. We must say enough and stop these injustices against the weakest. We all have a duty to ensure respect and dignity for all human beings. It is therefore important that this resolution should become the instrument through which positive change takes place for our own and future generations. We must be united and work to make this possible.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. Like the other Members of the National Front, I voted against the annual report on human rights and democracy in the world and the European Union's policy on human rights and democracy in this area. It is, of course, positive that the European Union is concerned about human rights in the world. However, this concern too often manifests itself ideologically and in a partisan way. This resolution provides several examples. Apparently, non-European immigration to Member States is considered a fundamental right in paragraph 183 of the text. Human rights are used to excuse and encourage a lax immigration policy. Not only is there a call to 'develop adequate channels of lawful migration', it is also a need to rob Member States of the possibility of applying their own asylum policy by imposing 'effective common standards for reception procedures across the Union'. This attack on the sovereignty of the Member States has nothing to do with the defence of human rights, it only enlarges the democratic deficit that characterizes the European Union.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report as it completely ignores the deterioration of the human rights situation in Western Sahara. In recent years, the situation in ̶ territory pending ̶ has worsened significantly in terms of freedom of association, freedom of expression and freedom of assembly. In this regard, there is no call for the release of political prisoners and Morocco is also not called upon to allow access to occupied Sahara by independent observers or Members of the European Parliament. The report mentions the situation of other specific cases, but by ignoring this particular I have found me without the possibility of voting in favour.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: In writing – The 2013 Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World is an important document that, based on its findings, sets out the path to be taken further in the field of human rights. It is important to keep working on an effective system for controlling respect for human rights throughout the European Union.   At the same time, a policy of implementing and respecting human rights and democracy by all EU institutions and bodies and by the Member States must be pursued internationally.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I abstained from the vote as there is more EU bilingualism on the issue of the protection of human rights in the world, at a time when the troika has, without any consequence, violated human rights in the countries that were put to a memorandum and especially in Greece. As the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe held that austerity leads to the violation of human rights, mercely austerity, which the European Union serves with religious reverence, leads to a massive and persistent violation of the human rights of the citizens of the Union.  What does the Commission say about all this? He goes on to "business as usual," insisting on austerity. Therefore, before the European Union supposedly decides to save the world, it is better to put its own house in order.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which uses human rights to justify the interference of the European institutions. The report suggests assessing the situation and actions of countries to the point of proposing sanctions if the national laws in place in the countries do not correspond to Brussels' expectations.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I cannot support the annual report on 'human rights and democracy in the world in 2013 and the European Union's human rights policy'. The report contains rules which undermine the principle of subsidiarity, as laid down in Article 100a of the Treaty. Article 5 of the Treaty on European Union. That is why I cannot agree, while fully supporting the need to combat female genital mutilation, early and forced child marriages and marital rape, all of which are contrary to European values and contrary to respect for human rights.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although the Panzeri report contains references, which I fully support, to the need to promote full respect for human rights in european foreign policy, I felt it appropriate to abstain from voting on it. Too many references to matters of national competence. There is no shortage of delicate elements in the text which, in my opinion, help to make the document totally inconsistent.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. I could not agree with the 2013 annual report on human rights and democracy in the world and the European Union's policy in this area. While the preservation of human rights and the promotion of democracy worldwide are essential objectives, the report is, in some respects, far from achieving these objectives. The arbitrary distribution of financial resources to any civil society or the promotion of lobbies that focus on different sexual tendencies definitely cannot be supported. Furthermore, the points relating to migration and refugees must be rejected, as these do not constitute sensible solutions.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained in the final vote on this report as I believe that matters covered in this report are subject to the subsidiarity principle.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This annual report on human rights around the world contains good elements. We have avoided the usual cartoonish passages on Cuba and Venezuela and I welcome the denunciation of mass surveillance even though the United States is not named. On the abolition of the death penalty or LGBTI rights, fortunately the amendments in the vote in the parliamentary committee of the right and the FN did not pass.  But, to the detriment of the sovereign positions of the Member States, it pursues the objective of "speaking with one voice" on foreign policy, going so far as to ask for a seat for the Union at the United Nations without foreseening that this cannot be the one already occupied by my country with the other victors of the Second World War. It calls for strengthening the financing instruments of organisations abroad, a tool for interference in third countries that sometimes funds NGOs and opposition organizations. Instead of inviting the Ukrainian conflict to be resolved, he sees Russia as a "strategic problem". I'm voting against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this report because I am at odds with the way some issues are addressed here. In particular, the recommendations for the adoption of quotas for women and issues relating to free access to voluntary termination of pregnancy.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Despite voting for the amendments in support of LGBTI rights, I could not support the final version of report, which regrettably includes unacceptable references to abortion.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ the report submitted on human rights and democracy in the world encroaches on areas where the Union and therefore the European Parliament do not have competence under the Constituent Treaties. This concerns, in particular, the regulation of abortion and the regulation of family law, including the recognition or non-recognition of so-called same-sex marriages, which are a matter for the Member States.  In this respect, I reiterate in this House that no international human rights document or EU law recognised the right to abortion as a human right.  However, it should be stressed that the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights clearly enshrines the 'right of everyone to life', and that right is not only required by the EU institutions, including the EP, not only to respect but also to protect and promote in their recommendations.  I therefore consider it unacceptable that, periodically, ep own-initiative reports should appear in formulations encouraging easy access to contraception and abortion, or condemning or criticising The Member States for implementing their contractually enshrined family law rights. For these reasons, I voted against all the amendments in this spirit.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This year, the report on the Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World 2013 is particularly important as it coincides with the conclusion of the human rights cycle initiated in 2012 by the EEAS. I fully support most of the references in the Report in relation to Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender/Transsexual and Intersex (LGBTI) rights, EU action against the death penalty, EU action against torture and other cruel, inhuman and degrading treatment or punishment, EU action to ensure freedom of expression rights online and offline and to limit the impact of surveillance technologies on human rights, rights of persons with disabilities and children’s rights, among others, including EU action on immigration. Nevertheless, I have never supported any references to sexual and reproductive health, rights, services and abortion and therefore I voted against those parts in paragraphs 135, 136 and 164, which impinge into competences of the Member States to decide on their health policies

name: Angelika Mlinar (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ It is really important that the European Parliament express itself on the implementation of the EU annual report on human rights in order to give it a concrete dimension which underlines the centrality of human rights in EU external policies. Respect for human rights should be a European priority put in practice inside and outside our borders in full respect of the EU’s commitment to the Treaty obligation to mainstream human rights into all EU external policies without exception. The EU strategy should also take into account the situation of disadvantaged groups, which is an aspect that has been highlighted in the report and in particular in the opinion of the gender equality committee.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Unfortunately, the optimism of the 1990s about the world swiftly embracing liberal democracy is firmly behind us. The EU has remained a force for good, but it needs both an extra dose of realism as to what is possible and where, and to be less consumed by its own problems and crises in its neighbourhoods, if it is to make more of a difference.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report advocates the indivisibility, invulnerability and universality of human rights and the need to make human rights a central element in all the Union's relations with third countries. Calls for EU support for human rights defenders and human rights organisations. It combats the death penalty, torture and other cruel, inhuman and degrading treatment or punishment. It deals in detail with issues of freedom of expression, including the provision of freedom of expression online, freedom of assembly and association, freedom of thought, conscience and religion, women's and children's rights, minority rights such as the rights of persons with disabilities, LGBTI and national minorities, corruption, trafficking in human beings and migration. At the same time, it is important that the principles of democracy and the rule of law do not apply in some Member States of the European Union. Europe can only credibly act abroad if the principles of human rights are fully applied at home.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal is to examine the European Union's policy on human rights and the establishment of democracy in the world in 2013. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that it is essential that there is a central role of human rights in the European Union's external policies, and the EU itself should take a more central and determined position in improving citizens' rights, freedoms and guarantees. However, I voted against the proposal to have "a safe and legal termination of pregnancy" because I argued that prevention measures, family planning should first be adopted and contraceptive methods should be made available to prevent pregnancy, thereby protecting the safeguarding of the human right.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. The report shows questionable interference in the foreign policy of the Member States. Indeed, it intends to require Member States to integrate, in all circumstances, the notion of human rights into their diplomatic relations. While this intention can be commendable and full of good feelings, it is an intolerable interference in the affairs of the Member States, which could have dangerous, even neo-imperialist consequences. There is a demand for the systematic inclusion of non-negotiable binding clauses in international agreements.  At the level of the Member States, it wants to force states in their fight against immigration by prohibiting them from deporting a refugee...  I voted against this report.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the 2013 annual report on human rights and democracy in the world and the European Union's policy in this area. In particular, I voted in favour of paragraph 136, which calls on Member States to guarantee women and girls the inalienable right to physical integrity and self-decision-making, particularly with regard to the right to legal abortion.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The protection and protection of human rights is one of the main aims of the European Union, not only as regards its own population but also as regards the population of the third states with which it has relations. The 'Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World in 2013 and on the European Union's human rights policy' addresses this issue courageously, reminding us of this end and our role.  There is a clear political will in the text: to extend rights instead of restricting them, by shifting the auction higher and higher to make an effective contribution to reducing injustices in the world, and with them also inequalities. To remind all of us that there is a way to grow without leaving anyone behind and that diversity is a value that must be protected and valued. For these reasons, I confirm my vote in favour without any reservations.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I obviously voted for this report because it lists violations of fundamental rights around the world and establishes or recalls the Union's position on these infringements and how to remedy them. Nevertheless, while I strongly condemn violence against women and homosexuals, I have voted to ensure that the issues of access to abortion and same-sex marriage, which are part of the internal debate of each nation-state, should not be subjects on which the European Union takes a stand.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the Panzeri report because I believe that the text undermines certain matters that are strictly a matter for the Member States. As defined in Article 5 of the Treaty on European Union, in areas which do not have its exclusive competence, the Union must intervene only when its action is considered more effective than that undertaken at national, regional or local level. Having noted that this is not the case, I think it would be appropriate for the principle of subsidiarity to be respected.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the report and am very pleased to record the need to review the human rights clauses of the European Union's international treaties signed with third states, in particular against China and Russia. We must say that they threaten the success of international relations by grossly violating human rights, and this has an impact on economic, social and political life. It is time for human rights to become an integral part of our international relations and treatirea and all our political actions. Let the European Union be an example to third countries. But to do that, we have to keep order in our own front door.  It is untenable to speak out against third countries, for example, for the fundamental human right to a fair trial, while in Slovakia, an EU Member State, Malina Hedvig, is being prosecuted by the State against her own citizen. He does so because he cannot face the fact that the schoolgirl was indeed beaten in the street in 2006 because she spoke Hungarian in her native language. It's time to put an account of double standards. It's time to face our own demons at home.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report as it compiles very important work done at an international level to identify, catalogue and propose options for all cases of human rights violations found. The situation in 2013 was in many ways an improvement from previous years, often due to the hard work done by the UN and the EU together. At the same time, I am afraid that the events following the Arab Spring, the war in Syria and Iraq, and now in Ukraine, might lead to a worsened reality from this perspective. That is why I hope all partners of the European Parliament will take note of this report and take steps, where possible, to better protect the rights and freedoms of people all over the world.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. In the founding treaties, the EU commits itself to basing its action at international level on principles such as human rights and minority rights. Unfortunately, these are all just words that fail even within the European Union. With regard to minorities, the EU still has a lot of work to do. Unfortunately, for me, this report does not guarantee human rights. First and foremost, human rights must be ensured with clear objectives and strategies. That is why I voted against the report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the annual report on human rights and democracy. Respect for and protection of the universality and indivisibility of human rights is the basis for the EU's foreign and security policy. Many authoritarian regimes have seriously questioned the universality of human rights. The EU must protect the indivisibility and integrity of human rights. Early warning signals, such as the repression of minorities and human rights violations, pointing to potential conflicts and humanitarian catastrophes must be identified.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece voted against the report 'on human rights and democracy in the world and EU policy in this area', as it is clear from this that human rights are determined each time by the EU, depending on the interests of the companies which it regards as their guardians.  In particular, the report shows that human rights are used by the EU as a tool for pressure and threats in third countries, in the search for new markets for capital interests, and are used as a pretext for imperialist interventions and the "fight against terrorism" that blood peoples. References to 'freedom and democracy' are hypocritical at the same time as the EU is working with reactionary fascist forces, such as in Ukraine, where these forces are persecuting the Ukrainian KK with the aim of putting it into law. The pre-election of child labour is a hypocritical wish list, since the report recognises and accepts it. The rights of each people are documented, guaranteed and guaranteed only when they are made by their own authority, released from the EU, the owner of the wealth they produce.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report. I am fully in the recommendations of this text which invites the European Union to speak with one voice in the UN institutions. The thematic and non-ad hominem approach chosen by the rapporteur has highlighted a number of challenges - the definition of the term climate refugee or the fight against the death penalty - and is very effective in guiding our external action. For this, the report has received my full support.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that due to the dramatic deterioration of the security environment across the EU, the international order based on Europe's law, stability and security has been called for at unprecedented levels since the beginning of European integration, which highlights the ongoing transformation of the world political order; whereas an ambitious and effective UNION foreign policy must be based on a shared vision of key European interests, values and objectives in external relations, as well as on a common perception of threats against the EU as a whole; whereas priority should be given to a process of strategic reflection on the EU's foreign and security policy;  whereas, due to recent developments, it is necessary to develop a new European security strategy that takes account of recent geopolitical changes and can therefore provide a response to new challenges and threats; I voted in favour.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I regret the fact that a report which should be dedicated to enlightening the value of human dignity has been hijacked through amendments against the fundamental right to human life. From this standpoint, I was unable to support the resolution as whole, as I would not be able to vote in favour of any text which does not respect human dignity from the moment of conception onwards. I can hardly accept that our House make recommendations on issues which under the principle of subsidiarity are the exclusive concern of the Member States, and it is up to them to decide on how to deal with the matter.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I welcome the adoption of the amendment I insisted on, which we have taken out of paragraph 165 the inadmissible calling of Croatia as an EU member state for holding a referendum on the constitutional protection of marriage in 2013. This corrected the injustice of calling on Member States to use democratic institutes in matters of importance to their citizens, making the Report inappropriately entered into the editing of internal policies which are the responsibility of the Member States. In the same way, the report entered the internal affairs of two other Member States, Slovakia and Lithuania, illegally in that paragraph.  I could not support the overall report because, unfortunately, despite the amendments invested, it retained references to the right to abortion and sexual and reproductive rights, in breach of the principle of subsidiarity within the European Union. In the same way, these topics are inappropriately imposed on countries outside the European Union which must also have the right to decide these topics on their own. It grieves me that the European Union is increasingly turning into an abortion promoter instead of a life promoter.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
