text: in writing. \u2012 I find it paradoxical that even today, despite the progress made by societies, it is still of primary importance to fight to ensure that all people can enjoy their rights, and so that they are not violated or completely suppressed. It should no longer be necessary to reaffirm a principle such as freedom of expression, thought, belief or sexual orientation, but there are still many people who are victims of abuse and who are denied these freedoms. My commitment, like that of the whole Parliament, is to guarantee and guarantee these human rights to all, specifically those minorities who suffer discrimination for their beliefs or for their ethnic, political or cultural affiliation. At international level, rights must be universally and fully protected, they must be extended to all peoples and in particular to those with whom the European Union maintains relations, so that this Parliament's political commitment to the promotion and protection of human rights does not fail.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ 2012 2013 was not the brightest example of respect for human rights, both in the European Union and in the world in general, despite the fact that on 23 June 2014, The Council adopted the EU's 2013 Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World, covering the first full year of implementation of the EU Strategic Framework and Action Plan for Human Rights and Democracy. The number of incidents related to freedom of religion or belief has increased drastically, as a result of, among other things, the increasing number of conflicts with religious features. 2013 is also the first full year of the new mandate of the EU Special Representative for Human Rights and the holder of this function should help the Union to coordinate its activities so that its actions in promoting respect for human rights around the world, in particular women's rights, are clearer and more pronounced. I would like to support, first of all, the part of the report that highlights the clear link between corruption and human rights violations. Sometimes, violations of rights in this way do not seem clear and obvious, but corruption in the public and private sectors encourages and exacerbates inequalities and discrimination and prevents the equal exercise of civil, political, economic, social and cultural rights. Unfortunately, EU citizens are still too often subjected to violations of their rights in this way.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Freedom, democracy and respect for human rights are fundamental values of our Union. Every year, the European Parliament publishes a report on human rights and democracy around the world.  The text adopted today deals with the situation of these rights in 2013 and sets out the EU's priorities. I am pleased to have voted in favour of this report. I wanted to stress that I am particularly attached to French values: women must maintain control over their health and their sexual and reproductive rights. On this particular point, I will not compromise.  However, even if we have to present a position, I would like to point out that the Union must respect the principle of subsidiarity: these subjects must remain the domain of States, in the same way as family and civil union issues between persons of the same sex.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU's common foreign and security policy must be guided by the defence of democracy, the rule of law, human rights and fundamental freedoms and respect for human dignity. The report stresses, however, that more than half of the world's population still lives under undemocratic regimes and that, over the past few years, global freedom has declined and numerous human rights violations have been recorded. In this context, it calls on the EU institutions and the Member States to give human rights a privileged place in their relations with third countries. To this end, it calls on the EU to effectively integrate human rights and democracy into development cooperation. It also condemns all forms of violence and discrimination based on ideology, religion or belief and calls for the recognition of women's inalienable rights to physical integrity. In this context, the rapporteur refers to the right of women to a legal termination of pregnancy. This is an aspect on which I have expressed my disagreement, and in this regard it is to remind you that this matter is the responsibility of the Member States. In any case, in view of the relevance of the issues dealt with in this resolution, I voted in favour.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. The annual report on human rights and democracy in the world in 2013 shows that much work remains to be done, particularly with regard to EU intervention. However, small steps have been taken towards the realising of human rights, not only in the EU's external policies, but also in internal ones. It is important that human rights are a primary objective of all eu institutions and all their Member States.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. We adopted yesterday (by 336 votes in each, 145 against and 64 abstentions) the annual report on the European Union's Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP). In summary, the text of the report suggests an improvement in internal working methods and institutional structures, the preservation and strengthening of the European political and legal order, and the strengthening of the rules-based world order.  In this text, we were concerned about the lack of coordination and coherence between EU policies and stressed how financial and budgetary constraints further restrict Europe's influence in the world and its role in the service of regional and global security. The watermark question in this report was, of course: how can a foreign policy be credible if it does not rely on the adequate defence capabilities of the Member States and an effective common security and defence policy (SDP)? In view of the current situation, the question is now even more acute and I hope that the summit of heads of state and government scheduled for June can help to move things forward in this area...

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution on the EU Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World in 2013 contains several considerations in which I see myself, first of all because I consider the european institutions' noblest functions to pro-action the promotion of human rights in the EU's relationship with third countries. And in this respect, the European Parliament has taken on a crucial role throughout its history, of which the Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Thought is just one of its many most visible faces. However, I draw attention to the unenforceability of introducing binding human rights clauses, with enforceable force and non-negotiable in all international agreements. Such a proposal would inhibit the conclusion of agreements with countries that do not have human rights standards as high as those of the Union and this is not the very specific scope of European foreign trade policy.  That said, and like another report voted at this session (A8-0015/2015), the vote on a set of separate amendments/votes failed to eliminate a number of considerations contained in the final report, notably Article 136 thereof, and I therefore voted against the final report.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. As every year, the European Parliament this lunchtime looked at the situation of human rights and democracy in the world. While the annual report deals with 2013, the trend is there, violent, with the proliferation of regional conflicts. When one does not fall into outright barbarism, with an increase of 15 to 24 in the number of countries victims of acts of terrorism that have claimed more than 50 lives. What constructive role can the European Union play in this global concert where more than half of the population still lives under undemocratic regimes? Certainly start by speaking with one voice and draw a common foreign policy in the major areas of influence of the planet. To be effective also in the territories where disorder reigns and which serves as the backbone of terrorism: the Sahel region, for example, and Libya in particular. Another problem to highlight is that the Union must bring its actions into line with its writings in the event of a clear violation of human rights by a partner country. The economic price to be paid will sometimes be significant, but nothing short of the legitimacy gained from public opinion.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote against it because the report, apart from a few chapters, is totally demagogic and unbalanced. It calls, for example, for more rights and protections for the Roma; the introduction of systems and efforts for the rights of migrants, refugees and asylum seekers in accordance with the principle of non-refoulement; the establishment of the figure of the "climate refugee", that is, those who are forced to leave their country as a result of environmental disasters due to climate change.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against it because despite agreeing on the main issues relating to the current human rights situation in the world and having tabled many amendments introducing such important issues as peoples' self-determination, political asylum, land grabbing, gender equality... we believe that the final report excludes these issues, mainly those related to sexual and reproductive rights as well as the rights of the LGBT collective. One of the most controversial points in the report is annex 1, which refers to a list of 'prisoners of conscience', setting aside the danger that this entails in the field of defence of human rights. Such a list could lead to instrumentalization of these issues to the extent that it is based on the epES' urgencies, where certain countries have more prominence over others.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this annual report, which takes stock of the state of respect for human rights and democracy in the world in 2013. The text reminds us that the European Union puts the person and human dignity at the heart of its action.  The text calls for the systematic inclusion of binding human rights clauses in EU international agreements, including trade agreements with third countries. Parliament also reaffirms its unequivocal position in favour of the abolition of the death penalty and is concerned about the persistence of the high number of executions in China, Iran, Indonesia, Saudi Arabia and Vietnam. In addition, the resolution strongly condemns attacks on Christian communities in Africa, Asia and the Middle East, and more generally attacks on religious minorities.  On the other hand, I prefer to abstain on the paragraph which 'encourages the institutions of the Union and the Member States to contribute more to the reflection on the recognition of same-sex marriage', because I believe that this issue falls within the exclusive competence of the Member States.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Having regard to my positive vote on the report on the ‘Annual report on human rights and democracy in the world 2013 and the EU policy on the matter’, I would like to clarify that such vote excludes approval for those clauses which signify acceptance of abortion, and on which I abstained when roll—call votes were called.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report as it completely ignores the deterioration of the human rights situation in Western Sahara. In recent years, the situation in ̶ territory pending ̶ has worsened significantly in terms of freedom of association, freedom of expression and freedom of assembly. In this regard, there is no call for the release of political prisoners and Morocco is also not called upon to allow access to occupied Sahara by independent observers or Members of the European Parliament. The report mentions the situation of other specific cases, but by ignoring this particular I have found me without the possibility of voting in favour.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today we voted in favour of the Panzeri report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World 2013 and the European Union’s policy on the matter. This report is a forward-looking analysis of the EU’s activities in this policy area. The need for continued reflection on Parliament’s own practices has been highlighted in relation to the mainstreaming of human rights into its activities and to the follow-up of its urgency resolutions on breaches of democracy, human rights and the rule of law.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing – I consider the report on human rights and democracy in the world in 2013 and the EU's policy in this area to be very important. Even in the 21st century, respect for human rights is not commonplace in Europe and in the world. Still nationality, race, gender or religious affiliation are grounds for violating human dignity and law. But poverty and social exclusion, which reduce living standards, are also the cause of the failure to meet the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. Respect for human rights, including economic, cultural, social and environmental rights, access to food, peace, security and access to a fair and effective judiciary, is an essential prerequisite for reducing poverty and inequality in individual Member States, but also in the world. The EU supports many states, many development programmes, so financial and development support should also condition respect for fundamental human rights.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report under consideration contains an important communication linking human rights, migration and also relations with the European Union's strategic partners. In the latter, human rights should be high on the agenda. However, it is absolutely necessary for the support of human rights activists to continue by the European Parliament. The topic of human rights and democracy in the world is very challenging and important. That's why we have to pay attention to her all the time. The 2013 report also mentions the fight against terrorism, but we sometimes interfere with human rights concerns. In particular, this applies to measures which constitute powers to collect data which may interfere with greater control of people. It is precisely this control that can mean interference with human rights. I would therefore be concerned if we adopted a package of the so-called "patriotic act" and we would be tempted to strengthen the role of "big brother." In this light, it is important to cooperate with the Council of Europe, which is the institution with which we could co-develop a longer-term strategy in the field of the protection of human rights. The fight against human rights in all areas is very important and needs to be upgraded, which is why I supported this report.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which aims to improve the action of promotion of human rights in our European external action. Furthermore, I welcome its support of Western Saharan rights and the new themes of the report, including legislation on same-sex marriage or same-sex civil unions.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ 2013 World Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy Piero Antonio Panzeri was originally adopted by the Foreign Affairs Committee, preceded by a heated controversy given the compromised principles of subsidiarity, the fundamental principle of the functioning of the European Union.  The report was created to draw attention to the importance of respect for human rights in the field of EU foreign policies. It also highlights the need to systematically include binding agreements in human rights clauses in international agreements signed by the EU with third countries, including trade and investment, and calls on the Commission to propose a draft document containing a human rights component.  It is commendable that the Report contains recommendations for the fight against corruption, ideologies, and for the protection of children's rights, but it contained unacceptable references to the situation in the Member States, including a referendum held in Croatia that challenges the right to life. Paragraphs 136 and 164 directly undermine and undermine the subsidiarity of the Member States of the Union, which is against the EU acquis and that is why I did not support this Report.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: I abstained in writing ‒ I abstained from voting on the report because, although the report makes many recommendations and findings in the area of combating human rights violations, this report also significantly exceeds its powers and the area of human rights in many other cases. The report also aims to influence areas such as fiscal policy, migration, climate policy, asylum and migration policy and so on.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 In the report there are many problematic reports with which we disagree. It calls for the strengthening of tools which, in the name of promoting democracy and human rights, are used for interventions in the internal affairs of third countries. It also reiterates the recommendation to impose EU sanctions on countries that violate human rights, a policy for which we have serious objections. Particularly problematic is the attitude of the two measures and two stations observed with regard to human rights violations outside the EU and the reference to child labour, which appears to be accepted under conditions. The report also absences important elements which the Group of the European United Left has tried to incorporate through the tabling of amendments. Such references are the impact of the crisis on the rights and freedoms of European societies, the right of peoples to self-determination, opposition to PNR agreements, the responsibility of companies to compensate victims of accidents they caused, CIA torture and NSA surveillance with a call to suspend TTIP negotiations, and the fight against all forms of violence against women including psychological violence.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This report recognises excessive rights for homosexuals and, without receiving substantial provision to reduce illegal immigration, requires Member States to guarantee a multitude of rights to them.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution and in particular strongly support the need for the EU and the Member States to recognise, without unnecessary ideological divisions, women's inalienable rights to physical integrity and decision-making autonomy, voluntary family planning and safe and legal termination of pregnancy. In the light of this, I join in calling for the EU to champion the fight against attempts to undermine the UN Beijing Platform for Action at the 59th Session on the Status of Women, and in particular access to education and health, as fundamental human rights, and to sexual and reproductive rights.  Finally, it is essential to recognise (and encourage where not yet implemented) the growing political support for a ban on sterilisation as a requirement for legal recognition of gender. These requirements, where they are still present, should be treated and prosecuted as a violation of the right to physical integrity, sexual and reproductive health and the rights of the individual.

name: Charles Tannock (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This year’s annual report on human rights in the world contains some good and constructive paragraphs on issues like: support for human rights defenders and the International Criminal Court; action against torture, discrimination and persecution of ethnic and religious minorities; women’s and children’s rights; and the fight against corruption, human trafficking, sexual violence and exploitation. A number of ECR proposals are included, such as on how business and human rights are not necessarily two opposites, but can reinforce each other. An important ECR suggestion adopted is the warning against continuously expanding the catalogue of human rights, including with unrelated issues, or politically or ideologically controversial ideas, as this only undermines the acceptance of human rights as universal. However, the report also contains issues the ECR Group cannot support, or which are subject to a free vote for its members, such as an institutionalized EP presence at the UN, calls for the abolition of the death penalty, including in the US, and abortion and same-sex marriage. Finally, this report swerves into many other policy areas such as development, trade, fiscal policy, climate and asylum and migration policies, which is something the ECR strongly opposed.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. Sad coincidence of the calendar, this file comes just after the vote of the resolution on the murder of a Russian political leader, who died presumably for his ideas.  I, of course, voted in favour of the report of my eminent Colleague Panzeri. The institutions and Member States of the Union must put human rights at the heart of the Union's relations with all third countries, including its strategic partners, and at the heart of all high-level declarations and meetings.  As co-chair of the sports intergroup, I would also like to point out the nonsense of awarding major international sporting events to countries that are making a mockery of labour law and where human rights are constantly violated. This is unacceptable.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report calling on the EU Institutions and Member States to put human rights at the heart of the EU’s relations with all third countries. Indeed, human rights are a key component of the EU’s external action. In this context of international tension, the EU should play an active role in defending fundamental values such as freedoms, rule of law and democracy.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. This report is more than a state of affairs on human rights in the world, it is an action plan for their universal establishment. Once again, human rights are the real Trojan horse of the European institutions to enshrine the principle of interference: it is a question of distributing the good and the bad points, even if sanctions are taken if national laws do not correspond to the European vision. This report exploits emotions to justify the dismantling of the national sovereignty of Member States, particularly on immigration. This report seeks to enshrine the rights of active minorities at the expense of the common good and true respect for the intrinsic dignity of the human person. It highlights "in particular the guidelines to promote and protect all human rights of lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and intersex (LGBTI) people." One might start by questioning the new adjective granted to the "LGBT" influence group and thus the legal and political recognition of the status of "intersex". It is legitimate to ask why a particular minority, whether it reaches a sexual orientation or a religion, should be favoured under Community law. So I voted AGAINST.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that human rights are a fundamental chapter that deserves the respect of legislators. For this very reason, we owe it to ourselves to keep this chapter within the limits of clarity and to avoid inflation that can please special sub-groups. I believe that the report submitted to the vote has leaned dangerously towards legislating for the benefit of particular agendas. Since my view is that, in this way, fundamental principles and institutions of public law risk being compromised, I abstained.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. For European Socialists, the defence, promotion and respect for human rights is a central and vertebrate element of EU foreign policy. This annual report represents one of Parliament's main instruments for monitoring and guiding Union action in this area. This year's text, drafted by a socialist rapporteur, provides an innovative perspective, focusing on cross-cutting and thematic issues, and contains specific recommendations on the main challenges facing human rights around the world.  Among the most noteworthy elements that have been introduced – despite in many cases the vote against the Group of the People's Party – are the strong defense of women's sexual and reproductive rights, the impetus for recognition of same-sex marriage or the concept of climate refugees.  The report strongly defends the universality and indivisibility of human rights in the face of the rise of the discourse of cultural relativism and addresses very important areas where further progress is needed such as the role of businesses, especially large multinationals, and strengthening the coherence of EU policies.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report as it completely ignores the deterioration of the human rights situation in Western Sahara. In recent years, the situation in that territory - pending decolonization - has worsened significantly in terms of freedom of association, freedom of expression and freedom of assembly. In this regard, there is no call for the release of political prisoners and Morocco is also not called upon to allow access to occupied Sahara by independent observers or Members of the European Parliament. The report mentions the situation of other specific cases, but by ignoring this particular I have found me without the possibility of voting in favour.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted with my European Parliament Labour Party colleagues in favour of this report because it introduces an international tax on financial transactions for additional source of funding for development and one requesting the revision of the Dublin regulation when it comes to refugees and common asylum package.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 Every year, the European Parliament examines the evolution and state of affairs of human rights in the world. This report was about the human rights situation in 2013. The number of countries that fell victim to terrorist acts that year with more than 50 deaths rose from 15 to 24 - anything but a hopeful finding. This report makes it clear every year that the European Union will have to work harder to combat these human rights violations. The European Union urgently needs to speak with one voice and draw the card of the protection of human rights, even if it can cause us economic damage.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The new Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy (VP/AR) stated that human rights will be one of its main priorities and that it intends to use them as a reference point in all its relations with third countries; whereas it also reiterated the EU's commitment to promoting human rights in all areas of external relations "without any exception"; and that the adoption of the new EU Action Plan on Human Rights and Democracy and the renewal of the mandate of the EU Special Representative for Human Rights will be on the EU agenda in early 2015. In this sense, it is important to ask what will become of the various partnership agreements that the EU has with several countries where human rights are trampled on every day. The most egregious example is Israel. But there are other examples such as Morocco or Ukraine where the illegalisation of a political party is currently underway.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on human rights because I believe that EU policy must be increasingly clear on the issue of women's rights and LGBTI rights. As Socialists and Democrats, we can only stand in favour of a policy that guarantees security, legitimacy and self-determination. Some rights are and must remain inalienable, such as the physical integrity and decision-making autonomy of women.  Furthermore, we must ensure that homosexuality is no longer considered, under any circumstances, to be a criminal offence. We must fight, politically, against homophobic and transphobic discrimination and we must promote equality as the only way to overcome the constant violation of human rights.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I am opposed to this report. It is an incoherent series of issues that have nothing to do with human rights violations in the world. Looking through the report, I found that the EU even has its own 'Special Envoy for Human Rights' – an expensive post for a former member of the government, in this case Stravos Lambrinidis, a Socialist from Greece. The EP is once again calling for 'abortion as a human right', which makes recognition of same-sex marriage a fundamental concern of human rights, while condemning states that define marriage as a union between a man and a woman. The EP is committed to asking the World Health Organisation to define diseases no longer according to the state of medical research, but according to political guidelines. In a human rights report, the EP advocates an international transaction tax. I do not support all this and that is why I voted against this resolution.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted with my European Parliament Labour Party colleagues in favour of this report because it introduces an international tax on financial transactions as an additional source of funding for development, and requests the revision of the Dublin regulation when it comes to refugees and the common asylum package.

name: Kristina Winberg (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ There are many paragraphs in this text that call for action to be taken by the EU – which is something that I am against in principle. There are also other parts of this text that I do not support due to their content. However, I still chose to vote in favour of this report. This is because I consider it more important to support the principle of human rights, which is under attack in many parts of the world, than it is to oppose the growing influence of the EU or to object to individual notions of human rights that I may not support.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece voted against the report 'on human rights and democracy in the world and EU policy in this area', as it is clear from this that human rights are determined each time by the EU, depending on the interests of the companies which it regards as their guardians.  In particular, the report shows that human rights are used by the EU as a tool for pressure and threats in third countries, in the search for new markets for capital interests, and are used as a pretext for imperialist interventions and the "fight against terrorism" that blood peoples. References to 'freedom and democracy' are hypocritical at the same time as the EU is working with reactionary fascist forces, such as in Ukraine, where these forces are persecuting the Ukrainian KK with the aim of putting it into law.  The pre-election of child labour is a hypocritical wish list, since the report recognises and accepts it. The rights of each people are documented, guaranteed and guaranteed only when they become, under their own power, released from the EU, the owner of the wealth they produce.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ in preparation of the report on respect for human rights and democracy in the world, I was responsible for preparing an opinion on women's rights and gender equality. In my opinion, I pointed out that domestic violence is one of the most widespread human rights violations ever. I stressed that the key to tackling this issue is to train experts (health professionals, police officers, prosecutors and judges) so that they can adequately help and support victims of violence. At the same time, we need to work with young people in particular in order to learn as a society that bruises and slaps cannot be perceived as something normal. In my opinion, I also highlight the need to pay specific attention to women and children in war conflicts and humanitarian crises, underlining the need to improve the life chances of Roma women and the importance of promoting the principles of inclusive education. As the report also included topics (sexual and reproductive rights) which, in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, fall within the competence of the Member States, I could not support the report and abstained in the vote.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted against the 2013 Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World. Democracy and human rights are fundamental values whose role in building a just and citizen-friendly state is crucial. A huge number of people around the world cannot exercise their rights solely because they were born.  The EU's role in promoting the highest democratic standards is not to be underestimated. Our experience, which has been created over the centuries as a result of painful conflicts and difficult transformations, should set an example for other regions of the world. However, it cannot be accepted that harmful ideological ideas are being smuggled under the guise of promoting human rights. These are so-called sexual and reproductive rights, which are in practice a form of promoting the fight against unborn life. It is a misunderstanding to promote contraception and abortion as tools for building a democratic and just world. This is a pervert of the fundamental task of human rights, which is to protect the weak and defenceless from the strong. We cannot talk about democracy when it comes to taking lives. The promotion of gay marriage is also a form of adverse influence of ideology on the European Union's efforts to support the process of democratisation and human rights in the world. This traditional family, in which the opinion and role of each member is respected, guarantees the building of a stable, safe and democratic society.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Containing aspects with which we agree, this report is essentially characterised by a manipulative and reductive view of human rights - political, social, economic and cultural - using them as an element of interference and political pressure on some States, where so-called "friends" countries are safeguarded (by omission) and criticising "others", always tailored to the EU's interests and conveniences. We omit glaring situations, which we recall here: the aggression against the Sahrawi people and the illegal occupation of Western Sahara by Morocco; the illegal occupation of part of cyprus' territory by Turkey; the serious humanitarian situation in the Gaza Strip, along with Israel's belligerent occupation of Palestinian territory. All with EU and US coverage. In contrast to the principles and objectives that the resolution proclaims as guiding EU policies, in the face of the analysis expressed there in a clear exercise of hypocrisy, are the policies imposed on the peoples of Europe and the world, by the EU and the USA, which have contributed to the increase in inequalities, poverty, unemployment and job security, exploitation and hunger , in addition to the withdrawal of rights, freedoms and guarantees.  We disagree with unconditional support for the ICC. For these and other reasons, we voted against it.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I have voted for the resolution and I would like to mention two points in my explanation of vote. First, the fight against terrorism in Europe or in the Middle East cannot be an excuse for the violation of human dignity, even in the case of those responsible for terrorist attacks. Western civilisation built on the Christian values of love and honour to every human being must reject any practice of unjust trial, torture or tribal retaliation. Second, the global fight against terrorism must acknowledge the initiative of local religious minorities, namely Christians. They have boldly stood against the atrocities of terrorism, and are willing to protect their ancient communities.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because terrorism poses a direct threat to all countries and all people, regardless of their ethnicity, religion or beliefs. It can be countered only by a global alliance, in full conformity with international law, fundamental values and international human rights standards.  Counter-terrorism measures should not be abused to suppress legitimate dissent or violate people's universal human rights.  To ensure adequate democratic and judicial control, the Resolution calls for the recently signed agreement between the EU and the Arab League on counter-terrorism cooperation to be made public. The Resolution calls for action on the root causes of terrorism, including political and cultural issues and emphasizing prevention and deradicization. Finally, it calls for improved cooperation between the parties to promote, protect and defend human rights. It also calls on Arab countries and EU Member States to work towards greater protection of religious minorities in the Arab world and to give full effect to EU guidelines on freedom of religion or belief.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The resolution put to the vote makes an express mention of the human rights violations that take place in the member countries of the Arab League and which, in my view, are an obstacle to regarding that organization as an ally in the fight against terrorism. However, there is no express mention of the fact that some of the Member States of that organization actively finance and support the organization of the Islamic State, which avoids the main problem that needs to be addressed at the moment. For all this, I abstained.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – There are a number of positive aspects to this resolution. It talks about the importance of respecting fundamental rights in ‘counter-terrorism’ strategies and the need to deal with root causes. It calls for stopping the death penalty and the use of torture, and warns against the exploitation of ‘counter-terrorism’ strategies to attack opposition movements in some countries. It also calls for publication of the Memorandum of Understanding between the EU and LAS, which I agree would be in the interest of transparency and democratic accountability. However, there is no recognition that the recent rise in violent extremism in Iraq and Syria is related to the US—led invasion of Iraq in 2003 – which was supported by some EU Member States such as Britain – as is the subsequent destruction and destabilisation in that country and the surrounding region. I believe this is a significant omission. If the serious threat of violent extremism is to be stopped affectively, an honest and sufficient analysis of how the threat developed is required. Considering the positive aspects of the resolution and its shortcomings mentioned above, I voted ‘abstention’.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. As terrorism knows no borders, cooperation between the EU and the League of Arab States is an important step in the fight against terrorism worldwide. Such an initiative is very commendable.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. This resolution calls for increased cooperation between the European Union and the League of Arab States against terrorism and in particular Islamist terrorism. Rather balanced, with the necessary balance between freedom and security, and encourages the Member States of the Union to be firmer and more cooperative with the Arab League states in the common fight against terrorism. The resolution rightly recalls that some Arab League States, sometimes having very close relations with certain Member States of the Union, have shown guilty complacency towards Islamist terrorist groups. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution, while wishing for a deepening of cooperation in the fight against terrorism, particularly with the most exposed countries of Egypt, Syria and Iraq.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support efforts to counter terrorism, but once again this report refers to the EU’s role in foreign affairs and defence, which is better dealt with by the Member States (which often hold differing philosophies and therefore should not have to act en bloc). I therefore abstained.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution on the agreement between the EU and the League of Arab States to cooperate in the fight against terrorism. The EU faces a major threat posed by so-called EU foreign fighters, i.e. those who go to other countries to commit terrorist acts. Today, between 3,500 and 5,000 EU citizens have left the EU in order to become foreign fighters in Syria, Iraq and Libya. I agree that the EU must step up its cooperation with the League of Arab States, establish a special mechanism to curb the arms trade, pay particular attention to the threat posed by The Islamic State, which has become the main sponsor of terrorism in areas under its control and beyond, and to support international initiatives to combat radicalisation and terrorism. I support calls for closer cooperation with key partners and countries in the fight against terrorist financing. It is important to address the causes of radicalisation by supporting initiatives throughout the Arab world aimed at young people, education, vocational training, job opportunities and civil society.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this surprisingly balanced resolution, which calls for cooperation between the Member States of the European Union and the Arab League states in the fight against terrorism.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Given the transnational nature of the terrorist threat, it is essential that as many states and international organizations cooperate to combat this threat and thus ensure peace and stability in the world. That is why I voted in favour of the strategic dialogue between the European Union and the League of Arab States. The two entities have a common interest in finding lasting solutions to the problem of terrorism and jihadism.  However, as the document points out, it is imperative that this cooperation between the Union and the League of Arab States be transparent. It is indeed necessary to be able to exercise democratic and judicial control over this cooperation.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. The terrorist threat in Europe is increasingly present, especially with radical Islamists. It is the eu's need for the European Union to maintain relations with the League of Arab States in order to fight terrorism and to provide adequate measures. This resolution is balanced and I therefore voted in favour.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 While expressing some principles that we support, this report has many unclear passages that are difficult to apply in the scenario of international relations, for these reasons I preferred to abstain.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because terrorism poses a direct threat to all countries and all people, regardless of their ethnicity, religion or beliefs. It can be countered only by a global alliance, in full conformity with international law, fundamental values and international human rights standards.  Counter-terrorism measures should not be abused to suppress legitimate dissent or violate people's universal human rights.  To ensure adequate democratic and judicial control, the Resolution calls for the recently signed agreement between the EU and the Arab League on counter-terrorism cooperation to be made public. The Resolution calls for action on the root causes of terrorism, including political and cultural issues and emphasizing prevention and deradicization. Finally, it calls for improved cooperation between the parties to promote, protect and defend human rights. It also calls on Arab countries and EU Member States to work towards greater protection of religious minorities in the Arab world and to give full effect to EU guidelines on freedom of religion or belief.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because the European Union is facing a constant and growing threat of terrorism, which over the last decade has seriously undermined several Member States by attacking its citizens and threatening the values and freedoms that form the basis of the Union. Terrorist propaganda is spreading more rapidly through the Internet and social media, and cyberterrorism allows terrorist groups to establish and maintain contacts without physical barriers at national borders. The European Parliament therefore welcomes the continued and joint efforts of the European Union and the Arab States to work together to address issues of common interest, mentioning the regular meetings of the Foreign Ministers of the European Union and the League of Arab States and the Memorandum of Understanding signed between the European External Action Service and the General Secretariat of the League of Arab States. The EU-League of Arab States participates in a strategic dialogue which provides for an exchange of political and security issues, exchanges of regular meetings between the EU Political and Security Committee and permanent representatives of the League of Arab States.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. Mr President, I support this memorandum of understanding between the EU and the League of Arab Countries. Terrorism is the greatest evil in the world today and certainly the fight against terrorism is much more effective if it is coordinated from several sides, and the signing of the memorandum strengthens efforts to address this global threat.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. The draft resolution on relations between the EU and the League of Arab States envisages increasing cooperation in the fight against terrorism. It appears to be balanced, since it aims to cope, in association with the states of the regions concerned, with the rise of Islamist terrorism. Although it is not for the Union in principle to deal with the foreign policy of the Member States, this is a common-sense measure that I support. I therefore voted in favour of the motions for a resolution.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Strong security in the European Union is needed, as it has changed radically in recent years due to new conflicts and riots in the union's neighbourhood. Account must be taken not only of the rapid development of new technologies, but also of the worrying increase in radicalisation leading to violence and terrorism worldwide. This threat can only be countered with the efforts of national governments and regional and international organisations. Furthermore, this motion for a resolution states that cooperation on humanitarian assistance is vital, but also to identify practical measures that should be taken into account to counter the radicalisation, recruitment and movement of foreign terrorists and fighters, as well as ways to treat fighters returning to their place of their leaving. I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that counter-terrorism measures can be more effectivethrough and integrated through close cooperation with third countries, in particular countries in the Arab world and Africa, which must focus on the root socio-economic and cultural causes of this phenomenon.

name: Cristian-Silviu Bușoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 19 January 2015, vp/HR, Federica Mogherini, and Secretary General of the League of Arab States (LSA), Dr. Nabil El Araby, signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MDHr) between the European External Action Service (EEAS) and the LSA Secretariat-General, whose content is not public. The aim of the MSD is to support and strengthen relations between EU Member States and LSA Member States with a view to improving their functional structures, exchanges of experience and dialogue, in order to achieve common goals and objectives in areas of mutual interest. I support the call to make public the content of the MDI with a view to its submission to democratic and judicial scrutiny. I also support cooperation to determine the practical measures that should be taken to counter terrorist threats, including a more effective fight against the radicalisation, recruitment and displacement of terrorists and foreign combatants, as well as addressing the problem of returning combatants, while stressing the need to maintain a balance between freedom and security in response to terrorist threats, as well as to analyse all measures to be taken in terms of their compatibility with the rule of law and the requirements arising from fundamental rights.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution on relations between the EU and the League of Arab States for cooperation in the fight against terrorism. The security situation in Europe has changed a great deal in recent years, both because of new conflicts and upheavals in the immediate neighbourhood, and because of the increasing radicalisation that often results in violence and terrorism.  The terrorist threat, particularly from Syria and Libya, cannot therefore be underestimated and must be mitigated by adopting a global approach combining diplomatic, socio-economic, development, conflict prevention, peace-building and crisis management instruments. Strategic dialogue between the EU and the League of Arab States on policy and security issues must also be intensified, with the aim of developing increasingly timely responses to crises. Furthermore, the European Union is obliged to increase cooperation both with Muslim communities in Europe and with Muslim countries outside Europe in order to develop an effective policy of uprooting, which I believe is absolutely essential in order to tackle the root causes of terrorism.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ There are a number of positive aspects to this resolution. It talks about the importance of respecting fundamental rights in ‘counter-terrorism’ strategies and the need to deal with root causes. It calls for stopping the death penalty and the use of torture, and warns against the exploitation of ‘counter-terrorism’ strategies to attack opposition movements in some countries. It also calls for publication of the Memorandum of Understanding between the EU and LAS, which I agree would be in the interest of transparency and democratic accountability. However, there is no recognition that the recent rise in violent extremism in Iraq and Syria is related to the US—led invasion of Iraq in 2003 – which was supported by some EU Member States such as Britain – as is the subsequent destruction and destabilisation in that country and the surrounding region. I believe this is a significant omission. If the serious threat of violent extremism is to be stopped affectively, an honest and sufficient analysis of how the threat developed is required. Considering the positive aspects of the resolution and its shortcomings mentioned above, I voted ‘abstention’.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome this report on the memorandum of understanding between the EU and the League of Arab States to combat terrorism, not only because it is tangible proof of the rejection of the rhetoric of the clash of civilisations. A concrete and joint commitment is needed (both between the EU and the Arab states, as well as within the two groups) to prosecute not only those who directly commit terrorist acts, even those who, more or less indirectly, subsidise or contribute to their organisation. I therefore voted in favour of the text, and we will ensure that the commitments made do not remain only on the expensive.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which, once not customary, offers a balanced vision of the measures to be taken to combat Islamic terrorism. In particular, the report calls for close and multilateral cooperation between member states and the League of Arab States. It also reaffirms the need to adopt a balance between the necessary measures to ensure our security and the attention that must be paid not to infringe on the freedom of our fellow citizens. Finally, the report recalls the need to rethink the European Union's responsibility for the spread of terrorism, particularly insofar as it continues to have privileged relations with countries suspected of financing terrorism. Because our security is not negotiable, the Patriotic Members have therefore supported this resolution.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that an effective fight against terrorism can only be guaranteed through joint action and cooperation between the Union and the Arab League states.  Furthermore, I firmly maintain that, in order to strengthen defence, it is essential to cooperate in order to identify concrete measures to deal with terrorist threats, including the fight against radicalisation, the recruitment and movement of foreign terrorists and fighters, as well as fighters returning to their places of origin.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution because I welcome cooperation and partnership between the EU and third countries in the fight against terrorism, and in working closely with regional actors such as the African Union, the Gulf Cooperation Council and the League of Arab States, as well as the UN Counter-Terrorism Committee. However, I would like to point out that counter-terrorism measures must never be applied abusively in order to suppress legitimate dissent or to violate the universal human rights of individuals.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution highlights two principles that I consider fundamental in the fight against terrorism: transparency and respect for fundamental rights. As far as the Union's internal policies are concerned, I have always advocated - and often against the current - the same principles. On the one hand, whatever the instrument it should be subject to transparent democratic control. On the other hand, under no circumstances can we protect our most fundamental values by jeopardising those same values. The Memorandum of Understanding signed on 19 January signed between the EU and the Arab League aims to - and well - act on one side of the fight against terrorism: cooperation with third countries. It remains to be democratically scrutinized.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU’s external policies must contribute to countering the terrorist threat, which is escalating in certain parts of its neighbourhood, in particular Syria and Libya. We need to consider actions for enhancing cooperation with key partners and countries on countering the financing of terrorism. The EU needs to engage with partner countries in a dialogue on the issue and to improve strategic communication, developing an outreach strategy to the Arab world and promoting fundamental rights. The motion for resolution stresses these objectives and calls for effective actions, so I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Communication plays a key role, which is why I welcome the EP's desire to overcome the widespread image of "clash between peoples" between the West and the East. I see this as a fundamental step in cooperation in the fight against terrorism.  In this respect, I welcomed the statement by the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy of 19 January 2015 on the position he has taken on the victims of terrorism: not Euro-centric but grateful that the primary victims of this phenomenon are Muslims and Islamists.  On this basis it is possible to create a system in which there is a functional exchange of information between the intelligence of the Member States of the European Union and the League of Arab States. That is why I am voting in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The resolution put to the vote makes an express mention of the human rights violations that take place in the member countries of the Arab League and which, in my view, are an obstacle to regarding that organization as an ally in the fight against terrorism. However, there is no express mention of the fact that some of the Member States of that organization actively finance and support the organization of the Islamic State, which avoids the main problem that needs to be addressed at the moment. For all this, I abstained.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 New forms of global terrorism threaten every corner of the globe, spreading a sense of insecurity that often provokes irrational and wrong responses. On the other hand, if the challenge is supranational, it must also be the answer, cooperating in order to achieve coordination by national governments and regional and international organisations, which operate in full respect of international law, fundamental values and human rights. Once again, it is Europe that can play a role of mediation and extraordinary synthesis, particularly with the countries of origin of the phenomenon. In view of the fact that in the fight against terrorism it is essential to address not only the consequences but also the factors underlying radicalisation, and that in order to do this we need an approach that does not underestimate the importance of promoting a culture of inclusion and tolerance, it will be crucial to pursue the path of dialogue with the authorities of the Arab League countries, with a view to building a real defence strategy. , which accompanies progress in the growth of political and civil liberties.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Terrorism is a global threat that must be addressed coordinated by national governments, regional and international organisations. A global alliance can deal effectively with this threat, respecting international law, fundamental values and international human rights standards. The international community is committed to adopting measures to ensure respect for human rights and the rule of law as a fundamental basis for the fight against terrorism by adopting the United Nations Global Strategy against Terrorism by the General Assembly. In this respect, cooperation between the EU and the League of Arab States in the field of counter-terrorism is needed, stressing the need to continue to promote and protect human rights, religious freedom and coexistence between different religions. At the same time, exclusions, extremism, as well as incitement to hatred and violence must be rejected.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution deals with the cooperation between the European Union and the League of Arab States (LAS) in countering terrorism. The resolution of the European Parliament starts from a clear point on transparency: by asking for the Memorandum of Understanding signed recently between the European External Action Service and the General Secretariat of the LAS to be published so that its content can be subject to democratic and judicial oversight. It continues to delve into the subject matter by pushing for exchange of information between the two sides in crisis situations, the sharing of assessments and best practices, as well as of cooperating in identifying practical steps to help address the threats, including more effective action to counteract radicalisation, recruitment and travel of terrorists and foreign fighters, as well as dealing with fighters returning to their place of departure. Moreover, apart from the angle on security the resolution also reaffirms the need to maintain a balance between freedom and security in response to terrorist threats and to consider all measures to be taken from the point of view of the compatibility of these measures with the rule of law and the requirements of fundamental rights. Hence, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe it is necessary to intensify cooperation with the main partners and countries in the fight against terrorist financing, and I firmly believe that the EU must initiate a dialogue with partner countries on combating terrorist financing and cooperate closely with its partners in this area.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This resolution welcomes the signing of a Memorandum of Understanding between the European Union and the League of Arab States to improve dialogue and cooperation in the fight against terrorism. In the face of the threat posed by terrorist groups, it is indeed necessary to strengthen the exchange of information on crisis situations and the sharing of assessments and good practices in order to define concrete actions to respond to the current threats related to the radicalization, recruitment and movement of terrorists and foreign fighters, but also the return to the place of origin of these fighters. Considering that this is the right approach and that these policies will not be effective without the close cooperation of the countries of origin and directly concerned with terrorism, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. In the face of the global threat of terrorism, we must provide a global response. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution to strengthen our cooperation with the League of Arab States in the fight against terrorism. It is crucial that we share our assessments and best practices, to prevent the recruitment and movement of terrorists and "foreign fighters", as well as to respond to the underlying factors of radicalization. I am very committed to this subject, as I myself rapporteur of the European Parliament on a text for the prevention of radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations. Everything must be done as soon as possible to address this growing global threat, and I welcome the rapid implementation of this strategic dialogue.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Union is facing a terrorist threat that is already hitting many countries. Clearly, the Member States of the Union and the Arab League States must strengthen their cooperation to fight together against this scourge. In particular, we are talking about strengthening our exchange of information on the recruitment and movement of terrorists and foreign fighters, as well as concretely combating radicalisation, arms trafficking and terrorist financing. This Memorandum of Understanding between the European External Action Service (EEAS) and the League of Arab States (LEA) is therefore absolutely necessary. The fight against terrorism requires coming together and acting together.  The resolution also reiterates that anti-terrorism measures cannot be misused to suppress legitimate protest voices or violate human rights. It also recalls the unwavering right of religious minorities to be protected.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. This resolution calls for increased cooperation between the European Union and the League of Arab States against terrorism and, in particular, Islamist terrorism. Rather balanced, with the necessary balance between freedom and security, and encourages the Member States of the Union to be firmer and more cooperative with the Arab League states in the common fight against terrorism.  The resolution rightly recalls that some Arab League States, sometimes having very close relations with certain Member States of the Union, have shown guilty complacency towards Islamist terrorist groups. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution, while wishing for a deepening of cooperation in the fight against terrorism, particularly with the most exposed countries of Egypt, Syria and Iraq.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution on the Memorandum of Cooperation between the EU and the League of Arab States because it is essential for me, as a representative in the European Parliament and member of the Committee on Foreign Policy, to find strategic partners in the fight against terrorism, in particular with Islamic State. The resolution includes important elements such as the need to take measures to limit uncontrolled migration, as well as the lack of accurate data on the number of European citizens going to be trained as terrorists or to actively participate in military action on the side of terrorist organisations. For this reason, I believe that it is right for the European Parliament to call on the European Council to develop a cooperation mechanism to make it possible to track migration and curb arms trafficking. An important collaborator in our fight against the terrorist group Islamic State is the member of the League of Arab States - Jordan. My personal belief is that the fight against Islamic State must be fought not only through airstrikes, but also through ground military action.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We unequivocally and vehemently condemn terrorism. In doing so, we must also denounce and condemn the role that the US has always played and also play in the creation, promotion and financing of terrorist groups. Groups that have served and serve their geostrategic interests, their expansionist and imperial drive of world rule. Especially in countries whose governments are not aligned with the interests of this US-EU axis. We strongly condemn the policies of alliances with states with authoritarian and repressive regimes of the League of Arab States, some direct warring actors in border conflicts that maintain the evident regional tension.  We reiterate our understanding that policies of terror and hatred are motivated, amplified, stimulated by the policies and interventions of imperialism, with the aggressions and interferences carried out in many countries. Full respect for international law, the UN Charter, national sovereignties, freedom and the interests of peoples is required. This is indispensable to end the broth of culture that promotes terrorism. Obviously we voted against this resolution.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ The dialogue between the European Union and the Arab League is important to strengthen on policy and security issues, also because of the recent terrorist acts in Paris and Copenhagen and for the safety of all citizens of the European Union. It is important that enhanced cooperation in the fight against terrorism is consistently based on the rule of law and respect for fundamental rights. However, we must prevent some kind of collusion and prevent the exchange of intelligence that could lead to human rights violations in a third country or the use of information obtained by torture outside the European Union.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not fully support the report as some of the principles included in the text, especially those relating to the fight against terrorism, are more than acceptable, but the report is not consistent with the work the EU is doing in the foreign policy scenario.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the motion for a resolution as a whole. The Union has demonstrated its hypocrisy and bilingualism on many occasions in terms of rendering the designation of terrorist, Member States have actively supported terrorist groups and organisations, while, at the same time, the text is yet another demonstration of cultural Imperialism, in which the Union makes full subjugation and alignment of foreign states with its own orders and with its own system of values.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to express my satisfaction on the High Representative's new approach to counter-terrorism cooperation between the European Union and the Arab States.  It is clear that, terrorism being a global threat; we need to face it together.  This "alliance of civilisation" is a revolutionary means for establishing a common and strong position on open conflicts and on-going crises.  It would prevent the creation of new bad situations, such as failed states, where there is an increased danger of spreading terrorism.   I believe it is important to support the moderate part of Arab societies, those that are willing to be our allies in the fight against terrorism and that have the capacity to set the grounds for establishment of peace and security in the Arab countries.  I truly hope that the dialogue with the Muslim communities in Europe as well as in the rest of the world could become the most powerful weapon to make the world a safer place for all.

name: Mariya Gabriel (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution because it insists on key points. First of all, our cooperation must be translated into concrete actions. There needs to be a multidimensional approach that takes into account, beyond security, cultural, religious and socio-economic aspects. Encouraging the exchange of good practices, as well as developing and disseminating a common counter-discourse in the face of religious extremism, are key actions.  In addition, we insist on the development of a common mechanism for early warning and crisis prevention. An intensified political dialogue must avoid a stalemate in crises that we do not know how to solve and promote the role of mediator of certain countries and cohesion towards a peaceful and democratic development of the region. Finally, the sources of funding and recruitment channels for terrorist groups must be dried up. There is a need to increase political pressure and build capacity on the ground, particularly at the borders.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ In order to achieve a joint and coherent response to the terrorism that is threatening the European way of life and values, strengthening cooperation should be a key element in EU’s counter terrorism strategy. I therefore welcome the recent Memorandum of Understanding that was signed with the League of Arab States on cooperation in countering terrorism. This sends a very positive message, because it shows that in a fight against terrorists driven by the ideology of Islamist extremism, our strong allies are the moderate Muslims. If, on one side, this cooperation will help us in our efforts to fight against radicalisation, trace terrorist financing and identify foreign fighters, on the other side it will hopefully stop the rise of any Islamophobic sentiment in the EU.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. It is important for EU security to intensify dialogue and cooperation in order to promote strategic dialogue between the European Union and the League of Arab States. Europe and the Arab world face common challenges, as terrorism poses a major threat to its citizens, so they must work together to achieve full eradication.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because terrorism poses a direct threat to all countries and all people, regardless of their ethnicity, religion or beliefs. It can be countered only by a global alliance, in full conformity with international law, fundamental values and international human rights standards. Counter-terrorism measures should not be abused to suppress legitimate dissent or violate people's universal human rights. To ensure adequate democratic and judicial control, the Resolution calls for the recently signed agreement between the EU and the Arab League on counter-terrorism cooperation to be made public. The Resolution calls for action on the root causes of terrorism, including political and cultural issues and emphasizing prevention and deradicization. Finally, it calls for improved cooperation between the parties to promote, protect and defend human rights. It also calls on Arab countries and EU Member States to work towards greater protection of religious minorities in the Arab world and to give full effect to EU guidelines on freedom of religion or belief.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because terrorism poses a direct threat to all countries and all people, regardless of their ethnicity, religion or beliefs. It can be countered only by a global alliance, in full conformity with international law, fundamental values and international human rights standards.  Counter-terrorism measures should not be abused to suppress legitimate dissent or violate people's universal human rights.  To ensure adequate democratic and judicial control, the Resolution calls for the recently signed agreement between the EU and the Arab League on counter-terrorism cooperation to be made public. The Resolution calls for action on the root causes of terrorism, including political and cultural issues and emphasizing prevention and deradicization. Finally, it calls for improved cooperation between the parties to promote, protect and defend human rights. It also calls on Arab countries and EU Member States to work towards greater protection of religious minorities in the Arab world and to give full effect to EU guidelines on freedom of religion or belief.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted with conviction for the important European Parliament resolution noting the signing of the Memorandum of Understanding between the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy Federica Mogherini and the Secretary-General of the Arab League, Nabil Elaraby, for cooperation and the fight against terrorism. We also heard this from the authoritative words of the King of Jordan two days ago: Europe and the Arab States must understand the need to forge new relations based on dialogue and mutual cooperation for the security and stability of the Mediterranean area and the Middle East. I would like to stress, as the text of the resolution rightly does, the need to always respect universal human rights in the fight against terrorism: counter-terrorism measures must never be applied abusively in order to suppress legitimate dissent or to violate the universal human rights of individuals.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution because there is a clear need for joining forces with Arab States in tackling terrorist groups that are threatening the security of people all over the world. Yet, such cooperation can only be truly effective if it also addresses repressive policies used by governments of Arab League member states against their citizens. Not only would it be morally reprehensible to be complicit in the human rights violations conducted by authoritarian governments in the region, it would also be highly counterproductive. If there is one lesson to be drawn from the Arab Spring, it is that repression breeds chaos and terrorism, not stability. If we do not want to repeat the mistakes of the past, this agreement will need to prioritize a genuine review of anti-terrorist laws in the Arab countries, in order to stop governments from using those laws against citizens who engage in legitimate protest.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as terrorism is a global threat and only global cooperation can defeat the terrorist agenda. An alliance between Europe and the Arab States in a fight against terrorism is therefore vital. We can learn from the experiences of Arab countries that already have strategies in place for countering extremism. Europe and the Arab League states must pursue a comprehensive counter—terrorism strategy that tackles the root causes of radicalisation.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this Memorandum of Understanding because, following the bloody attacks in Paris and Copenhagen, it is essential that the European Union acts against terrorism in cooperation with all major international organisations and communities.  This agreement aims in particular to support and strengthen relations between the European Union and the Arab League in the fight against terrorism, transnational organised crime and the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, and will enable better management of possible crises.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because terrorism poses a direct threat to all countries and all people, regardless of their ethnicity, religion or beliefs. It can be countered only by a global alliance, in full conformity with international law, fundamental values and international human rights standards.  Counter-terrorism measures should not be abused to suppress legitimate dissent or violate people's universal human rights.  To ensure adequate democratic and judicial control, the Resolution calls for the recently signed agreement between the EU and the Arab League on counter-terrorism cooperation to be made public. The Resolution calls for action on the root causes of terrorism, including political and cultural issues and emphasizing prevention and deradicization. Finally, it calls for improved cooperation between the parties to promote, protect and defend human rights. It also calls on Arab countries and EU Member States to work towards greater protection of religious minorities in the Arab world and to give full effect to EU guidelines on freedom of religion or belief.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because terrorism poses a direct threat to all countries and all people, regardless of their ethnicity, religion or beliefs. It can be countered only by a global alliance, in full conformity with international law, fundamental values and international human rights standards.  Counter-terrorism measures should not be abused to suppress legitimate dissent or violate people's universal human rights.  To ensure adequate democratic and judicial control, the Resolution calls for the recently signed agreement between the EU and the Arab League on counter-terrorism cooperation to be made public. The Resolution calls for action on the root causes of terrorism, including political and cultural issues and emphasizing prevention and deradicization. Finally, it calls for improved cooperation between the parties to promote, protect and defend human rights. It also calls on Arab countries and EU Member States to work towards greater protection of religious minorities in the Arab world and to give full effect to EU guidelines on freedom of religion or belief.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the Joint Proposal for a Resolution on Relations between the EU and the League of Arab States and cooperation in the fight against terrorism, on the grounds that terrorism in particular, based on Jihad extremism, is becoming a serious global threat that needs to be addressed through a coordinated effort by national governments and international organisations.
