Solutions need to be found to achieve peace and stability, but also causes that lead to the development of extreme forms of terrorism that do not choose potential victims. It is important that efforts and actions to combat terrorism do not undermine human rights and freedoms and a satisfactory balance needs to be found in this regard.  I support the publication of the Memorandum of Understanding signed on 19.01.2015 between the European External Action Service and the General Secretariat of the League of Arab States, as such a document should be available and subject to democratic and judicial examination.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. This text calls for the necessary cooperation between the European Union and the League of Arab States, in order to establish an adequate policy in the face of terrorism and in particular in the face of Islamist terrorism. This motion for a resolution takes into account the necessary balance between freedom and security and encourages THE Member States of the Union to be firmer and more cooperative with the Arab League states in the common fight against terrorism. In addition, it recalls that some Member States of the Arab League, sometimes having very close relations with certain Member States of the Union, have shown guilty complacency towards Islamist terrorist groups. Therefore, in the hope of further cooperation in the fight against terrorism, I have of course voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the relationship between the European Union and the League of Arab States and cooperation against terrorism. The draft resolution stresses the importance of cooperation in humanitarian assistance, as part of concrete actions to respond to terrorist threats and a more effective approach to preventing the movement of terrorists and foreign fighters. But it is also important to maintain the balance between freedom and security in response to terrorist threats. This proposal was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Terrorism is a global threat and only global cooperation can defeat the terrorist agenda and all those that support it. Calling for an alliance between Europe and the Arab States in a fight against terrorism is therefore vital and I welcome the recently signed memorandum. There are many Arab countries with good strategies for countering radicalisation, extremism and depriving terrorist groups from financing. We can learn from their experiences. It is vital however that the cooperation avoids the mistakes of the past. Respect for human rights and the rule of law must not fall victim to combating terrorism. These must be the bedrock of it. Europe and the Arab league states must pursue a comprehensive counterterrorism strategy that tackles the root causes of radicalization with particular focus on the economic and social situation of the younger generation in many of these countries. Young people must be inspired by values of mutual respect and an inclusive society, so that we stop the vicious cycle of violence. We need to work together, as we are all facing the same threat.

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With this vote we strongly supported the value of cooperation with the countries of the League of Arab States in the fight against terrorism: a direct threat against every person, of every ethnicity and every religion. A fight that can only succeed through a global alliance, while keeping the fundamental principles of human rights firm. Violating these principles means handing victory over to terrorism, which aims to undermine the founding values of our common life.  Combating the ideology of terror also means consolidating the rule of law. Civil rights cannot be sacrificed on the altar of security. There are no rights without security, no security without rights. Terrorism is a global challenge to which we must give global responses. International cooperation in the fight against extremist groups is essential to tackle at source the factors that lead to the radicalisation and spread of this totalitarian ideology.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. National Front MEPs have decided to vote for the relatively balanced resolution on relations between the European Union and the League of Arab States and on cooperation in the fight against terrorism. As advocated in the resolution, cooperation between the Member States of the European Union and the countries of origin, transit and destination through which foreign jihadists and the resources to support them have been channelled must be strengthened. However, we must remain vigilant against countries suspected of financing terrorism.  The resolution rightly recalls that "the rights of religious minorities are inseparable from respect for other fundamental rights and fundamental freedoms, including the rights to freedom, security, equal opportunities for men and women and freedom of expression, and calls on the LEA, the EEAS and the member states of both organisations to protect religious minorities in the Arab world."

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. The threat posed by terrorism on a global scale requires a coordinated response involving national governments, international integration organizations and non-state actors. This integrated response, on the part of a kind of international alliance, will only be effective if it is carried out in full conformity with the principles governing international law and from full respect for human rights and the values on which international society is based. In this context, the SEAE and the Arab League Secretariat last month signed the MEMORANDUM of Understanding between the EU and the Arab League for the Fight against Terrorism. The central idea of the agreement is that it is not only Europe that suffers the terrorist threat, but especially the Arab countries and with a special emphasis Iraq, Libya and Syria. The battle to be fought against terrorism cannot be only military or in the field of security, but must also address the political and cultural dimensions and the fundamental chapter of prevention.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The resolution put to the vote makes an express mention of the human rights violations that take place in the member countries of the Arab League and which, in my view, are an obstacle to regarding that organization as an ally in the fight against terrorism. However, there is no express mention of the fact that some of the Member States of that organization actively finance and support the organization of the Islamic State, which avoids the main problem that needs to be addressed at the moment. For all this, I abstained.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 Terrorism and violent extremism are serious threats to security and freedom on a global scale. Therefore, to address this threat effectively, a coordinated effort is needed by national and regional governments and international organizations. It is clear that the current terrorist threat in the EU and Arab states has jihadist extremism among its main causes. Both sides share the view that a policy of deradicization and counter-terrorism cannot be effective if it is not developed in close cooperation with the countries of origin. However, we must ensure that counter-terrorism measures are never illegitimately used to suppress legitimate dissent or violate people's universal human rights. Agreeing with the content of the Resolution, I vote favorably, noting further that the EU and the League of Arab States (LEA) share a common interest in finding lasting solutions that guarantee peace and stability in all regions.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. At the third meeting of the Foreign Ministers of the European Union and the League of Arab States last year , a declaration was adopted in which ministers expressed support for European-Arab cooperation and ensured communion in future strategic challenges . The proposal for a resolution of the European People's Party Group welcomes the strengthening of dialogue and cooperation between the European Union and the League of Arab States. The plan is to increase understanding of political and security issues through the exchange of experience, information and best practices with a view to better responding to crises, fighting terrorism and organised crime and combating weapons of mass destruction. I join the condemnation of all forms of terrorism and extremism as these are the main threats to our security and should continue to work in line with the UN Global Counter-Terrorism Strategy.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. Because the main thing is for all of us to understand that the fight against terrorism is not the fight against Islam. This is not a fight against non-Christian countries. It is the fight of people against non-human beings. For Europe, the terrorist threat is now a major problem. Cooperation with the League of Arab States brings great benefits to the EU and hopes for a successful and secure future in Europe, Asia and Africa.

name: Ramona Nicole Mănescu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution for the following reasons: the Memorandum of Understanding between the European Union and the League of Arab States is the prerequisite softer of cooperation in the fight against terrorism. I am sure that, in the fight against terrorism, the coordinated effort between all parties engaged in the process of supporting peace and democracy is very important. I am confident in the results of cooperation with the League of Arab States, and I also believe that we must also work with the African Union and the Gulf Cooperation Council, as well as the UN Counter-Terrorism Committee. It is essential to cooperate effectively and intelligently with all partners, including by exchanging information on trafficking in firearms and terrorist financing, but also learning from previous mistakes. In addition, the counter-terrorism strategy should be seen as part of a broader picture, fully integrated into our external and development policies. To combat terrorism, we need to understand its causes, such as poverty, hopelessness and poor governance. We will defeat terrorism when we unite with our allies to provide a better future for young people who can be attracted to extremist groups.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the resolution, because as jihadists strengthen their forces and become more aggressive and dangerous, the European Union's cooperation with the Arab League can help to reduce terrorism. Of course, I have the reservations I expressed during the debate as I believe that Qatar should be held accountable for its alleged links with the jihadists.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. Vote in favour of this resolution. This resolution calls for balanced cooperation between the Member States of the European Union and the members of the League of Arab States to combat terrorism.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the relationship between the EU and the League of Arab States and cooperation in the fight against terrorism. This is an even more sensitive issue at the moment: terrorism and violent extremism represent serious threats to security and freedom worldwide. One of the results of terrorist acts is to also target freedom of expression, which is not possible given the existence of fundamental rights that must be respected. Another phenomenon to be combated is that of fighters leaving Europe to various destinations with the aim of fighting jihad, which is expected to persist in the coming years.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Increased cooperation between the European Union and the League of Arab States, based on strong diplomatic relations, and a mutual exchange of information, would help stem the advance of the terrorist threat. I felt it was right to vote in favour of the resolution, because I believe that it adequately refers to the need to strengthen the link between the parties.  I believe it is to be hoped that the European Union and the League of Arab States will come together against the rise of jihadist extremism.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Union and the League of Arab States must maintain and, where possible, increase their cooperation in the fight against terrorism, always ensuring that the rule of law and the enforcement of human rights are not jeopardized. As noted in the report I have supported, jihadist terrorism is now one of the main causes of threat in the EU and Arab states, and that is why it is necessary to address the underlying factors of radicalisation and take a holistic approach to the fight against terrorism.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. While the joint fight against IS terrorists with the League of Arab States is a good approach, cooperation with this Arab League raises some concerns. Social justice and respect for other religions are fundamental pillars of a successful fight against ISIS. Whether this cooperation with Salafist Muslims in the Emirates can work, however, seems highly questionable. Especially since the content of the agreement between this league and the EU on cooperation in the fight against terrorism is not publicly known.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The text reaffirms the importance of cooperation between the European Union and the Arab League in the fight against terrorism. Cooperation is well underway since it tells us in passing that a Memorandum of Understanding, kept secret, was signed between the European External Action Service (EEAS) and the General Secretariat of the League of Arab States (LEA) on 15 January. The text therefore calls for the terms of this agreement to finally be made public.  I am generally opposed to the action of the EEAS or any other attempt by the European Union to do without sovereign states in terms of foreign policy.  I abstain from approving the advertising request without approving the action or the service that conducts it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. Terrorism and violent extremism pose serious threats to security and freedoms worldwide and respect for fundamental rights is an essential factor for successful counter-terrorism policies. Terrorism is a global threat that must be combated through the combination of efforts by national governments and regional and international organisations. Only a global alliance can deal with this threat effectively, acting in full compliance with international law, fundamental values and international human rights standards. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution stresses the need to have a holistic and comprehensive approach to tackling radicalisation and terrorism. It is essential that the EU focus its attention on the underlying factors of radicalisation and utilise a comprehensive cross-sectoral and multidisciplinary approach guaranteeing the involvement of all the policies concerned. It also urges the EU to implement comprehensive anti-terrorism measures which combine diplomatic, socio-economic, development, conflict prevention, peacebuilding and crisis management tools. Therefore, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I applaud the adoption of this resolution, which underlines the importance of cooperation between the European Union and the League of Arab States in the fight against terrorism. Indeed, terrorism, which affects the entire international community, must be combated in consultation with the States of origin. It is above all a question of identifying and combating the factors of radicalization, including poverty, discrimination, corruption, etc. The resolution also recognizes the importance of balancing freedom and security in order to preserve our values. In this way, it reaffirms the need- particularly for the member countries of the League of Arab States - to work towards the recognition and respect of fundamental rights and freedoms.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my support to the Parliament resolution on the Relations between the EU and the League of Arab States and cooperation in countering terrorism. Terrorism poses a direct threat to all countries and all people and it is therefore so important to tackle terrorism threats in the roots. This can only be done by a global alliance, in full compliance with international law, fundamental values and international human rights standards.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The resolution supports action against international terrorism, which poses a universal threat, especially its extremist jihadist branch, pointing out that the fight against terrorism must address not only the consequences but also the underlying causes of radicalisation, and citing the fact that a policy of reversing radicalisation and combating terrorism cannot be effective without close cooperation with the countries of origin. The resolution is not only forward-looking, but also extremely topical.  The principles, aims and functioning of terrorists are fundamentally threatening our European, Western world. Taking action against them is our fundamental human, moral, and allied duty.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. The Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, Federica Mogherini, and the Secretary-General of the League of Arab States, Nabil El Araby, signed a Memorandum of Understanding in January 2015 to strengthen relations between the two sides.  The challenges we face today globally also need global responses. For this reason, I am in favour of this understanding which seeks to strengthen cooperation in political and security terms, in particular with regard to combating terrorism and the exchange of information, rapid alerts and combating transnational crimes. We must be able to halt the advance of the Islamic State and not let the climate of fear settle in Europe. We should exchange more information on fighters from Europe. We must not surrender to the terrorists.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. This resolution on relations between the Union and the League of Arab States envisages increasing cooperation in the fight against terrorism. It appears to be balanced, since it aims to cope, in association with the States of the regions concerned, with the rise of terrorism. Although it is not in principle the responsibility of the European Union to deal with the foreign policy of the Member States, this is a common-sense measure that can be voted on.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this joint resolution on cooperation between the European Union and the League of Arab States in the fight against terrorism. The resolution rightly reminds us that terrorism poses a direct threat to all countries and people, regardless of ethnicity, religion or belief. It also stresses that a policy of deradicalisation and the fight against terrorism cannot be effective without the close cooperation of the countries of origin. Finally, the text calls for better protection of religious minorities in the Arab world.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Terrorism poses a threat to security and freedoms worldwide and must therefore be countered by a coordinated effort by national governments and regional and international organisations. We welcome the joint efforts to initiate a strategic and structured dialogue between the EU and the League of Arab States. We welcome the growing number of initiatives across Europe bringing together different religious communities and groups against extremism and in defence of fundamental values and freedoms, and we welcome the recent memorandum between the EU and the Arab League placing dialogue and cooperation at a multilateral level.  The policy of deradicalisation and the fight against terrorism can only be effective if europe's Muslim communities play an active role and if dialogue and close cooperation with Muslim countries outside Europe are guaranteed. We must continue to cooperate, to promote universal respect for all human rights, including the right to economic and social development, freedom of expression and freedom of religion, and I believe, while upholding the values of tolerance and coexistence between different religions and rejecting exclusion, extremism, incitement and the spread of hatred and violence.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because I consider terrorism to be a global threat that must be combated through the coordinated efforts of national governments and international organisations, and as such, the strengthened fight against all forms of extremism, including jihadist extremism, requires extensive cooperation between the European Union and the League of Arab States.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The text of this resolution strongly supports cooperation between the EU and the League of Arab States in the fight against terrorism, stressing that this phenomenon can only be combated through a global alliance, in full respect of international law, fundamental values and international standards on human rights. In addition, in order to ensure adequate democratic and judicial control, the memorandum signed on 19 January 2015 between the European External Action Service and the Secretariat-General of the League of Arab States on counter-terrorism cooperation, the fight against organised crime and the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction is to be made public. Finally, the report highlights the importance of closer cooperation in the promotion of human rights. Arab countries and EU Member States must protect religious minorities and fully implement the EU guidelines on the promotion and protection of freedom of religion or belief.  In the light of the above, I have decided to support the resolution favourably.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the Memorandum of Understanding on cooperation on terrorism between the EU and the Arab League, because I believe it is important to develop dialogue and cooperation in areas of common interest, in particular on political and security issues and in the fight against terrorism.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report to welcome the Union's commitment to close cooperation with the Arab League countries. It is only through mutual understanding, cooperation and understanding that we will fight terrorism on a long-term and at its source. This is the complementary policy component of the security component.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. Whereas the promotion of democracy and respect for human rights and civil liberties are fundamental principles and objectives of the European Union and constitute a common basis for its relations with third countries; that, in accordance with international human rights law and, in particular, Article 18 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, everyone has the right to freedom of thought, conscience and religion; while the UN and other international organisations have denounced the serious and widespread violations of international humanitarian and human rights law by ISIS/Da'ish and associated groups in Syria and Iraq, especially against ethnic and religious minorities, including targeted killings, kidnappings, the sale of women, the slavery of women and children, the recruitment of children for suicide bombings, sexual abuse and torture; shocked and saddened by the brutal actions of ISIS/Da'ish extremists against Assyrians in Syria and Coptics in Libya; I strongly condemn ISIS/Da'ish and its serious human rights violations which amount to crimes against humanity and war crimes in accordance with the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court (ICC).  For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. Terrorism and violent extremism are among the main threats to our security and our freedoms. I welcome cooperation with a view to fostering a strategic dialogue between the EU and the League of Arab States. The EU needs to provide active support to the global partnership against terrorism and work closely with regional actors such as the African Union, the Gulf Cooperation Council and the League of Arab States, in particular the neighbouring countries of Syria and Iraq, as well as with the UN, notably its Counter-Terrorism Committee.  The European Union must focus its foreign and development policy towards a comprehensive fight against terrorism, with a view to combating poverty, discrimination and marginalisation, fighting corruption and promoting good governance, and preventing and resolving conflicts, as all these phenomena contribute to the marginalisation of individual groups and segments of society and make them more vulnerable to propaganda by extremist groups.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is necessary to counter the global threat of terrorism through a global alliance that allows us to effectively and coordinatedly address the danger of terrorist attacks. This action is coordinated not only between the Member States, but also with third countries and in particular with the League of Arab States. To this end, the EEAS reached a compromise last month which led to the signing of the 'Memorandum of Understanding between the EU and the League of Arab States to cooperate in the fight against terrorism'.  The threat has become real and present everywhere, and is no longer confined to muslim states, as the sad events in France and Denmark in recent months have shown. That is why I am in favour of the implementation of repressive and coordinated measures, in particular for the prevention of the development of terrorist groups by implementing and promoting with third countries the resolutions adopted by the UN Security Council.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒Terrorism and violent extremism pose major threats to security and freedoms globally, therefore EU policies must also contribute to the fight against the terrorist threat, which is becoming increasingly serious in certain parts of its neighbourhood, especially in Syria and Libya. In particular, as the EU faces a serious and growing threat from so-called 'EU foreign fighters', namely individuals who go to a country where they are not resident or are nationals with a view to carrying out or planning acts of terrorism or participating in terrorist training, either as trainees or as trainees, also in relation to armed conflicts. Since the outbreak of war and violence in Syria, Iraq and Libya, an estimated 3,500 to 5,000 EU nationals have fled their homes to become foreign fighters. We are talking about thousands of EU nationals, reportedly as many as a tenth of the Forces of the Islamic State. The military victory over dictators and terrorists alone is not enough, because it is easier to remove the top of the regime than the political, economic and social circumstances in which they were held . It is necessary to properly identify and focus efforts on the deep socioeconomic and cultural causes of this phenomenon. It is also necessary to strongly advocate consideration of the nature of the political system in the countries with which it cooperates in order to protect respect for the principles of human rights, the rule of law and democracies.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Memorandum of Understanding between the EU and the League of Arab States on counter-terrorism cooperation strengthens the relationship between the EU and Arab states in the fight against the greatest threat to peace of today - terrorism.  The resolution is essential to adopt, as its adoption will enhance dialogue and cooperation with a view to promoting the EU-League of Arab States strategic dialogue on political and security issues in the area of timely warning and response to crises in the fight against terrorism, transnational organised crime and the fight against the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. Peace in Arab states is also an OBLIGATION of the EU due to a stable policy of neighbourly relations, especially in the Middle East, Libya, Syria and Iraq.  When a terrorist attack was carried out on the newsroom of the French satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo at the beginning of the year, it was a clear signal that the terrorist movement was not at rest and was the very threat to our citizens and societies. The constant dialogue between the EU and the League of Arab States and combating the radicalisation, recruitment and travel of terrorists and foreign fighters and the treatment of fighters returning to their place from where they started is the only correct path for both parties to the Memorandum signatories, and in this regard it is essential to adopt this Resolution.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am, of course, in favour of the European Union and the League of Arab States cooperating effectively in the fight against terrorism, and I believe that the opening of a strategic dialogue to this end is of great importance. From our past experience, we have seen that cooperation on the fight against terrorism was weak, which is why we must focus on this renewed commitment by the EU and the League of Arab States by seeking to have a more comprehensive and precise strategy on anti-terrorist measures, so that extremist groups can be combated and more decisive action taken to neutralise recent phenomena such as foreign fighters.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. Relations between the EU and the Arab League are based on the Memorandum of Understanding (ME) of 19 January 2015 between Federica Mogherini, Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, and Nabil Elaraby, Secretary-General of the League of Arab States (LEA), to combat terrorism. Terrorism poses a serious threat to security and freedoms, and a global alliance can effectively address this threat. This resolution considers that the EU and the LEA have a common interest in finding lasting solutions to ensure regional peace and stability. It also stresses the importance of cooperation on humanitarian assistance issues through the exchange of information on crisis situations. It also welcomes the establishment of a strategic dialogue between the EU and the LEA on political and security issues and commends the progress made in the area of early warning and crisis response. Finally, it calls for the publication of the EO so that its content can be subject to democratic and judicial scrutiny. I voted in favour.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This document welcomes the Memorandum of Understanding between the EU and the League of Arab States. It is essential that both cooperate in areas of common interest, based on the principles of mutual trust and mutual benefits. By making it clear that all acts of terrorism are resonating and that joint cooperation is of the utmost importance in combating this phenomenon, particularly with regard to the threat posed by terrorist groups and foreign fighters, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. The High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy signed a Memorandum of Understanding (Mousor) last January with the Secretary General of the League of Arab States (LEA) sealing cooperation between the two organisations in the fight against terrorism.  This resolution, which I voted on, is a reminder that any alliance with third countries must be done with respect for human rights. We welcome the progress made in the fight against terrorism, including the creation of a centre dedicated to the issue within the United Nations. And while we recognise the need for coordinated action with the LEA, we must not turn a blind eye to the fact that some of its Member States regularly violate fundamental rights. We have been kept secret so far and call for the publication of the contents of this agreement, in order to ensure democratic and judicial control.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because terrorism poses a direct threat to all countries and all people, regardless of their ethnicity, religion or beliefs. It can be countered only by a global alliance, in full conformity with international law, fundamental values and international human rights standards.  Counter-terrorism measures should not be abused to suppress legitimate dissent or violate people's universal human rights.  To ensure adequate democratic and judicial control, the Resolution calls for the recently signed agreement between the EU and the Arab League on counter-terrorism cooperation to be made public. The Resolution calls for action on the root causes of terrorism, including political and cultural issues and emphasizing prevention and deradicization. Finally, it calls for improved cooperation between the parties to promote, protect and defend human rights. It also calls on Arab countries and EU Member States to work towards greater protection of religious minorities in the Arab world and to give full effect to EU guidelines on freedom of religion or belief.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 First - as I said in plenary - I would like to welcome the timely signing of the Memorandum of Understanding that gave rise to this resolution. I believe that this strengthening of cooperation and strategic dialogue, embodied in the sharing of experiences, information and best practices, will of course result in the creation of institutional contact points to coordinate joint action, the intensification of mutual consultations, as well as the establishment of joint working groups. In addition, the important step that has been taken in the implementation of the UN global strategy to combat terrorism, which I would also like to highlight, is precisely through the creation of partnerships on an increasingly global scale and involving more and more regional organisations moving towards the effective implementation of this strategy, which aims to act on an extremely complex reality , constantly changing and increasingly well equipped in financial, logistical and technological terms. I also believe that we should use this memorandum to act directly on the fight against terrorism in the countries of origin, transit and destination of many of the terrorists and to promote greater coordination between the Member States, Eurojust and Europol, especially in operational terms.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which reaffirms cooperation between the European Union and the League of Arab States, particularly in the fight against terrorism. This resolution follows the signing on 19 January 2015 of a Memorandum of Understanding between the European External Action Service (EEAS) and the General Secretariat of the League of Arab States (LEA).  This protocol will allow both sides to extend their dialogue and cooperation to promote EU-LEA strategic dialogue, including exchanges on political and security issues. Increased cooperation will address the threat posed by terrorist groups and foreign fighters, and develop the exchange of best practices to improve actions. The work will also be carried out as part of the full implementation of the UN's global counter-terrorism strategy. We are currently in a difficult period where the European Union needs to think quickly about its strategy on counter-terrorism measures.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 19 January 2015, the High Representative and the Secretary-General of the Arab League signed a Memorandum of Understanding to strengthen relations between the two parties, which provides for a strengthening of dialogue and cooperation in the fields of combating terrorism, combating organised crime and combating the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. It is essential that the efforts of individual Member States and the European Union are combined with that of international organisations and cooperation with Arab and Mediterranean countries.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I have chosen to abstain because the report does not convince me. Some of the principles included in the text, especially those relating to the fight against terrorism, are more than acceptable, but the report is not consistent with the work of the European institutions that is ineffective on the international stage.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which establishes a protocol for cooperation between the European Union and the League of Arab States to combat terrorism.  Jihadist extremism is one of the main causes of the current terrorist threat in the European Union and Arab States. A policy of deradicalisation and counter-terrorism cannot be effective without close cooperation with countries of origin.  The text calls for the development of a mechanism to stem arms trafficking and a more effective approach to preventing the radicalization, recruitment and movement of terrorists and foreign fighters, as well as measures targeting returning combatants.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The resolution put to the vote makes an express mention of the human rights violations that take place in the member countries of the Arab League and which, in my view, are an obstacle to regarding that organization as an ally in the fight against terrorism. However, there is no express mention of the fact that some of the Member States of that organization actively finance and support the organization of the Islamic State, which avoids the main problem that needs to be addressed at the moment. For these reasons my vote has been abstention.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The motion for a resolution on relations between the EU and the League of Arab States and cooperation in countering terrorism was passed today in the plenary session. Terrorism and violent extremism are major threats to security and freedoms at global level. The resolution highlights the importance of cooperation between the EU and the LAS in the field of human rights, emphasising the significance of continuing to promote and protect human rights and uphold all human rights for all. These human rights include the right to economic and social development, freedom of expression and freedom of religion or belief while also promoting the values of tolerance and coexistence between different religions and rejecting exclusion, extremism, incitement and dissemination of hatred and violence.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the proposal for a resolution on the Memorandum of Understanding between the EU and the League of Arab States on counter-terrorism cooperation. The Memorandum of Understanding, signed on 19 January 2015, supports and strengthens relations between the EU and the League of Arab States.  Political dialogue and cooperation on security issues between Europe and the Arab League are key instruments in the fight against extremism and terrorism. The comprehensive European strategy against terrorism must make full use of elements of development cooperation, not only in the form of classic anti-poverty and inequality programmes, but also in innovative initiatives to combat corruption and promote the rule of law and inclusive institutions. In this way, our development policy will also contribute to a general effort to narrow the space for extremists who often try to legitimize their radical policies by impersonating fighters against corrupt regimes in the Arab world.  The current imperative to fight terrorism must not lead us to give in to respect for human rights and the rule of law in the countries with which we want to build a partnership against terrorism.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We condemn the criminal attacks. However, we must at the same time look for the objectives of these actions and who benefits from them. The so-called jihadists are the creation of the UNITED States and the dominant circles that equipped, reinforced, organized and used them in their imperialist interventions and designs in the wider region. So now, as in the past, they are methodically using "terrorism" as a pretext to legitimise and promote policies and measures of monitoring and repression. We cannot consent to new measures to file and monitor privacy, to create secret services and to strengthen repressive mechanisms that will result in the restriction and abolition of basic freedoms and democratic rights. We cannot consent to measures for an even more savage hunt for migrants and refugees in the context of border controls. Instead, they must strengthen the fight against neoliberal policies. The fight to promote policies that aim to serve the needs of man and society.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union has often used hypocrisy and bilingualism in terms of rendering the concept of terrorist. There are its Member States, which have actively supported terrorist groups and organisations in the past. The Union must not make full subjugation and alignment of foreign states with its own orders and its own system of values a condition for its assistance.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour. I am in favour, in principle, of any cooperation and partnership between the European Union and third countries aimed at combating terrorism and working together with regional actors such as the African Union, the Gulf Cooperation Council and the League of Arab States, as well as with the United Nations, including its Committee against Terrorism.  I would remind you, however, that counter-terrorism measures cannot be misused to suppress legitimate protest voices or to undermine the universal fundamental rights of citizens.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution on the relations between the EU and the League of Arab States. In this period of international tension and development of terrorism, the Arab States are a key partner for the EU.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. The Arab League is strangely silent and inactive about Islamist terrorism that threatens the world.  We must support any once balanced initiative that puts additional pressure on this House, which must really combat this scourge. I voted FOR this text even though I think it is futile to expect anything from it. I recall that the Arab League has excluded the representation of Syria from its meetings, a country that is at the forefront of the fight against terrorism and which courageously confronts the bloody Islamic fundamentalism.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because terrorism poses a direct threat to all countries and all people, regardless of their ethnicity, religion or beliefs. It can be countered only by a global alliance, in full conformity with international law, fundamental values and international human rights standards.  Counter-terrorism measures should not be abused to suppress legitimate dissent or violate people's universal human rights.  To ensure adequate democratic and judicial control, the Resolution calls for the recently signed agreement between the EU and the Arab League on counter-terrorism cooperation to be made public. The Resolution calls for action on the root causes of terrorism, including political and cultural issues and emphasizing prevention and deradicization. Finally, it calls for improved cooperation between the parties to promote, protect and defend human rights. It also calls on Arab countries and EU Member States to work towards greater protection of religious minorities in the Arab world and to give full effect to EU guidelines on freedom of religion or belief.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The resolution put to the vote makes an express mention of the human rights violations that take place in the member countries of the Arab League and which, in my view, are an obstacle to regarding that organization as an ally in the fight against terrorism. However, there is no express mention of the fact that some of the Member States of that organization actively finance and support the organization of the Islamic State, which avoids the main problem that needs to be addressed at the moment. For all this, I abstained.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Cooperation in a multilateral framework is not in itself prohibitive. It should even be the preferred approach of the European Union, which should not replace the Member States in bilateral agreements. I would have preferred the same eagerness at the time of the Arab revolutions, four years ago, to support the democratic transition. The message to the people of these countries would have been very different. We know that this has not been the case, and the situation in these countries has even deteriorated considerably, with a responsibility sometimes active, sometimes passive of some Member States. So today we are talking about cooperation in the fight against terrorism. However, it should be conditional on a minimum of respect for human rights. But the actions of the CIA, in which both EU and LEA Member States participated, would be enough to show that one can only be sceptical, let alone respect for human rights in many LEA states. Already concerned about the security excesses in the Union, cooperation with such regimes on terrorism therefore leaves me more than dubious. I have chosen to abstain on this resolution paved with good intentions and to follow the position of my group.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In theory, cooperation and partnership between the EU and third countries to fight terrorism and work closely with regional actors such as the African Union, the Gulf Cooperation Council and the League of Arab States, as well as the United Nations and in particular its Committee against Terrorism, is positive. We recall, however, that anti-terrorism measures should never be misused to crack down on legitimate governments or violate the universal human rights of citizens. Unfortunately, recent history is full of examples where countries that fail to serve the interests of the United States or the EU move from friends to enemies, emerging as if by spontaneous generation, popular demonstrations followed by armed actions using highly sophisticated weapons, not knowing how these ended up there, with instruction manual and everything.  We fear that this report is just another manifestation of hypocrisy designed to alleviate consciences but to leave everything in it.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. – The joint fight against IS terrorists with the League of Arab States is a good approach, but cooperation with this Arab League brings with it some concerns. Social justice and respect for other religions are fundamental pillars of a successful fight against ISIS. Whether this cooperation with Salafist Muslims in the Emirates can work, however, seems highly questionable. Especially since the content of the agreement between this league and the EU on cooperation in the fight against terrorism is not publicly known.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Closer cooperation between the EU and the Arab League is an important and worth supporting issue. The violence and torture carried out by ISIS and the terrorist attacks carried out by extremist groups in Europe demonstrate the need for Europe and the Arab League to work together to combat terrorism. The countries of the Arab League have a great responsibility to provide correct information about Islam and the values of Islam, because attacks by extremist groups have raised suspicions in Europe against islam as a whole. It is therefore important to promote intercultural and interreal dialogue and to strengthen interregional cooperation in areas such as the economy, research and education.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. This resolution takes a position on an agreement signed on 19 January 2015 by the EU Foreign Minister and the Secretary-General of the League of Arab States. I have co-negotiated this resolution on behalf of my group, and there are specific points: 1. Parliament reaffirms the need to maintain a balance between peace and security in the response to terrorist threats and to ensure that the measures are implemented in accordance with the rule of law and fundamental rights. For a society that deprives itself of its freedom out of fear is embedded in the strategy of the terrorists. 2. The rights of religious minorities are inextricably linked to respect for other fundamental human rights and freedoms, such as the right to freedom, security, equal opportunities for men and women and freedom of expression. 3. The League of Arab States and its member states, as well as the EU Foreign Ministry in Brussels and the governments of the EU Member States, are invited to protect religious minorities in the Arab world and to fully implement the EU guidelines on the promotion and protection of freedom of religion and belief. The Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, of all people, tabled amendments to the deletion on the first point. But they didn't get through it. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite the fact that the fight against terrorism has recently been at the forefront of all debates in Europe, it still shows a large number of shortcomings. Perhaps we are finally beginning to realise that the EU alone will achieve nothing and needs partners to stand by it. And it is the Arab League that is one of them. I therefore fully support this resolution, I believe that such declarations of cooperation will increase in the future.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Following the condemnation of terrorist practices, we cannot fail to denounce the role that the EU and the US have always played in the creation, promotion and financing of terrorist groups that, through social and political destabilization in states with progressive policies, or not aligned with this axis, have served the expansionist and world-dotted interests of Imperialism. We strongly condemn the EU's alliance and financing policies to states with authoritarian and repressive regimes of the League of Arab States, some direct warring actors in border conflicts that maintain the evident regional tension.  We reiterate our understanding that policies of terror and hatred are motivated, amplified, stimulated, by the dominant political lines, and that only with a radical change in the international political framework, with the establishment of democratic and progressive regimes, with respect for and defense of national sovereignties, freedom and the interests of peoples, can the path to peace be paved the way for Peace. We voted against it.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, this is a topic which is very important for my country, particularly because we have been ahead of the curve in our efforts to conserve stocks of sea bass. Everybody knows that without conservation methods, without proper scientific up-to-date information, one cannot have a sustainable fishing industry, and we certainly have done an awful lot in this area in the last 20 years, where commercial landing of sea bass was not allowed and for leisure purposes it has been very limited. For that reason we would not have a track record and, if the TACs were to come in, it could actually discriminate against a country like Ireland, which has done so much in this area, when things are beginning to come right. That is the point I want to make on behalf of the fishing community of my country. I hope it will be taken into consideration when this comes to be implemented under the CFP.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained when voting on this resolution because, although it refers to important aspects such as the lack of scientific data on sea bass, thereby urging the Commission and States to make an assessment of resources, and while also taking into account the importance of proximity management that contemplates the diversity of situations at the regional level , general considerations are then set out together with European management measures that contradict these principles and ignore the diversity of existing situations.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This seems to be a particularly unworkable piece of legislation.  I note that the amendment to paragraph 7 was split into two parts: the first set out the problems with introducing a Total Allowable Catch; the second wished to introduce one anyway.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because I believe that it is necessary that measures to manage fishing activities at the bar are taken at European level if this species is to be safeguarded. I also believe that such measures should take due account of scientific knowledge and promote local management and the principle of regionalisation.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 There is insufficient scientific information on the state of sea bass stocks, on the exact boundaries of their habitats, migration paths and reproductive sites. Sea bass is a noble fish and its demand in the fishing industry is very high due to its exceptional economic value. In 2013, it was found that the level of stocks of this fish was reached above the maximum sustainable yield. I support the calls for an assessment of the state of sea bass stocks, a multi-annual management plan to ensure that its stocks exceed the maximum sustainable yield, to take a scientifically sound decision on the minimum allowable landing size and the suspension of fishing in certain areas in order to protect breeding grounds.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which consists of assessing stocks, putting in place a total allowable catch (TAC) and quotas as part of a multi-year management plan, which will apply to recreational fishing. This proposal corresponds to the wishes expressed by the French fishermen and I have therefore supported it.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. In view of the worrying state of bar stocks and its high economic value, it is essential that the European Union adopt measures to bring the stock population to a level that allows for maximum sustainable yield. Such measures are necessary both for the biodiversity of our oceans and for the prosperity of our fishing industry.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. Following a request from the United Kingdom, the European Commission has banned fishing from the pelagic trawl bar until the end of April in the English Channel, the Celtic Sea and the North Sea. However, this ban appears to be unfair and ineffective, with pelagic trawling accounting for only 25% of catches. Pelagic net fishing is mainly carried out by the French, recreational fishing (75%) English, who are behind the request for a ban. The motion for a resolution presented here is in line with the demands of French fishermen since it intends to assess stocks and, above all, to put in place quotas (even for recreational fishing) as part of a multi-year management plan. I have therefore spoken in favour of this text.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 While I agree with some passages in the resolution analysing the sustainable exploitation of sea bass, I believe that there are too many ambiguous and unclear passages, for these reasons I abstained pending the possibility of assessing the substance of the text during the next phase of codecision.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution which addresses the problems faced by the French, British and Irish from the indiscriminate fishing of sea bass, especially recreational, in the English Channel during the harvesting season.  The European Commission is requested to carry out a comprehensive analysis of sea bass stocks, as well as the establishment of a multi-year plan for the fishing and implementation of a quota system (TAC), in order to deal with the current overexploitation situation.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because the state of the sea bass stocks is worrying. Sea bass is a noble fish, the need for which in the fishing industry is very high due to its exceptional economic value. Unfortunately, the mortality rate of this species remains very high and sea bass is growing and growing slowly, so it takes a long time for their population size to be restored. The European Parliament therefore calls on the Commission and the Member States to assess the state of the sea bass stocks, the limits of their habitats, the migration of species and the exact places of reproduction. Calls also on the Commission and the Member States to make use of the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund, which provides significant funding for the collection of scientific data. It should be noted that it is important to accurately assess the segment of the various activities related to sea bass fishing and the percentage segment of recreational fisheries in relation to the catches of this species. Commercial fishing and recreational fisheries must therefore be compatible with each other in order to maintain stocks in excess of the maximum sustainable yield in line with the objectives of the common fisheries policy.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Sea bass is a noble species that is highly sought after in the fishing industry due to its considerable economic value. The recovery of the size of the sea bass population takes a long time due to the fact that the mortality rate remains very high and that it is a species that matures late and grows slowly. According to research, the number of sea bass is decreasing despite the measures prescribed by the European Commission so far. Although this report deals with the state of the sea bass population in the northern seas of the European Union, the report is also relevant for southern seas such as the Adriatic.  In Croatia, sea bass cultivation in fish farming is increasingly present, which covers a good part of the demand for this fish on the market.  Measures to preserve the sea bass population are necessary, but I call on the Commission not to impose binding measures without taking into account regional specifics.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. The resolution is aimed at banning the fishing of pelagic trawling from the sea bass until the end of April in the English Channel, the Celtic Sea and the North Sea, following a request from the United Kingdom. This ban, which is totally disproportionate, allows us to measure the degree of disconnection of Brussels technocrats with the daily lives of fishing professionals. This ban is initially ineffective because it affects only 25% of catches, while the remaining 75% is made up of recreational fishing and other types of artisanal fishing. It should also be noted that pelagic net fishing is mainly practised by French fishermen, while recreational fishing is mainly practiced by the English. Therefore, this prohibition is discriminatory, as it will penalize French shipowners first. As such, Sylvie Goddyn, a Front National MP, had already relayed the french fishermen's request, in particular calling for the temporary ban to be extended to all types of fishing. Of course, I voted for this motion for a resolution.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the sustainable exploitation of sea bass because, despite the measures previously taken by the Commission, recent studies show that the status of sea bass stocks is worrying and their mortality continues to be very high, given that sea bass is a species with a very slow development and takes a long time to breed. Due to its significant economic value, sea bass is a noble and highly sought-after species by the fishing industry, but account must be taken of the fact that the exploitation of this species during breeding periods must be limited. It is proposed to develop a multiannual plan for the management of sea bass to bring stocks back to a level above maximum sustainable production, as well as measures at EU level on recreational fishing by setting quantitative limits thereafter.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the European bar management measures, which I tabled on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries. This resolution proposes a roadmap for putting in place a multi-year European management plan on the bar. This plan, which will have to be based on scientific advice, will be prepared in consultation with all stakeholders involved. It should contain concrete long-term management measures for professional and recreational fishing. The resolution identifies various possible management measures: TAC testing, increasing the minimum landing size, setting up biological resting periods, quantitative limitations for recreational fishing. At this stage, these are only options that will have to be decided by the legislator, in the light of scientific advice and after a thorough consultation with all the stakeholders concerned. I now ask the European Commission to launch a public consultation on the bar with a view to proposing a real management plan for this species.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution on the sustainable exploitation of sea bass because the state of sea bass stocks is worrying, despite the emergency measures already taken by the Commission and national management measures to conserve the species. Sea bass is a noble species in great demand by the fishing industry because of its important economic value and its fishing therefore affects a considerable number of vessels. The recovery of the sea bass population takes a very long time, given the still very high mortality rate and the fact that sea bass is a slow-growing and late-ripening species. I therefore believe that the exploitation of sea bass during spawning periods should be particularly limited as it visibly slows down the renewal of the stock and prevents its recovery.  The resolution adopted by Parliament also had the merit of calling on the Commission to propose a multiannual management plan for sea bass that would allow stocks to be brought above the levels capable of producing maximum sustainable yield, involving professional fishermen, recreational fishermen and advisory councils in drawing up this management plan.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Regulation (EU) No 1380/2013 of 11 December 2013 on the common fisheries policy provides for stocks to be replenished or maintained above levels capable of producing maximum sustainable yield. Several studies show that the state of sea bass stocks is alarming, despite the emergency measures already taken by the European Commission. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which aims to propose measures for sustainable fishing, while backing the Commission's unfair ban last April on fishing for pelagic trawling in the English Channel, the Celtic Sea and the North Sea. For example, the proposal consists of an assessment of bar stocks to subsequently determine an eligible total catch (TAC), as well as quotas under a multi-year management plan that will apply for recreational fishing. A measure long demanded by French fishermen and which, moreover, is done in a dynamic of preserving our ecosystem.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I support the need to implement water ed bass management measures at European level in order to safeguard this species.  I firmly believe that these measures must also take account of scientific knowledge and promote proximity management and the principle of rationalisation.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution banning sea bass fishing with pelagic trawls during the breeding season because it is precisely this stage of reproduction that depends on the presence of sea bass in the seas. Targeted fishing on these reproductive aggregations during the period in question contributes significantly to the reduction in the number of adult specimens that can successfully reproduce.  I am concerned that the spawning biomass of the stock is about to reach the lowest levels ever recorded, given that the current fishing mortality is almost four times higher than the stock can sustain. I therefore believe that measures must be taken to substantially reduce fishing mortality.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Sea bass is very much in demand by the fishing industry for its significant economic value. Various studies show that the stock status of sea bass is worrying. The resolution calls on the Commission to propose a multiannual management plan for sea bass in order to bring the stock to a level above the maximum sustainable yield. In the light of the necessity of dealing with the state of sea bass stocks, the motion for a resolution also calls for the consideration of the introduction of total allowable catch (TAC) measures. Such measures are being proposed in the best interests of fishermen who, in the long term, unless measures are taken, may experience drastic effects due to a considerable decline in the species. I have thus voted in favour.

name: Richard Corbett (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Sea Bass are currently in serious decline and there is a vital need to address the way in which they are fished to prevent the complete collapse of the stock.  I welcomed the European Commission's recent emergency measures to protect Sea Bass during the crucial spawning season - but having to resort to reactive emergency measures only served as a reminder that we need real pre-emptive and evidence-based policy-making for Sea Bass.  Recovering Bass stocks in Europe is in the long term interest of fishers - but without a long term plan we risk requiring to implement emergency measures on a reoccurring basis - or worse – total stock collapse. Protecting Sea bass is not just important for commercial fishers - but also for recreational sea anglers - who contribute an estimated 200€ million a year to western Europe's coastal communities. I therefore support the resolution's call for a longer term strategy to address the ongoing issues and call on the European Commission to propose a multiannual management plan for the stocks of Sea Bass.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of this resolution because the condition of the sea bass stock in EU waters is worrying. The lack of scientific studies on this species have led to the adoption of emergency measures by the Commission, although these will expire in April this year. Consequently, it was necessary for the Committee on Fisheries to present this resolution, which prompts the Commission to consider the possibility of including a quota TAC system for this species and to accompany it with a multiannual resource management plan, in line with the indications of the new common fisheries policy (CFP). The resolution takes account of the need to take certain measures for the restocking of stocks without underestimating two important factors: the importance of recreational fishing for this species (it is estimated that a quarter of catches come from recreational fishing) and its high commercial value.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained when voting on this resolution because, although it refers to important aspects such as the lack of scientific data on sea bass, thereby urging the Commission and States to make an assessment of resources, and while also taking into account the importance of proximity management that contemplates the diversity of situations at the regional level , general considerations are then set out together with European management measures that contradict these principles and ignore the diversity of existing situations.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution deals with the fact that scientific information on the stock status of sea bass is insufficient. Therefore, it calls on the Commission and the Member States to evaluate the status of the stock of sea bass and its delimitation, migration of the species and the exact places of reproduction. It also stresses the importance of evaluating in a precise manner the segment of various sea bass fishing activities and the segment of the percentage of recreational fishing in catches. It also states that measures to manage the operation of the sea bass fishery at European level are needed in order to safeguard this species. Furthermore, it calls on the Commission to propose a multiannual management plan on sea bass in order to bring the stock to a level above the maximum sustainable yield, stressing that this should be done with the involvement of professional and recreational fishermen. Hence I voted in favour of this report.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Commission took emergency measures in January to close sea bass fishing in European waters for pelagic trawlers until 30 April 2015. These measures are intended to ensure the preservation of the species but are not intended to last. The European Parliament therefore calls, through this resolution, on the European Commission and the Member States to assess the state of the bar stock and its delimitation. Considering that it is necessary for the European Commission to quickly propose a multi-year resource management plan taking into account scientific advice and in consultation with the relevant stakeholders, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. In order to preserve the stocks of endangered maritime species in European waters, I voted in favour of this resolution on European bar management measures. A multi-year management plan based on scientific advice must be put in place for this species, which is very popular in the fishing community, both professional and recreational.  The European Parliament, through this resolution, thus encourages the European Commission to put in place long-term measures, such as increasing the minimum landing size or setting up biological rest periods, for better management of this species, while managing the impact they can have on the stakeholders concerned. , especially French fishermen.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. – The UK Delegation fully supports this resolution on the situation of sea bass. We are deeply concerned about depleting stock levels and we welcome emergency measures which have been applied to the North Sea, English Channel, Celtic Sea and Irish Sea. The UK Delegation has voted against those amendments and paragraphs which refer to the need for EU measures for recreational fisheries; we believe that we need more scientific data on how recreational fisheries contribute to sea bass mortality and careful consideration of whether EU measures on anglers are necessary. In the UK, sea bass anglers have shown a willingness to take sustainable measures and are responsible fishers tending to fish only for mature sea bass. The UK Delegation believes that a bag limit on recreational fisheries at this current time would be disproportionate and be to the detriment of the conservation work of the UK’s anglers, the jobs it offers and the enjoyment it brings as a favoured pastime.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on sustainable fishing for wolf perch. I believe that further measures at EU level are needed to manage fishing for this species in order to conserve the species. These measures should take due account of scientific knowledge and rely on local governance and the principle of regionalisation. It is clear that 30% of the earth's seas are overfished and that the survival of marine fish stocks could be at risk. Justified steps to maintain marine fish stocks will result in a continuous and significant reduction in the amount of marine fish fish fished. Therefore, the common fisheries policy should pay much more attention to sustainable fish farming, i.e. aquaculture, and in particular freshwater fish farming. A significant number of fish ponds in Hungary are located in Natura 2000 sites. These farms do not pose any threat to the natural assets of these areas. Moreover, in many cases it is precisely because of our closed-system fish ponds that they have created or preserved individual wetland associations. Consequently, freshwater aquaculture should be freed from unduly stringent and unnecessary sustainability standards, which are justified only for sea fishing. Efforts should already be made to clearly define the concept and regulation of freshwater aquaculture.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This diploma establishes measures to keep stocks above the minimum levels of preservation of the species.  Sea bass is a noble species, much sought after by the fisheries sector, given its important economic value, but it is also of late maturity and slow growth, so the situation of stocks is, according to some studies, "worrying". This resolution therefore calls on the Member States to assess the situation of the sea bass stock, using the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund, which provides for considerable funding for the collection of scientific data. Finally, the setting of total allowable catches should be introduced, always taking into account mitigating factors and the historical fishing quotas of each country, in order to achieve the maximum possible fishing yield within a sustainability framework.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Scientific information on the situation of sea bass stocks is not sufficient, in particular the available data on their precise delimitation, their migration routes and their breeding sites and there are several studies showing that the situation of sea bass stocks is worrying. Mortality is still very high and sea bass is a kind of late maturity and slow growth. The recovery of this stock requires a long period of time. I agree to assess the situation of the sea bass stock and its delimitation, the migration of the species and the exact breeding sites, and that management measures at European level for sea bass fishing are taken into account in order to safeguard that species.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Fisheries management measures are often implemented in a top-down approach, supported by poor scientific knowledge, distanced from regional specificities, indifferent to the involvement of the sector and communities, their contributions and, as well as, the impacts that these measures may have. This is an approach that we have distanced ourselves from and which we cannot fail to criticize, as we have always done. We value that the resolution recognises the need for an adequate assessment of the resource, addressing the gaps in knowledge about European sea bass populations. We value other aspects of this resolution, such as the reference to the importance of proximity management, which take into account the diversity of situations at regional level, all the more so since we are the result of amendments that we have made. However, the resolution turns out to be somewhat contradictory, recommending the imposition of cross-cutting management measures at European level. These measures are contradictory to the principle of regionalisation and ignore the diversity of existing situations.  We regret that the amendments we have tabled in plenary have not been accepted and that they have introduced responses to these concerns, seeking to eliminate the contradictions that are patent, favouring management measures adjusted to each specific situation.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ Morona silvery is a noble species of fish that is highly sought after due to its significant high value in the fishing industry. The International Council for the Research of the Sea distinguishes between four species of silvery moron population and several studies have shown that the decline in its population is worrying. National fisheries management measures are not sufficient to preserve this species and do not address the problem of sharing and access to resources. I therefore support the adoption of European management measures and the establishment of a multiannual management plan so that the stock of silvery moronics exceeds the level of maximum sustainable yield.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report cannot be fully supported because the basis of the measure I only notice is a strict closure of fishing activity. If the text improves, I will be happy to be able to give my full support to the report.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution on the sustainable exploitation of sea bass, because I believe that measures are needed to manage sea bass fisheries at European level in order to preserve this species.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. According to various studies on the state of sea bass stocks, this is worrying, despite the emergency measures already taken by the Commission, as sea bass needs a long period of time for the recovery of its stocks. The segment of the various bass fishing activities and the percentage segment of recreational fishing in catches must be precisely determined. It is necessary to protect the sea bass.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report because there is an urgent need to protect sea bass. According to scientists, sea bass in the Celtic Sea, Channel, Irish Sea and southern North Sea are suffering from a rapid decline that risks leading to a collapse if no action is taken. The current fishing mortality is almost four times as high as the stock can sustain. In name of biodiversity, this situation needs to be urgently reversed. Sea bass, moreover, is one of the most valuable fish on which many people in the fishing industry, especially small fishing enterprises, depend.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. I voted for this motion for a resolution for two reasons: on the one hand, there is no denying that the situation of bar stocks is worrying and requires an appropriate response; on the other hand, it is necessary to restore visibility to the professionals who live off this fishery, which is not possible under the use of the moratorium used by the European Commission in the absence of more precise legislation. It is therefore essential that the European Parliament takes up the problem.
