I will be vigilant in the drafting of the legislation and will in particular ensure that it does not harm any of the sectors involved.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted abstention in this motion for a resolution because, while it is an initiative that aims to promote a protection plan for an overexploded species such as sea bass, it has contradictory aspects. Fishing grounds are in a worrying situation, despite the measures taken by the Commission. In addition, the lack of more accurate scientific data, the definition of types of bass stocks or the different regional impact between commercial and recreational fisheries, among others, are aspects that can have a negative impact when proposing multiannual plans and setting quotas, which could be regionally unbalanced.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Sea bass are currently in serious decline, which is why I voted in favour of this report calling for a longer term strategy to address the recovery of European sea bass stock. There is a vital need to address the way in which they are fished to prevent the complete collapse of the stock.  Protecting sea bass is not just important for commercial fishers but also for recreational sea anglers, who contribute an estimated EUR 200 million a year to Western Europe’s coastal communities. I therefore strongly support the resolution calling for European Union management measures for commercial and recreational fisheries based on precise evaluation and scientific data.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We abstained from this motion for a resolution because, while it is an initiative which seeks to promote a protection plan for an overexploded species such as sea bass, it has contradictory aspects. The fishing grounds are in a worrying situation, despite the measures taken by the Commission. However, the lack of more accurate scientific data, the definition of types of bass stocks or the different regional impact between commercial and recreational fisheries, among others, are aspects that can have a negative impact when proposing multiannual plans and setting quotas, which could be regionally unbalanced.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Resolution on Sustainable Sea bass Harvesting because the Resolution points to the problems of overfishing and the problems of biological sustainability of this noble fish species, given the insufficient scientific data on sea bass stocks, but also various warning studies on the state of stocks despite previously taken measures by the Commission. It has also been shown that safeguards at national level are insufficient.  This resolution creates assumptions and calls on the Commission to take the necessary measures to preserve sea bass and to fish sustainably, both recreationally and professionally.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which proposes a roadmap for the implementation of a sustainable management plan for sea bass fishing, including several possible measures. I believe that a public consultation should be launched quickly in order to propose a real management plan for this species.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Sea bass is one of the most valuable fish on which many fishermen, especially small fishing enterprises, depend. According to scientific advice sea bass in the Celtic Sea, Channel, Irish Sea and southern North Sea suffers from a rapid decline that risks leading to a collapse if no action is taken. The current fishing mortality is almost four times as high as the stock can sustain. I therefore strongly support the resolution calling for Union management measures for commercial and recreational fisheries based on precise evaluation and scientific data.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I supported the resolution on the sustainable exploitation of sea bass. It recalls many principles that we can support, including the need to identify measures for the management of sea bass fishing in European territory aimed at ensuring adequate protection of the species. Indeed, scientific literature shows that the state of sea bass stocks is worrying, despite the emergency measures already taken by the European Commission in this area.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. For years, scientists have been warning us that the bar is over-exploited, but the Commission has never been able to convince Member States of the need for European-wide control for the conservation of this species. Currently, the restrictions are limited to technical measures: minimum landing size and mesh limit. So much so that the Commission had to enact an "emergency measure" banning fishing for certain trawlers until the end of April. The purpose of this resolution is to ask the Commission to assess the status of the stocks and to propose a multi-year management plan for the bar with catch quotas, which should save the species. In the interests of protecting the environment and preserving the species, I therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. National Front MPs voted in favour of the resolution on sustainable fishing of the bar, as it is a balanced text aimed at avoiding the extension of the moratorium on sea bass fishing after 30 April 2015, while proposing sustainable fishing measures after that date. The resolution rightly reminds us that restrictions should not be placed on professional fishing alone, which is responsible for only 25% of catches.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained when voting on this Resolution because, although it refers to important aspects such as the lack of scientific data on sea bass, thereby urging the Commission and States to make an assessment of resources, or to the importance of proximity management that provides for the diversity of situations at the regional level , general considerations are then set out together with European management measures that contradict these principles and ignore the diversity of existing situations.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The Commission and the Member States are requested to assess the status of sea bass stocks and their delimitation, as well as the migration of the species and the exact places of reproduction. It is considered that to protect sea bass, fisheries management measures of this species are necessary at European level and that these measures should take scientific knowledge into account and favour proximity management and the principle of regionalisation. I voted in favour of this proposal, which calls on the Commission to propose a multiannual management plan for sea bass in order to place stocks above the maximum sustainable yield.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Cadec's motion for a resolution calls on Member States to define the state of sea bass stocks and limit harvesting of this species, as the fisheries committee's recommendations are to reduce harvests by up to 60 percent to protect the species. It also calls on the Commission to propose a multiannual plan for harvesting and sea bass stocks.  In January, an emergency measure banning the harvesting of blue sea bass to the UK, France, Belgium and the Netherlands came into force, at a time of spawning that lasts until the end of April. Regardless of these measures, sea bass continues to be fished because blue fish has economic value. I support the proposal for a resolution aimed at encouraging Member States to regulate the catch of blue fish in order to preserve the species, but I hereby call for regional characteristics to be taken into account.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the resolution on the sustainable exploitation of sea bass, because it protects the sea bass by preserving it as a species of fish while at the same time managing the relevant fish stocks satisfactorily. It also creates conditions for the financial support of professional fishermen affected by the economic crisis.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the motion for a resolution on the sustainable exploitation of sea bass, as a subject that can be traced back to a number of priorities at European level. We need a multi-year management plan for sea bass that allows stocks to be above the levels that can produce the maximum sustainable yield, taking care to have sufficient scientific data for the calculation. Identifying a total allowable catch and having a minimum landing size is part of the criteria necessary to implement sustainable fishing.  There are various technical measures, as well as the problems related to discards, all of which are nevertheless necessary for a practice consistent both with the need to manage fishing efficiently at a regulatory level and to meet the needs of those who do the work and therefore best protect the figure of the fisherman.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Several scientific studies show that the current state of sea bass stocks is worrying, despite the fact that the European Commission has already implemented emergency actions in this specific area.  This resolution, which I supported, draws attention to the need to identify Community measures relating to the management of sea bass fishing, so as to guarantee this marine species adequate protection.  In view of this very necessary action, I have decided to support this document with a vote in favour.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. The proposal on sustainable fishing for sea bass has received my positive vote, as the measures to regulate and protect the conservation of biodiversity and to fish for this species are to be welcomed.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Motion for Resolution as overfishing is a serious problem which needs to be addressed.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The bar is a late-maturing and slow-growing fish, prized by both professional and amateur fishers. I was in Lorient in January 2015 for a Forum on the Sea in the presence of Alain Cadec, chairman of the European Parliament's fisheries committee, when the Commission took its unilateral decision on the closure of sea bass fishing. I was calling for a necessary multi-year quota management, which I saw as two key principles: on the one hand, the necessary definition of an all-inclusive catch (TAC) and quotas for the bar, on the other hand, the planning of the management of activities over a long period of time. This motion for a resolution goes in this direction and I therefore vote in favour.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission and the Member States shall assess the situation of the sea bass stock and its delimitation, the migration of the species and the exact breeding sites. The Commission and the Member States should be based on the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund, which provides for considerable funding for the collection of scientific data. We must impose management measures at European level for sea bass fishing in order to safeguard this species. These measures should take due account of scientific knowledge, promote proximity management and also consider the principle of regionalisation. Only in this way will a sustained and profitable exploitation of this important fishing species be possible.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it highlights the fact that measures for commercial and recreational fisheries should be coherent with each other to maintain the stock above the maximum sustainable yield, which is in accordance with the objectives of the common fisheries policy.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the draft Motion for Resolution on sustainable exploitation of sea bass.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. The purpose of this resolution is to revise the ban on pelagic trawling in the English Channel, the Celtic Sea and the North Sea until the end of April, which had been requested by the United Kingdom.  This ban is initially ineffective since only 25% of the seas caught are concerned, and is unfairly discriminatory since it applies only to pelagic trawling, which is responsible for only a minor part of the total catch concerned. However, it turns out that it is mainly French fishermen who resort to this practice, when recreational fishing is more practiced by the English. The improvements contained in the resolution, which meet the request of the French fishermen, are going in the right direction, so I voted in favour.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the sustainable operation of the bar, whose stock condition is worrying. The text calls on the Commission and Member States to assess the state of bar stocks and their delimitation, migration and exact breeding sites of the species, if necessary by using the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund, which provides considerable funding for the collection of scientific data.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The national management measures taken for sea bass fishing in European waters have so far proved insufficient to maintain species and have not solved the problems of sharing and access to resources. New regulatory measures are needed to promote neighbourhood management and the principle of régionalisation. As these are political choices, we call for them to be made with the involvement of all stakeholders. We call on the Commission and the Member States to use the European Fisheries Fund, which provides funding for the collection of scientific data, and to propose a multiannual management plan in order to keep the stock at a maximum sustainable level.  Let us remember that multiannual management plans should be prepared under the codecision procedure, so we expect the EP to be actively involved throughout the procedure. Account will have to be taken of the various management measures for commercial fisheries, the creation of a TAC (total allowable catch) and the need for a scientifically sound decision on the minimum landing size, as well as possible space-time bans, with the consequent difficulties related to the calculation of historical catches, the distribution of quotas at national level and the coverage of recreational fishing activities.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution proposing a roadmap for setting up a multi-year European management plan on the bar, as it will be prepared in consultation with all stakeholders and will contain concrete and innovative measures for professional and recreational fishing in the long term.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Sea bass is a slow-growing, late-ripening species whose fishing mortality rate is currently four times higher than maximum sustainable yield levels. In view of the worrying state of this stock, which could be on the verge of collapse, this resolution considers that sea bass fisheries management measures are needed at European level in order to safeguard this species and calls on the Commission to propose a multiannual management plan for sea bass that will bring stocks below maximum sustainable yield levels. In the light of the above, I have decided to support the resolution favourably.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the draft because, due to the poor situation of the stocks of redfish, european-level measures are needed to protect the species.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that scientific information on the state of sea bass stocks, in particular the available data on the exact demarcation, migratory routes of stocks and places of reproduction of sea bass, is insufficient;  Whereas the International Council for the Exploration of the Sea (ICES) identifies four types of sea bass stocks: the Celtic Sea/English Channel/North Sea, the Bay of Biscay, waters west of the Iberian Peninsula and west of Scotland/Ireland;  whereas sea bass is a noble species in high demand by the fishing industry; calling on the Commission to propose a multiannual management plan for sea bass that will allow stocks to be brought above levels capable of producing maximum sustainable yield; stressing the need to involve professional fishermen, recreational fishermen and advisory councils in the preparation of this management plan; considering a multiannual management plan for sea bass focusing in particular on the introduction of a total allowable catch and on the need for a decision with a solid scientific basis with regard to the minimum landing size and space-time bans for the protection of reproduction, as well as other technical measures; I voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. I support the European Parliament's resolution on the sustainable use of sea bass, as it speaks of the need to protect this species from overfishing and measures that must be based on scientific evidence.  In particular, I welcome in the Resolution the aforementioned principle of regional approach. Sometimes parliament talks about levelling standards and practices within the European Union, but nature does not know how to level standards and practices, as it depends on its adaptation to the geographical area in which it exists and the climate and other conditions given. However, different environmental conditions and past fishing practices in different geographical areas of sea bass harvesting result in greater or lesser pressure on the viability of the species.  In areas where this pressure has been demonstrated and significantly expressed, appropriate measures should be taken, while in areas where pressure has been shown to be lower and without possible consequences, measures will not be necessary. It is equally important that the measures are consulted by fishermen, as they will feel the consequences the most. Their interest is to protect the fish resource for the future, such as the EU's interest in protecting its citizens - fishermen.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. According to various studies, the status of sea bass stocks is worrying, regardless of the measures taken earlier by the Commission. The recovery of the size of the sea bass population takes a long time due to the fact that the mortality rate remains very high and that it is a species that matures late and grows slowly. Catches under recreational fishing are significant and represent at least a quarter of the catches of this species. Given that scientific data on the status of sea bass stocks are insufficient, in particular data on livestock borders, migratory and sea bass propagation sites, Member States should use the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund, which has significant financial resources to collect scientific data.  All together, european institutions and Member States, we need to create a multiannual management plan for sea bass to bring the stock above the highest sustainable yield and to protect this particular and valuable fish species.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the European Parliament's resolution on sustainable sea bass fishing, as despite previously taken action by the Commission, various studies show the worrying status of sea bass stocks and their mortality rate remains very high and is a species that matures late and grows slowly. Due to its significant economic value, sea bass is a noble species that is in high demand in the fishing industry and it should be borne in mind that the exploitation of sea bass during the spawning period must be extremely limited. It is important to point out that in the long term all stocks should be exploited at a level that will enable them to produce maximum sustainable yield, and in this regard it is necessary for the Commission to adopt a multiannual management plan for sea bass and to include professional fishermen and recreational anglers and advisory councils in its design. Measures to manage sea bass fishing should be adopted at European level and should also advocate close-up management and the principle of regionalisation. At the same time, measures for recreational and commercial fishing must be mutually aligned and in line with the objectives of the Common Fisheries Policy.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on sea bass because I believe that it is of fundamental importance for the protection of fish stocks that there should be clear management measures for sea bass fishing at European level. That is why I think it is right that we should draw up a multiannual plan for the management of sea bass fishing in order first to determine commercial fishing, with maximum catch quotas and minimum size indications, to identify periods for reproduction, the renewal of the stock and its recovery is of primary importance, and then recreational fishing by indicating quantitative and temporal restrictions.  The ultimate objective must be good management of sea bass exploitation in order to keep the stock at the highest possible levels.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Scientific information on the situation of sea bass stocks is not sufficient, in particular the available data on their precise delimitation, their migration routes and their breeding sites. In any case, several studies have shown that the situation of sea bass stocks is worrying. Mortality is very high and sea bass is a kind of late maturity and slow growth, and the recovery of this stock requires a long period of time. As a result, this resolution calls on the Commission and the Member States to assess the situation of the sea bass stock and its delimitation, the migration of the species and the exact breeding sites. Furthermore, it considers that management measures are required at European level for sea bass fishing in order to safeguard that species, which includes, inter alia, the establishment of a multiannual sea bass management plan to restore the stock to a level above the maximum sustainable yield. I voted in favour.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report for giving some indications related to the protection of sea bass. Several studies show that the situation of sea bass stocks is worrying, despite the emergency measures already taken by the Commission. It is urgent for the Commission and the Member States to assess the situation of the sea bass stock and its delimitation, the migration of the species and the exact breeding sites in order to protect this species by taking advantage of the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund, which provides for considerable funding for the collection of scientific data. Management measures should be imposed at European level for sea bass fishing in order to safeguard and restore the stock to acceptable levels.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. So what fly stung MEPs on Thursday to discuss and vote on the sustainable operation of the bar? An admittedly delicious fish, found all over Europe, from the North Sea to the Bay of Biscay, through the inland waters of the Iberian Peninsula and Ireland; this undeniably makes it a European fish, but which usually has more honours from the culinary production studios than from the European Chamber.  Going up the river that allowed the bar to make its way to the plenary, we recognize the excellent work of the Committee on Fisheries and its members, who have alerted them to the danger to this species. Indeed, the bar is fashionable. So much so that the world's reserve of this fish has decreased by 32% over the past five years. A worrying decline prompted the Commission to ban sea bass fishing using pelagic trawls until 30 April 2015 in most European seas. The alarm signal issued by the European Parliament this afternoon is salutary. For not having done so in time, wild cod is at risk of extinction in the years to come.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the necessary scientific reasoning, it is urgent to reconcile economic interests with the safeguarding of the species.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution which addresses the problems faced by the French, British and Irish from the indiscriminate fishing of sea bass, especially recreational, in the English Channel during the harvesting season.  The European Commission is requested to carry out a comprehensive analysis of sea bass stocks, as well as the establishment of a multi-year plan for the fishing and implementation of a quota system (TAC), in order to deal with the current overexploitation situation.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. In view of the worrying state of the bar stock in European waters (it has indeed declined sharply since 2012...), we adopted a resolution on Thursday 12 March calling for the establishment of a management plan to manage bar fishing activities. The text of the resolution endorses the proposed regulation that the European Commission published on 26 January, which prohibits vessels fishing with pelagic trawls from holding, transferring, transferring and disembarking bars until the end of April 2015.  For the post-2015, measures to manage bar stocks are still under discussion... The text adopted in plenary also notes the importance of assessing various management measures relating to commercial fishing, in particular the establishment of a TAC (total allowable catch) - a measure already proposed by the European Commission a few years ago. However, as The Member States have still not been able to agree on the allocation of quotas between them, discussions will therefore resume shortly between the Council and the Commission.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this resolution proposing a roadmap for the implementation of a multi-year European management plan on the bar. A public consultation could thus be launched by the Commission in order to propose a genuine management plan for this species.  This plan will need to be developed in consultation with all stakeholders and will contain concrete long-term management measures for professional and recreational fishing. Among the options that are possible, but which will have to be decided by the legislature: the setting up TAC (total allowable catch), the increase in the minimum landing size, the establishment of biological rest periods or quantitative limitations for recreational fishing.  This resolution is a real signal to the European Commission and we hope that it will be heard.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. We believe that it is necessary for measures to manage fishing activities at the bar are taken at European level if this species is to be safeguarded. The Commission must propose a multi-year management plan for the bar in order to bring the stock population above the levels of achieving maximum sustainable yield.  It is important to involve professional fishers and recreational fishers and advisory councils in the development of such a plan.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution calling for the creation of a management plan for fishing activities for sea bass. It has been demonstrated that sea bass stocks have been on the decline since 2012 and it is time to react to protect this species.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. Following a request from the United Kingdom, the European Commission has banned fishing from the pelagic trawl bar until the end of April in the English Channel, the Celtic Sea and the North Sea.  This ban appears to be unfair and ineffective: pelagic trawling accounts for only 25% of catches, while the remaining 75%, unaffected by the ban, is due to recreational fishing and other types of fishing (line, bottom trawl, net, etc.). It appears, therefore, that the scarcity of resources cannot be seriously combated by a discriminatory measure that affects only 25% of catches. It should be noted that pelagic net fishing is mainly practiced by the French and that recreational fishing is mainly practiced by the English, who are at the origin of the demand for a ban on pelagic net fishing. The proposal of the chairman of the Fisheries Committee, Alain Cadec, is to assess stocks, to put in place a total allowable catch (TAC) and quotas as part of a multi-year management plan, quotas that will apply to recreational fishing. This proposal corresponds to the request made by French fishermen. I voted FOR.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained in the vote on this motion for a resolution because, while it is an initiative that aims to promote a protection plan for an overexploted species such as sea bass, it has contradictory aspects. The fishing grounds are in a worrying situation, despite the measures taken by the Commission. However, the lack of more accurate scientific data, the definition of types of bass stocks or the different regional impact between commercial and recreational fishing, among other things, are aspects that can have a negative impact when proposing multiannual plans and setting quotas, which could be regionally unbalanced.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because there is currently no limit to sea bass catches, despite their high commercial value. This species is found massively in the North Sea, in the English Channel and in western waters. The Resolution calls for multiannual management plans and controls.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained when voting on this resolution because, although it refers to important aspects of the lack of scientific data on sea bass, thereby urging the Commission and States to make an assessment of resources, and while also taking into account the importance of proximity management that provides for the diversity of situations at the regional level , general considerations are then set out together with European management measures that contradict these principles and ignore the diversity of existing situations.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. As other fish species, sea bass populations, mainly in the North Atlantic between Ireland and Portugal, are declining, with the renewal of this species threatened in the long term if regulatory measures are not taken quickly.  This fishery has the distinction of having a large share of recreational fishing, and even especially sport, whose catches represent 25% of the total number of catches. In order to ensure better management of bar populations for the preservation of this species, the resolution calls on the Commission to take concrete measures such as stock assessment, a multi-year plan taking into account breeding periods, or the study of the introduction of fishing quotas. Although I regret the rejection of my group's amendments calling for the extension of emergency measures and the adoption of a regionalised approach to the management of this fishery, I voted in favour of this text which calls for better control of this fishery in order to safeguard the sea bass and therefore the biodiversity of our oceans.  This is a step in the right direction, even if it is a position taken by the European Parliament without legislative consequences.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I have chosen to abstain because the proposal's mechanism contains elements that are only useful for monitoring and collecting data on the state of health of stocks, also mentioning the useful difference between the recreational and professional fisheries sectors. However, the 'spirit' of the measure is too generally directed towards a strict closure of fishing activity and seems to be a 'blank delegation' to the Commission, which will thus be able to reject a Regulation that will risk, on the basis of partial technical assumptions, having a negative impact on the sector.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We abstained in the vote on this motion for a resolution because, while it is an initiative that seeks to promote a protection plan for an overexploded species such as sea bass, it has contradictory aspects. The fishing grounds are in a worrying situation, despite the measures taken by the Commission. However, the lack of more accurate scientific data, the definition of types of bass stocks or the different regional impact between commercial and recreational fisheries, among others, are aspects that can have a negative impact when proposing multiannual plans and setting quotas, which could be regionally unbalanced.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution initiated by my colleague Alain Cadec, which proposes a roadmap for setting up a multi-year European management plan on the bar.  This proposal follows the temporary ban on bar fishing announced as a matter of urgency in January 2015 to stop the fall in stocks. Unlike other species, the bar is not the subject of a specific management plan. The resolution proposes options to replenish resources and protect the interests of small fisheries. Parliament insists that future recommendations be based on scientific advice.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained when voting on this resolution because, although it refers to important aspects of the lack of scientific data on sea bass, thereby urging the Commission and States to make an assessment of resources, and while also taking into account the importance of proximity management that provides for the diversity of situations at the regional level , general considerations are then set out together with European management measures that contradict these principles and ignore the diversity of existing situations.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs and the S&D Group voted in favour of the resolution on sustainable exploitation of sea bass. Scientific information on the stock status of sea bass is insufficient, in particular the data available on precise boundaries, stock migration paths and the places of reproduction of the sea bass. This resolution calls on the Commission and the Member States to evaluate the status of the stock of sea bass and its delimitation, migration of the species and the exact places of reproduction.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. There are currently no limits on sea bass catches found in the North Sea and English Channel and other western waters. Sea bass is a commercially very important type of fish. I believe that it is also and important to call for a controlled catch of sea bass, which is clearly defined in the resolution under consideration. I think it is very important to make a multi-year plan for managing sea bass hunting, as scientists have been warning for several years about the problem of excessive sea bass hunting. So far, the European Commission has not been successful enough to convince the Member States to adopt control over sea bass catching. In addition to commercial catches, the problem represents as much as 25% of sea bass catches by recreational fishermen, whose current legislation does not include catch restrictions. While some Member States have limits on the quantity of sea bass caught, this is not enough. I certainly support the need to introduce international management of sea bass catch management, both for commercial and personal purposes. Because it's the only way that the adjustment plan can be successful and effective. Otherwise, in time, we may be at risk of extinction of this hugely important fish. And, of course, we cannot afford such ecological catastrophes. For these reasons, I supported the resolution and voted in favour of its adoption.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Scientific data on the status of sea bass stocks are incomplete, and according to various studies the status of stocks is worrying. Sea bass is a noble species, which due to its economic value is in high demand in the fishing industry. Sea bass as a species is not subject to European rules on total allowable catches and national management measures are insufficient to maintain the species and address sharing and access to resources.  I supported this resolution on sustainable sea bass fishing and agree that measures to manage sea bass fishing need to be adopted at European level to protect this species and bring stocks to levels above the highest sustainable yield or to maintain themselves at these levels. I welcome the proposal to include professional fishermen, recreational anglers and advisory councils in the development of plans and measures at European level.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. – Today, numerous scientific studies show that the status of sea bass stocks is worrying, regardless of the Commission's measures taken earlier, and the recovery of the size of the sea bass population takes a long time due to the fact that the mortality rate remains very high and is a species that matures late and grows slowly.  It is also important to stress that at the same time it is a species that is very popular when it comes to recreational fishing and should focus consumers on the consumption of other, less popular species. The Scientific, Technical and Economic Committee for Fisheries (STECF) recommends that fishing mortality of sea bass be reduced by approximately 60 % and for this reason it is necessary to create a sustainable plan for stocks and a balance between recreational and commercial fishing, which has become increasingly popular in recent years.  I believe that the resolution is welcome, but I also emphasize that it is very important to take into account regional differences, thus primarily I mean the Croatian Adriatic. The fact is that the Republic of Croatia did not receive the best conditions for small fishermen during the accession negotiations, so I consider this issue extremely important and valuable to further consider and improve the problem of small fishermen.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Any measure that helps safeguard marine life is in the right direction.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution considers, in good, the lack of scientific information on sea bass and calls on the Commission and the Member States to carry out an assessment of the appeal.  We also value other positive aspects of this resolution, such as the reference to the importance of proximity management, which take into account the diversity of situations at regional level. Nevertheless, there is general considerations and, from now on, with management measures at European level which are apparently contradictory to these principles and seem to ignore the diversity of existing situations.  The meaning of the amendments we are presenting here – and which we hope can be supported – is to try to eliminate these apparent contradictions by favouring undoubtedly necessary management measures, but adjusted to each specific situation.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: – Mr President, unfortunately I had to vote against the resolution on the 28th Session of the UNHRC. I agree that there are a lot of good points in this resolution. However, I do not like the unbalanced view on certain issues. For example, Israel is blamed for not cooperating in Palestine issues, but why did the resolution say nothing on Palestinian non—cooperation? That is my question. Another issue is the mentioning of sexual reproductive rights. Again – and I have often said it – this is a competence of the Member States. These issues and some others led me to vote against.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the 28th Session of the United Nations Human Rights Council focused special attention on Myanmar, which is something that I would like to emphasise during this debate. Yanghee Lee, the UN Special Rapporteur on Human Rights in Myanmar, recently stated that that she fears the country is sliding back towards conflict. The fate of the displaced Rohingya in especially worrying. The government’s response to religious clashes is poor and it refuses to grant non—national races citizenship. Christian and Muslim populations such as the Rohingya face religious persecution, and it is difficult for non—Buddhists to obtain government jobs. A couple of days ago there was a harsh crackdown by the army on student protects. The dedicated session of the UNHRC on Myanmar was therefore more than welcome. I urge the European Parliament, and particularly the ASEAN Delegation to organise a similar session.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, arís vótáil mé le mo ghrúpa ins na moltaí go léir anseo agus arís, mar a fheicim, bhí tagairt ann do ghinmhilleadh a bheith ar fáil go forleathan. Tá sé beagnach i ngach aon tuarascáil anois agus ní dóigh liom gur ceart é sin.  Taobh amuigh de sin tá a lán moltaí maithe anseo agus caithfimid obair orthu, go háirithe chun cothromaíocht a thabhairt do mhná ach go háirithe. Tá sé an-tábhachtach, ní hamháin san Eoraip ach trasna an domhain, go mbeadh cothromaíocht idir mná agus fir agus níl aon chúis in aon chor nach mbeadh sé sin timpeall an domhain uilig.  Freisin, caithfimid cearta an duine óig a chosaint agus cháineamar ar maidin an cleachtadh sa tSúdáin Theas daoine óg a thógaint agus iad a chur isteach san arm agus gunnaí a thabhairt dóibh agus mar sin de i.e. saighdiúirí óga. Níl sé sin féaráilte ach oiread.  Agus an pointe deireanach, is dóigh liom nach ceart d’aon duine nó aon tír a bheith ar an gComhairle mura nglacann siad cearta sibhialta agus cearta daonna ina dtíortha féin.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The United Nations Human Rights Council is a unique platform for the defence of universal human rights. That is precisely why I regret that I was unable to vote in favour of the resolution on EU priorities for EU meetings this year. The European Union insists on applying a double standard in its human rights policy. Thus, even if I agree with the general framework, and set out aspects that I consider fundamental – such as the abolition of the death penalty, the defence of the rights of women, children and LGBTI people or economic and social rights – when dealing with specific cases, Parliament sweeps down the carpet the systematic human rights violations of the Palestinian people perpetrated by the Israeli regime or the Moroccan repression against the people Saharawi, which has prevented me from voting in favor.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This resolution prioritised a wide range of human rights issues such as social and economic rights, women’s rights, civil and political rights, rights of the child, LGBTI rights, and human rights in the context of climate change. It also expresses full support for the role of the International Criminal Court.  It referred specifically to a number of challenges such as socio-economic rights concerning access to food, water, healthcare, education, housing etc. and the need to address extreme inequalities as a means to fight poverty. It also identified tax evasion and the mismanagement of public goods as a violation of citizens’ rights which, it pointed out, diverts funds from investment in much-needed public services. It also condemns violence against women in war and peacetime and recognises the vital role of women in peace-building. I welcome Palestine being named a priority country and the denouncement of Israel for not cooperating with the UN Commission of Inquiry into Gaza. Unfortunately, the resolution does not state clearly that the illegal occupation and blockade are the root cause of the conflict in Palestine. Overall however, the resolution was much more positive than negative. I voted in favour.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Much of the work done by the UNHRC is good; however, I could not support the text of the report.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, which aims to assess the EU's priorities in the run-up to the Session of the United Nations Human Rights Council in 2015. Regular meetings of the Human Rights Council, the mechanism for the periodic evaluation of the protection of human rights and the empowerment of persons in specific country-specific matters under specific procedures contribute to the promotion and respect of the principle of human rights, democracy and the rule of law. I support calls on all governments to encourage and support civil society organisations and human rights defenders, as well as to allow them to act without fear, repression or intimidation. I support calls for the EU, the Commission and the EEAS to integrate human rights into all areas of external policy in third countries. I agree with the need to support and strengthen the UN Human Rights Monitoring Mission and the OSCE Special Monitoring Mission in Ukraine.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this very ideological resolution which, under the guise of defending human rights, encourages immigration, wants to prevent Member States from regaining control of their borders and promotes gender theory and its procession of ultra-minority communitarian demands.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. In view of the universality of human rights and the importance of human rights in the integration project as well as in the external policies of the European Union, it is normal that we support all international bodies aimed at promoting and enforcing human rights around the world.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this resolution because it is a balanced and comprehensive text, and because it has great value in being a product of consensus among parliamentary groups. However, it is a resolution that is late. It was adopted on 12 March, i.e. we are referring to what Parliament believes should be the EU's priorities for the UN Human Rights Council ten days after the first session began. Needless to say, the title of the resolution has been changed with the aim of covering the various sessions to be held throughout this year. In addition, there is one issue in a way that I believe we should improve for future occasions: the internal nature of many of its sections. I believe that a text that addresses all stakeholders and is not as EU-focused would be more value.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I did not intend to support with my vote the report on the EU's priorities for the UN Human Rights Council, because it does not go beyond being a mere list of principles, but without offering concrete ideas for acceptable solutions; It also manages to be incisive on the condemnation of Islamic extremism when it faces the attack in Paris last January.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This resolution demonstrates the European Union's ambiguity on human rights, particularly in the case of Syria. While it is certainly commendable to condemn the violation of human rights (even if we cannot really judge the internal affairs of other countries), it is worrying that the Union is sending back to back the terrorist group "Islamic State" and the Syrian government of Bashar al-Assad. We must renew dialogue and relations with Syria in order to prevent it from falling into the hands of terrorists.  Moreover, this proposal clearly condemns Russia in the Ukrainian conflict, once again aligning itself with the American view of the situation. The Union is even considering the creation of a European army, an old federalist dream to further erase nations and their sovereignty. So I voted against it.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. We address here, on the one hand, cross-cutting issues such as political and social rights, women's rights, children's rights, LGTBI, fight against torture, death penalty, etc. And, on the other hand, a geographical perspective with a review of the countries that are somehow part of the Human Rights Council's agenda or the priorities expressed by the EU for this session, including: Ukraine, Syria, Libya, Iraq, Bahrain, South Sudan, Egypt, etc.  Particular emphasis is placed on the need to counter the increasingly frequent attempts to undermine the universal, indivisible and interdependent status of human rights, while aiming for an EU that, speaking with one voice, will strengthen its presence at the United Nations, increasing its credibility, visibility and coherence. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because all states must respect the fundamental rights of their citizens, take concrete steps to facilitate respect for these rights at national level, and cooperate at international level in order to remove obstacles to the safeguarding of human rights in all areas. The promotion and respect of the principle of human rights, democracy and the rule of law shall be accompanied by regular meetings of the Human Rights Council, the appointment of special rapporteurs, through the universal periodic review mechanism. The European Parliament is concerned about all restrictions on freedom of assembly and association, including bans on civil society organisations, the aggressive application of criminal laws on defamation and other restrictive laws. We therefore call on all governments to promote and support civil society organisations and human rights defenders, as well as to allow them to act without fear, repression or intimidation, and to cooperate with the United Nations Human Rights Council through a global periodic review mechanism and to ensure that the states responsible for the crackdown on human rights activists should take this responsibility.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒  This resolution prioritised a wide range of human rights issues such as social and economic rights, women’s rights, civil and political rights, rights of the child, LGBTI rights, and human rights in the context of climate change. It also expresses full support for the role of the International Criminal Court.  It referred specifically to a number of challenges such as socio-economic rights concerning access to food, water, healthcare, education, housing etc. and the need to address extreme inequalities as a means to fight poverty. It also identified tax evasion and the mismanagement of public goods as a violation of citizens’ rights which, it pointed out, diverts funds from investment in much-needed public services. It also condemns violence against women in war and peacetime and recognises the vital role of women in peace-building. I welcome Palestine being named a priority country and the denouncement of Israel for not cooperating with the UN Commission of Inquiry into Gaza. Unfortunately, the resolution does not state clearly that the illegal occupation and blockade are the root cause of the conflict in Palestine. Overall however, the resolution was much more positive than negative. I voted in favour.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. The Union's lack of realism and impartiality is at its height and the position it expresses at the United Nations seems dangerous.  On Syria, the European Union condemns the violation of human rights and places the Islamic State and Bashar al-Assad on an equal footing. However, it is in the interest of the Member States of the Union to resume dialogue with Bashar al-Assad, because his government is the only credible bulwark against the Islamic State. If his regime collapses, Syria will become a backbone for the group, which will use it to increase acts of terrorism in Europe.  On Ukraine, the Union unequivocally condemns Russia, which is responsible for all evils, and takes the American position in all circumstances, going so far as to want to create a European army, an old utopian sea snake, as the interests of the countries are divergent in this case. Diplomacy is the responsibility of sovereign states and not of the Union, I voted against this text.

name: Cristian-Silviu Bușoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Article 21 of the Treaty of Lisbon, which underpins the EU's actions in its relations with third countries, reaffirms the universality and indivisibility of human rights and fundamental freedoms and provides for respect for human dignity, the principles of equality and solidarity, as well as respect for the principles of the United Nations Charter and international law. Respect, promotion and guarantee of the universality of human rights are also an integral part of the European Union's ethical and legal acquis and are one of the cornerstones of European unity and integrity. I support the EU's promotion of the universality and indivisibility of human rights, including civil and political, economic, social and cultural rights, in accordance with Article 21 of the Treaty of Lisbon and the General Provisions on the Union's external action, as well as the EU's priorities for the UN Human Rights Council on: civil and political rights, social and economic rights, business and human rights, women's and children's rights, climate change and human rights, international cultural and sporting events and human rights, the fight against impunity and the International Criminal Court (ICC), as well as WITH EU priorities on specific issues of certain countries (Ukraine, Iran, democratic People's Republic of Korea, Myanmar/Burma, Bahrain, Belarus, Egypt, Mali, South Sudan, Sri Lanka, Syria, Iraq, Palestine/Israel).

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The United Nations Human Rights Council was established in 2006. This body is made up of 47 states with the mission of enforcing and promoting human rights around the world. The European Union must be a world leader in this area. That is why it is important to send a parliamentary delegation to each session representing the European Parliament. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted today in favour of the resolution on the 28th session of the United Nations Human Rights Council (UNHRC). I consider the resolution adopted to be a good resolution which has the merit of touching on many aspects dear to Parliament.  It stresses the importance of tackling growing inequalities in order to combat poverty in general and to promote social and economic rights, while also facilitating access to food, water, education, health care and adequate housing. In addition, with the adoption of the resolution, MEPs reiterated that freedom of expression, at the basis of every free and democratic society, is a fundamental right of every individual. Furthermore, the resolution condemns the misuse of religion by extremist and jihadist groups in all countries, in particular Syria, Iraq, Libya, Myanmar/Burma, Nigeria and Central Africa. Finally, I consider the reference to women's rights and the firm condemnation of all forms of violence against them to be very important.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. This resolution prioritised a wide range of human rights issues such as social and economic rights, women’s rights, civil and political rights, rights of the child, LGBTI rights, and human rights in the context of climate change. It also expresses full support for the role of the International Criminal Court.  It referred specifically to a number of challenges such as socio-economic rights concerning access to food, water, healthcare, education, housing etc. and the need to address extreme inequalities as a means to fight poverty. It also identified tax evasion and the mismanagement of public goods as a violation of citizens’ rights which, it pointed out, diverts funds from investment in much-needed public services. It also condemns violence against women in war and peacetime and recognises the vital role of women in peace-building. I welcome Palestine being named a priority country and the denouncement of Israel for not cooperating with the UN Commission of Inquiry into Gaza. Unfortunately, the resolution does not state clearly that the illegal occupation and blockade are the root cause of the conflict in Palestine. Overall, however, the resolution was much more positive than negative. I voted in favour.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This document is a good resolution, addressing the issues of respect for human rights globally. I therefore voted in favour, hoping that the same and the indications contained therein will not remain a dead letter. We often do not have the direct means to avoid violations in the world, but action can be taken to this end within different policies.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which takes up the proposals of the Panzeri report on human rights. It is therefore a very ideological bias used to justify the interference of the European Union, the self-proclaimed guardian of universal morality. Thus, paragraph 10, which essentially attacks the independence of Member States in terms of their votes in the UN Human Rights Council. Or the repeated encouragement to promote gender theory, as is the case with paragraph 34 of the report. Finally, what about the double standards, which are still in force when it comes to denouncing human rights abuses? Russia's alleged "annexation" of Ukraine is denounced, but other suspicious behavior in this area, committed by countries such as Qatar and Saudi Arabia, is omitted. In the name of realism and common sense, I had to vote against this report.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The United Nations does an excellent job but with limits. The European Parliament should try to learn from the problems of the other supranational institutions, whereas in the case of this report I have seen some attempts to fall back into the diplomatic games that block decision-making. The practice of name and shame does not make much sense when it comes to states, and it stirs up a hatred that exaggerates problems rather than solving them.  My vote is motivated by the desire to take the opposite approach.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Portugal is, for the first time, since January 2015 and until December 2017, member of the United Nations Human Rights Council. For me, as a representative of the Portuguese, and for the Portuguese Republic, this report is of great importance. Portugal aligns itself with the fundamental recommendations of this report at the thematic level, and has already committed itself to the presentation, as author, of resolutions on economic, social and cultural rights, as well as to the elimination of violence against women, the elimination of all forms of discrimination and the protection of the most vulnerable people and groups and the rights of the child. This report also highlights the call for a strong and concerted union position, for the rights of refugees and immigrants, for the new challenges of freedom of expression in the online world. I have therefore voted positive for this joint resolution.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the EU’s priorities for the 28th regular session of the United Nations Human Rights Council and I fully support the UNHRC Special Rapporteur’s latest report and conclusions on contemporary forms of racism, racial discrimination, xenophobia and related intolerance, and discrimination against migrants, including asylum seekers and refugees. I am also concerned about other EU human-rights priorities in country-related issues, and I call for the EU and the Member States to implement the Special Rapporteur’s recommendations in their internal policies for combating the violation of human rights worldwide. The motion for a resolution calls for legal abortion, an issue that falls outside EU competence, and consequently I voted against it.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 All human rights are indivisible, related, and interdependent. The lack of respect for human rights and the lack of legitimate democratic participation are the cause of instability, state failure, humanitarian crises and armed conflicts. These concepts must be constantly reiterated and supported. For this reason, I voted in favour. With particular reference to individual human rights, which I consider to be inter-employees, I voted in favour of the issue of LGBTI rights. In Europe, attitudes towards homosexuality and transsexuality vary considerably from country to country. In many European states – including Belarus, Georgia, Lithuania, Macedonia, Moldova, Russia, Serbia and Ukraine – LGBTI people are denied the right to freedom of expression, assembly and demonstration in public.  Authorities in different countries foster intolerance and fear against LGBTI communities that are discriminated against in law and practice. Prides have often been banned or participants have not been protected from violent interruptions of homophobic groups. That is why it is important to keep a high focus on this point, and I voted in favour of it.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The United Nations Human Rights Council is a unique platform for the defence of universal human rights. That is precisely why I regret that I was unable to vote in favour of the resolution on EU priorities for EU meetings this year. The European Union insists on applying a double standard in its human rights policy. Thus, even if I agree with the general framework, and set out aspects that I consider fundamental – such as the abolition of the death penalty, the defence of the rights of women, children and LGBTI people or economic and social rights – when dealing with specific cases, Parliament sweeps down the carpet the systematic human rights violations of the Palestinian people perpetrated by the Israeli regime or the Moroccan repression against the people Saharawi, which has prevented me from voting in favor.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The crisis in Ukraine, the worrying situation in the Middle East and Africa, as well as the terrorist attacks in Europe, show how important it is for the EU to be united and to show determination in respect for and defending human rights. In the fight against terrorism we understand its root causes, including social exclusion, political marginalisation and inequalities. We have a duty to make every effort to protect the rights of persons belonging to religious minorities. It is important that all states support civil society and human rights defenders and allow them to operate in a normal climate without fear, repression or intimidation.  The European Commission and the SEAE have a duty to encourage EU delegations around the world in an effort to promote and respect human rights, including by European companies, and to ensure that 'business and human rights' are among the most important themes in the event of the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In this resolution, Parliament acknowledges the United Nations Human Rights Council (UNHRC) for its work, and sees the confirmed participation of Commission Vice-President Mogherini at the 28th session of the UNHRC as a positive sign of European engagement, while stressing the importance of presenting the EU position with one voice. More importantly, the resolution considers that the continued harassment and detention of human rights defenders and opposition figures by a number of UNHRC member countries undermines the credibility of the UNHRC. It reiterates Parliament’s position that UNHRC members should be elected from among states which uphold respect for human rights, and it urges the EU Member States to promote and adopt human rights performance criteria, which should apply to any state to be elected as a member of the UNHRC. I voted in favour of this resolution, as I agree with a more unified representation of the EU, and I fully back Parliament’s call for electing UNHRC members from countries with a proven track record of protecting human rights and individual freedoms.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. In the context of the 28th session of the UN Human Rights Council, the European Parliament recalls the inalienable nature of human rights, whether civil, political, social or economic, as well as the Union's priorities in this area, particularly with regard to its partners in which human rights violations are most evident. This resolution also seeks to address a subject that I think is important, namely the links between climate change and human rights. Environmental changes threaten the livelihoods of particularly vulnerable populations in low-income countries as well as in coastal states and small low-lying island states that do not have the economic resources to adapt to radical environmental changes. In this respect, climate change is hindering the realization of internationally recognized fundamental rights. Because I believe that the States Parties to the Conference of the Parties on Climate Change will have to take a position on this issue, participate in legally defining the term 'climate refugee' at the international level and adopt ambitious mitigation and adaptation measures, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. This resolution on the 28th session of the United Nations Human Rights Council deals with many issues, two of which have been motivating me for a long time and which have prompted me to vote in favour of this resolution. On the one hand, the resolution stresses that the terrorist attacks in Paris and Copenhagen are attacks on fundamental rights, the first of which is freedom of expression. It strongly condemns the attacks and the instrumentalization of religion by some extremists. On the other hand, the resolution ends with the situation of women in the world. In this regard, it is rightly critical of the still too weak progress in equality between men and women and strongly condemns the sexual violence against women.  To combat inequality and violence, the European Parliament has called on the European Union to actively participate in the 59th session of the Commission on the Status of Women, while welcoming the International Criminal Court's recognition of crimes related to sexual affiliation, including rape, sexual assault and humiliation, and its recommendation to treat them as war crimes.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Respect, promotion and safeguarding of the universality of human rights are part of the legal and ethical acquis of the European Union and are one of the foundations of European unity and integrity. Human rights are inherent rights of all human beings, regardless of nationality, race, sex, ethnic origin, religion or any other status. Their non-observance and the lack of legitimate democratic participation cause instability and are the source of failed states, humanitarian crises and armed conflicts. I therefore welcome the priorities set by the EU for the next 28th ordinary session of the UN Human Rights Council, as well as the appointment of Ambassador Joachim Rücker as President of the Human Rights Council in 2015.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 These debates in Parliament are customary on the occasion of the UN Human Rights Council. Debates in which the instrumental and restrictive view of human rights, which is that of the majority of this Parliament, emerges. Once again, the rule was not over. In stark contrast to the priorities and objectives that the resolution proclaims, in a clear exercise of hypocrisy, there are the policies imposed on the peoples of Europe and the world, by the EU and the USA, which have contributed to the increase in inequalities, poverty, unemployment and job insecurity, exploitation and hunger, alongside the withdrawal of rights, freedoms and guarantees. On the other hand, with regard to the EU's priorities by country, we omit glaring situations and responsibilities that we recall here: - The illegal occupation of Western Sahara by Morocco;  - the illegal occupation of part of the territory of Cyprus by Turkey;  - the serious humanitarian situation in the Gaza Strip, along with Israel's belligerent occupation of Palestinian territory; - The criminal blockade of Cuba and the increasingly unacceptable common position of the EU; - The responsibilities of the EU and the US in the situation in several Countries of the Middle East.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ The world kills people every day or violates their fundamental and human rights. It is our duty to protect people, so I also welcome the appointment of Ambassador Joachim Rucker as President of the UN Human Rights Council for 2015. At the same time, we express our strong support for the mandate and efforts of Zayd Raad al-Hussein to appoint a High Commissioner for Human Rights (UNHCR). It is our duty to defend the independence of the Office of the High Commissioner, thereby ensuring that his tasks are fulfilled in an effective and impartial manner.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the resolution because it does not offer any ideas of particular interest and lists only a list of principles and good intentions.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the joint motion for a resolution for the 28th session of the UN Human Rights Council as it calls on the EU and its Member States to implement the Special Rapporteur's recommendations in their internal policy, and to combat the spread of racial, nationalism and its instigating, via the internet and social media, which is an abhorrent restriction on our national sovereign rights.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that Europe, at the next UNHRC session in Geneva, must speak with a single voice: this is the only way to raise the visibility and influence of the EU as a global actor and to encourage all moderate States in the UN to stand at our side on highly important matters, like, for example, what is going on in Ukraine – violations and abuses of human rights. With my favourable vote I supported the resolution’s call on EU Member States to actively oppose any attempt to undermine the concepts of universality, indivisibility and interdependence of human rights, to focus on the need to keep Special Procedures, and to preserve the independence and adequate funding of the Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights as well as sufficient funding to keep regional UNHRC offices open.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. The promotion, protection and universal nature of human rights are part of the EU's identity. Human rights are inherent in all human beings, regardless of nationality, race, sex, ethnicity or religion. The EU is firmly committed to the HRC and the multilateral human rights system. It is important that the UN can defend human rights and freedoms around the world independently, an objective for which it will always have EU support.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. – on the occasion of the European Parliament resolution on the Union's priorities for the 28th session of the 2015 UN Human Rights Council, I am pleased to congratulate the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, on the issues and urgencies identified and established as essential and determined policies for the European Union and its Member States. In the light of the European Charter of Human Rights, but above all of the EU's strategic framework and actions for human rights and democracy of 25 June 2012, Europe, a symbol of safeguarding the universality of human rights, confirms its commitment with adequate funding and with every support measure at its disposal to promote the work of the United Nations Council on Human Rights and the UNHCHR.  It is essential in this context to encourage the participation and involvement of civil society in the project to protect freedom of speech, religion and association and to strongly condemn the death penalty, torture, forms of discrimination and violence, exploitation and repression. Europe remains a symbol and guarantor of a solid and priority system based on values, dignity and democracy, and be vigilant about the emergencies and fragilities that still persist.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report. If the EU is to be a credible global actor, it is crucial that EU Member States actively oppose any attempt to undermine the concept of universality, indivisibility and interdependence of human rights, defend the practice of Special Procedures and  help ensure adequate funding of the Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights, as well as regional OHCHR offices.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against it, as the commitment signed by all groups except the GUE/NGL Group does not reflect what we consider to be key human rights points. While it is true that the resolution condemns violations of rights in different countries, it does not refer to the main causes of such violations and does not reject the concept of 'responsibility to protect'. The resolution is particularly weak on issues related to gender, immigration, lgbt rights, debt, the protection of personal rights, peoples' self-determination and the right of peoples to dispose of their natural resources, arms trade, Israel's occupation of the West Bank and East Jerusalem, and the situation of Palestinian prisoners.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report because human rights are the cornerstone of the European Union. The implementation of the UN’s guiding principles on business and human rights must be a key priority in the renewed action plan on human rights. I support the call for the EU delegations in New York and Geneva to increase the coherence of EU policy through timely and substantive consultation, in order to present the EU’s position with one voice.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it includes key human rights provisions such as human rights mainstreaming, the death penalty, human rights and climate change and the rights of the child. I also think we need to recognise the importance of sending parliamentary delegations to sessions of the Human Rights Council and to other relevant UN General Assembly sessions in order to seek ways to support countries in the fulfilment of their human rights obligations.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against it, since the commitment signed by all groups except the GUE/NGL Group does not reflect what we consider key human rights points. While it is true that the resolution condemns violations of rights in different countries, it does not refer to the main causes of such violations and does not reject the concept of 'responsibility to protect'. The resolution is particularly weak on issues related to gender, immigration, lgbt rights, debt, the protection of personal rights, peoples' self-determination and the right of peoples to dispose of their natural resources, arms trade, Israel's occupation of the West Bank and East Jerusalem, and the situation of Palestinian prisoners.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a joint proposal for a resolution on european union priorities for the United Nations Human Rights Council in 2015 on the grounds that one of the pillars of the cornerstone of the European Union is the protection and promotion of the universality of human rights.  A free and democratic society must be based on respect for the civil and political and social and economic rights of all individuals in order to ensure the effective and comprehensive application of internationally recognised human rights. Further efforts are needed on gender equality, the rights of children and LGBTI people to ensure the universality and indivisibility of these rights.  I also believe that the European Union must continue to provide concrete assistance to individual countries where fundamental human rights are not fully respected or violated, as has been established in the case of Ukraine, Syria and others.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this resolution as it, among other issues, highlights the rights of the child. It specifically urges the United Nations to increase pressure on the African authorities to act in the conflict in South Sudan, where the human rights of the population are systematically abused. I feel particularly strongly about this sentiment and can only reiterate my previous calls for the complete publication of the African Union’s Commission of Inquiry report on South Sudan.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the 28th session of the UN Human Rights Council. I share the priorities of the European Union developed in the text on civil and political rights, economic and social rights and children's rights.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ EH Bildu abstained in the vote on the joint motion for a resolution on EU priorities for the United Nations Human Rights Council (UNHRC) in 2015. The joint motion presented notes on country-related priorities for the EU for Ukraine, DPRK (the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea), Iran, Myanmar, Belarus, Bahrain, Egypt, Mali, South Sudan, Sri Lanka, Syria, Iraq and Palestine / Israel, but it omitted many countries with a complicated situation, including Colombia, Mexico, Saudi Arabia, Turkey, Burundi, Nigeria, Gambia, Afghanistan, Azerbaijan, Uzbekistan and many others. Indeed, it is sad to see that cases such as those of Mexico, Azerbaijan and Uzbekistan, included in the group motions for resolutions, were omitted in order to achieve compromise. Moreover, several inalienable rights are not mentioned or are barely addressed. There is nothing on cultural rights or on public services; the text does not go deeply into economic and social issues; and the situation of migrants and refugees is not well addressed. Hence, supporting this proposal would be complicated for us. Nevertheless, some positive points about it should be noted, such as the development of a section on climate change and human rights, and the paragraphs on women’s rights and children’s rights.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Human rights are part of the European Union's ethical and legal basis and for the Labour Party MEPs this is a major political commitment on foreign policy. I therefore supported the resolution calling the EU delegations in New York and Geneva to increase the coherence of EU policy through timely and substantive consultation in order to present the EU’s position with one voice. The promotion of human rights must be a cornerstone of EU relations with other countries.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. National Front MEPs voted against the European Union's 2015 resolution on priorities for the UN Human Rights Council. It is, as every year, a highly ideological text. Note paragraph 21, which is devoted to immigration and leads to a questioning of border protection mechanisms. This is once again an attack on the sovereignty of states in matters of immigration, under the guise of respect for human rights.
