How can we talk about "arbitrary arrests and detentions" when it comes to illegal immigrants? How can they be deported if they can no longer be deported? There is talk of other solutions to this problem, but these solutions are never specifically named. The angelism of all the established political groups in this Parliament has never solved any problems, but only contributes to making them worse.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The United Nations Human Rights Council is a unique platform for the defence of universal human rights. That is precisely why I regret that I was unable to vote in favour of the resolution on EU priorities for EU meetings this year. The European Union insists on applying a double standard in its human rights policy. Thus, even if I agree with the general framework, and set out aspects that I consider fundamental – such as the abolition of the death penalty, the defence of the rights of women, children and LGBTI people or economic and social rights – when dealing with specific cases, Parliament sweeps down the carpet the systematic human rights violations of the Palestinian people perpetrated by the Israeli regime or the Moroccan repression against the people Saharawi, which has prevented me from voting in favor.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the resolution on the 28th session of the United Nations Human Rights Council, which prioritizes civil and political rights, including freedom of thought and expression, religion and the fight against all forms of discrimination and violence.  I welcome the UN Development Plan for Social and Economic Rights and efforts to eradicate poverty by 2030. We should be aware that corruption, tax evasion and mismanagement of public goods and lack of accountability contribute to human rights violations. Governments are obliged to respect citizens' rights and provide education, health services and other social rights. The motion for a resolution notes that women's rights, despite progress made, remain at risk, with women underrepresented in decision-making positions and violence against women widespread. Children's rights are equally at risk and more than 58 million children do not have basic conditions for normal development, education and life.  All Member States are urged to promote the universality and indivisibility of human rights, accordingly human rights should be included in all areas of foreign policy, including trade policy, investment development and policy, security and defence policy.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained from the vote as there is more EU bilingualism on the issue of the protection of human rights in the world, at a time when the troika has, without any consequence, violated human rights in the countries that were put to a memorandum and especially in Greece.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. Vote against. Like the Panzeri report on the annual report on human rights and democracy in 2013 voted earlier, this highly ideological resolution uses human rights to justify Brussels' interference in the affairs of third countries.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The defence of human rights, civil and political rights is one of the cornerstones of the European Union and as such we must work to safeguard these rights in line with the United Nations Human Rights Council. I believe, however, that in the joint motion for a resolution between the various political groups in this Parliament, competences relating to the European Union's foreign policy have been bypassed, which is why my final vote was against.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the forthcoming 28th session of the United Nations Human Rights Council, to be held from 2 to 27 March, the European Parliament has given its opinion on the priorities identified by the European Union with a view to its meeting. By fully agreeing with the content of a resolution, which refers to the need to put the protection of human rights before any economic and/or political interests, I have decided to support it with my vote in favour.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. Respect for, promotion and respect for human rights is an important cornerstone of the European Union. Respect for human dignity, the principles of equality and solidarity contribute to the promotion and respect of human rights, democracy and the rule of law. For this reason, the EU's priorities for the forthcoming 28th session of UNHCR are to be welcomed.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I vote against reports calling on the Union to "speak with one voice" on foreign policy, as this goes against the sovereign positions of the Member States. In this case, it is a resolution to give a mandate to the delegation of the European Union which takes part in the annual work of the UN Human Rights Council. The European Parliament has once again given lessons to Russia, redefined, alongside Qatar and Azerbaijan, as a "totalitarian state" without a word for Kuwait, Saudi Arabia and some other rich allies of the United States. But above all, the resolution avoids positioning itself on some of the debates on the agenda of the session: housing rights, access to public services and debt cancellation. Inalienable rights undermined by European austerity policies, which have also been scrutinised by the United Nations.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Respect, promotion and safeguarding of the universality of human rights are part of the legal and ethical acquis of the European Union and are one of the foundations of European unity and integrity. Human rights are rights inherent in all human beings, regardless of nationality, race, sex, ethnic origin, religion or any other status, and that respect for these rights is enshrined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, as well as the Conventions , subsequent international declarations and resolutions on human rights.  I therefore agree with the EU's priorities for the next 28th ordinary session of the UN Human Rights Council (UNHRC) presented in the Council conclusions of 9 February 2015. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ It is unfortunate that an otherwise balanced joint motion for a resolution included unacceptable references to sexual health and reproductive rights which may be interpreted as a right to abortion.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I support the joint resolution adopted by the European Parliament on the priorities set by the European Union in 2015 for the UN Human Rights Council. The issues set out in it represent what the Union is working on in human rights, including women's rights, LGBTI rights, civil and political rights, economic and social rights, etc.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution highlighting horizontal issues such as civil, political, social and economic rights, women’s and children’s rights as well as EU priorities on country-related issues on the agenda of the part-session, inter alia Ukraine, Syria, Libya, Iraq , Bangladesh, Myanmar/Burma, Belarus, Bahrain, Egypt, Mali, South Sudan and Sri Lanka.

name: Angelika Mlinar (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the adoption of the resolution. It is extremely important to send the right signal and show the EU’s strong commitment to the multilateral human rights system. Condemning human rights violations and calling for EU human-rights mainstreaming is the way forward if we want to be a credible international partner, capable of guaranteeing the observance of human rights, which is the cornerstone of every free and democratic society.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The resolution proposes priorities to be represented at the UN Human Rights Council meeting by the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy/Vice-President of the Commission. It takes action on all aspects of the 2013 report on human rights and democracy. It criticises the fact that some of the current members of the E.P.A. are considered to be the most serious human rights violators and urges Member States to adopt human rights performance standards, which should apply to all states to be elected members of the E.P.A. It supports the establishment of a strong multilateral human rights system under the auspices of the UN and takes on the member states most critical to human rights.  Moving forward and applying the resolution would significantly help the UN's work in the protection of human rights and is therefore, in my view, worthy of support.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. I am in favour of this motion for a resolution identifying the Union's priorities for the 28th session of the UN Human Rights Council. The importance of the European Union in supporting the implementation of human rights is essential to me. In this document we talk about Civil and Political Rights, Social and Economic Rights, Human Rights, Women's Rights, Children's Rights, the Rights of LGBTI People, climate change, the fight against impunity, the right of minorities.  I could number some of the countries here, but I do not, because the full conquest and safeguarding of human rights is still a long way from being achieved.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. The European Union has a lack of realism in its defence of human rights. Indeed, the position it expresses at the United Nations seems dangerous.  On Syria, the European Union condemns the violation of human rights but sends back the Islamic State and Bashar al-Assad. However, it is in the interest of the Member States of the Union to resume dialogue with Bashar al-Assad, because his government is a bulwark against the Islamic State. If his regime collapses, Syria will become a backbone for the group, which will use it to increase acts of terrorism in Europe.  On Ukraine, the Union unequivocally condemns Russia, which is responsible for all evils, and takes the American position in all circumstances, going so far as to want to create a European army, an old utopian sea snake, as the interests of the countries are so divergent. Diplomacy being the business of sovereign states and not of the Union, I voted against this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The implementation of the UN’s guiding principles on business and human rights must be a key priority in the renewed action plan on human rights, including better access to justice for victims of corporate human-rights abuses worldwide.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this joint resolution on the 2015 priorities of the European Union for the UN Human Rights Council. The text, which condemns the January 2015 attacks in France, reaffirms that freedom of expression, the cornerstone of any free and democratic society, is a fundamental right of every person. It also condemns the use of religion by extremists and jihadists around the world.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Respect for, promotion and safeguarding the universality of human rights are an integral part of the European Union's ethical and legal acquis and are one of the cornerstones of European unity and integrity. In view of the work of the UN Council, we would like to stress our full support for certain horizontal issues that will be addressed: the universality and indivisibility of civil, political, economic and social rights in accordance with Article 21 of the Treaty of Lisbon; the protection of women's and children's rights; current affairs related to the difficult situations in Ukraine, Syria, Libya, Iraq, Bahrain, Egypt, Mali, South Sudan, Sri Lanka.  We once again call on the European Union and all Member States to sign and ratify the Council of Europe Convention on preventing and combating violence against women and domestic violence, recalling the EU's commitment to integrating human rights and gender issues into the missions of the Common Security and Defence Policy, in accordance with historic UN Security Council Resolutions 1325 and 1820. We call for the systematic participation of women to be recognised as an essential component of peace processes and for gender perspectives to be integrated into democratic transition processes.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution examines the human rights situation in the world and presents the EU's priorities for the 28th session of the UN Human Rights Council (UNHRC), including the elimination of the death penalty, respect for human rights and children's rights, and the fight against climate change. Considering that the promotion and safeguarding of the universality of human rights is not only an integral part of the European Union's ethical and legal acquis, but is also one of the cornerstones of European unity and integrity, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The United Nations was established 70 years ago and since then has been a member of 193 countries committed to the protection of human rights, human dignity for all people, a better life and world peace. Today, however, the organization's credibility is starting to resemble that of the salt bureau, the office of unresmanageable affairs. These are critical times. Thousands of people are tortured and killed every day in the world, human rights seem to matter to us only as long as they can be comfortably fulfilled, as long as their list of à la carte systems allows us to raisin that I love this, I don't like that.  It is time to set an example because of our situation. To do that, we're going to have to clean up our own front door. Enough with the double standards. It is untenable, for example, to speak out against third countries for the fundamental human right to a fair trial, while in Slovakia, an EU Member State, malina hedvig is being prosecuted by the State against her own citizen. He does so because he cannot face the fact that the schoolgirl was indeed beaten in the street in 2006 because she spoke Hungarian in her native language.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the unified text of this resolution because I believe that Parliament needs to be a more active partner and supporter of the United Nations Human Rights Council (UNHRC). The text comprehensively covers the most important human-rights issues, but we could add even more subjects, such as freedom of expression and assembly, which require more protection throughout the world. The EU needs to coordinate better with the UNHRC, and the Member States of the Union also need to align their policies better with both the European External Action Service and the UN, as there can be duplication of effort in some places while in others not enough is done.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. The report had many aspects which I share. These include, for example, the condemnation of Hamas' rocket attacks on Israel. On the other hand, however, the report also contains many statements which I cannot support. Examples of this would be the significant expansion of migrants' rights or statements on gender mainstreaming. That is why I abstained.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the draft because respect for, promotion and protection of the universality of human rights is part of the European Union's ethical standards and acquis and one of the cornerstones of European unity and integrity. All countries have a duty to respect the fundamental rights of their inhabitants and to take concrete measures to guarantee their rights. A very high emphasis must be placed on combating terrorism and curbing extremism.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I would like to vote in favour of the resolution on the European Union's priorities for the United Nations Human Rights Council, as I believe that the defence of the rights of the individual is a fundamental value that the EU and its Parliament must be at the forefront of supporting. We cannot look at the persistent violations of human rights that are still taking place outside, at borders and, unfortunately, even within the Union. Any threat, discrimination and repression of fundamental freedoms must be firmly condemned and the violators of law isolated. I hope that Europe will be able to talk about human rights more and more with one voice, so I join Parliament's call for faster and more effective action by the EEAS, so that better cooperation between the European Union and the United Nations can enhance monitoring, strengthen promotion and ensure an adequate response in cases of legal violations.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that respect for, promotion and safeguarding of the universality of human rights is one of the cornerstones of European unity and integrity;  whereas human rights are specific to all human beings regardless of nationality, race, sex, ethnic origin, religion or any other condition; whereas all human rights (whether civil, political, economic, social or cultural) are indivisible, related and interdependent and the deprivation of any of them has a negative and direct impact on others; Given that the lack of respect for human rights and the lack of legitimate democratic participation are the cause of instability, state failure, humanitarian crises and armed conflicts, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The UN Human Rights Council justifiably condemns the self-proclaimed Islamic State, which in my opinion is only the latest, extreme form of threat to Christian communities living in areas we consider to be the cradle of our faith, and today they are facing total vanishing.  The tragedy of the disappearance of Christians from areas sacred to us is the tragedy of losing its connection to our roots.  Communities and cultures that have been going on for almost two thousand years are facing religious and cultural destruction today.  Rivers of blood still flow through the Middle East today. Rivers of blood of Christians who, despite all historical adversity, survived in the countries where our faith was born. Faith that often makes Christians in the Middle East second-class citizens.  The doors of the European Union must be open to our sisters and brothers fleeing death threats, but everything needs to be done to preserve Christianity in the Middle East.  We must be concrete in our action, not just silently watch our brothers and sisters being killed or make resolutions that remain a dead letter on paper. Enough of the shrugging and justifying that Parliament has no executive role. But we have a responsibility. As politicians and as people. Let's show it.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the EU must make its voice heard loud and clear within the UN, giving credibility and coherence to Parliament's action to guarantee civil, political, social and economic rights, especially for women and children. I naturally support the EU priorities listed in the resolution, in particular the need to address difficult situations in countries such as Egypt, Syria, Myanmar, Belarus and South Sudan. The EU must also bring to the attention of the UN Human Rights Council issues relating to other, more up-to-date rights such as the protection of indigenous people, whose lives and natural habitats are put at risk by climate change, support for human rights defenders, protection for LGBTI rights, protection of children's rights in armed conflicts, the fight against torture and the death penalty.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution because it is a priority for the European Parliament to commit itself to supporting a structured multilateral system of human rights, under the aegis of the United Nations, and for the Union to speak with one voice, loud and clear, especially at a time of serious instability in various areas around the EU. The EU must also activate its delegations around the world to work to promote respect for human rights and democracy even in remote parts of the world, with the maximum involvement of civil society.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution concerns the EU's priorities for the 28th ordinary session of the UN Human Rights Council (UNHRC), presented in the Council conclusions of 9 February 2015. Respect, promotion and safeguarding the universality of human rights are part of the legal and ethical acquis of the European Union and are one of the foundations of European unity and integrity.  The ordinary sessions of the Human Rights Council, the appointment of special rapporteurs, the Universal Periodic Review mechanism and the Special Procedures to address country-specific situations or thematic issues contribute to the promotion and respect of human rights, democracy and the rule of law. This resolution therefore defends the importance of sending parliamentary delegations to the three sessions of the Human Rights Council and to the other relevant sessions of the UN General Assembly in order to find ways to support countries in fulfilling their human rights obligations. I voted in favour.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document for supporting a robust multilateral human rights system under the aegis of the United Nations. I agree that we should strengthen support for civil society organisations and human rights defenders by allowing them to carry out their activities without fear in order to jointly combat the humanitarian crisis we have been witnessing. It is a priority to ensure that fundamental rights, such as freedom of expression, are guaranteed and to condemn any act of violence, whether committed by extremist groups, with the shield of religion, or by governments, using the death penalty and acts of torture.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this joint resolution of the S&D, EPP, ECR, ALDE, Verdes/ALE and EFDD groups on the 28th session of the United Nations Human Rights Council following the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy.  The Resolution addresses, on the one hand, cross-cutting issues such as political and social rights, women's rights, children's rights, LGTBI, combating torture, the death penalty, etc. And, on the other hand, a geographical perspective with a review of the countries that are somehow part of the human rights council's agenda or the priorities expressed by the EU for this session, including Ukraine, Syria, Libya, Iraq, Bahrain, South Sudan, Egypt, etc.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the 28th session of the UN Human Rights Council, which took place from 2 to 27 March in Geneva.  The Human Rights Council is an intergovernmental body of the United Nations system. It is made up of 47 states responsible for strengthening the promotion and protection of human rights around the world. The Council thus addresses and makes recommendations on human rights violations.  This resolution recalls the importance of international human rights advocacy and sets priorities for the fight against the death penalty, the defence of children's rights and the monitoring of the human rights situation.  The text also reiterates the importance for the European Union of sending parliamentary delegations to the three sessions of the Human Rights Council to show the support given by the Union and parliamentarians in the defence of human rights, a central objective of the Union's external action.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote against it because this resolution, over and above the mere list of principles, which we can also partly support on the human rights front, does not offer any ideas of particular interest or for which we can express a positive opinion. When the text addresses the issue of what happened with the attack on 'Charlie Hebdo', the references to the serious responsibilities of Islamic extremists are too incisive. There are also numerous out-of-place references to the alleged rights of LGBTI people.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against it, since the commitment signed by all groups except the GUE/NGL Group does not reflect what we consider key human rights points. While it is true that the resolution condemns violations of rights in different countries, it does not refer to the main causes of such violations and does not reject the concept of 'responsibility to protect'. The resolution is particularly weak on issues related to gender, immigration, lgbt rights, debt, the protection of personal rights, peoples' self-determination and the right of peoples to dispose of their natural resources, arms trade, Israel's occupation of the West Bank and East Jerusalem, and the situation of Palestinian prisoners.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which lists the priorities of the European Parliament for the 28th session of the UN Human Rights Council.  The text expresses its support for the work of Prince Zeid Ra'ad Zeid Al Hussein as the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, reaffirms that freedom of expression is the cornerstone of any free society and strongly condemns the attacks in Paris and Copenhagen by terrorists using religion to commit acts of barbarism.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The United Nations Human Rights Council is a unique platform for the defence of universal human rights. That is precisely why I regret that I was unable to vote in favour of the resolution on EU priorities for EU meetings this year. The European Union insists on applying a double standard in its human rights policy. Thus, even if I agree with the general framework, and set out aspects that I consider fundamental – such as the abolition of the death penalty, the defence of the rights of women, children and LGBTI people or economic and social rights – when dealing with specific cases, Parliament sweeps down the carpet the systematic human rights violations of the Palestinian people perpetrated by the Israeli regime or the Moroccan repression against the people Saharawi, which has prevented me from voting in favor.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today the Socialist and Democrats Group voted in support of the resolution on the EU’s priorities for the UN Human Rights Council in 2015. The resolution highlights horizontal issues such as civil, political, social and economic rights and women’s and children’s rights. In addition, it sets out EU priorities on country-related issues in Ukraine, Syria, Libya, Myanmar, Egypt, Mali and South Sudan to name a few. It calls on EU Member States to actively oppose any attempt to undermine the concept of universality, indivisibility and interdependence of human rights.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The motion for a resolution is based on current and thematic issues such as the identification of human rights, the death penalty, civil and political rights, women's rights and children's rights, and the inclusion and placing of human rights at the heart of EU policy. Respecting, promoting and protecting the universality of human rights is one of the fundamental principles of the European Union. That is why I also stress the importance of the participation of parliamentary delegations at human rights council meetings as well as all other relevant UN sessions, as this contributes to the promotion and respect of human rights and democracy.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I express my satisfaction with this proposal because it is obvious that the UN Human Rights Council is one of the most important factors in protecting and promoting the universality of human rights. All states are obliged to respect the fundamental rights of their populations and are obliged to take concrete measures, in order to provide a guarantee for the protection of human rights, they should first and foremost provide protection within their borders.  Freedom of expression is the backbone of any free and democratic society and we must not allow cases such as Charlie Hebdo to ever happen again, I condemn the use of religion for the purposes of extremist and jihadist groups in all countries, especially in Syria and Iraq. I also appeal to the situation in the east of Ukraine and welcome all efforts to protect human rights that are increasingly at risk in this area every day. This resolution is important because it supports the work of the International Criminal Court in the field of abolishing the practice of impunity for perpetrators of serious crimes. It also deals with the protection of the rights of women, children and immigrants and these are just another reason why I will support this resolution and join in the fight to protect fundamental human rights.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal because I agree with the recommendations of the resolution on the protection of human rights. I am particularly pleased that the proposal talks about the positive relationship between trade and human rights and how trade and human rights can be mutually supportive. Greater economic freedom leads not only to greater prosperity, but also to greater overall freedom.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The special rapporteur's recommendations on the internal policy of the Member States, to combat the spread of racial nationalism and its instigating, using the internet and social media, should be made with respect for their national sovereign rights.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. It should be remembered, however, that the continued harassment and detention of human rights defenders and opposition figures by a number of members of the Human Rights Council undermines its credit.  Parliament wishes to reaffirm that the members of the Human Rights Council should be elected from states that respect human rights, the rule of law and democracy and have agreed to issue permanent invitations to all special procedures. Parliament urges Member States to promote and adopt human rights outcome criteria, which should apply to all states before they can be elected as members of the Human Rights Council.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution, if not perfect, supports important principles such as respect for fundamental freedoms, rule of law and democracy. These are key elements for the EU and should also be for the international community.  This is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against it, as the commitment signed by all groups except the GUE/NGL Group does not reflect what we consider to be key human rights points. While it is true that the resolution condemns violations of rights in different countries, it does not refer to the main causes of such violations and does not reject the concept of 'responsibility to protect'. The resolution is particularly weak on issues related to gender, immigration, lgbt rights, debt, the protection of personal rights, peoples' self-determination and the right of peoples to dispose of their natural resources, arms trade, Israel's occupation of the West Bank and East Jerusalem, and the situation of Palestinian prisoners.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it sets out a clear position on what the priorities of the EU and its Member States should be at the various sessions of the 2015 UN Human Rights Council. However, I would like to express my specific disagreement with the final wording of the paragraph addressing the situation in the Gaza Strip. The People's Party Group has tabled an amendment even though the text had already been negotiated by the various groups signatories to the joint motion for a resolution. The original text sought to focus on the tragic humanitarian situation, without going into addressing, for this time and for the sake of consensus, the degree of responsibility of the various actors involved in the conflict. The Socialists strongly condemn Hamas's launch of rockets at the Israeli civilian population, but the text, as amended by the People's Group, ignores the enormous degree of responsibility of the Israeli Army and Government in the current situation of enormous humanitarian crisis, generated after last offensive last July, and aggravated by the continued and illegal blockade imposed on the Strip.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The United Nations Human Rights Council is a unique platform for the defence of universal human rights. That is precisely why I regret that I was unable to vote in favour of the resolution on EU priorities for EU meetings this year. The European Union insists on applying a double standard in its human rights policy. Thus, even if I agree with the general framework, and set out aspects that I consider fundamental – such as the abolition of the death penalty, the defence of the rights of women, children and LGBTI people or economic and social rights – when dealing with specific cases, Parliament sweeps down the carpet the systematic human rights violations of the Palestinian people perpetrated by the Israeli regime or the Moroccan repression against the people Saharawi, which has prevented me from voting in favor.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 We consider that all States have an obligation to respect the fundamental rights of their populations and the duty to take concrete measures to facilitate respect for these rights at national level, as well as to cooperate at international level with a view to removing obstacles to the achievement of human rights in all areas. We find that, regrettably, some of the current members of the Human Rights Council are recognised as being among the worst human rights offenders, have a negative track record in terms of cooperation with the UN Special Procedures and of fulfilling their reporting obligations to the bodies established by the UN Human Rights Treaties. We follow the report on the defence of political rights, in the defence of emigrants, and of all the most disadvantaged layers. We follow the death penalty conviction. We are sorry that social and labour rights, the violation of which constitutes the foregoing violation of other fundamental rights, is not properly raised in this report.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. Respect for, promotion and respect for human rights is an important cornerstone of the European Union. Respect for human dignity, the principles of equality and solidarity contribute to the promotion and respect of human rights, democracy and the rule of law. For this reason, the EU's priorities for the forthcoming 28th session of UNHCR are to be welcomed.

name: Kristina Winberg (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ With this resolution the European Parliament has consistently reminded all countries mentioned of their obligations under international human rights and humanitarian law. As long as this does not include automatic EU interference in domestic policies, I accept the content of the resolution.  I firmly want to underline that expressing serious concerns about the humanitarian situation in a country must not, and should not imply, that Parliament is arbitrarily judging or choosing sides in ongoing conflicts.   Concerning Article 68, I also want to emphasise the importance of an appropriate and credible investigation into possible violations of international human rights law and international humanitarian law by both Palestine and Israel in the conflict in the Gaza strip, to be fulfilled in accordance with internationals standards. Parliament must direct its recommendations to both Israel and Palestinian actors. Parliament should ensure appropriate follow-up of this particular crisis by assessing whether appropriate investigations have been conducted by both sides, not only by Israel.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Resolution adopted by the EP states that human rights – civil, political, economic, social or cultural – are indivisible, interrelated and interdependent, and that the deprivation of any of these rights has a direct and negative impact on third parties. It also considers that all States have an obligation to respect the fundamental rights of their populations. In contrast to the priorities and objectives that the resolution proclaims, in a clear exercise of hypocrisy, there are the policies imposed on the peoples of Europe and the world, by the EU and the USA, which have contributed to the increase in inequalities, poverty, unemployment and job insecurity, exploitation and hunger, alongside the withdrawal of rights, freedoms and guarantees. On the other hand, as far as the EU's priorities by country are concerned, unacceptable situations of disrespect for human rights are omitted, such as aggression against the Sahrawi people and the illegal occupation of Western Sahara by Morocco, turkey's illegal occupation of part of Cyprus, the serious humanitarian situation in the Gaza strip, alongside Israel's belligerent occupation of Palestinian territory. , the criminal blockade of Cuba or the responsibilities of the EU and the US in the situation in several Countries of the Middle East.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE).
text: – My support for the resolution we have adopted today is much more than a vote. It's a loud and clear enough! to make a people suffer that doesn't deserve to be put through what's going on. That's enough! of killing students. That's enough! to imprison politicians and businessmen with complete impunity. That's enough! of opponents fearing for their lives.  That's enough! conspiracy theories to, through enabling decrees, infringe fundamental rights. That's enough! of hiding under a dictatorship disguised as democracy. That's enough! that the division of powers is not respected. That's enough! that the Venezuelan people live in fear. But it's also a enough! to look the other way.  Those who do not condemn what is happening in Venezuela are complicit in this, and here, unfortunately, we have seen some cases today. Venezuela needs no compassion, it needs decisive action by all Democrats; that's our challenge today.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: – I am very concerned about the ongoing violence and violations of fundamental human rights against representatives of the opposition and students in Venezuela, who are absolutely denied the presumption of innocence, as well as repeated violence against the opposition. This has brought a large number of injured and even dead, which is really unacceptable at the moment in a civilised country. The non-resolution of this situation can lead to further violence and to the destabilisation of the country, so I fully support the resolution proposing the creation of a European Parliament delegation. I believe that this delegation can be an effective instrument necessary for dialogue with government officials in Venezuela.

name: Pablo Echenique (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in Podemos we defend the fundamental principles of the rule of law and freedom of expression. We also believe that, in a democracy, the way to resolve conflicts is dialogue. That is why we believe that this Parliament should use its capacity for influence to promote democratic solutions that respect the sovereignty of peoples, and not to support sanctions that only make things worse or to interfere with the domestic politics of other countries. We think it is obvious that there are many problems in Venezuela. But we also believe that the only way to solve these problems is to open up spaces for understanding and peaceful and constructive dialogue between all parties. As Ban Ki-moon has said, as Pope Francis has said, as CELAC and Unasur have said, in Podemos we believe that the best way to defend democracy and human rights in Venezuela is dialogue. That's the goal we should pursue.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. We have supported the joint resolution tabled by Parliament's most important groups to send a respectful but forceful and clear message to the Venezuelan authorities that they have to respect the rules of the democratic game; they have to free detained politicians; they must not only not harass or detain, but protect elected officials, and should seek to restore coexistence and dialogue with opposition forces. We also call for the removal of instructions authorizing security forces to shoot protesters.  The arrest of the mayor of Caracas and the worsening conditions of detention of other political leaders motivated a debate in the plenary mini-session on 25 February. In the resolution, we support the mediation efforts of Unasur and some Latin American representatives to return to dialogue and the creation of a crisp democratic space where they can concentrate on strengthening their coexistence and the rule of law.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The resolution put to the vote is a direct attack on the will of a people, the Venezuelan, who years ago decided to live in accordance with their own rules, carrying out their changes in line with the principles of international law and without being interfered with in the internal affairs of other States. This principle has not found reciprocity in the European Union and in the majority parties of Parliament, which once again lash out at that South American country. Energy independence and the sovereign will of peoples are two principles against which the Union acts with real saña, both outside and within its borders. Indirectly urging sanctions is nothing more than following U.S. policy, a country that recently declared Venezuela "a threat to its national security." In this context, calls for respect for human rights are hypocritical, as the Venezuelan state has mechanisms in place to defend its Constitution, jeopardized by a handful of minority party leaders. I voted against this resolution because I believe in the principle of respect for the sovereignty of peoples in choosing their destiny.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I did not feel that it was appropriate for me to support the amendment condemning the actions of the US Federal Government in terms of imposing sanctions against Venezuela.  The nature of the amendments in general were quite complex, and the report seemed to me to be particularly emotive. I therefore abstained on the final vote.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because I support the need for a firm and united response from Europe, given the increasing human rights violations in that country. We reiterate with this deliberation our call on the Venezuelan regime to respect democratic freedoms and demand the immediate release of all citizens who have been imprisoned or unjustly detained for having disagreed with the official doctrine of the Chavist government.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution on the situation in Venezuela. As a result of the february 2014 Street protests have erupted in Venezuela following the arrests of democratically elected politicians and the imprisonment of opposition leaders in Venezuela, killing 44 people. The resolution calls on the Venezuelan government to release imprisoned political protesters and to stop allowing security forces to use firearms to suppress civil protests. I support the calls for the Venezuelan Government to ensure that citizens are not punished for exercising their rights to peaceful assembly and freedom of expression. It is also important for the government to respect its constitution and its international obligations regarding the independence of the judiciary and political pluralism, which are the basis of democracy. The Venezuelan government must also ensure that the country has the right conditions to hold parliamentary elections in 2015. I agree that the European External Action Service must continue to monitor the investigations and court hearings of opposition leaders.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. I abstained on this resolution, which for no good reason overrides the principle of non-interference to which I remain attached.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The increasingly tense political situation in Venezuela, the recent arrests of the mayor of Caracas and the opposition leader, as well as the sometimes violent repression of peaceful demonstrations raise the question of the future of stability and peace in the country. The European Parliament had to react and show its commitment to the rule of law and democratic values. In addition, we also welcome all peaceful means of resolving the conflict, and that is why we support the mediation proposal made by Unasur.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this resolution which deals with a matter of utmost gravity and urgency. The Venezuelan government's latest actions are a flagrant violation of human rights. The new Resolution 8610, which allows the Army to use firearms in the control of "public meetings and peaceful demonstrations" – contrary to article 68 of the Venezuelan Constitution, on the use of firearms – the new political arrests, which do not meet the minimum procedural and legal safeguards, and torture in prisons force us to denounce and send a strong response. We underline the agreement reached in the resolution for the sending to Venezuela of a delegation of Members of the European Parliament.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. The motion for a resolution calls on the Venezuelan authorities to immediately release Antonio Ledezma, Leopoldo Lopez, Daniel Ceballos and all peaceful protesters, students and opposition leaders arbitrarily detained for exercising their right to freedom of expression and fundamental rights in Venezuela. The latest figures, dating from 2006, rank Venezuela 115th out of 168 countries by Reporters Without Borders (RSF) in terms of press freedom. That same year, an NGO recorded 106 violations of freedom of expression. RSF also highlighted the adoption of new laws in 2004 and 2005 against various types of "offences", notably against the person of the President, and against calls for violence, deeming them "very restrictive in terms of freedom of expression" and claiming that they create "a climate of self-censorship within the media". The political situation in Venezuela is thus tense. Nevertheless, being against interference in the internal affairs of other countries, I abstained on this text.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe it is essential for the EU to raise its voice loudly in defence of democracy and democratic principles that are currently being so blatantly violated in Venezuela. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. We have supported the joint resolution tabled by Parliament's most important groups to send a respectful but forceful and clear message to the Venezuelan authorities that they have to respect the rules of the democratic game; they have to free detained politicians; they must not only not harass or detain, but protect elected officials, and should seek to restore coexistence and dialogue with opposition forces. We also call for the removal of instructions authorizing security forces to shoot protesters.  The arrest of the mayor of Caracas and the worsening conditions of detention of other political leaders motivated a debate in the plenary mini-session on 25 February. In the resolution, we support the mediation efforts of Unasur and some Latin American representatives to return to dialogue and the creation of a crisp democratic space where they can concentrate on strengthening their coexistence and the rule of law.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, in which the European Parliament expresses its deep concern at the deteriorating situation in Venezuela and condemns the use of violence against demonstrators. A 14-year-old schoolboy who took part in a demonstration over food and drug shortages in Venezuela became the first victim after being allowed to use firearms in such protests. Parliament condemns such attacks during civil demonstrations and expresses its condolences to the families of the students killed. It also calls on the Venezuelan Government to respect its constitution and international obligations regarding judicial independence, the right to freedom of expression, associations and peaceful assembly and political pluralism, which are the basis of democracy. Calls also on the Venezuelan Government to enable human rights defenders and independent non-governmental organisations to carry out their legitimate activities in promoting human rights and democracy. It is important to stress that the Venezuelan Government, as a non-permanent member of the United Nations Security Council, has a special responsibility to uphold the rule of law and international law. The European Parliament also calls on the Venezuelan Government to ensure that the accusations are investigated promptly and impartially, without leaving any possibility of impunity and fully respecting the principle of the presumption of innocence and ensuring a fair legal process.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Venezuela has been shaken for some time by social and political unrest caused by the economic situation and the deep polarisation of society. The detention of democratically elected politicians, the lifting of legislative immunity for lawmakers in the National Assembly and the continued detention of opposition leaders since February 2014 are among the causes of protests and street clashes that have killed 44 people.  New protests can cause even more violence, and this would only deepen the gap between the government's position and the opposition and polarise the sensitive political situation even more. That is why I dinghy at representatives of all parties and parts of Venezuelan society to remain calm in both words and deeds. Furthermore, I call on the Venezuelan Government to abide by its own Constitution and respect international obligations regarding judicial independence, the right to freedom of expression, association and peaceful assembly and political pluralism, as these are the foundations of democracy.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. Venezuela is facing an internal political crisis that has called into question the authority of President Nicolas Maduro. While its up-to-the-button economic options may be questionable given the worrying drop in the price of a barrel of oil and the development of corruption, the fact remains that pressure from the United States is largely fuelling internal tensions, notably through the instrumentalization of the opposition. A staunch defender of its sovereignty, Venezuela is still seeking a balanced position in its development model. And it is not the small moral lessons of the European Union that will help it. That is why I abstained on these motions for a resolution.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In Venezuela, democratic slippages of the "bolivarian" regime have exceeded the limit of authoritarianism by moving to dictatorial measures. Numerous arrests by prominent opposition leaders reveal that President Maduro is on the verge of tearing down the last vestiges of democracy. There are serious fears that the mid-term elections in September will demonstrate the same thing: that the electoral machine created by the late Chavez, based on mentions, pressure and threats, will confirm the same state of affairs. Recent opinion polls show that if elections were held during this period, the governing party would lose more than 20 percent. Therefore, the Government of Caracas is expected to postpone the elections, which would increase the protests and mobilize the opposition. I support the motion for a resolution on the situation in Venezuela, convinced that if this aggression continues and any form of dialogue is refused, the result will mean economic regression, social instability and international isolation.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution on the situation in Venezuela, where peaceful protests against the government of President Nicolás Maduro have resulted in a disproportionate use of violence against demonstrators by police, members of the National Guard and out-of-control pro-government armed groups.  I believe that this Parliament must strongly condemn the use of violence against demonstrators. Furthermore, I believe that the Venezuelan authorities must ensure the release of all peaceful demonstrators, students and opposition leaders arbitrarily detained for exercising their right to freedom of expression. The European Union, the Member States and High Representative Mogherini should also urge the Venezuelan Government to establish an effective dialogue with the other political parties. I believe that a confrontation that allows all the political actors to discuss the serious problems facing the country is the only way for Venezuela to find decisive and lasting solutions that improve the current conditions in the country.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 As I mentioned during the debate on the situation in Venezuela, we will continue to condemn any form of violation of human rights and restriction of freedom of expression, but we will also condemn any form of improper interference in a sovereign state.  I hope that Venezuela will soon be able to have free and credible elections and that the confrontation will be political and not violent.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution today to condemn the increasingly authoritarian practices of the Maduro regime. The resolution takes a hard stance on human rights abuses, particularly those committed against peaceful protesters and an increasing number of political prisoners.  It is becoming more and more clear that President Maduro intends to silence the opposition and create a climate of social and political confrontation and instability in the run-up to the parliamentary elections this year. With the risks of social chaos growing, it is important that the EU takes a strong and united stance to support democratic opposition and freedom of expression.  I regret, however,  that the ALDE group’s amendment that called on the Council to consider adequate and proportional measures in the event of a worsening situation, was not supported by the majority of this house. It would have been an important step forward in trying to prevent an escalation of actions on behalf of a desperate regime.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because it falls into the way it claims to fight, namely ideology. In this resolution, it is the ideology of interference that is at work. It must be understood that Venezuela is still trying its way between the refusal of submission to the United States and an equally dangerous submission to socialist ideology. As a patriot, I can only commend the efforts made over the past decade by a country that has defended its sovereignty tooth and nail, notably by fighting the Monroe doctrine, which led to a genuine vassalization of South American countries to the interests of the United States. Yet the rejection of ultra-liberal ideology must not lead it into the arms of the socialist ideology which, as we see with the current situation, condemns peoples to distress: economic distress that drives millions of Venezuelans to resort to rationing; but also political distress with a police state, sclerotic by corruption and drug trafficking and where the opposition is gagged as we saw with the totally illegal incarceration of Ledezma. Like many of my colleagues, President Maduro continues to brandish the red rag of an alleged "fascist" threat to avoid lifting the veil on the dangerous effects of his illusions.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I express my deepest concern at the worsening situation in Venezuela. Specifically, I am condemning the imprisonment of Mayor Ledezma, as well as the attempt to waive the parliamentary immunity of a Member.  I also condemn the persecution of students and opposition leaders. I am in line with the demands of the various UN bodies and have therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure driven by a deep concern about the worsening situation in Venezuela; I condemn the imprisonment of Mayor Antonio Ledezma and the persecution of students and opposition leaders; I support the call of the various international organisations for the immediate release of the Mayor of Caracas and the other arbitrarily imprisoned people. I hope that the Venezuelan Government will ensure that all judicial proceedings comply with international standards and I believe that respect for the principle of the separation of powers is fundamental in a democratic regime because the authorities cannot use the judicial system as an instrument of political persecution and repression of the democratic opposition.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Respect, promotion and safeguarding of human rights are one of the foundations of the unity and integrity of peoples. Human rights are inherent rights of all human beings. Failure to respect human rights and lack of legitimate democratic participation causes instability and is the cause of failed states, humanitarian crises and armed conflict. Unfortunately, this is the situation in Venezuela. Disrespect for human rights, restrictions on freedoms of assembly, worsening acts of intimidation and ill-treatment of opposition leaders and students who participated in the 2014 demonstrations, arbitrary arrests of opposition leaders, political persecution, non-compliance with constitutional norms and international obligations. Only respect for fundamental rights and freedoms, constructive and respectful dialogue can help Venezuela emerge from this serious crisis to overcome future difficulties. For this it is crucial to resume the so-called "Dialogue Table" between government and opposition; that the Government of Venezuela end political persecution, repression of the opposition and censorship of the media and to immediately release all political prisoners and all peaceful protesters and arbitrarily detained opposition leaders.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Respect for freedom of the press, information and opinion and political pluralism are fundamental to democracy, and I deplore the existence of media and web censorship in Venezuela and the fact that access to some blogs and social networks is limited. I agree with the objectives of the motion for a resolution. Only full respect for fundamental rights and freedoms, constructive and respectful dialogue and tolerance can help Venezuela find a way out of this serious crisis and thus overcome future difficulties.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I did not sign the resolution on Venezuela because I believe that it has a basic facility based on information sources that report only views of the Venezuelan opposition, while showing obvious shortcomings in reporting the positions and reasons of the Government of Caracas. In addition to the lack of balance in reporting sources, the resolution has wide traits of interference with the Authority of the Bolivarian Republic as well as a lack of respect for national sovereignty. Considering that this resolution does not bring any benefit to the already nervous situation in Venezuela, I voted against it.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The resolution put to the vote is a direct attack on the will of a people, the Venezuelan, who years ago decided to live in accordance with their own rules, carrying out their changes in line with the principles of international law and without being interfered with in the internal affairs of other States. This principle has not found reciprocity in the European Union and in the majority parties of Parliament, which once again lash out at that South American country. Energy independence and the sovereign will of peoples are two principles against which the Union acts with real saña, both outside and within its borders. Indirectly urging sanctions is nothing more than following U.S. policy, a country that recently declared Venezuela "a threat to its national security." In this context, calls for respect for human rights are hypocritical, as the Venezuelan state has mechanisms in place to defend its Constitution, jeopardized by a handful of minority party leaders. I voted against this resolution because I believe in the principle of respect for the sovereignty of peoples in choosing their destiny.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The arrest of Caracas Mayor Antonio Ledezma, accused of conspiracy and imprisoned in a military prison, is yet another vulnus to the civil and democratic system that is being perpetrated in Venezuela. One of the world's richest commodity-rich countries, but literally starved to the point where only last month a 14-year-old student was killed by a gunshot fired by law enforcement as he protested the shortage of food and medicine. It is paradigmatic for a government to accuse the opposition of conspiratorial conspiracies and, at the same time, to authorize arrests and broadcasts of politicians in military prisons, as well as the possibility of suppressing riots with the use of firearms. Once again, Europe and Parliament are faced with calls for governments - with which trade relations are established - to commit themselves to respecting the basic rules of democracy and respect for opposition.  It seems to be a sterile exercise, yet it is the testimony that we are capable of monitoring, paying attention and never failing to support those who are fighting for the extension of civil and democratic freedoms.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution deals with the political and social turmoil in Venezuela following the escalation of tensions between the Government and the Opposition parties, especially over the detention of mayor Antonio Ledezma in a military prison and the death of a 14-year-old schoolboy during protests last month. The lack of judicial independence, the intimidation and detention of leading opposition figures and the violent repression of demonstrators are contributing to Venezuela’s growing international isolation since the protests of February 2014. Venezuela is becoming a focus for instability in South America, and its people are tired of social and political unrest, as well as the severe economic crisis. The European Union’s assistance in settling the conflict and its support for regional efforts to this end are of the utmost importance. The resolution calls on the Venezuelan Government to release all political protesters and opposition leaders detained in military prisons, and to create the conditions for the country to hold parliamentary elections in 2015. Hence I voted in favour.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Venezuela, which explicitly calls on the government to immediately release the political demonstrators and opposition leaders currently arbitrarily detained and to respect constitutional guarantees and international obligations regarding the independence of the judiciary. The responsibilities of the Venezuelan Government are increasing when it is a non-permanent member of the United Nations Security Council. I believe that the Venezuelan Government must now initiate an inclusive political process, based on consensus through effective national dialogue and involving all democratic political forces in the framework of democracy, the rule of law and full respect for human rights.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This resolution follows the arbitrary arrest on 19 February of Antonio Ledezma, the leading Venezuelan opposition figure and elected mayor of the Caracas metropolitan district, and the subsequent crackdown on protests. Concerned by the recent deterioration of the situation in Venezuela and the use of violence against opposition political actors and civil society as well as protesters, the European Parliament calls on Venezuela to immediately release Antonio Ledezma and also Leopoldo Lopez, Daniel Ceballos and all peaceful demonstrators, students and opposition leaders arbitrarily detained for exercising their right to freedom of expression and their fundamental rights. Considering that opposition rights and freedom of expression are inalienable principles and the foundations of any democratic society, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. In recent months, the situation in Venezuela has deteriorated sharply, jeopardizing the exercise of certain fundamental freedoms such as freedom of expression. The increase in arrests of political opponents, including Antonio Ledezma, mayor of Caracas, illustrates this degraded climate. In this regard, the resolution voted by the European Parliament expresses its deep concern at the deteriorating situation in Venezuela and calls for the sending of a delegation of MEPs to establish a dialogue between the various political parties. Moreover, the European institution rightly condemns the use of force against protesters and demands the release of political opponents.

name: Anneliese Dodds (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this resolution as a whole (and also abstained on two amendments; amendment 6 and amendment 3). I did this because, while I fully understand that the resolution offered a compromise between different political groups on the situation in Venezuela, and while I am aware of the dire situation in that country, I felt that overall the resolution offered a very partial picture of developments. In particular, its coverage of the position of regional-level actors and their views on current developments in Venezuela was incomplete and gave, in my view, an inaccurate impression.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report has had my cooperation in its preparation and aims to draw attention to the following factors as relevant in the contemporary Venezuelan political situation: the arrest of the mayor of Caracas, Antonio Ledezma, some considerations of the international community on civil liberties, the use of firearms in the control of demonstrations, the procedural rights of the accused, the accelerated inflation of basic products, the EU's responsibility within the framework of the UN Security Council, the pre-election period as an opportunity to engage in constructive dialogue. In this context, it reiterates its request to the VP/AR to request the immediate release of demonstrators who have been arbitrarily detained since the beginning of the protest demonstrations, also inviting the EEAS and the EU delegation in Venezuela, as well as member state embassies, to continue to monitor inquiries and court hearings by opposition leaders. It reiterates its call for an ad hoc delegation from the European Parliament to be sent as soon as possible to assess the situation.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The deteriorating situation in Venezuela, the worsening of limitations on freedom and democracy and the use of violence against demonstrators deserve my concern. The arrest of António Ledezma is one of the signs that the conditions in that Latin American country are not the best, since his arrest was made without any arrest warrant or any evidence of the commission of a crime.  Its colouring in a military prison is incompatible with international standards and Venezuela has an obligation to guarantee the life, humanitarian treatment and security of all persons deprived of liberty, as well as to ensure conditions of detention that are in line with existing international standards. The call for his release, as well as all political prisoners, and his access to medical care is a cause to which I join. I also hope that the Venezuelan government will end political persecution, repression of democratic opposition, violations of freedom of expression and demonstration, and censorship of the media.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This resolution presents a biased view of the political and social situation in Venezuela, misrepresenting facts, omitting events, in a register of hatred that seeks to justify the systematic interference and aggression that the US and EU have imposed on the Venezuelan people for more than a decade. The systematic attempts to destabilise social destabilization and overthrow elected governments in successive electoral acts are hypocritically omitted, in deep contempt for popular will and democracy, notably through US-funded orchestrated operations such as Operation JERICHO or the La salida Plan, where the far right takes a leading role, alongside the millions of dollars to finance political parties and anti-governmental organizations. The reality surrounding events such as the arrest of António Ledezma or the death of the young Kluiverth Roa is tampered with, while the clashes in the streets permanently promoted by reactionary forces since 2002, which have been killed by dozens of people and hundreds of wounded, are forgotten. It suppresses the significant social development that is underway in that country – increased social investment, significant reduction of extreme poverty and malnutrition, illiteracy – at a pace that few, if any of the countries of the signatories of this resolution, will be able to follow. Obviously we voted against it.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ The situation in Venezuela has been tense, especially since 19 February 2015, when the mayor of Caracas and one of the opposition leaders were detained. The detention of civilians in military prisons is incompatible with international law. In the past, democratic opposition leaders have been repeatedly and for no reason accused of involvement in destabilisation and coups. We therefore logically believe that the presumption of innocence has been violated. A democratic state must not criminalise the leaders of the political opposition and must guarantee the participation of all groups in the political life of the country, while protecting the human rights of those who subscribe to the opposition.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report, which is balanced and strongly in defence of the civil rights of the democratic opposition.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This motion for a resolution seeks to overthrow the legally elected Government of Venezuela, with the aim of a side-by-side blow to Russia and full control of the region's oil reserves., that is why my vote is against.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the motion on the situation in Venezuela. I am concerned by the current political situation there as member after member of the opposition is arrested and intimidated. The current government is not respecting the rights of its citizens. It is essential that the government allows free and fair elections this year.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. The degradation of the political situation, respect for human rights and the most fundamental freedoms is a remarkable fact in Venezuela. Once synonymous with wealth and well-being, Venezuela is now a state that is in a state of progressive deterioration of democratic coexistence, in a climate of political violence, of violation of fundamental rights. The arrest of the metropolitan mayor of Caracas, Mr. Antonio Ledezma, accused of conspiracy, highlights the situation of helplessness in the country. Similarly, opposition leader Leopoldo López has also been detained for more than a year in a military prison. I therefore call on the Government of Venezuela to comply with its own Constitution and its international obligations with regard to judicial independence, the rights of freedom of expression, association and peaceful assembly, as well as political pluralism.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I supported the joint resolution tabled by Parliament's most important groups to send a respectful but forceful and clear message to the Venezuelan authorities that they have to respect the rules of the democratic game; they have to free detained politicians; they must not only not harass or detain, but protect elected officials, and should seek to restore coexistence and dialogue with opposition forces. We also call for the removal of instructions authorizing security forces to shoot protesters.  The arrest of the mayor of Caracas and the worsening conditions of detention of other political leaders motivated a debate in the plenary mini-session on 25 February. In the resolution, we support the mediation efforts of Unasur and some Latin American representatives to return to dialogue and the creation of a crisp democratic space where they can concentrate on strengthening their coexistence and the rule of law.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. We have supported the joint resolution tabled by Parliament's most important groups to send a respectful but forceful and clear message to the Venezuelan authorities that they have to respect the rules of the democratic game; they have to free detained politicians; they must not only not harass or detain, but protect elected officials, and should seek to restore coexistence and dialogue with opposition forces. We also call for the removal of instructions authorizing security forces to shoot protesters.  The arrest of the mayor of Caracas and the worsening conditions of detention of other political leaders motivated a debate in the plenary mini-session on 25 February. In the resolution, we support the mediation efforts of Unasur and some Latin American representatives to return to dialogue and the creation of a crisp democratic space where they can concentrate on strengthening their coexistence and the rule of law.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. – In light of the many cases recorded in Venezuela of arbitrary detention, most recently the arrest of Caracas Mayor Antonio Lezedma suddenly and forcefully taken from the city hall offices on charges of conspiracy and subversive activity to the Maduro government, given the actions of political persecution of political opponents and the media, and given the aptitude for incrimination of anyone who works to promote peaceful change , the European Union intervenes and demands the application in the country of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights to which Venezuela has acceded and also promotes the values that have always represented it: the fight against torture, the degrading treatment of prisoners and political violence, respect for democracy and the application of the separation of powers, the release of those still arbitrarily detained in prisons and the call for respect for human rights. , civil and personal freedoms and a political confrontation based not on violence, but on dialogue and respect.  For all these reasons, I fully support the resolution on the situation in Venezuela.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I expressed, with my vote in favour, concern for the democratic resilience of this country. The denied freedom of expression and the violence against those who claim the possibility of exercising the right to political pluralism unequivocally undermine the founding values of an institutional democracy. Dialogue, political confrontation that does not transcend violence are the conditions for economic and social growth and development. I am thinking of the European business system with the same concern that I address to citizens of European origin who live and work in that country, and allow me to address words of solidarity and political but also human closeness to the citizens who have emigrated from the south of my country, and in particular from Puglia.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution on the situation in Venezuela because the recent arrest and detention of veteran opposition leader Antonio Ledezma and reports of the alleged intimidation and mistreatment of Leopoldo López and other imprisoned opposition activists are unacceptable. 2015 is an electoral year for Venezuela, and  it is crucial that we send a strong signal to the government that elections need to be free and fair. This cannot be achieved unless repression of political activists is stopped and restrictions on media are lifted.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. The situation in Venezuela is deteriorating in leaps and bounds. The opposition is criminalized and imprisoned, protests suppressed with violence, the media are subjected to suffocating control and intimidation, the separation of powers shines by their absence, the population suffers from a shortage of products... In view of this situation, the European Union must act in favour of respect for democracy and human rights in Venezuela and demand, in particular, fair treatment for Antonio Ledezma and Leopoldo López. Few votes as easy as supporting this Resolution.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We support all parts of the resolution that promote dialogue and a democratic solution to Venezuela's problems. There is an article of the resolution, however, which does not match European values and which represents a way of tying up international relations that we do not share, either in this case or in any other case, because, instead of promoting the resolution of conflicts, it hinders it. Paragraph 12 'urges the Commission and the Council to consider and take whatever measures are necessary to safeguard European interests' in Venezuela, opening the door to sanctions, as the United States has already done recently. These policies, rather than promoting dialogue, make it difficult: the price of sanctions is not paid by governments, but by citizens (as in the case of Russia with Spanish farmers), and sanctions would also be harmful to the interests of our companies. We want the EU to be a diplomatic tool to promote dialogue and a democratic solution to conflicts. We are on the side of peace, democratic dialogue and human rights, and we condemn any violation of fundamental rights, wherever it occurs.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I am deeply concerned about the deteriorating situation in Venezuela and the use of violence against protesters.
