I support the call to the Venezuelan authorities to immediately release all peaceful protesters that are arbitrarily detained, and to put an end to the political persecution and repression of the democratic opposition.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. We have supported the joint resolution tabled by Parliament's most important groups to send a respectful but forceful and clear message to the Venezuelan authorities that they have to respect the rules of the democratic game; they have to free detained politicians; they must not only not harass or detain, but protect elected officials, and should seek to restore coexistence and dialogue with opposition forces. We also call for the removal of instructions authorizing security forces to shoot protesters.  The arrest of the mayor of Caracas and the worsening conditions of detention of other political leaders motivated a debate in the plenary mini-session on 25 February. In the resolution, we support the mediation efforts of Unasur and some Latin American representatives to return to dialogue and the creation of a crisp democratic space where they can concentrate on strengthening their coexistence and the rule of law.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. We have supported the joint resolution tabled by Parliament's most important groups to send a respectful but forceful and clear message to the Venezuelan authorities that they have to respect the rules of the democratic game; they have to free detained politicians; they must not only not harass or detain, but protect elected officials, and should seek to restore coexistence and dialogue with opposition forces. We also call for the removal of instructions authorizing security forces to shoot protesters.  The arrest of the mayor of Caracas and the worsening conditions of detention of other political leaders motivated a debate in the plenary mini-session on 25 February. In the resolution, we support the mediation efforts of Unasur and some Latin American representatives to return to dialogue and the creation of a crisp democratic space where they can concentrate on strengthening their coexistence and the rule of law.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I think the Parliament needs to express its concern at the deteriorating situation in Venezuela. Reports of political persecution and repression of democratic opposition need to be raised on the international stage and pressure needs to be applied to the authorities to stop any human rights abuses.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We support all parts of the resolution that promote dialogue and a democratic solution to Venezuela's problems. There is an article of the resolution, however, which does not match European values and which represents a way of tying up international relations that we do not share, either in this case or in any other case, because, instead of promoting the resolution of conflicts, it hinders it. Paragraph 12 'urges the Commission and the Council to consider and take whatever measures are necessary to safeguard European interests' in Venezuela, opening the door to sanctions, as the United States has already done recently. These policies, rather than promoting dialogue, make it difficult: the price of sanctions is not paid by governments, but by citizens (as in the case of Russia with Spanish farmers), and sanctions would also be harmful to the interests of our companies. We want the EU to be a diplomatic tool to promote dialogue and a democratic solution to conflicts. We are on the side of peace, democratic dialogue and human rights, and we condemn any violation of fundamental rights, wherever it occurs.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒I supported the Resolution on the Situation in Venezuela, as I believe that the European Parliament should take a stand and act actively in terms of pointing out the evident violation of human rights and the undemocratic use of the levers of power in a political struggle.  This resolution gives a clear sign that the EU Parliament knows what is happening in Venezuela, and calls on the High Representative, other EU institutions and international institutions to act in this regard.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the draft resolution on the situation in Venezuela. He called on the Venezuelan government to end the repression of opponents and violations of freedoms of expression and demonstration, and called for the immediate release of protesters who had been arbitrarily arrested since the protests began. He also expressed concern that the upcoming protests could lead to further violence. This proposal was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution.  The situation in Venezuela is taking dramatic turns. President Maduro is systematically trying to clamp down any democratic opposition. Further, he has authorized using firearms against demonstrators protesting against the government politics. Up to 40 protesters have been killed as consequence of extreme police brutality, more than 1700 are awaiting trial, 69 are imprisoned.  Venezuelan authorities must immediately release Antonio Ledezma who was arbitrarily detained on 19.02.2015, Leopoldo López who has been detained in a military prison for more than a year and suffered physical, psychological torture and solitary confinement, Daniel Ceballos, all peaceful protesters, students and opposition leaders arbitrarily detained for exercising their right to freedom of expression and their fundamental rights, in line with the demands made by several UN bodies and international organisations. Further Venezuelan authorities should withdraw the unfounded accusations against them. Antonio Ledezma, Leopoldo López, Daniel Ceballos and all other political prisoners must be ensured any medical attention they may require, as well as immediate, private and regular access to their families and to lawyers of their choice.  I urge the EEAS, and the EP to meet the Venezuelan opposition politicians and activists and discuss the grave situation and provide them with needed support.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am deeply concerned about the deteriorating situation in Venezuela and the use of violence against protesters. I therefore supported the resolution calling for the Venezuelan authorities to immediately release all peaceful protesters, students and opposition leaders arbitrarily detained for exercising their right to freedom of expression and fundamental rights, and to put an end to the political persecution and repression of the democratic opposition.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I am voting in favour of the resolution on the situation in Venezuela because I believe it is important to call on the venezuelan Government to promote stabilisation action involving the release of political prisoners with full respect for fundamental rights. Last February, the venezuelan opposition leader, who was twice elected mayor of the City of Caracas, was unjustly imprisoned in the Ramo Verde military prison. The Venezuelan Government has authorised the use of force during demonstrations by students and opponents who peacefully exercised their right to freedom of expression.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. National Front MPs have decided to abstain on the final vote on the resolution on the situation in Venezuela. There are positive elements to this text, such as paragraph 12 urging the Commission and the Council to consider and adopt any measures necessary to guarantee European interests and the principle of legal certainty of European companies in Venezuela. As was already the case under Mr Chavez, this is a real problem. A certain left seeks to make Mr. Maduro's regime look like a victim of the United States. Even if this were indeed the case, it does not justify the current distress situation facing the Venezuelan population, nor the apparently arbitrary arrests of opposition leaders. However, this joint resolution of the established political groups goes against the principle of non-interference that the National Front wishes to see respected.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The resolution put to the vote is a direct attack on the will of a people, the Venezuelan, who years ago decided to live in accordance with their own rules, carrying out their changes in line with the principles of international law and without being interfered with in the internal affairs of other States. This principle has not found reciprocity in the European Union and in the majority parties of Parliament, which once again lash out at that South American country. Energy independence and the sovereign will of peoples are two principles against which the Union acts with real saña, both outside and within its borders. Indirectly urging sanctions is nothing more than following U.S. policy, a country that recently declared Venezuela "a threat to its national security." In this context, calls for respect for human rights are hypocritical, as the Venezuelan state has mechanisms in place to defend its Constitution, jeopardized by a handful of minority party leaders. I voted against this resolution because I believe in the principle of respect for the sovereignty of peoples in choosing their destiny.

name: Peter Lundgren (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour, since it calls on the council to consider taking appropriate action on government crackdowns student demonstrations etc.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Recent developments in Venezuela point to a political, economic and social crisis. Evidence of the political crisis is the violent detention of the mayor of the Caracas area a month ago and alleged plots from abroad, plans to destabilise and attempt to kill senior officials exposed by President Nicolás Maduro on national television.  Venezuela is the country with the highest energy reserves in Latin America, with citizens suffering from shortages of basic foods and food prices doubling. At the same time, they live in fear of a government that enforces strict censorship. Worryingly, at the beginning of the year, the defence ministry approved the use of potentially lethal force as a last-year means of avoiding riots.  I support the proposal for a resolution that expresses deep concern about the volatile situation in Venezuela, the deterioration of democratic coexistence, the climate of political violence and violations of fundamental rights and the growing authoritarianism of the government. I call for respect for fundamental human rights and freedoms and dialogue for Venezuela to resolve this social, economic and political crisis.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am abstaining because the Resolution is unilateral and not objective.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the motion for a resolution on the situation in Venezuela. Whereas the detention of civilians in a military prison is incompatible with international standards; that Venezuela has an obligation to guarantee the life, humane treatment and safety of all persons deprived of their liberty, as well as to guarantee conditions of detention in accordance with the applicable international standards, together with the fact that there have been killings of students to be condemned, I express my agreement with this resolution.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Last February, Antonio Ledezma, leader of the Venezuelan opposition, twice elected mayor of Caracas, was unjustifiably imprisoned in the Ramo Verde military prison. The background to this incident is a situation of absolute deterioration in the rule of law. A large number of peaceful demonstrators, students and opponents of the government have been arbitrarily arrested, only for exercising the inalienable right to freedom of expression. The country's government has even authorised the use of force on several occasions during peaceful protests. I supported this resolution, because I believe that it strongly expresses the European Parliament's concern about what is happening in Venezuela. I particularly welcome the reference in the text to the need to urge the government of the country to promote stabilisation action, involving the release of political prisoners, and the absolute restoration of fundamental rights.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. The deterioration of the situation in Venezuela is worrying. Respect for fundamental rights and freedoms, including freedom of expression and the right to take part in peaceful demonstrations, is not a matter of course in Venezuela at the moment. The Venezuelan Government is responsible for upheld the rule of law and international law, which is why it must put an end to the political persecution and repression of the democratic opposition, violations of the right to freedom of expression and demonstration, and the censorship of the media. However, the state of the information is not currently sufficient to support the request. That is because of this, I abstained from the vote.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. While a new coup against the government of the Bolivarian Revolution has just been foiled, this resolution condemns the victims. And the putschists are described as "peaceful protesters", although they have been well equipped with Molotov cocktails and weapons of war. As always in this Parliament, a closely Atlanticist vision dominates. It was even expected that the resolution would propose to declare Venezuela a "threat to the security" of Europe, as the United States has just done. I am voting against this ridiculous text, which is a crude order from the United States.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. We are all deeply concerned about the deteriorating situation in Venezuela and the use of violence against protesters. As a sign of goodwill, the Venezuelan authorities must immediately release Antonio Ledezma, Leopoldo López, Daniel Ceballos and all peaceful protesters, students and opposition leaders arbitrarily detained for exercising their right to freedom of expression and the exercise of fundamental rights in accordance with requests made by various international organizations and the United Nations , unfounded charges against them should be dropped. The Venezuelan government must end political persecution, repression of democratic opposition, violations of freedom of expression and demonstration and media censorship, the voice of the opposition is fundamental to a democratic society. Venezuela must return to the path of democracy, under penalty of being permanently isolated from the international community.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it strongly condemns the escalation of violence in Venezuela.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I agree with the Resolution saying that the Venezuelan authorities must immediately release all peaceful protesters, students and opposition leaders arbitrarily detained for exercising their right to freedom of expression and fundamental rights. The government must also put an end to the political persecution and repression of the democratic opposition, it added.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 A vote to punish abuses against which we Romanians are or should be very sensitive: political arrests of opposition leaders remind us of our own 1950s and communist terror. Sad that MPs on the far left had the historic temerity to come up with motivations such as: Venezuela's Attorney General had issued an arrest warrant for the arrest of Caracas Mayor Antonio Ledezma. And Ceaușescu could give anyone an arrest warrant, so things were done, nicely, right, in full "legality".

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The resolution reiterates the EP's concern about the deteriorating situation in Venezuela, protests against the harassment, arrest, detention and persecution of leading politicians of the democratic opposition, demands adequate medical care and legal representation for them, and calls on the Venezuelan government to uphold the basic standards of democracy, the rule of law and human rights. It is concerned about the free and fairness of the upcoming elections and demands that freedom and fairness be guaranteed. I support the resolution.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. The situation in Venezuela shows that the chosen line, that is, the rejection of any imperialism of the United States and dogmatic socialism, can lead to autocratic excesses. If the economic situation is worrying, it is largely due to the government's up-to-the-pointness and the low price of oil, and it is not clear what the European Parliament should interfere with in this. Nor does it have to make injunctions on the fate of the political opponents of a sovereign country, whose elections are recognized as democratic by NGOs. However, the political situation is worrying, as evidenced by Ledezma's illegal incarceration, corruption and drug trafficking. But the European Union is cracking down on Venezuela, as Venezuela has been the subject of six debates in the last five years. So I abstained.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this joint resolution on the situation in Venezuela. In particular, the text calls on the Venezuelan authorities to release all persons it arbitrarily detains for exercising their freedom of expression, and more generally calls on the Venezuelan government to comply with its own Constitution and international obligations regarding the independence of the judiciary, the right to freedom of expression, association and peaceful assembly, and political pluralism.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We express our deep concern at the continued detention of opposition politicians and the violent repression of street protests that have broken out in Recent Weeks in Venezuela. Freedom of expression and the right to take part in peaceful demonstrations are the cornerstones of every democracy: only respect for fundamental rights and freedoms, and constructive and respectful dialogue conducted in a spirit of tolerance can help the country to emerge from the serious crisis and overcome future difficulties.  We therefore call on the Venezuelan Government to release all political demonstrators and opposition leaders who are currently being held in military prisons; we call for an end to the violence and respect for its constitutional and international obligations with regard to the independence of the judiciary, the right to freedom of expression, association and peaceful assembly and respect for political pluralism. We regret the absence of a formal bilateral dialogue between the European Union and the Venezuelan Government, considering it necessary to encourage further ad hoc discussions on human rights during the meetings between the EU delegation, the embassies of the Member States and the Venezuelan authorities, and therefore hoping for a rapid resumption of negotiations on the Association Agreement between the European Union and Mercosur.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this text because, like many citizens, I am alarmed by the situation of human rights, democracy and the right to opposition in Venezuela, and I consider it our moral and political duty to ask, with the utmost respect, but firmly, the Venezuelan authorities to respect these rights enshrined in us. Europe, in the Basic Charter of Human Rights.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I offered my support to this resolution because, first of all, it expresses a strong condemnation of the authoritarian practices that the Venezuelan Government has implemented towards all opposition leaders. The European Union, the Member States and the High Representative must use all the instruments at their disposal to urge the Venezuelan Government to reverse this trend by establishing an effective and constructive dialogue with the other political parties. Indeed, I believe that a confrontation that allows all political actors to discuss the problems facing Venezuela is the only way to find decisive and lasting solutions that improve the current conditions in the country.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. The report left a ambivalent impression on me: on the one hand, there was a positive reference to existing abuses in the country, particularly in the area of respect for human rights, and on the other hand, the report had a number of contradictory statements and information. That is why I abstained.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution on the situation in Venezuela. The violence that exacerbates the confrontation must be ended, talks to ensure public security and protection and return to peace and normality must be ended with the participation of all political forces. The Venezuelan government must comply with its constitution and comply with international obligations.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering that on 19 February 2015 Antonio Ledezma, democratically elected twice mayor of the metropolitan district of Caracas and one of the opposition leaders, was arbitrarily imprisoned by heavily armed officials of the Bolivian intelligence service (SEBIN) without an arrest warrant or evidence of crime; that, following his imprisonment, Antonio Ledezma was charged with conspiracy and conspiracy, offences punishable by serious prison sentences in Venezuela, and was imprisoned in ramo verde military prison; Whereas President Nicolas Maduro has announced on national radio and television that an alleged plan to destabilise his government by means of a coup has been foiled; Recalling that international obligations regarding the independence of the judiciary, the right to freedom of expression, association and peaceful assembly and political pluralism, which are fundamental elements of democracy; calling on the Venezuelan Government to ensure that rapid and impartial investigations are carried out in relation to the accusations, leaving no room for impunity, while fully respecting the principle of the presumption of innocence and due process;  I voted in favour.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU should keep its global role in promoting the fundamental values of democracy, the rule of law and the respect for human dignity. Venezuela is traversing very hard times in this respect and the EU should be engaged in levelling up fundamental values, such as the respect for personal freedom, and support all processes that would lead and help Venezuela towards a process of democratisation.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ 14-year-old student Kluviert Rou was murdered in cold blood by a Venezuelan state police officer during anti-government protests near the Catholic University of Táchira, making him the first victim after Nicolás Maduro authorized the use of firearms against protesters. President Nicolás Maduro announced on a national broadcaster the unveiling of an alleged plan to destabilise his government with an alleged coup involving leaders of the Democratic Union Coalition, and has already accused democratic opposition leaders repeatedly and baselessly of participating in alleged plans to destabilise the state and coups, resulting in constant political persecution and the lifting of their parliamentary immunity. The situation that is happening in Venezuela is unacceptable and a strong response from international law institutions is needed to prevent further gross violations of the fundamental principles of democracy.  Venezuelan citizens deserve support in the fight against repression by the government there. We must not leave them alone, our task is to care about respect for democracy, freedom, the rule of law and tolerance in all parts of the world. Intimidation and punishment of dissidents is intolerable, freedom of thought and freedom of speech should be protected because they form pillars of our society.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ After the detention of democratically elected politicians, the removal of legislative immunity from members of the National Assembly and the detention of leading opposition figures since February 2014, street protests broke out in Venezuela. Since February 2014, 44 people have been killed, including a 14-year-old schoolboy. Following anti-government protests in February 2014, most of the arrested protesters have been released, but 83 people are still in prison and are currently awaiting trial for alleged involvement in the protests. All this data clearly indicates the need to react. All the more so because the EU funds a wide range of projects by the Venezuelan government and NGOs to strengthen human rights and democracy, especially through the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights. I support calls on the Venezuelan Government to ensure maximum neutrality and transparency of the democratic process to allow all candidates and political parties to participate and conduct an election campaign on an equal footing. I also support calls on the Government to ensure that people are impunity for exercising their rights to peaceful assembly and freedom of expression and to abolish the recently published Resolution 008,610, which allows security forces to use firearms or other potentially lethal weapons. These are just some of the preconditions for improving the situation and respecting the rights of citizens that we must stand for, no matter where they are.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. After Hugo Chavez's death, we wanted to believe that Venezuela would turn the page on totalitarianism and initiate the process of transition to a democratic society, with the latest developments pointing to an alarming situation in the segment of human rights and democracy. A year after legitimate and peaceful opposition protests calling for President Maduro's resignation, which have been countered by the repression and killing of 43 people, Venezuelan opposition leader and Mayor of Caracas, Antonio Ledezma, has been arrested these days, charged without any evidence of plotting a coup. The latest cold-blooded murder of high school student Kluivert Roa and the arrests of opposition leaders confirm that Maduro's government is becoming highly authoritarian and oppressive. In this context, it is important to restart the dialogue between the Government, the opposition and civil society organisations, which will reach a consensus in resolving the dramatic situation.  The Venezuelan people will have the opportunity to participate in parliamentary elections at the end of this year, so it is important that the conditions of political pluralism, the protection of human rights, democracy, freedom of the media, freedom of speech and assembly are secured in the coming period. In further relations with Venezuela, the European Parliament urges the establishment of the rule of law and demands the democratisation of society while respecting international obligations in the domain of human rights, so I support this resolution of the European Parliament.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am seriously concerned about the continuing deterioration of the political situation in Venezuela, and I welcome the resolution. I find that the democratic opposition is being persecuted by violent attacks, there are restrictions on freedom of expression and demonstration, and the media are suffering from increasingly urgent censorship which prevents them from carrying out their work independently and freely. I hope that the government will understand the seriousness of the situation and ensure that all democratic political forces are properly involved in the next parliamentary elections, so that elections can be held in a free and balanced manner, so that the country can undertake the necessary reforms it needs.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. On February 19, 2015, Antonio Ledezma, democratically elected Mayor of the Caracas metropolitan area and one of the opposition leaders, was arbitrarily detained by heavily armed agents of the Bolivarian Intelligence Service (Sebin). This resolution recalls that the detention of civilians in a military prison is incompatible with international standards.  In the past, democratic opposition leaders have been repeatedly and unfoundedly accused of participating in alleged destabilization plans and coups d'état. However, a democratic state cannot criminalise the leaders of the political opposition, but must guarantee the participation of all sectors in the political life of the country and respect for the human rights of those who are part of the opposition. The state's revealed inability to maintain law and order and growing political polarization have made Venezuela one of the most violent countries in the world.  This resolution therefore considers that only respect for fundamental rights and freedoms, a constructive and respectful dialogue conducted in a spirit of tolerance, can help Venezuela to emerge from this serious crisis and overcome future difficulties. I voted in favour.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, because the deteriorating situation in Venezuela worries anyone who is faithful to democratic principles and who defends human rights. The use of violence against demonstrators is unacceptable, and venezuelan authorities are asked to immediately release all peaceful demonstrators, students and opposition leaders arbitrarily detained for exercising their right to freedom of expression and the exercise of fundamental rights, as advocated by the United Nations. It is urgent that the Venezuelan government end political persecution, repression of the democratic opposition, violations of freedom of expression and demonstration and censorship of the media. The voice of the opposition is fundamental to a free and democratic society. For all this, the Commission and the Council are called upon to study and take all necessary measures to safeguard European interests and the principle of legal certainty for European companies in Venezuela.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. On 19 February 2015, Antonio Ledezma, mayor of Caracas and a Venezuelan opposition figure, was arrested without an arrest warrant by officers of the Sebin, the national intelligence service (political police), and then held in a military prison without any form of trial, with no evidence of guilt in an offence.  On 24 February 2015, 14-year-old Kluivert Roa was shot dead while taking part in a peaceful demonstration over food and medicine shortages in San Cristobal.  Two facts among many that demonstrate that Chavez's heirs have kept his formula: oppression, intimidation, violent repression, imprisonment...   This lunchtime, the European Parliament called on the Venezuelan government to get back on the road to democracy, the real one. The one that does not silence the opposition by force, that does not violate freedoms of expression and demonstration, that does not censor all forms of media and that respects the separation of powers.  With this vote, the Union reaffirms its full support for one of the poorest people in Latin America, yet living in a country that has sufficient assets to be one of the richest.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because I am extremely concerned about the developments in Venezuela, which is constantly deteriorating. The imprisonment on 19 February of Antonio Ledezma, mayor of Caracas and a member of the opposition, embodies the authoritarian drift of the current government. The recent imprisonments, the ill-treatment of prisoners in prison, and the omnipotence now available to the armed forces since they were authorized by decree to use weapons against demonstrators, are unacceptable. Venezuela does not respect the basic rules of democracy, such as freedom of expression and association. We call on the Venezuelan authorities to release all peaceful protesters and opposition leaders detained for using their freedom of expression, and encourage the peaceful means of resolution initiated by Unasur. Finally, it is clear that the European Union should take into account the deterioration of respect for the fundamental rights of Venezuelans in its bilateral relations, particularly in its trade policy towards Venezuela.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. 'political persecution, arbitrary detentions and violations of freedom of expression' have been recurrent in Venezuela. The justifications of Venezuelan rulers are often unfounded. Genuine dialogue with all political forces is absolutely necessary to promote democratic values, justice and full respect for human rights. As elections approach, it will be more urgent for the EU to call for free and fair elections in an inclusive process of all democratic actors within the limits of the constitutional order.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Marked by high internal tensions and heavy accusations about the Maduro regime, Venezuela, in addition to a political crisis, is currently hit hard by an unprecedented economic crisis (linked to the sharp drop in oil prices that severely reduce the fiscal situation of a country whose incomes depend almost entirely on its oil exports and inflation approaching 70%).  The text of the resolution passed today condemns the use of violence against opponents of the ruling government and asks the Venezuelan authorities to immediately release several of them, including Antonio Ledezma, the mayor of Caracas. "An end to the political persecution and repression of the democratic opposition" and "censorship of the media" should be "ended," the text of the resolution stresses. The European Commission and the Council of the European Union were also asked to adopt "any measures necessary to guarantee European interests and the principle of legal security of European companies in Venezuela". Finally, "deeply concerned" about the "deteriorating" situation in Venezuela, the European Parliament has called for a delegation of MEPs to establish a dialogue on the ground with all parties.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text to express my deep concern about the violent repression of protesters in Venezuela. The resolution calls for the release of protesters, students and opposition leaders who have been arbitrarily arrested and detained, jeopardizing freedom of expression and assembly. It is essential that the government ceases all political repression and ensures respect for fundamental freedoms as soon as possible.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote in favour because it is a balanced report, strongly in defence of the civil rights of the democratic opposition and the legitimate interests of foreign investors, including European investors.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We support all parts of the resolution that promote dialogue and a democratic solution to Venezuela's problems. There is an article of the resolution, however, which does not match European values and which represents a way of tying up international relations that we do not share, either in this case or in any other case, because, instead of promoting the resolution of conflicts, it hinders it. Paragraph 12 'urges the Commission and the Council to consider and take whatever measures are necessary to safeguard European interests' in Venezuela, opening the door to sanctions, as the United States has already done recently. These policies, rather than promoting dialogue, make it difficult: the price of sanctions is not paid by governments, but by citizens (as in the case of Russia with Spanish farmers), and sanctions would also be harmful to the interests of our companies. We want the EU to be a diplomatic tool to promote dialogue and a democratic solution to conflicts. We are on the side of peace, democratic dialogue and human rights, and we condemn any violation of fundamental rights, wherever it occurs.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which condemns the use of violence against protesters in Venezuela and the arbitrary arrest of opposition figures in February 2015. The text recalls that one year after the February and June 2014 protests in Venezuela, more than 1,700 protesters are awaiting trial, more than 69 are still behind bars and at least 40 people have been killed during the protests, their killers have not been held accountable, and that police, members of the National Guard and armed pro-government groups have been killed. , violent and out of control have made excessive and systematic use of force and violence against demonstrators. Parliament is concerned that, in the context of an election year, the political opposition will be the victim of detentions and attacks that could call into question the legitimacy of the elections.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The resolution put to the vote is a direct attack on the will of a people, the Venezuelan, who years ago decided to live in accordance with their own rules, carrying out their changes in line with the principles of international law and without being interfered with in the internal affairs of other States. This principle has not found reciprocity in the European Union and in the majority parties of Parliament, which once again lash out at that South American country. Energy independence and the sovereign will of peoples are two principles against which the Union acts with real saña, both outside and within its borders. Indirectly urging sanctions is nothing more than following U.S. policy, a country that recently declared Venezuela "a threat to its national security." In this context, calls for respect for human rights are hypocritical, as the Venezuelan state has mechanisms in place to defend its Constitution, jeopardized by a handful of minority party leaders. I voted against this resolution because I believe in the principle of respect for the sovereignty of peoples in choosing their destiny.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the situation in Venezuela. There is deep concern about the deteriorating situation in Venezuela and Members of the European Parliament condemn the use of violence against protesters in the country. We urge the Venezuelan Government to cease the political persecution and repression of the democratic opposition and the violations of freedom of expression and of demonstration and to put an end to media censorship.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing – I supported the resolution, which expresses its deep concern at the deteriorating situation in Venezuela and condemns the use of violence against demonstrators. It is totally unacceptable that a 14-year-old pupil, who thus became the first victim since the use of firearms to suppress protests, should be shot dead during a demonstration against food and medicine shortages, such as on 24 February this year. The Venezuelan Government is politically persecuting and inferior to repression of the democratic opposition, violating their freedom of expression and suppressing their right to demonstrations. The government is not respecting its constitutional and international obligations with regard to judicial independence, the right to freedom of expression, association and peaceful assembly and political pluralism. The Venezuelan authorities should use the forthcoming parliamentary elections to create an inclusive process based on consensus and shared responsibility, through a genuine national dialogue involving all democratic political forces.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Despite the current very difficult and serious situation in Venezuela, the will of the Venezuelan people, who have decided in a democratic way as many as 18 times that what he wants is the 21st century socialism introduced by Chávez and continued today by President Nicolas Maduro. The most difficult problem facing the Bolivarian Revolution is the ongoing attempt at coup or destabilising of the constitutional order through economic and media wars and the incited street violence. The fact is that Venezuelan society is highly polarised and both sides are using violent gripes that are not acceptable to a democratic society. I believe that mediation should be used and the rule of law respected. Violence is certainly not the solution to getting out of the current difficult situation. In a democracy, the will of the majority must be respected, and the Venezuelan people have chosen the path of a new socialism called 21st century socialism. The use of violence against violence is not the solution, for this reason I did not support this resolution.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ The situation in Venezuela is more critical every day and with any further imprisonment, political process or anti-democratic action. Human rights are under threat in the country. It is the EU's duty to monitor these parts of the world as well, because their development affects us. The deficit of democracy and respect for the law can create dangerous outbreaks of tension that can spread.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ When, on February 19th this year, an armed group of Venezuela's intelligence service forced its way into the offices of the mayor of the metropolitan area of Caracas and without any court order, and on charges of conspiracy and conspiracy to conspire, took the mayor to a military prison the masks of the Venezuelan government finally fell. It has become clear that venezuela does not respect the political freedoms and freedoms of individuals and that there is no respect for democracy in Venezuela. The democratic opposition, media and protesters have consistently faced political persecution. Maduro was elected in a democratic election, but it is not just about electing the government democratically, but the opposition and civil liberties must be respected. When the government starts to narrow these freedoms and imprison its political opponents, it is an authoritarian regime. Nicolás Maduro's regime has clearly morphed into a dictatorship. Venezuela is increasingly west into poverty and repression. I supported this proposal for a resolution on the situation in Venezuela, as I believe we need to send a clear message on behalf of the international community and the European Parliament.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I believe it is necessary to stop the political persecution and repression of the democratic opposition in Venezuela as soon as possible, as it is inadmissible to repeat cases such as the imprisonment of Antonio Ledezmu and the removal to a military prison (twice the democratically elected mayor of the metropolis district of Caracas and one of the opposition leaders imprisoned without an arrest warrant and any concrete evidence), and a statement by the president himself on the national broadcaster in which he said he had thwarted a plan that allegedly aimed to bring down his Government. The government should be reminded that without opposition there is no democratic society. They should be warned to abide by their own Constitution, as Supreme Court judges have openly rejected the principle of power-sharing. Worrying are allegations by local and international organisations that one year after peaceful demonstrations, more than 1,700 protesters are awaiting trial, more than 69 remain imprisoned and at least 40 people have been killed in protests while their killers are still held accountable. Given the alarming situation in Venezuela, I supported the resolution with a view to singading the situation as soon as possible.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The unlawful prosecution of any man as well as political opponents on the part of the Government of a State is reprehensible. Any prosecution should be carried out by lawful procedures and with respect for human rights. However, the attitude of the European Union is hypocritical when it is interested in such persecution in third countries and allows them to take place in Member States of the Union. Its specific attitude is biased, reprehensible and therefore reprehensible.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I signed up in support of the resolution. I am deeply concerned by the deteriorating situation in Venezuela and condemn the use of violence against demonstrators.  We therefore call on the Venezuelan authorities to immediately release Antonio Ledezma, Leopoldo Lopez, Daniel Ceballos and all peaceful demonstrators, students and opposition leaders arbitrarily detained for exercising their right to freedom of expression and fundamental rights, in accordance with the demands of several United Nations and other international organizations.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The situation in Venezuela is consistently worsening and this is the reason why I voted in favour of this resolution. With this text the European Parliament sends a strong message to the Venezuelan Government to cease the political persecution and repression of the democratic opposition and it urges an end to media censorship.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We support all parts of the resolution that promote dialogue and a democratic solution to Venezuela's problems. There is an article of the resolution, however, which does not match European values and which represents a way of tying up international relations that we do not share, either in this case or in any other case, because, instead of promoting the resolution of conflicts, it hinders it. Paragraph 12 'urges the Commission and the Council to consider and take whatever measures are necessary to safeguard European interests' in Venezuela, opening the door to sanctions, as the United States has already done recently. These policies, rather than promoting dialogue, make it difficult: the price of sanctions is not paid by governments, but by citizens (as in the case of Russia with Spanish farmers), and sanctions would also be harmful to the interests of our companies. We want the EU to be a diplomatic tool to promote dialogue and a democratic solution to conflicts. We are on the side of peace, democratic dialogue and human rights, and we condemn any violation of fundamental rights, wherever it occurs.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. We have supported the joint resolution tabled by Parliament's most important groups to send a respectful but forceful and clear message to the Venezuelan authorities that they have to respect the rules of the democratic game; they have to free detained politicians; they must not only not harass or detain, but protect elected officials, and should seek to restore coexistence and dialogue with opposition forces. We also call for the removal of instructions authorizing security forces to shoot protesters.  The arrest of the mayor of Caracas and the worsening conditions of detention of other political leaders motivated a debate in the plenary session of 25 February. In the resolution, we support the mediation efforts of Unasur and some Latin American representatives to return to dialogue and the creation of a crisp democratic space where they can concentrate on strengthening their coexistence and the rule of law.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The resolution put to the vote is a direct attack on the will of a people, the Venezuelan, who years ago decided to live in accordance with their own rules, carrying out their changes in line with the principles of international law and without being interfered with in the internal affairs of other States. This principle has not found reciprocity in the European Union and in the majority parties of Parliament, which once again lash out at that South American country. Energy independence and the sovereign will of peoples are two principles against which the Union acts with real saña, both outside and within its borders. Indirectly urging sanctions is nothing more than following U.S. policy, a country that recently declared Venezuela "a threat to its national security." In this context, calls for respect for human rights are hypocritical, as the Venezuelan state has mechanisms in place to defend its Constitution, jeopardized by a handful of minority party leaders. I voted against this resolution because I believe in the principle of respect for the sovereignty of peoples in choosing their destiny.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Some sectors of Venezuela have been conducting an economic war in recent months through rising prices, smuggling goods and storage activities. The Government of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela denounced the "Operation Jericho", the latest coup attempt against the democratically elected government planned by the far-right opposition for February 12, 2014, with the financing and support of the U.S. government, as well as the support of several senior Venezuelan army officials. According to information provided by the Venezuelan government, the coup attempt was based on a four-step plan for the removal of President Maduro, beginning with the economic war and ending a violent military insuprising aimed at bombing strategic targets with Tucano warplanes, including some of the government's main facilities, such as the Presidential Palace, the Ministry of Defense and telesur television channel; these events must have occurred after the publication of a manifesto calls for a transition and the establishment of an interim government.  It is the duty of this House to support a legitimately elected government, through free elections, in which observers of this Parliament were present. To do the opposite is to deny all the values proclaimed by this Europe.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. The deterioration of the situation in Venezuela is worrying. Respect for fundamental rights and freedoms, including freedom of expression and the right to take part in peaceful demonstrations, is not a matter of course in Venezuela at the moment. The Venezuelan Government is responsible for upheld the rule of law and international law, which is why it must put an end to the political persecution and repression of the democratic opposition, violations of the right to freedom of expression and demonstration, and the censorship of the media. However, the state of the information is not currently sufficient to support the request. That is because of this, I abstained from the vote.

name: Kristina Winberg (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution since it calls on the council to consider taking appropriate action on government crackdowns student demonstrations etc. Whereas president Maduro has also announced bizarre alleged foreign conspiracies destabilisation plans and assassination attempts, which have been reported by the national administration several occasions.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This resolution presents a lying view of the political and social situation in Venezuela, misrepresenting facts, omitting events, in a register of hatred that seeks to justify the systematic interference and aggression that the US and EU have imposed on the Venezuelan people. The systematic attempts to destabilise social destabilization and overthrow elected governments in successive electoral acts are hypocritically omitted, in deep contempt for popular will and democracy, notably through US-funded orchestrated operations such as Operation JERICHO or the La Salida Plan, where the far right takes a leading role, alongside the millions of dollars to finance political parties and anti-government organizations. The reality surrounding events such as the arrest of António Ledezma (preemptively arrested not for being mayor but for inciting and participating in coup smear sprees against the democratic constitutional regime) is adulterated, while the violent clashes in the streets permanently promoted by reactionary forces since 2014, which resulted in the deaths of dozens of people and hundreds of wounded, are forgotten. It suppresses the significant social development that is underway in that country – increased social investment, significant reduction of extreme poverty and malnutrition – at a pace that few, if any of the countries of the signatories of this resolution, will be able to follow. We voted against it.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Venezuela, in which members of parliament advocated maintaining the rule of law and respecting democratic values, as well as for the security of European businesses in Venezuela. Venezuelan intelligence arbitrarily detained the opposition leader, the democratically elected mayor of the city of Caracas, Antonio Ledezmo, on 19 February 2015, with no evidence that he had committed a crime, nor had an arrest warrant. Members have called for his immediate release, as well as the release of all peaceful protesters, students and other opposition leaders who have been detained for exercising their right to free expression at protests in 2014. We condemned the execution of seven students in Venezuela. Opposition leaders in Venezuela have been accused in the past of allegedly planning coups without evidence. The intimidation and harsh treatment of opposition leaders and students has intensified, suggesting that fundamental rights and freedoms mean less and less, and even the upcoming elections could be at risk. The country, which has one of the highest rates of violence in the world, as it is no longer able to maintain law and order, has the largest energy reserves in Latin America, and its inhabitants still suffer severe shortages of basic goods.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: I declare the session of the European Parliament adjourned. (The sitting was closed at 1.45 p.m.)
